<p>The City &amp; Guilds Textbook: Electrical Installations Book 1</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="about-the-author">About the author<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#about-the-author" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251222-55ac8f21.jpeg" alt="img-2.jpeg"></p>
<p>I started in the electrotechnical industry while still at school, chasing walls for my brother-in-law for a bit of pocket-money. This taught me quickly that if I took a career as an electrician I needed to progress as fast as I could.</p>
<p>Jobs in the industry were few and far between when I left school so after a spell in the armed forces, I gained a place as a sponsored trainee on the Construction Industry Training Board (CITB) training scheme. I attended block release at Guildford Technical College, where the CITB would find me work experience with 'local' employers. My first and only work experience placement was with a computer installation company located over 20 miles away so I had to cycle there every morning, but I was desperate to learn, and enjoyed my work.</p>
<p>Computer installations were very different in those days. Computers filled large rooms and needed massive armoured supply cables so the range of work I experienced was vast – from data cabling to all types of containment systems and low-voltage systems.</p>
<p>In the second year of my apprenticeship I found employment with a company where most of my work centred around the London area. The work was varied, from lift systems in well-known high-rise buildings to lightning protection on the sides of even higher ones!</p>
<p>On completion of my apprenticeship I worked for a short time as an intruder alarm installer, mainly in domestic dwellings – a role in which client relationships and handling information are very important.</p>
<p>Following this I began work with a company where I was involved in shop-fitting and restaurant and pub refurbishments. It wasn't long before I was managing jobs and gaining further qualifications through professional development. I was later seconded to the Property Services Agency, designing major installations within some of the best-known buildings in the UK.</p>
<p>A career-changing accident took me into teaching, where I truly found the rewards the industry has to offer. Seeing young trainees maturing into qualified electricians is a highly gratifying experience. I often see many of my old trainees when they attend further training and updated courses. Following their successes makes it all worthwhile.</p>
<p>I have worked with City &amp; Guilds for over 25 years and represent them on a variety of industry committees, such as JPEL64, which is responsible for the production of BS 7671. I am passionate about using my extensive experience to maintain the high standards the industry expects.</p>
<p>Peter Tanner</p>
<p>June 2022</p>
<p>How to use this book</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="how-to-use-this-book">How to use this book<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#how-to-use-this-book" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Throughout this book you will see the following features:</p>
<p>INDUSTRY TIPS and KEY FACTS are particularly useful pieces of advice that can assist you in your workplace or help you remember something important.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="industry-tip">INDUSTRY TIP<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#industry-tip" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Remember, when you are carrying out your practical tasks either in the workplace or your place of learning, everyone, including you, is responsible for safety.</p>
<p>KEY TERMS in bold purple in the text are explained in the margin to aid your understanding. (They are also explained in the Glossary at the back of the book.)</p>
<p>HEALTH AND SAFETY boxes flag important points to keep yourself, colleagues and clients safe in the workplace. They also link to sections in the health and safety chapter for you to recap learning.</p>
<p>ACTIVITIES help to test your understanding and learn from your colleagues' experiences.</p>
<p>IMPROVE YOUR MATHS items combine improving your understanding of electrical installations with practising or improving your maths skills.</p>
<p>IMPROVE YOUR ENGLISH items combine improving your understanding of electrical installations with practising or improving your English skills.</p>
<p>At the end of each chapter there are some TEST YOUR KNOWLEDGE questions and PRACTICAL TASKS. These are designed to identify any areas where you might need further training or revision. Answers to the questions are at the back of the book.</p>

<p>This page intentionally left blank</p>
<p>HEALTH AND SAFETY AND INDUSTRY PRACTICES</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="introduction">INTRODUCTION<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#introduction" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Every year, accidents at work result in the deaths of more than one hundred people in Great Britain, with several hundred thousand more being injured in the workplace. In 2019/20, Health and Safety Executive (HSE) statistics recorded 38.8 million working days being lost due to work-related illness (32.5 million) and workplace injury (6.3 million).</p>
<p>Occupational health and safety affects all individuals and aspects of work in the complete range of working environments – hospitals, factories, schools, universities, commercial undertakings, manufacturing plants and offices. As well as the human cost in terms of pain, grief and suffering, accidents in the workplace also have a financial cost, such as lost income, insurance and production disturbance. The HSE put this figure at £16.2 billion for the year 2018/19. It is therefore important to identify, assess and control the activities that may cause harm in the workplace.</p>
<p>In addition to injuries to persons, construction site activities lead to many recorded incidents of land and air contamination impacting the environment we live in.</p>
<p>This chapter is designed to enable you to understand health, safety and environmental legislation and associated practices and procedures, when installing and maintaining electrotechnical systems and equipment. You will need this knowledge to underpin the application of health, safety and environmental legislation, practices and procedures.</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251222-fd562a5d.jpeg" alt="img-3.jpeg">
Figure 1.1 The five steps for risk assessment</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="industry-tip">INDUSTRY TIP<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#industry-tip" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>You can see the most up-to-date statistics relating to accidents in the workplace by visiting the HSE website.</p>

<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="key-terms">KEY TERMS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#key-terms" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Civil law: decides on a dispute between parties.
Criminal law: decides if someone is guilty of a criminal act.
Liability: a debt or other legal obligation in order to compensate for harm.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="1-the-law-roles-and-responsibilities">1 THE LAW: ROLES AND RESPONSIBILITIES<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#1-the-law-roles-and-responsibilities" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>When something goes wrong, there are two sub-divisions of the law that apply to health and safety: civil law and criminal law.</p>
<ul>
<li>Civil law – deals with disputes between individuals, between organisations, or between individuals and organisations, in which compensation can be awarded to the victim. The civil court is concerned with liability and the extent of that liability rather than guilt or non-guilt.</li>
</ul>
<p>Example: If a sub-contractor has not been paid by a main contractor, the subcontractor may make a claim against the main contractor through a civil court. The judge will examine the terms of the contract and settle the dispute based on those terms.</p>
<ul>
<li>Criminal law – the body of rules that regulates social behaviour and prohibits threatening, harming or other actions that may endanger the health, safety and moral welfare of people. The rules are laid down by the government and</li>
</ul>
<p>Chapter 1 Health and safety and industry practices</p>
<p>are enacted by Acts of Parliament as <strong>statutes</strong>. The Health and Safety at Work etc. Act 1974 (HSW Act) is an example of criminal law. It is enforced by the Health and Safety Executive (HSE) or Local Authority environmental health officers.</p>
<p>In terms of health and safety, criminal law is based only on statute law, but civil law may be based on either common law or statute law.</p>
<ul>
<li><strong>Common law</strong> – the body of law based on custom and decisions made by judges in courts. In health and safety, the legal definitions of terms such as ‘negligence’, ‘duty of care’, and ‘so far as is reasonably practicable’ are based on legal judgments and are part of common law. Common law usually uses past cases that set a precedent to help the judge decide an outcome.</li>
<li><strong>Statute law</strong> – the name given to law that has been laid down by Parliament as Acts of Parliament.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="industry-tip">INDUSTRY TIP<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#industry-tip" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>In terms of common law, ‘so far as is reasonably practicable’ involves weighing a risk against the trouble, time and money needed to control it.</p>
<p>In summary, criminal law seeks to protect everyone in society and civil law seeks to recompense individuals, to make amends for loss or harm they have suffered (i.e. provide compensation).</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="the-main-legal-requirements-for-health-and-safety-at-work">The main legal requirements for health and safety at work<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#the-main-legal-requirements-for-health-and-safety-at-work" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The HSW Act 1974 is the basis of all British health and safety law. It provides a comprehensive and integrated piece of legislation that sets out the general duties that employers have towards employees, contractors and members of the public, and that employees have towards themselves and each other. These duties are qualified in the HSW Act by the principle of ‘so far as is reasonably practicable’.</p>
<p>What the law expects is what good management and common sense would lead employers to do anyway; that is, to look at what the risks are and take sensible measures to tackle those risks. The person(s) who is responsible for the risk and best placed to control that risk is usually designated as the <strong>duty holder</strong>.</p>
<p>The HSW Act lays down the general legal framework for health and safety in the workplace, with specific duties being contained in regulations, also called statutory instruments (SIs), which are also examples of laws approved by Parliament.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="industry-tip">INDUSTRY TIP<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#industry-tip" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The duty holder must be competent by formal training and experience and have sufficient knowledge to avoid danger. The appropriate level of competence will differ for different areas of work.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="key-term">KEY TERM<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#key-term" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p><strong>Statute</strong>: a major written law passed by Parliament.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="industry-tip">INDUSTRY TIP<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#industry-tip" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>You can access more information about the HSW Act 1974 on the HSE website.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="key-term">KEY TERM<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#key-term" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p><strong>Duty holder</strong>: the person in control of the danger.</p>
<p>The City &amp; Guilds Textbook: Electrical Installations Book 1</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="key-term">KEY TERM<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#key-term" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Enabling Act: an Enabling Act allows the Secretary of State to make further laws (regulations) without the need to pass another Act of Parliament.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="activity">ACTIVITY<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#activity" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Think of any jobs you have had in the past, such as part-time work in the holidays. What do you think were your responsibilities for health and safety?</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="individuals-responsibilities-under-health-and-safety-legislation">Individuals' responsibilities under health and safety legislation<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#individuals-responsibilities-under-health-and-safety-legislation" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>The HSW Act, which is an Enabling Act, is based on the principle that those who create risks to employees or others in the course of carrying out work activities are responsible for controlling those risks.</p>
<p>The HSW Act places specific responsibilities on:</p>
<ul>
<li>employers</li>
<li>the self-employed</li>
<li>employees</li>
<li>designers</li>
<li>manufacturers and suppliers</li>
<li>importers.</li>
</ul>
<p>This section will deal with the responsibilities of employers, the self-employed and employees.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="responsibilities-of-employers-and-the-self-employed">Responsibilities of employers and the self-employed<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#responsibilities-of-employers-and-the-self-employed" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Under the main provisions of the HSW Act, employers and the self-employed have legal responsibilities in respect of the health and safety of their employees and other people (e.g. visitors and contractors) who may be affected by their undertaking and exposed to risks as a result. The employers' general duties are contained in Section 2 of the Act.</p>
<p>They are to ensure, 'so far as is reasonably practicable', the health, safety and welfare at work of all their employees, in particular:</p>
<ul>
<li>the provision of safe plant and systems of work</li>
<li>the safe use, handling, storage and transport of articles and substances</li>
<li>the provision of any required information, instruction, training or supervision</li>
<li>a safe place of work including safe access and exit</li>
<li>a safe working environment with adequate welfare facilities.</li>
</ul>
<p>These duties apply to virtually everything in the workplace, including electrical systems and installations, plant and equipment. An employer does not have to take measures to avoid or reduce the risk if that is technically impossible or if the time, trouble or cost of the measures would be grossly disproportionate to the risk.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="industry-tip">INDUSTRY TIP<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#industry-tip" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Remember, when you are carrying out your practical tasks either in the workplace or your place of learning, everyone, including you, is responsible for safety.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="responsibilities-of-employees">Responsibilities of employees<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#responsibilities-of-employees" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Employees are required to take reasonable care for the health and safety of themselves and others (including work colleagues, clients, members of the public and practically anyone who is affected). To achieve this aim, they have two main duties placed upon them:</p>
<ul>
<li>to take reasonable care for the health and safety of themselves and others who may be affected by their acts or omissions at work</li>
<li>to co-operate with their employer and others to enable them to fulfil their legal obligations.</li>
</ul>
<p>Chapter 1 Health and safety and industry practices</p>
<p>In addition, there is a duty not to misuse or interfere with safety provisions. Most of the duties in the HSW Act and the general duties included in the Management of Health and Safety at Work Regulations 1999 (the Management Regulations) are expressed as goals or targets that are to be met 'so far as is reasonably practicable' or through exercising 'adequate control' or taking 'appropriate' (or 'reasonable') steps. This involves making judgements as to whether existing control measures are sufficient and, if not, deciding what else should be done to eliminate or reduce the risk. This risk assessment will be produced using Approved Codes of Practice (ACoP) and published standards, as well as HSE or industry guidance on good practice, where available.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="industry-tip">INDUSTRY TIP<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#industry-tip" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>You can access Management of Health and Safety at Work Regulations 1999 (the Management Regulations) by searching the HSE website.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="2-health-and-safety-legislation">2 HEALTH AND SAFETY LEGISLATION<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#2-health-and-safety-legislation" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>When the HSW Act came into force, there were already some 30 statutes and 500 sets of regulations in place. The aim of the Health and Safety Commission (HSC) and the Health and Safety Executive (HSE) was to progressively replace the existing regulations with a system of regulation that expresses general duties, principles and goals, with any supporting detail set out in ACoPs and guidance.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="regulations">Regulations<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#regulations" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Statutory Instruments (SIs) are laws approved by Parliament. The regulations governing health and safety are usually made under the HSW Act, following proposals from the HSC/HSE. This applies to regulations based on European Commission (EC) Directives as well as those produced in Great Britain.</p>
<p>The HSW Act, and general duties in the Management Regulations, set goals and leave employers the freedom to decide how to control the risks they identify. Guidance and ACoPs give advice.</p>
<p>Some risks are considered so great or the proper control measures so costly that it would not be appropriate to leave employers to decide what to do about them. Regulations identify these risks and set out the specific action that must be taken. Often these requirements are absolute – they require something to be done, without qualification. The employer has no choice but to undertake whatever action is required to prevent injury, regardless of cost or effort.</p>
<p>Some regulations apply across all workplaces. Such regulations include the Manual Handling Operations Regulations 1992, which apply wherever things are moved by hand or bodily force, and the Health and Safety (Display Screen Equipment) Regulations 1992, which apply wherever visual display units (VDUs) are used. Other regulations apply to hazards unique to specific industries, such as mining or the nuclear industry.</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251222-34885524.jpeg" alt="img-4.jpeg">
Figure 1.2 An example of the front page of a regulatory document</p>
<p>The City &amp; Guilds Textbook: Electrical Installations Book 1</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="industry-tip">INDUSTRY TIP<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#industry-tip" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>You can search the Government's legislation database for each of these regulations at the GOV.UK website.</p>
<p>The following regulations apply across the full range of workplaces.</p>
<ul>
<li>Control of Noise at Work Regulations 2005: require employers to take action to protect employees from hearing damage.</li>
<li>Control of Substances Hazardous to Health (COSHH) Regulations 2002 (as amended): require employers to assess the risks from hazardous substances and take appropriate precautions.</li>
<li>Electricity at Work Regulations 1989: require people in control of electrical systems to ensure they are safe to use and maintained in a safe condition.</li>
<li>Health and Safety (Display Screen Equipment) Regulations 1992: give specific requirements for the use of display equipment such as computer screens. This may affect the choice of lighting to reduce glare.</li>
<li>Health and Safety (First-Aid) Regulations 1981: require employers to provide adequate and appropriate equipment, facilities and personnel to ensure their employees receive immediate attention if they are injured or taken ill at work. These regulations apply to all workplaces, including those with fewer than five employees, and to the self-employed.</li>
<li>Health and Safety Information for Employees Regulations 1989: require employers to display a poster telling employees what they need to know about health and safety.</li>
<li>Management of Health and Safety at Work Regulations 1999 (as amended): require employers to carry out risk assessments, make arrangements to implement necessary measures, appoint competent people and arrange for appropriate information and training.</li>
<li>Manual Handling Operations Regulations 1992: cover the moving of objects by hand or bodily force.</li>
<li>Personal Protective Equipment at Work Regulations 1992 (as amended): require employers to provide appropriate protective clothing and equipment for their employees.</li>
<li>Provision and Use of Work Equipment Regulations 1998: require that equipment provided for use at work, including machinery, is suitable and safe.</li>
<li>Reporting of Injuries, Diseases and Dangerous Occurrences Regulations 2013: require employers to notify the HSE of certain occupational injuries, diseases and dangerous events.</li>
<li>Workplace (Health, Safety and Welfare) Regulations 1992: cover a wide range of basic health, safety and welfare issues such as ventilation, heating, lighting, workstations, seating and welfare facilities.</li>
</ul>
<p>The following specific regulations cover particular areas, such as asbestos and lead.</p>
<ul>
<li>Chemicals (Hazard Information and Packaging for Supply) Regulations 2002: require suppliers to classify, label and package dangerous chemicals and provide safety data sheets for them.</li>
<li>Construction (Design and Management) Regulations 2015: cover safe systems of work on construction sites.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="industry-tip">INDUSTRY TIP<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#industry-tip" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>As an electrician in the building services industry, you will not need to know all of the relevant legislation inside out – unless you are also training to be a lawyer! What you need to know is that they exist and generally, what they cover, and any parts which directly affect your role when at work.</p>
<p>Chapter 1 Health and safety and industry practices</p>
<ul>
<li>Control of Asbestos Regulations 2012: affect anyone who owns, occupies, manages or otherwise has responsibilities for the maintenance and repair of buildings that may contain asbestos.</li>
<li>Control of Lead at Work Regulations 2002: impose duties on employers to carry out risk assessments, prevent or control exposure to lead and monitor the exposure of employees.</li>
<li>Control of Major Accident Hazards Regulations 1999 (as amended): require those who manufacture, store or transport dangerous chemicals or explosives in certain quantities to notify the relevant authority.</li>
<li>Dangerous Substances and Explosive Atmospheres Regulations 2002: require employers and the self-employed to carry out a risk assessment of work activities involving dangerous substances.</li>
<li>Work at Height Regulations 2005: apply to all work at height where there is a risk of a fall liable to cause personal injury.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="approved-codes-of-practice-acops">Approved Codes of Practice (ACoPs)<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#approved-codes-of-practice-acops" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>ACoPs offer practical examples of good practice. They were made under Section 16 of the HSW Act and have a special status. They give advice on how to comply with the law by, for example, providing a guide to what is reasonably practicable. For example, if regulations use words such as 'suitable' and 'sufficient', an ACoP can illustrate what is required in particular circumstances. If an employer is prosecuted for a breach of health and safety law, and it is proved that they have not followed the provisions of the relevant ACoP, a court can find them at fault unless they can show that they have complied with the law in some other way.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="guidance-and-non-statutory-regulations">Guidance and non-statutory regulations<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#guidance-and-non-statutory-regulations" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The HSE publishes guidance on a range of subjects. Guidance can be specific to the health and safety problems of an industry or to a particular process used in a number of industries. The main purposes of guidance are:</p>
<ul>
<li>to interpret and help people to understand what the law says</li>
<li>to help people comply with the law</li>
<li>to give technical advice.</li>
</ul>
<p>Following guidance is not compulsory and employers are free to take other action, but if they do follow the guidance, they will normally be doing enough to comply with the law.</p>
<p>One very good example of guidance and non-statutory regulation is BS 7671 The IET Wiring Regulations, 18th Edition. If electrotechnical work is undertaken in accordance with BS 7671, it is likely to meet the requirements of the Electricity at Work Regulations 1989, which deal with work with electrical equipment and systems.</p>
<p>BS 7671 is the national standard in the UK for low-voltage electrical installations. The document is largely based on documents produced by the European Committee for Electrotechnical Standardization (CENELEC). The regulations deal with the design, selection, erection, inspection and testing of electrical installations operating at a voltage up to 1000 V AC.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="key-terms">KEY TERMS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#key-terms" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Suitable: appropriate for a particular purpose or situation.</p>
<p>Sufficient: enough or adequate.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="industry-tip">INDUSTRY TIP<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#industry-tip" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Although the EWR 1989 states that all metallic parts which form part of an electrical installation must be earthed to protect persons from electrocution, the EWR 1989 does not contain any technical information on how to carry this out. Such details are, however, found in BS 7671 the Wiring Regulations, which is an example of how complying with a non-statutory document can also result in complying with statutory requirements.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="industry-tip">INDUSTRY TIP<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#industry-tip" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>BS 7671 is the 18th edition of the Wiring Regulations. It was published in July 2018 and has had two subsequent amendments, most recently in 2022. It can be obtained from the IET's online bookshop, or from many electrical wholesalers/suppliers.</p>
<p>BS 7671 is amended approximately every three years; the 18th edition will probably be amended two or three times before it is replaced with the 19th edition.</p>
<p>The City &amp; Guilds Textbook: Electrical Installations Book 1</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="european-law">European law<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#european-law" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>In recent years, much of Great Britain's health and safety law has originated in Europe. Proposals from the European Commission (EC) may be agreed by member states, which are then responsible for making them part of their domestic law. Modern health and safety law in this country, including much of that from Europe, is based on the principle of risk assessment as required by the Management of Health and Safety at Work Regulations 1999.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="role-of-the-hse-in-enforcing-health-and-safety-legislation">Role of the HSE in enforcing health and safety legislation<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#role-of-the-hse-in-enforcing-health-and-safety-legislation" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Today, the HSE's aim is to prevent death, injury and ill health in United Kingdom workplaces and it has a number of ways of achieving this. Enforcing authorities may offer the duty holder information and advice, both face to face and in writing, or they may warn a duty holder that, in their opinion, the duty holder is failing to comply with the law.</p>
<p>In carrying out the HSE's enforcement role, inspectors appointed under the HSW Act can:</p>
<ul>
<li>enter premises at any reasonable time, accompanied by a police officer if necessary</li>
<li>examine, investigate and require the premises to be left undisturbed</li>
<li>take samples, photographs and, if necessary, dismantle and remove equipment or substances</li>
<li>review relevant documents or information such as risk assessments, accident books, or similar</li>
<li>seize, destroy or make harmless any substance or article</li>
<li>issue enforcement notices and start prosecutions.</li>
</ul>
<p>An inspector may serve one of three types of notice:</p>
<ul>
<li>a Prohibition Notice tells the duty holder to stop an activity immediately</li>
<li>an Improvement Notice sets out action needed to remedy a situation and gives the duty holder a date by which they must complete the action</li>
<li>a Crown Notice is issued under the same circumstances that would justify a Prohibition or Improvement Notice, but is only served on duty holders in Crown organisations such as government departments, the Forestry Commission or the Prison Service.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="environmental-legislation-and-dealing-with-waste">ENVIRONMENTAL LEGISLATION AND DEALING WITH WASTE<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#environmental-legislation-and-dealing-with-waste" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>In the past, it was common for all waste produced on a construction site to be placed in a skip and for that waste to go to landfill. This practice has resulted in land pollution and groundwater pollution and even contributed to climate change due to the greenhouse gases that are emitted from landfill sites.</p>
<hr>
<p><strong>KEY TERM</strong></p>
<p>Comply: act in accordance with.</p>
<hr>
<p><strong>INDUSTRY TIP</strong></p>
<p>Following a serious accident, a HSE investigation will treat the situation as a crime scene, which is why evidence may be seized or photographed and people may be interviewed as soon as possible, before their memories fade.</p>
<hr>
<p><strong>KEY TERMS</strong></p>
<p>Waste: something which has no further use to the person disposing of it.</p>
<p>Landfill: bury waste in large holes in the ground.</p>
<p>Pollution: contaminating the natural environment, causing change to that environment.</p>
<p>Chapter 1 Health and safety and industry practices</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251222-0f56f60b.jpeg" alt="img-5.jpeg">
Figure 1.3 A landfill site</p>
<p>European and UK laws have placed legal obligations on employers and operatives within all industry sectors to reduce waste, avoid pollution, reduce carbon emissions and recycle wherever possible.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="what-is-waste">What is waste?<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#what-is-waste" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Waste is quite difficult to define but, in general terms, it is any item that is thrown away because it is no longer useful or required by its owner. Electrical installation work generates many forms of waste, from packaging materials that come with new equipment and excess materials that cannot be saved for future use, such as part-used cable reels, to stripped-out materials and equipment, such as old light fittings and sockets and, of course, general building waste such as brick rubble and timber.</p>
<p>However we define waste, its disposal is governed by legislation. Previously, the majority of construction waste went to landfill sites without any thought to the potential impact of the buried materials on the environment.</p>
<p>European Union laws, that have been applied in the UK, have led to radical changes in waste handling and disposal. If you work within the construction industry, you need to have an understanding of those laws.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="legislation-to-protect-the-environment">Legislation to protect the environment<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#legislation-to-protect-the-environment" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The Department for Environment, Food and Rural Affairs (DEFRA) defines the environment as the land, water and air around us. Any pollution of land, water or the air will affect the quality of life for all organisms living within that environment.</p>
<p>The environment is under increasing pressure, not only because of our demand for resources, but also due to our need to dispose of waste.</p>
<p>Both of these can lead to pollution. There are several legislative documents that determine how we deal with waste and limit our impact on the environment:</p>
<ul>
<li>Control of Pollution Act 1974 (COPA): applies to activities such as waste disposal, water pollution, noise, atmospheric pollution and public health.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="key-terms">KEY TERMS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#key-terms" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Carbon emission: the polluting gas given off from the burning of fossil fuels such as gas, oil or coal.</p>
<p>Recycle: to reuse the object or material.</p>
<p>Environment: the land, water and air around us.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="industry-tip">INDUSTRY TIP<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#industry-tip" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Visit DEFRA's website for further information at: <a href="http://www.defra.gov.uk" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">www.defra.gov.uk</a></p>
<p>The City &amp; Guilds Textbook: Electrical Installations Book 1</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="industry-tip">INDUSTRY TIP<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#industry-tip" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>You can access these legislative documents related to waste management by searching the Government's legislation database at: <a href="http://www.legislation.gov.uk" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">www.legislation.gov.uk</a></p>
<ul>
<li>Environmental Protection Act 1990 (EPA): makes provision for the improved control of pollution arising from certain industrial and other processes.</li>
<li>Environment Act 1995: empowers the Environment Agency to control pollution and enhance the environment and conservation of natural resources.</li>
<li>Hazardous Waste Regulations 2005: make provision for the controlled management of hazardous waste from the point of production to the final point of disposal or recovery.</li>
<li>Pollution Prevention and Control Act 1999: requires a range of industrial installations to be regulated in which emissions to air, water and land, plus other environmental effects, are considered.</li>
<li>Waste Electrical and Electronic Equipment Regulations 2013 (WEEE Regulations): require that producers (and with lesser obligations, distributors) of electrical and electronic equipment ('EEE') must be financially responsible for managing the waste.</li>
<li>Packaging (Essential Requirements) Regulations 2003: relate to the management of packaging and packaging waste.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="activity">ACTIVITY<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#activity" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>A four-storey block of flats built in the 1930s is to be totally refurbished. It still has the original imperial metal conduit (a metal pipe used to protect cables) but was rewired with PVC single-core cables in the late 1960s. List five different materials which will have to be disposed of in the proper manner.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="control-of-pollution-act-1974-copa">Control of Pollution Act 1974 (COPA)<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#control-of-pollution-act-1974-copa" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>The aim of this Act is to deal with environmental issues including waste on land, water pollution, air pollution and noise pollution. If a person or organisation is found guilty under this Act, they can be imprisoned or fined (or both), and they may have to pay an additional fee for each day the offence continues after conviction.</p>
<p>Local authorities require construction companies to apply for a permit under the Act prior to starting work. The construction company must carry out an analysis of the likely impact of noise and vibration on those in the surrounding area. The Act gives local authorities the power to impose restrictions on companies or individuals carrying out construction or demolition work, including imposing limits on noise levels and working times so as to avoid causing a nuisance to neighbours.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="environmental-protection-act-1990-epa">Environmental Protection Act 1990 (EPA)<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#environmental-protection-act-1990-epa" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>The Environmental Protection Act (EPA) applies to England, Scotland and Wales. It deals with the disposal of controlled waste on land and sets out a framework for duty of care. The EPA specifically deals with:</p>
<ul>
<li>waste</li>
<li>contaminated land</li>
<li>statutory nuisance.</li>
</ul>
<p>Chapter 1 Health and safety and industry practices</p>
<p>Controlled waste is domestic, commercial and industrial waste – in fact, all waste that is disposed of on the land. Under the EPA, it is an offence for anyone to deposit waste on any land unless a waste management licence authorising that deposit is held.</p>
<p>Land can be contaminated with naturally occurring substances, such as arsenic, by industrial processes, such as oil refining, or by fly tipping (illegally disposing of waste in undesignated sites).</p>
<p>Part 2A of the EPA works on the principle of the 'polluter pays'. The 'polluter' is defined as the person who caused the pollution or who 'knowingly permitted' the contamination. 'Knowingly permitted' not only applies to allowing the contamination to take place but also to having knowledge of the contamination and failing to deal with it. Where the polluter is unknown then the occupier or owner of the land is responsible.</p>
<p>Part 2A of the EPA applies where significant harm to the land has taken place or where the possibility of significant harm could take place or where rivers or groundwater are or could be affected.</p>
<p>The EPA also covers statutory nuisance and applies to any premises that may be detrimental to health or that cause a nuisance. This section is used by local authorities when dealing with antisocial behaviour, but it also applies to work procedures and covers such things as the emission of:</p>
<ul>
<li>dust</li>
<li>steam</li>
<li>smells</li>
<li>effluvia</li>
<li>noise.</li>
</ul>
<p>When someone complains about any of the above, the local council must investigate. If the investigation reveals that a statutory nuisance does exist, a Notice of Abatement will be issued containing a list of steps that must be followed to reduce the nuisance. In the case of construction, this action could have a serious impact on the completion of the work.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="environment-act-1995">Environment Act 1995<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#environment-act-1995" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The Environment Act 1995 set new standards for environmental management and led to the creation of a number of agencies to oversee this management. The agencies created by this Act are:</p>
<ul>
<li>The Environment Agency</li>
<li>The Scottish Environment Protection Agency</li>
<li>The National Park Authorities.</li>
</ul>
<p>The Act required that the Government prepare strategies on air pollution, national waste and the protection of hedgerows. The stated purpose of the Environment Agency is to 'enhance or protect the environment and promote sustainable development' and 'to create a better place for people and wildlife'. The Agency looks after everything from fishing rod licences to waste disposal, from flood defences to air pollution.</p>
<hr>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="industry-tip">INDUSTRY TIP<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#industry-tip" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<p>Access the Environmental Protection Act (EPA) by searching the GOV.UK website.</p>
<hr>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="key-terms">KEY TERMS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#key-terms" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<p><strong>Statutory nuisance</strong>: an unlawful interference with a person's right to use or enjoy land they have lawful access to.</p>
<p><strong>Effluvia</strong>: emissions of gas, or odorous fumes given off by decaying waste.</p>
<hr>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="industry-tip">INDUSTRY TIP<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#industry-tip" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<p>There are strict rules about making changes to buildings that are within National Parks. This could even include rules about items such as outside lighting.</p>
<p>The City &amp; Guilds Textbook: Electrical Installations Book 1</p>
<p>The Environment Agency has been given the powers to:</p>
<ul>
<li>stop offending taking place</li>
<li>restore and/or remediate, for which it will seek to recover the costs</li>
<li>bring under regulatory control</li>
<li>punish and/or deter, whether that be by criminal or civil sanctions.</li>
</ul>
<p>The Environment Agency publishes all prosecutions and associated fines on their website and these range from a couple of thousand pounds for fishing without a licence to many hundreds of thousands of pounds for operating without a waste licence.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="hazardous-waste-regulations-2005">Hazardous Waste Regulations 2005<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#hazardous-waste-regulations-2005" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The Hazardous Waste Regulations set out a regime of control for the tracking and movement of hazardous waste, and deal with the production and disposal of that waste. Hazardous waste includes such items as:</p>
<ul>
<li>fluorescent tubes</li>
<li>television sets</li>
<li>fridges</li>
<li>PC monitors</li>
<li>batteries</li>
<li>aerosols and paint</li>
<li>contaminated soils.</li>
</ul>
<p>When hazardous waste is moved from one location to another, a consignment note must be completed and passed to the licensed waste carrier. Hazardous waste must be kept separate from general waste. Electrical wholesalers generally run schemes whereby fluorescent tubes can be returned to them for safe disposal. It is a requirement of the Hazardous Waste Regulations that records are kept for a period of three years.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="pollution-prevention-and-control-act-1999">Pollution Prevention and Control Act 1999<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#pollution-prevention-and-control-act-1999" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>According to this Act, industries that emit certain substances can only operate with a permit issued by the local authority or the Environment Agency. Included in the schedule of industries requiring a permit are those involved in metal and waste processing.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="key-term">KEY TERM<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#key-term" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>WEEE: waste electrical and electronic equipment.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="industry-tip">INDUSTRY TIP<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#industry-tip" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Access the Waste Electrical and Electronic Equipment Regulations 2013 (WEEE Regulations) by searching the GOV.UK website.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="waste-electrical-and-electronic-equipment-regulations-2013-weee-regulations">Waste Electrical and Electronic Equipment Regulations 2013 (WEEE Regulations)<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#waste-electrical-and-electronic-equipment-regulations-2013-weee-regulations" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The WEEE Regulations are the implementation of a European Directive to address the environmental impact of unwanted electrical and electronic equipment, namely to reduce the amount of WEEE that is sent to landfill sites and to encourage recycling, reuse and recovery before disposal in an environmentally friendly manner.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="industry-tip">INDUSTRY TIP<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#industry-tip" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Remember, when you are undertaking practical activities and assessment, in college or on site, make sure you sort your waste materials for disposal.</p>
<p>Chapter 1 Health and safety and industry practices</p>
<p>You must comply with the WEEE Regulations if you manufacture, import, rebrand, distribute or dispose of electrical and electronic equipment. While it may seem obvious that manufacturers and distributors must comply, WEEE Regulations apply to anyone who disposes of such equipment.</p>
<p>As electricians frequently remove redundant electrical equipment and have surplus materials for disposal, compliance with the WEEE Regulations is an obligation that must be met.</p>
<p>Under the WEEE Regulations, electrical and electronic items are divided into 10 categories:</p>
<ol>
<li>Large household appliances, for example refrigerators, fans and panel heaters</li>
<li>Small household appliances, such as vacuum cleaners and toasters</li>
<li>IT and telecommunications equipment</li>
<li>Consumer equipment, such as radios and televisions</li>
<li>Lighting equipment, for example fluorescent tubes and discharge lamps</li>
<li>Electrical and electronic tools, such as drills</li>
<li>Toys, leisure and sports equipment</li>
<li>Medical devices</li>
<li>Monitoring and control instruments, such as smoke detectors and thermostats</li>
<li>Automatic dispensers, for example vending machines.</li>
</ol>
<p>Electricians most commonly deal with items in categories 5 and 9 but, at times, other categories may also apply.</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251222-4452158e.jpeg" alt="img-6.jpeg">
Figure 1.4 Examples of small electrical appliances</p>
<p>Bear in mind that some WEEE may also be classified as hazardous waste. Examples are: smoke detectors, which contain radioactive emitters; fluorescent tubes, which contain mercury and cadmium; as well as old discharge lighting control gear containing PCBs (polychlorinated biphenyls), which are hazardous to persons and the environment. If in doubt regarding any of these items, always seek advice.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="key-terms">KEY TERMS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#key-terms" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Redundant: no longer needed or useful, even though the part may still function. For example, if the cables were removed from a conduit, but the conduit remained as its removal would create decorating problems, the conduit is classed as redundant.</p>
<p>Surplus: more than what is needed. For example, if 75 m of cable was used from a 100 m reel, the remaining 25 m is surplus.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="activity">ACTIVITY<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#activity" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Look around your home and identify five items that come under the WEEE Regulations.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="industry-tip">INDUSTRY TIP<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#industry-tip" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The WEEE Regulations will apply to you when disposing of any electrical equipment.</p>
<p>The City &amp; Guilds Textbook: Electrical Installations Book 1</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="industry-tip">INDUSTRY TIP<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#industry-tip" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Access the Packaging (Essential Requirements) Regulations 2003 by searching the GOV.UK website.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="packaging-essential-requirements-regulations-2003">Packaging (Essential Requirements) Regulations 2003<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#packaging-essential-requirements-regulations-2003" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>These regulations require anyone, but generally manufacturers of products, who place packaging into the marketplace, to take certain steps to:</p>
<ul>
<li>minimise the amount of packaging used</li>
<li>make sure packaging can be recovered (recycled)</li>
<li>ensure that packaging has the minimum possible impact on the environment</li>
<li>ensure that packaging does not contain high levels of hazardous materials or heavy metals.</li>
</ul>
<p>Packaging has a very short life cycle. It is useful only from the time it leaves the manufacturer to when it arrives at the end user. While the Packaging (Essential Requirements) Regulations are not directly aimed at end users, they do reinforce the requirements for dealing with any waste product.</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251222-c2549a6a.jpeg" alt="img-7.jpeg">
Figure 1.5 A poor waste model</p>
<p>It is obvious that the poor waste model for packaging in Figure 1.5 is unsustainable. The sustainable waste model shown in Figure 1.6 is far better.</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251222-48621fa6.jpeg" alt="img-8.jpeg">
Figure 1.6 A sustainable waste model</p>
<p>Chapter 1 Health and safety and industry practices</p>
<p>In the sustainable waste model, the packaging is made of materials that will cause minimum pollution in landfill sites. However, the materials are actually recyclable, thus cutting down waste and also reducing the demands on dwindling resources.</p>
<p>The key person in this cycle is the person who ensures that the waste product is recycled.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="dealing-with-health-and-safety-in-the-work-environment">DEALING WITH HEALTH AND SAFETY IN THE WORK ENVIRONMENT<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#dealing-with-health-and-safety-in-the-work-environment" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="the-role-of-safety-culture">The role of safety culture<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#the-role-of-safety-culture" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>An organisation’s <strong>safety culture</strong> can have as big an influence on safety outcomes as the safety management system itself, with safety culture being a subset of the overall organisational or company culture. Poor safety culture has contributed to many major incidents (e.g. the Piper Alpha oil platform disaster; the fire at King’s Cross underground station; the sinking of the Herald of Free Enterprise passenger ferry; the passenger train crash at Clapham Junction; the Chernobyl disaster) and personal injuries. Success in this area normally comes from good leadership, good worker involvement and good communications.</p>
<p>By paying attention to human factors, forward-looking companies can identify and deal with potential hazards before they manifest themselves as accidents. This, coupled with legislation in the form of regulations and ACoPs that are easily understood and complied with, can have a positive effect on health and safety standards and help prevent or reduce accidents and incidents.</p>
