<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="procedures-for-handling-injuries-sustained-on-site">Procedures for handling injuries sustained on site<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#procedures-for-handling-injuries-sustained-on-site" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The type of accident that can occur in the workplace is dependent on the work activity being undertaken but can range from a cut finger to a <strong>fatality</strong>, or from a vehicle collision to the collapse of a structure. The person in control of the premises, such as a site supervisor, needs to be prepared to deal with all types of accidents to ensure that the injured person can be treated quickly and effectively and that all the legal obligations are met.</p>
<p>Having a well-established procedure that everyone on site is aware of and understands will enable the person in control of the premises to cope calmly and effectively when dealing with an accident. Good management following an accident will ensure that the injured person is attended to promptly, appropriate records are made, the accident is reported correctly and any lessons to be learned from the accident are understood and communicated to the workforce.</p>
<p>The procedures to be followed in the event of any accident or incident should be clear and specific to the project or site and should detail the following as a minimum:</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="key-terms">KEY TERMS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#key-terms" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<p><strong>Safety culture</strong>: ‘the product of individual and group values, attitudes, perceptions, competencies, and patterns of behaviour that determine the commitment to, and the style and proficiency of, an organisation’s health and safety management.’ (Source: Health and Safety Executive)</p>
<p><strong>Fatality</strong>: death.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="health-and-safety">HEALTH AND SAFETY<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#health-and-safety" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<p>The examples of poor safety culture that are given here all led to the loss of many lives. In each case, poor safety procedures were used and/or shortcuts were taken to save time or energy. It is easy for these shortcuts to turn into habits which then become seen as acceptable procedure. Everyone should do their part to ensure this does not happen. Safety procedures are in place for very good reasons and should not be ignored, but instead be constantly reviewed.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="activity">ACTIVITY<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#activity" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<p>How would you deal with a deeply cut hand sustained while cutting metal trunking?</p>
<p>The City &amp; Guilds Textbook: Electrical Installations Book 1</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251222-00529e0c.jpeg" alt="img-9.jpeg">
Figure 1.7 CPR being performed</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="key-terms">KEY TERMS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#key-terms" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Accident: an unplanned event that results in injury or ill health, damage, or loss of business.</p>
<p>Business opportunity: in this context, the opportunity to make profit from the work or contract.</p>
<ul>
<li>name of the appointed person(s) who will take control when someone is injured or falls ill</li>
<li>name of the person(s) who will administer first aid</li>
<li>location of the first aid boxes and name of the person(s) responsible for ensuring they are fully stocked</li>
<li>course of action that must be followed by the appointed person who takes control in the event of an accident</li>
<li>guidance on action to take after the accident.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="how-to-deal-with-electric-shocks">How to deal with electric shocks<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#how-to-deal-with-electric-shocks" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>If all of the correct requirements are met, precautions taken and training of staff undertaken, it is unlikely that an electrical accident will occur. However, procedures should be in place to deal with electric shock injury in the event of an accident. The recommended procedure for dealing with a person who has received a low-voltage shock is as follows:</p>
<ul>
<li>
<p>Raise the alarm (colleagues and a trained first-aider).</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Make sure the area is safe by switching off the electricity supply.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Request colleagues to call an ambulance (999 or 112).</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>If it is not possible to switch off the power supply, move the person away from the source of electricity by using a non-conductive item.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Check if the person is responsive, whether their airway is clear and whether they are breathing.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>If the person is unconscious and breathing, move them into the recovery position.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>If they are unconscious and not breathing, start to give cardiopulmonary resuscitation (CPR):</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>CPR is undertaken by interlocking the hands and giving 30 chest compressions in the centre of the chest, between the two pectoral muscles, at a rate of about 100 pulses per minute.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Tilt the casualty's head back gently, by placing one hand on the forehead and the other under the chin, to open the airway and give two mouth-to-mouth breaths.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Repeat the cycle of 30 compressions to two breaths until either help arrives or the patient recovers.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Any minor burns should be treated by placing a sterile dressing over the burn and securing with a bandage.</p>
</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="procedures-for-recording-accidents-and-near-misses-at-work">Procedures for recording accidents and near misses at work<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#procedures-for-recording-accidents-and-near-misses-at-work" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>An accident is defined by the HSE as 'any unplanned event that results in injury or ill health of people, or damage or loss to property, plant, materials or the environment, or a loss of a business opportunity'.</p>
<p>Chapter 1 Health and safety and industry practices</p>
<p>A near miss is an unplanned event that does not result in injury, illness or damage, but had the potential to do so. Normally, only a fortunate break in the chain of events prevents an injury, fatality or damage taking place. So, a near miss could be defined as any incident that could have resulted in an accident. The keeping of information on near misses is very important in helping to prevent accidents occurring. Research has shown that damage and near miss accidents occur much more frequently than injury accidents and therefore give an indication of hazards.</p>
<p>The Social Security Act 1975 specifically requires employers to keep information on accidents. This should be the Statutory Accident Book for all Employee Accidents or an equivalent. Each entry should be made on a separate page and the completed page securely stored to protect personal data (under the General Data Protection Regulation 2021). An entry may be made by the employee or by anyone acting on their behalf. This information should be kept for a period of not less than three years.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="industry-tip">INDUSTRY TIP<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#industry-tip" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>You can access the Social Security Act 1975 by searching the HSE website.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="reporting-the-incident">Reporting the incident<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#reporting-the-incident" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The reporting of certain types of injury and incidents to the enforcing authority (the HSE or the local authority) is a legal requirement under the Reporting of Injuries, Diseases and Dangerous Occurrences Regulations 2013 (RIDDOR). Failure to comply with these regulations is a criminal offence.</p>
<p>RIDDOR states that deaths, specified injuries (listed in the regulations) and injuries resulting in absence from work for over seven days, and dangerous occurrences (again, listed in the regulations) and occupational diseases must be reported. This seven-day period does not include the day of the accident, but does include weekends and rest days. The report must be made within 15 days of the accident.</p>
<p>It is the responsibility of employers or the person in control of premises to report these types of incidents. Reportable specified injuries include fractures, amputations, permanent loss of sight, crush injuries and serious burns. A dangerous occurrence is a 'near-miss' event (incident with the potential to cause harm). There are also special requirements for gas incidents. Accidents must be recorded, but not reported, where they result in a worker being incapacitated for more than three consecutive days.</p>
<p>The police and HSE have the right to investigate fatal accidents at work. Therefore, all fatal accidents must also be notified to the police. The police will often notify the HSE, but it is always a sensible precaution to ensure that the HSE has been notified.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="key-term">KEY TERM<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#key-term" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Near miss: any incident that could, but does not, result in an accident.</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251222-9d469839.jpeg" alt="img-10.jpeg">
Figure 1.8 An accident book</p>
<p>The City &amp; Guilds Textbook: Electrical Installations Book 1</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="activity">ACTIVITY<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#activity" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Ask to see the accident book at your place of work and see what the most common cause of accidents is.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="investigating-accidents">Investigating accidents<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#investigating-accidents" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>There is nearly always something to be learned following an accident and ideally the causes of all accidents should be established regardless of whether injury or damage resulted. The level and nature of an investigation should reflect the significance of the event being investigated. The results of the accident investigation may lead to a review, possible amendment to the risk assessment and appropriate action to prevent similar accidents from occurring.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="industry-tip">INDUSTRY TIP<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#industry-tip" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Try to keep notes of what happened during any incident. People are very bad at remembering what they actually saw, so take notes straight away or use your phone and record a voice memo.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="keeping-records">KEEPING RECORDS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#keeping-records" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>There are numerous records to keep following even a minor accident. Easily accessible records should be maintained for all accidents that have occurred. In addition to the legal requirements, accident information can help an organisation identify key risk areas within the business. The accident book must be kept for three years following the last entry. The HSE has an online reporting tool which you can find by searching for RIDDOR on the HSE website.</p>
<p>The F2508 for reportable incidents should be kept for a period of not less than three years from the date the accident occurred.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="what-to-do-in-an-accident-or-emergency">What to do in an accident or emergency<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#what-to-do-in-an-accident-or-emergency" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>When an emergency situation occurs and the emergency services need to be called, be sure you know the following information:</p>
<ul>
<li>the address and location of the incident</li>
<li>the nature of the incident, such as fire, injury etc.</li>
<li>any difficulties the emergency services may encounter while trying to get to the incident, such as a high-rise building or in a field in a remote location</li>
<li>any immediate dangers such as explosive materials, persons trapped etc.</li>
</ul>
<p>Should an emergency occur that requires evacuation, it is essential you know what or where the designated escape route is. On construction sites, due to their ever-changing nature, designated escape routes may frequently move so always be sure you are familiar with them. What may have been a safe escape route one day could be a dangerous route the next.</p>
<p>In nearly all fire situations, the emergency services should be called, but some very small fires may be extinguished before they become too serious. Be sure you know how to tackle different fires and know where appropriate fire-fighting devices are located.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="ending">ENDING<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#ending" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>You must only ever tackle a fire if you can do so without endangering yourself or others.</p>
<p>In an emergency, think quickly but do not act hastily.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="emergencies">Emergencies<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#emergencies" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Emergency procedures are there to limit the damage to people and property caused by an incident. Although the most likely emergency to be dealt with is fire, there are many more emergency situations that need to be considered, including the following.</p>
<p>Chapter 1 Health and safety and industry practices</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="electrical-fire-or-explosion">Electrical fire or explosion<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#electrical-fire-or-explosion" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Fires involving electricity are often caused by lack of care in the maintenance and use of electrical equipment and installations. The use of electrical equipment should be avoided in potentially flammable atmospheres as far as is possible. However, if the use of electrical equipment in these areas cannot be avoided, then equipment purchased in accordance with the Equipment and Protective Systems Intended for Use in Potentially Explosive Atmospheres Regulations 1996 must be used.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="escape-of-toxic-fumes-or-gases">Escape of toxic fumes or gases<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#escape-of-toxic-fumes-or-gases" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Some gases are poisonous and can be dangerous to life at very low concentrations. Some toxic gases have strong smells such as the distinctive 'rotten eggs' smell of hydrogen sulphide (H₂S). The measurements most often used for the concentration of toxic gases are parts per million (ppm) and parts per billion (ppb). More people die from toxic gas exposure than from explosions caused by the ignition of flammable gas. With toxic substances, the main concern is the effect on workers of exposure to even very low concentrations. These could be inhaled, ingested (swallowed) or absorbed through the skin. Since adverse effects can often result from cumulative, long-term exposure, it is important to measure not only the concentration of gas, but also the total time of exposure.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="gas-explosion">Gas explosion<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#gas-explosion" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>A gas explosion is an explosion resulting from a gas leak in the presence of an ignition source. The main explosive gases are natural gas, methane, propane and butane because they are widely used for heating purposes in temporary and permanent situations. However, many other gases, such as hydrogen, are combustible and have caused explosions in the past.</p>
<p>The source of ignition can be anything from a naked flame to the electrical energy in a piece of equipment. Industrial gas explosions can be prevented with the use of intrinsic safety barriers to prevent ignition. The principle behind intrinsic safety is to ensure that the electrical and thermal energy from any electrical equipment in a hazardous area is kept low enough to prevent the ignition of flammable gas. Items such as electric motors would not be permitted in a hazardous area.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="employer-and-employee-responsibilities">Employer and employee responsibilities<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#employer-and-employee-responsibilities" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Employers have a duty of care to each of their employees. This duty rests solely with the employer and cannot be assigned to other persons – for example, consultants who offer advice on health and safety matters, or sub-contractors who are employed to undertake tasks within the company. All organisations should have a clear policy for the management of health and safety. The policy sets the direction for health and safety within the organisation, and its contents need to be clearly communicated to everyone within the organisation to ensure everyone understands what their responsibilities are in day-to-day operations.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="industry-tip">INDUSTRY TIP<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#industry-tip" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Access the Equipment and Protective Systems Intended for Use in Potentially Explosive Atmospheres Regulations 1996 by searching the GOV.UK website.</p>
<p>The City &amp; Guilds Textbook: Electrical Installations Book 1</p>
<p>Everyone has responsibility for safety, but employers have the following duties under the HSW Act:</p>
<ul>
<li>the health, safety and welfare at work of employees, and other workers whether they are contractors, casual, temporary, part time or trainees</li>
<li>the health and safety of anyone who is allowed to use the organisation's equipment</li>
<li>the health and safety of anyone who may be affected by the organisation's activities, i.e. the general public or adjacent organisations or neighbours.</li>
</ul>
<p>Examples of matters under the control of an employer include:</p>
<ul>
<li>establishing policy to ensure that electrical equipment is purchased to an appropriate specification</li>
<li>establishing policy to ensure that electrical equipment is properly maintained (including user inspection)</li>
<li>implementing policy through the introduction of appropriate management systems</li>
<li>on-going monitoring to confirm that the policy is properly implemented and remains fully relevant.</li>
</ul>
<p>Employees have specific responsibilities under the HSW Act and these can be summarised as:</p>
<ul>
<li>to take reasonable care for the health and safety of themselves and others who may be affected by their acts or omissions at work</li>
<li>to co-operate with their employer and others to enable them to fulfil their legal obligations</li>
<li>not to interfere with or deliberately misuse anything provided in the interests of health and safety.</li>
</ul>
<p>Examples of matters under the control of an employee include:</p>
<ul>
<li>adherence to company procedures and systems of work</li>
<li>use of equipment in accordance with information and training provided</li>
<li>not to use equipment that is faulty or damaged but to report it in accordance with company arrangements for dealing with defective equipment.</li>
</ul>
<p>In summary, under the HSW Act employers have duties to ensure that appropriate management systems are established so that electrical work can be undertaken in a safe manner, while employees have a responsibility to comply fully with such management systems.</p>
<p><strong>ACTIVITY</strong></p>
<p>Consider some situations where you could be at risk because the desire to get the work done is greater than the need to spend some time creating a safe situation. One example is disconnecting bonding before isolating the entire installation!</p>
<p><strong>What to do if you have concerns about health and safety issues</strong></p>
<p>Employees are responsible for ensuring that the work they are required to undertake is carried out in a manner which is safe for themselves and other persons who may be affected by the work activity. They must undertake this work activity in accordance with the instruction or procedure provided by the employer.</p>
<p>If an employee has concerns about health and safety at work, or feels that there is a situation which they believe exceeds their level of responsibility, then these concerns should be raised with their supervisor or line manager. If the organisation</p>
<p>Chapter 1 Health and safety and industry practices</p>
<p>has a recognised trades union and a safety representative has been appointed, it may be appropriate for the safety representative or the trades union official to be the first point of contact.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="what-to-do-if-you-have-concerns-about-your-work-activity">What to do if you have concerns about your work activity<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#what-to-do-if-you-have-concerns-about-your-work-activity" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The law requires employers and the self-employed to conduct their business in such a way as to ensure, 'so far as is reasonably practicable', that persons affected are not exposed to risks to their health or safety. This includes providing essential welfare facilities for employees.</p>
<p>If it is believed that an employer's (or someone else's) work activity is creating a risk or causing damage to health, then the concern should be raised with that employer or person responsible for the work activity. If no improvement is made and the safety or health risk continues, then it should be reported to the relevant enforcing authority, which should be asked to investigate.</p>
<p>There are two relevant enforcing authorities.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="health-and-safety">HEALTH AND SAFETY<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#health-and-safety" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<p>If you see someone carrying out a dangerous procedure, report it to your supervisor. It may not make you the most popular person but may save their, or another person's life, maybe even yours.</p>
<p>▼ Examples of workplaces covered by each enforcing authority</p>
<table><thead><tr><th>The HSE</th><th>The Local Authority Environmental Health Department</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>Mines</td><td>Shops</td></tr><tr><td>Factories</td><td>Hotels</td></tr><tr><td>Building sites</td><td>Restaurants, public houses and clubs</td></tr><tr><td>Nuclear installations</td><td>Leisure premises</td></tr><tr><td>Hospitals and nursing homes</td><td>Nurseries and playgroups</td></tr><tr><td>Gas, electricity and water systems</td><td>Offices (except government offices)</td></tr><tr><td>Schools and colleges</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>Offshore installations</td><td></td></tr></tbody></table>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="who-to-report-concerns-to">Who to report concerns to<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#who-to-report-concerns-to" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>All companies need an effective internal system for reporting health, safety and welfare-related matters and this should be readily available to all employees, including the names and contact details of the relevant responsible persons.</p>
<p>The names, positions and duties of those people within the organisation who have responsibility for health and safety will normally be contained within the safety policy. This will include:</p>
<ul>
<li>managers (directors, site managers, supervisors)</li>
<li>specialists (health and safety advisors, safety officers, first aiders, fire officers)</li>
<li>employee representatives (trades union representatives, safety representatives)</li>
<li>HSE Officers and Local Authority Environmental Health Officers.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="industry-tip">INDUSTRY TIP<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#industry-tip" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Many places of work have notice boards detailing the contact information of the person responsible for health, safety and welfare issues. Other organisations have internal websites (intranets) detailing this information.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="activity">ACTIVITY<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#activity" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Look around your college or place of learning and identify any health and safety notices, such as first aid, detailing the person to contact.</p>
<p>The City &amp; Guilds Textbook: Electrical Installations Book 1</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="key-terms">KEY TERMS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#key-terms" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Risk: the chance (large or small) of harm actually being done when things go wrong (e.g. risk of electric shock from faulty equipment).</p>
<p>Compliance: the act of carrying out a command or requirement.</p>
<p>Hazard: anything with the potential to cause harm (e.g. chemicals, working at height, a fault on electrical equipment).</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="industry-tip">INDUSTRY TIP<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#industry-tip" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>You must be able to identify hazards as part of a risk assessment. It should then be possible to eliminate, reduce, isolate or control the risk by the application of suitable control measures. The use of personal protective equipment (PPE) should be a last resort.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="industry-tip">INDUSTRY TIP<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#industry-tip" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>When working on practical tasks in college or on site, always keep the work area clean and tidy. Dangerous working will mean you could fail.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="establishing-a-safe-working-environment">ESTABLISHING A SAFE WORKING ENVIRONMENT<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#establishing-a-safe-working-environment" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>The control of risks is essential to the provision and maintenance of a safe and healthy workplace and ensures compliance with the relevant legal requirements.</p>
<p>Risk assessment starts with the need for hazard identification. Risk assessment is usually evaluated in terms of:</p>
<ul>
<li>the likelihood of something happening (i.e. whether a hazard is going to occur)</li>
<li>the severity of outcome (i.e. how serious the resulting injury will be).</li>
</ul>
<p>To control these hazardous situations, duty holders need to:</p>
<ul>
<li>find out what the hazards are</li>
<li>decide how to prevent harm to health</li>
<li>provide control measures to reduce harm to health</li>
<li>make sure the control measures are used</li>
<li>keep all control measures in good working order</li>
<li>provide information, instruction and training for employees and others</li>
<li>provide monitoring and health surveillance in appropriate cases</li>
<li>plan for emergencies.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="common-hazardous-situations-on-site-housekeeping">Common hazardous situations on site Housekeeping<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#common-hazardous-situations-on-site-housekeeping" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Housekeeping is one of the most important single items influencing safety within the workplace. Poor housekeeping not only causes an increase in the risk of fire, slips, trips and falls, but may also expose members of the public to risks created during building services engineers' work activities. The following are some examples of good housekeeping.</p>
<ul>
<li>Stairways, passages and gangways should be kept free from materials, electrical power leads and obstructions of every kind.</li>
<li>Materials and equipment should be stored tidily so as not to cause obstruction and should be kept away from the edges of buildings, roofs, ladder access, stairways, floor openings and rising shafts.</li>
<li>Tools should not be left where they may cause tripping or other hazards. Tools not in use should be placed in a tool belt or tool bag and should be collected and stored in an appropriate container at the end of each working day.</li>
<li>Working areas should be kept clean and tidy. Scrap and rubbish must be removed regularly and placed in proper containers or disposal areas.</li>
<li>Rooms and site accommodation should be kept clean. Soiled clothes, scraps of food, etc. should not be allowed to accumulate, especially around hot pipes or electric heaters.</li>
<li>The spillage of oil or other substances must be contained and cleaned up immediately.</li>
<li>All flammable liquids, liquefied petroleum gas (LPG) and gas cylinders must be stored properly.</li>
</ul>
<p>Chapter 1 Health and safety and industry practices</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251222-d5376416.jpeg" alt="img-11.jpeg">
▲ Figure 1.9 Stairs are a particular risk</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251222-f5a6ca88.jpeg" alt="img-12.jpeg">
▲ Figure 1.10 A tool belt is a good way to avoid leaving tools lying around</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251222-0c11cb5b.jpeg" alt="img-13.jpeg">
▲ Figure 1.11 Gas cylinders must be stored correctly</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="slips-trips-and-falls">Slips, trips and falls<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#slips-trips-and-falls" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>These are the most common hazards to people as they move around the workplace. They account for 29% of all major workplace injuries according to statistics provided by the HSE for 2019/20. Listed below are the main factors that can play a part in contributing to a slip-free and trip-free environment.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="flooring">Flooring<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#flooring" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>The workplace floor must be suitable for the type of work activity that will be taking place on it.</li>
<li>Floors must be cleaned correctly to ensure they do not become slippery, or be of a non-slip type that keeps its slip-resistant properties.</li>
<li>Flooring must be fitted correctly to ensure that there are no trip hazards and any non-slip coatings must be correctly applied.</li>
<li>Floors must be maintained in good order to ensure that there are no trip hazards such as holes, uneven surfaces, curled-up carpet edges, or raised telephone or electrical sockets.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="activity">ACTIVITY<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#activity" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Search the HSE website to see the most common accidents. Then consider or discuss methods of preventing accidents in each of the categories shown.</p>
<p>The City &amp; Guilds Textbook: Electrical Installations Book 1</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="health-and-safety">HEALTH AND SAFETY<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#health-and-safety" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Floorboards must be lifted correctly and nails removed from them. Be careful not to cut any cables or pipes laid below them. Use a proper floorboard saw.</p>
<ul>
<li>Ramps, raised platforms and other changes of level should be avoided. If they cannot be avoided, they must be highlighted.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="stairs">Stairs<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#stairs" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Stairs should have:</p>
<ul>
<li>high-visibility, non-slip, square nosings on the step edges</li>
<li>a suitable handrail</li>
<li>steps of equal height</li>
<li>steps of equal width.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="key-terms">KEY TERMS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#key-terms" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Nosings: the front edges of steps. If they are not square, they can lead to people slipping down the step. Many steps are fitted with additional metal strips to avoid the step from wearing.</p>
<p>Contamination: the introduction of a substance that should not be there, such as water, oil or dust.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="contamination">Contamination<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#contamination" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Most floors only become slippery once they become contaminated. If contamination can be prevented, the slip risk can be reduced or eliminated.</p>
<p>Contamination of a floor can be classed as anything that ends up on a floor, including rainwater, oil, grease, cardboard, product wrapping, dust, and so on. It can be a by-product of a poorly controlled work process or be due to bad weather conditions.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="cleaning">Cleaning<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#cleaning" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Cleaning and tidying are important in every workplace. It is not just a subject for the cleaning team. Everyone's aim should be to keep their workspace clear and deal with contamination such as spillages as soon as they occur.</p>
<p>The process of cleaning can itself create slip and trip hazards, especially for those entering the area being cleaned, including those undertaking the cleaning. Smooth floors left damp by a mop are likely to be extremely slippery. Trailing wires from a vacuum cleaner or polishing machine can present an additional trip hazard.</p>
<p>People often slip on floors that have been left wet after cleaning. Access to smooth wet floors should be restricted by using barriers, locking doors or cleaning in sections. Signs and warning cones only warn of a hazard – they do not prevent people from entering the area. If the water on the floor is not visible, signs and cones are usually ignored.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="human-factors">Human factors<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#human-factors" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>How people act and behave in their work environments can affect the risk of slips and trips. Accidents can be reduced by:</p>
<ul>
<li>having a positive attitude toward health and safety – e.g. dealing with a spillage right away instead of waiting for someone else to deal with it</li>
<li>wearing the correct footwear</li>
<li>concentrating and avoiding distractions, such as being in a hurry, carrying large objects or using a mobile phone, all of which increase the risk of an accident.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="environmental-factors">Environmental factors<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#environmental-factors" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Environmental issues can affect the incidence of slips and trips. For example:</p>
<ul>
<li>Too much light on a shiny floor can cause glare and stop people from seeing hazards on floors and stairs.</li>
</ul>
<p>Chapter 1 Health and safety and industry practices</p>
<ul>
<li>Rainwater on smooth surfaces inside or outside a building may create a slip hazard.</li>
<li>Too little light will prevent people from seeing hazards on floors and stairs.</li>
<li>Unfamiliar and loud noises can be distracting.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="footwear">Footwear<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#footwear" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Footwear can play an important part in preventing slips and trips. For example:</p>
<ul>
<li>The choice of footwear should take into account factors such as comfort and durability, as well as obvious safety features such as providing the protection required for the tasks undertaken.</li>
<li>A good tread pattern on footwear is essential on wet surfaces.</li>
<li>Sole tread patterns should not be allowed to become clogged with any waste or debris on the floor, as this makes them unsuitable for their purpose.</li>
<li>Sole material type and hardness are key factors influencing safety.</li>
<li>Footwear can perform differently in different situations – e.g. footwear that performs well in wet conditions might not be suitable where there are food spillages.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="industry-tip">INDUSTRY TIP<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#industry-tip" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>When working with petrol, oils and lubricants, footwear must be impervious to the chemicals involved.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="the-requirements-for-a-risk-assessment">The requirements for a risk assessment<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#the-requirements-for-a-risk-assessment" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The HSW Act requires employers to provide health and safety systems and procedures in the workplace, and directors and managers of any company that employs more than five employees can be held personally responsible for failure to control health and safety. The general duties of Section 2 of the HSW Act imply that risk assessment is necessary. The aim of the Management of Health and Safety at Work Regulations 1999 (MHSWR) is to give more detail on how to achieve this and to encourage a more systematic and better organised approach to dealing with health and safety in all workplaces. The main objective of risk assessment is to determine the measures required by the organisation to comply with relevant health and safety legislation and so reduce the level of occupational injuries and ill health.</p>
<p>MHSWR Regulation 3 requires that:</p>
<p>'Every employer and self-employed person shall make a suitable and sufficient assessment of:</p>
<ul>
<li>the risks to the health and safety of his employees to which they are exposed while they are at work; and</li>
<li>the risks to the health and safety of persons not in his employment arising out of or in connection with the conduct by him of his undertaking...'.</li>
</ul>
<p>All organisations must have the freedom to prepare systems of work that match the risk potential of their particular work activity and which are practical in their application. Electrotechnical work operations are no different to other work disciplines in this respect and employers must examine the work activities and the workplace and introduce systems of work through a process of 'risk assessment' that takes account of the risks and the application of the health and safety</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="key-term">KEY TERM<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#key-term" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Systematic: working to a fixed plan or procedure.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="industry-tip">INDUSTRY TIP<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#industry-tip" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Section 3 of the Management of Health and Safety at Work Regulations 1999 (MHSWR) covering risk assessments can be accessed by searching the GOV.UK website.</p>
<p>The City &amp; Guilds Textbook: Electrical Installations Book 1</p>
<p>legislation designed to manage those risks. An example of this would be carrying out safe isolation before working on electrical equipment.</p>
<p>The HSE promotes a risk assessment process entitled Five Steps to Risk Assessment. The five steps are as follows (and covered in further detail later in the section).</p>
<p>Step 1 Identify the hazards.</p>
<p>Step 2 Decide who may be harmed and how.</p>
<p>Step 3 Evaluate the risks and decide on precautions.</p>
<p>Step 4 Record the findings and implement them.</p>
<p>Step 5 Review the assessment and update if necessary.</p>
<p>It is important to remember that a risk assessment is a continual process, as the circumstances are constantly changing. Therefore, although the five steps are shown as a list, the process tends to be more of a cycle (Figure 1.12).</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251222-fbcc9c55.jpeg" alt="img-14.jpeg">
Figure 1.12 The five steps for risk assessment</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="industry-tip">INDUSTRY TIP<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#industry-tip" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>A risk assessment identifies the hazards and identifies methods of reducing the risk. It should be continuously reviewed as the working environment changes.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="completing-a-risk-assessment">Completing a risk assessment<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#completing-a-risk-assessment" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="step-1-identify-the-hazard">Step 1: Identify the hazard<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#step-1-identify-the-hazard" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Identifying the hazard is probably the easiest stage of the risk assessment. The person performing the risk assessment must understand fully what is involved in the task. So that the hazards are easier to identify, it is important not to overcomplicate analysis of the task.</p>
<p>The person doing the risk assessment should also consider the specific work environment, so it can be helpful to talk to others who have performed the task.</p>
<p>Remember a risk assessment must be specific to the exact task being performed in a certain place – generic risk assessments are only a starting point.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="step-2-assess-harm">Step 2: Assess harm<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#step-2-assess-harm" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>When assessing the potential for harm, consider where the task is being performed – different locations may change the risk. For example, using a power tool in a public place involves a different set of risks compared to use of the power tool in a workshop or factory because the people in a place of work are more aware of risks than members of the public. Remember, the same task performed by different people may present different hazards, according to each person's knowledge, experience and work ethic.</p>
<p>Chapter 1 Health and safety and industry practices</p>
<p>Some hazards have different impacts depending on who is involved. For example, a person in a wheelchair may be at a particular risk from an activity, whereas a non-disabled person may be able to avoid the hazard. Having identified who may be at risk, the next stage is to think about how they could be harmed. Essentially, all the people at risk must be identified, as well as the potential harm that could be caused.</p>
<p>Because young people at work lack experience and maturity, special risk assessments need to be made, known as Young Person Risk Assessments.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="step-3-evaluate-risks">Step 3: Evaluate risks<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#step-3-evaluate-risks" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Once you have identified the hazard, established who may be affected and in what ways, you must plan how to remove the risks. At this stage, it is a good idea to rank the risks in terms of likelihood and severity of outcome. It may not be possible to remove some risks and so a level of control may be more appropriate, such as the use of barriers.</p>
<p>A simple way to rank the risks is to consider them in terms of impact versus likelihood of the risk happening. A complex numbering system can be used to score the risk: the higher the number the more important it is to reduce the risk. Alternatively, a simple 'traffic light' matrix can be used, as shown in Figure 1.13.</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251222-69ff701f.jpeg" alt="img-15.jpeg"></p>
<p>Figure 1.13 A risk evaluation matrix</p>
<ul>
<li>Red: high risks that must be controlled. Work cannot proceed until these risks are removed or reduced.</li>
<li>Amber: medium-level risks. The control measure is to ensure the safest working procedures and practices are being applied.</li>
<li>Green: minor and unavoidable risks. There should be a plan for what to do if the hazard should occur.</li>
</ul>
<p>It is possible for hazards to move from one level of risk to another as work is undertaken. Therefore, the risk assessment must be constantly monitored and evaluated.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="key-term">KEY TERM<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#key-term" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Young people: people under the age of 18.</p>
<p>The City &amp; Guilds Textbook: Electrical Installations Book 1</p>
<p>Once the risks have been ranked into red, amber and green classifications, solutions need to be implemented. The approach to risk management includes a hierarchy of control, which should be approached in this sequence:</p>
<ol>
<li>Elimination</li>
<li>Reduction</li>
<li>Enclosure</li>
<li>Remove persons</li>
<li>Reduce contact.</li>
</ol>
<p>Risk management option 1, Elimination, is the most effective and should always be the first choice. Risk management option 5, Reduce contact, is the least effective, but is often chosen – it covers the use of personal protective equipment (PPE). Other control measures that can also be used include:</p>
<ul>
<li>protective clothing</li>
<li>instruction</li>
<li>training</li>
<li>following a defined procedure for a task</li>
<li>implementing a permit-to-work system</li>
<li>information signs</li>
<li>information sheets.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="key-term">KEY TERM<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#key-term" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Method statement: instructions on performing tasks safely in accordance with the risk assessment. (There is more detail on method statements later in this section.)</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="industry-tip">INDUSTRY TIP<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#industry-tip" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Access the Construction (Design and Management) Regulations 2015 (CDM) by searching the GOV.UK website.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="step-4-document-and-implement-solution">Step 4: Document and implement solution<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#step-4-document-and-implement-solution" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Risk assessments are not very effective unless everyone knows about them. Therefore the documentation of hazards, risks and their control measures is essential.</p>
<p>Control measures need to be documented and people must be trained in any changes to working practices. Sometimes, while training is taking place, other potential risks may be identified. Part of the documentation can include method statements to ensure that work practices and safety measures are in place and followed correctly. A record should be kept of who receives training. In some cases, this is signed to confirm that workers have received training and understand the requirements now placed on them. This record can help employers to prove they are meeting the legal requirement to do everything reasonably practicable to keep people safe.</p>
<p>If the work is to be performed on a construction site, the Construction (Design and Management) Regulations 2015 (CDM) specify that the risk assessments and method statements must be retained in the site safety file. This file is referred to in most site safety induction training sessions and forms the basis of an employee site safety manual.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="step-5-evaluate-review-and-update">Step 5: Evaluate, review and update<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#step-5-evaluate-review-and-update" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Once a risk assessment has been performed, it should be checked regularly or before the task in question is performed to ensure the control measures being followed are effective. As well as being reviewed regularly, the risk assessment should be reassessed if the work or environment changes. Any changes that are required will become part of the future review process.</p>
<p>Chapter 1 Health and safety and industry practices</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="control-of-high-level-risks">Control of high-level risks<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#control-of-high-level-risks" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>If the risk level identified is high, the control measures may need to be more extensive. The aim of risk assessment is to reduce all residual risks to as low a level as reasonably practicable and use the resulting information to prepare control measures as necessary. Many hazards have specific regulations or guidance available to give advice on reducing the risk (e.g. lead, electricity, asbestos) and these should be referred to in the first instance, to obtain advice for the preparation of control measures.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="safe-systems-of-work">Safe systems of work<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#safe-systems-of-work" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>A safe system of work is a work method that results from a systematic examination of the working process to identify the hazards and to specify work methods designed either to completely remove the hazards or to control and minimise the relevant risks. Section 2 of the Health and Safety at Work etc. Act 1974 (HSW Act) requires employers to provide safe plant and systems of work. Many of the regulations made under the HSW Act have more specific requirements for the provision of safe systems of work.</p>
<p>Safe systems of work should be developed by a competent person – that is, a person with sufficient training and experience or knowledge to assist with key aspects of safety management and compliance. Staff who are actively involved in the work process also have a valuable role to play in the development of the system. They can help to ensure that it is of practical benefit and that it will be applied diligently. All safe systems of work need to be monitored regularly to ensure that they are fully observed and effective, and updated as necessary. Safe systems of work are normally formal and documented, but may also be given as a verbal instruction. Examples of documented safe systems of work would be for asbestos removal, air-conditioning maintenance, working on live electrical equipment and portable appliance testing. Examples of verbal instructions could be as simple as 'ensure you clear the route before moving those ladders'.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="method-statements">Method statements<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#method-statements" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>A method statement is a description of a safe system of work, presenting in a logical sequence, and generally in writing, a method of undertaking an activity without risk to health. The method statement should be clear, and illustrated where applicable by simple sketches. Statements are for the benefit of those carrying out the work and their immediate supervisors and should not be overcomplicated. The statement includes all the risks identified in the risk assessment and the measures to control those risks. The statement need be no longer than necessary to achieve the objective of safe working.</p>
