<p>Employees should know what to do if the work process has changed and the method statement no longer achieves its aim. Method statements must be reviewed on a regular basis to accommodate any such changes in the work process.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="key-terms">KEY TERMS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#key-terms" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Plant: tools and machinery.</p>
<p>Competent person: recognised term for someone with the necessary skills, knowledge and experience to manage health and safety in the workplace.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="activity">ACTIVITY<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#activity" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Clear instructions are important. Can you spot the difference between the two instructions below?</p>
<p>It needs to go over there, head for the door.</p>
<p>It needs to go over their head for the door.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="activity">ACTIVITY<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#activity" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Write a brief method statement for a simple task such as moving an awkwardly large but lightweight box from one end of a workshop to the other.</p>
<p>The City &amp; Guilds Textbook: Electrical Installations Book 1</p>
<table><thead><tr><th>Method statement (safe system of work)</th><th></th><th></th><th></th><th></th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>Contract ref: RLF-0012-18 Address: Office 34, New Road, New Town. <p><span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">△</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\triangle</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8889em; vertical-align: -0.1944em;"></span><span class="mord">△</span></span></span></span></span>  Figure 1.14 A method statement should be clear and simple</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="key-terms">KEY TERMS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#key-terms" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Permit-to-work (PTW): a written safe system of work produced to support the safe completion of potentially dangerous work and support communications between different persons.</p>
<p>Hot work: work that involves actual or potential sources of ignition, carried out in an area where there is a risk of fire or explosion (e.g. welding, flame cutting or grinding).</p>
<p>Audit: conduct a systematic review to make sure standards and management systems are being followed.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="permit-to-work-procedures">Permit-to-work procedures<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#permit-to-work-procedures" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>A permit-to-work (PTW) procedure is a specialised written safe system of work that ensures that potentially dangerous work is done safely. Examples include work in confined spaces, hot work, work with asbestos-based materials, work on pipelines with hazardous contents, or work on high-voltage electrical systems (above 1000 V) or complex low-voltage electrical systems.</p>
<p>A PTW procedure also serves as a means of communication between site or installation management, plant supervisors and operators, and those who carry out the hazardous work.</p>
<p>For example, if an electrician needed to work on the low-voltage side of a transformer controlled by a supply company, they would obtain a PTW that states that the supply company have isolated the transformer and the system is safe to work on.</p>
<p>A PTW should only be issued by a technically competent person, who is familiar with the system and equipment, and is authorised in writing by the employer to issue such documents.</p>
<p>Essential features of PTW systems are:</p>
<ul>
<li>clear identification of who may authorise particular jobs (and any limits to their authority) and who is responsible for specifying the necessary precautions</li>
</ul>
<p>Chapter 1 Health and safety and industry practices</p>
<ul>
<li>training and instruction in the issue, use and closure of permits</li>
<li>monitoring and <strong>auditing</strong> to ensure that the system works as intended</li>
<li>clear identification of the types of work considered hazardous</li>
<li>clear and standardised identification of tasks and risk assessments</li>
<li>permitted task duration and any additional activity or control.</li>
</ul>
<p>The effective operation of a PTW system requires involvement and co-operation from a number of persons. The procedure for issuing a PTW should be written and adhered to.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="the-hierarchy-of-control">The hierarchy of control<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#the-hierarchy-of-control" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The control of risk is essential to the provision of a safe working environment that complies with all of the relevant legal requirements. To maintain this safe working environment, any control measures (detailed below) that are produced require assessment and, if necessary, amendment or the introduction of new measures.</p>
<p>There is an acknowledged ‘hierarchy of control’, which is simply a list of measures designed to control risks that are considered in order of importance, effectiveness or priority. This control sequence normally begins with an extreme measure of control and ends with personal protective equipment as a last resort. If we consider a task such as working near a big hole in the ground, we consider:</p>
<ol>
<li><strong>Eliminate</strong> – does the hole need to be there, or can it be filled in?</li>
<li><strong>Substitute</strong> – can the task be done somewhere else?</li>
<li><strong>Isolate</strong> – e.g. by putting something over the hole to cover it</li>
<li><strong>Control</strong> – e.g. by introducing guarding around the hole</li>
<li><strong>Manage</strong> – e.g. by implementing a safe system of work near a hole</li>
<li><strong>Personal protective equipment</strong> – e.g. working with a harness or rope.</li>
</ol>
<p>Only once all of the measures numbered 1 to 5 above have been tried, and found ineffective in controlling the risks to a reasonably practical level, must point 6, personal protective equipment (PPE), be used.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="personal-protective-equipment-ppe">Personal protective equipment (PPE)<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#personal-protective-equipment-ppe" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The Personal Protective Equipment at Work Regulations 1992 identify the need for employers to provide suitable PPE for their employees to perform their work activities safely. The PPE Regulations cover all forms of protection, including clothing that is required to give protection against the weather. However, it does not necessarily include the provision of <em>all</em> protective equipment.</p>
<p>Hearing protection such as ear plugs and ear defenders are <em>not</em> covered by these regulations as they are covered by other specific regulations, as are respiratory devices. If you are working in environments where these items of PPE are required, other regulations and legislation also apply. Items such as cycle helmets and crash helmets that would normally be worn on public highways are also not covered by these regulations, even if the wearer is using a bicycle or motorbike as part of their job function.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="activity">ACTIVITY<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#activity" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<p>Identify possible risks in using a ladder as access equipment when fixing a PIR luminaire 4 m high.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="industry-tip">INDUSTRY TIP<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#industry-tip" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<p>PPE cannot stop accidents; it merely reduces their effects.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="industry-tip">INDUSTRY TIP<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#industry-tip" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<p>Access the Personal Protective Equipment at Work Regulations 1992 by searching the HSE website.</p>
<p>The City &amp; Guilds Textbook: Electrical Installations Book 1</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251222-41c1f723.jpeg" alt="img-16.jpeg"></p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251222-29626e5b.jpeg" alt="img-17.jpeg">
Figure 1.15 Personal protective equipment used in the industry includes gauntlets and spats</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="industry-tip">INDUSTRY TIP<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#industry-tip" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Risk assessments can be used to identify the PPE required. The British Safety Industry Federation provides support as to the most suitable PPE for different functions.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="industry-tip">INDUSTRY TIP<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#industry-tip" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>You should always ensure you are wearing the correct PPE when working on practical tasks in college or on site. Many sites operate a card system for workers not wearing the appropriate PPE – the first time is a warning (yellow card); if there's a second offence, you are off site (red card).</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="industry-tip">INDUSTRY TIP<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#industry-tip" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Employers are not allowed to charge employees for PPE. However, if an employee does not return items when they leave the employment, they can be charged.</p>
<p>According to the regulations, an employer has a legal duty to:</p>
<ul>
<li>provide the correct PPE</li>
<li>ensure that it is used correctly</li>
<li>ensure it is stored correctly</li>
<li>train employees in the correct use.</li>
</ul>
<p>The term 'employer' also applies to employment agencies, which must ensure that they comply with regulations.</p>
<p>When thinking about the suitability of PPE, ask these questions:</p>
<ul>
<li>Is the PPE appropriate, based on the risks identified?</li>
<li>Does it prevent or adequately control the level of risk?</li>
<li>Could it increase the risk or create a new risk?</li>
<li>Can it be adjusted to fit different wearers?</li>
<li>Is it suitable for the individual wearing it?</li>
<li>Will wearing the PPE cause discomfort?</li>
<li>Is it compatible with other PPE that has to be worn at the same time?</li>
</ul>
<p>Consider that, if the PPE is cumbersome, not practical or uncomfortable, the employee may not wear it. If they do wear it, they may not wear it correctly. For example:</p>
<ul>
<li>Sunglasses are popular but are not suitable eye protection for drilling or grinding.</li>
<li>Safety boots may be tedious to lace up correctly but should not be left with loose laces.</li>
<li>High visibility jackets do not make a suitable tool belt.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="types-of-ppe">Types of PPE<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#types-of-ppe" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>PPE is about protecting people from harm. Certain tasks present different hazards to different parts of the body. The PPE Regulations consider different parts of the person, with each area requiring different protection. These areas are:</p>
<ul>
<li>eyes</li>
<li>head</li>
</ul>
<p>Chapter 1 Health and safety and industry practices</p>
<ul>
<li>breathing</li>
<li>the body</li>
<li>hands and arms</li>
<li>feet and legs.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="eyes">Eyes<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#eyes" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Losing or damaging your sight can have a life-changing effect, not just on your ability to work, but on your standard and way of living. The types of hazard that can affect your eyes include:</p>
<ul>
<li>chemical splash</li>
<li>metal swarf</li>
<li>dust particles</li>
<li>projectiles</li>
<li>gas and vapour</li>
<li>radiation (in welding).</li>
</ul>
<p>Depending on the work to be undertaken, there are several types of PPE that provide suitable protection for the eyes (Figure 1.16):</p>
<ul>
<li>safety glasses</li>
<li>goggles</li>
<li>face shield</li>
<li>visor.</li>
</ul>

<img src="assets/images/image-20251222-a327efaa.jpeg" alt="img-23.jpeg"></p>
<p>Figure 1.16 Different types of eye protection</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="head">Head<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#head" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Concussion, caused by a simple knock to the head, can be fatal if not treated correctly. Therefore, head protection is vitally important. Head protection is intended to provide protection from:</p>
<ul>
<li>impact of falling objects</li>
<li>impact of flying objects</li>
<li>bumping your head on hard surfaces or sharp edges</li>
<li>hair entanglement.</li>
</ul>
<p>Depending on the work activity, the choice of PPE includes:</p>
<ul>
<li>general safety helmet</li>
<li>working-at-height safety helmet</li>
<li>safety helmet with in-built visor</li>
<li>safety helmet with in-built ear defenders</li>
<li>bump cap</li>
<li>hair net.</li>
</ul>
<p>Figure 1.17 Types of head protection: hard hat (top), bump cap (bottom)</p>
<p>The City &amp; Guilds Textbook: Electrical Installations Book 1</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="health-and-safety">HEALTH AND SAFETY<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#health-and-safety" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Oxygen-deficient atmospheres are found, for example, in confined locations where there is little or no air flow. A person can slip into unconsciousness before they realise they are in danger.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="breathing">Breathing<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#breathing" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The risk to breathing is not always immediately apparent – some illnesses that are caused by particle inhalation can take years to show, and a person's life may be limited by the time they receive a diagnosis. The types of hazard that must be considered include:</p>
<ul>
<li>dust</li>
<li>vapour</li>
<li>gas</li>
<li>oxygen-deficient atmospheres.</li>
</ul>
<p>The PPE for breathing hazards are:</p>
<ul>
<li>disposable filtering face pieces</li>
<li>disposable respirators</li>
<li>half- or full-face respirators</li>
<li>air-fed helmets</li>
<li>breathing apparatus.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="health-and-safety">HEALTH AND SAFETY<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#health-and-safety" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Breathing in silica dust, which is present when drilling through certain rock or stone products, can lead to cancer and/or long-term lung diseases such as silicosis. Silica is also a major constituent of construction materials such as bricks, tiles, concrete and mortar. Always wear facemasks to filter the dust.</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251222-371574d8.jpeg" alt="img-24.jpeg">
Figure 1.18 Different types of facemasks</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251222-d74313af.jpeg" alt="img-25.jpeg"></p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251222-116773fb.jpeg" alt="img-26.jpeg"></p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="protection-of-the-body">Protection of the body<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#protection-of-the-body" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>General protection of the body is often overlooked but, in certain work activities, hazards that affect the body can be very important. These hazards include:</p>
<ul>
<li>temperature extremes</li>
<li>adverse weather</li>
<li>chemical splashes</li>
<li>spray from pressure leaks or spray guns</li>
<li>impact or penetration</li>
<li>contaminated dust</li>
</ul>
<p>Chapter 1 Health and safety and industry practices</p>
<ul>
<li>excessive wear</li>
<li>electrical explosion</li>
<li>entanglement.</li>
</ul>
<p>There are several PPE options, including:</p>
<ul>
<li>overalls</li>
<li>boiler suits, or bib and brace</li>
<li>high-visibility clothing</li>
<li>thermal underwear</li>
<li>waterproof clothing</li>
<li>leather aprons</li>
<li>flash protection suits</li>
<li>chain-mail aprons.</li>
</ul>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251222-14e22342.jpeg" alt="img-27.jpeg">
Figure 1.19 Body protection: high-visibility jacket (left), bib and brace (centre) and apron (right)</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="hands-and-arms">Hands and arms<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#hands-and-arms" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The hands and arms are easily injured, especially in electrical installation work, which tends to be mostly manual labour. The hazards to hands and arms include:</p>
<ul>
<li>abrasion</li>
<li>temperature extremes</li>
<li>cuts and punctures</li>
<li>impact</li>
<li>chemicals</li>
<li>electric shock</li>
<li>skin infection</li>
<li>disease</li>
<li>contamination.</li>
</ul>
<p>Many injuries occur when people hold items that they are trying to cut or drill. In such cases, training in the correct cutting or drilling technique might be a better solution than PPE.</p>
<p>There are several PPE options for protecting hands and arms:</p>
<ul>
<li>gloves made of different material based on the protection needed, such as oil resistance, anti-cut, anti-slip</li>
<li>gauntlets, which provide protection further up the arm.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="industry-tip">INDUSTRY TIP<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#industry-tip" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Wearing gloves or using barrier creams can also reduce skin irritations or the possibility of developing dermatitis.</p>
<p>The City &amp; Guilds Textbook: Electrical Installations Book 1</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251222-4069bcab.jpeg" alt="img-28.jpeg">
Figure 1.20 A selection of work gloves</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="health-and-safety">HEALTH AND SAFETY<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#health-and-safety" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The range of gloves available is vast. When choosing gloves, think of the task and what the gloves need to do such as grip, protect from chemicals, protect from cuts, and so on.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="feet-and-legs">Feet and legs<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#feet-and-legs" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Safety boots are the most common form of PPE among construction site workers. These protect against falling objects. However, feet and legs can be subject to other hazards including:</p>
<ul>
<li>wet conditions</li>
<li>slipping</li>
<li>cuts and punctures</li>
<li>falling objects</li>
<li>metal splashes from welding or cutting</li>
<li>chemical splashes</li>
<li>abrasion</li>
<li>irritants such as dust or powders.</li>
</ul>
<p>The use of safety boots does not address all these hazards. Other options include the use of:</p>
<ul>
<li>safety boots or shoes with protective toe caps and penetration resistant midsole</li>
<li>boots or shoes with oil-resistant soles</li>
<li>gaiters</li>
<li>leggings</li>
<li>overalls.</li>
</ul>
<p>All construction sites now display safety boards at each entrance advising that people are not allowed on site unless they are wearing safety boots, high-visibility</p>
<p>Chapter 1 Health and safety and industry practices</p>
<p>clothing and a hard hat. Some companies are going further than this by ensuring workers do not wear shorts or go topless, due to the risk of skin damage from abrasion.</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251222-fa1abae7.jpeg" alt="img-29.jpeg">
Figure 1.21 Foot protection: shoes (left), rigger boots (centre) and safety boots (right)</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251222-8f5c00e0.jpeg" alt="img-30.jpeg"></p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251222-7f382dd4.jpeg" alt="img-31.jpeg"></p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="safety-signs">Safety signs<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#safety-signs" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>The Health and Safety (Signs and Signals) Regulations require employers to display signage where risks to health and safety have not been removed by other means, such as a safe system of work. Many premises and construction sites will display a range of signs in addition to having safe systems in place.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="prohibition-signs">Prohibition signs<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#prohibition-signs" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>These signs indicate an activity that must not be done. They are circular white signs with a red border and red cross bar.</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251222-69998663.jpeg" alt="img-32.jpeg">
No access for unauthorised persons</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251222-d9350ef1.jpeg" alt="img-33.jpeg">
No smoking in this building</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251222-16bd8568.jpeg" alt="img-34.jpeg">
In the event of fire do not use this lift</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251222-b4d043c0.jpeg" alt="img-35.jpeg">
Do not drink</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="warning-signs">Warning signs<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#warning-signs" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>These provide safety information and/or give warning of a hazard or danger. They are triangular yellow signs with a black border and symbol.</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251222-a12c584b.jpeg" alt="img-36.jpeg">

<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="key-term">KEY TERM<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#key-term" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Severity: seriousness.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="industry-tip">INDUSTRY TIP<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#industry-tip" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>You do not need to know all of the detail in the GHS as an electrician, but it is important that you are aware of it and how it might directly affect your process and work onsite. Further information about the GHS can be found by searching the HSE's website.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="symbols-for-hazardous-substances">Symbols for hazardous substances<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#symbols-for-hazardous-substances" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Hazardous substances are given a classification according to the severity and type of hazard they may present to people in the workplace. However, all over the world there are different laws on how to identify the hazardous properties of chemicals. The United Nations has therefore created the Globally Harmonised System of Classification and Labelling of Chemicals (GHS). The aim of the GHS is to have, worldwide, the same:</p>
<ul>
<li>criteria for classifying chemicals according to their health, environmental and physical hazards</li>
<li>hazard communication requirements for labelling and safety data sheets.</li>
</ul>
<p>The GHS is not a formal agreement, but is a non-legally binding international agreement. In Great Britain, the existing legislation is the Chemicals (Hazard Information and Packaging for Supply) Regulations 2009 (CHIPS), but this has gradually been replaced by the European Classification, Labelling and Packaging of Substances and Mixtures Regulations.</p>
<p>Examples of the GHS labelling system are shown in Figure 1.27.</p>
<p>Chapter 1 Health and safety and industry practices</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251222-a4441f9d.jpeg" alt="img-48.jpeg">
Figure 1.27 The hazard signs shown indicate substances that are (top row, left to right) corrosive, dangerous to the environment, gas under pressure, require caution (irritants), toxic; and (bottom row, left to right) long-term health hazards (causes of cancer), oxidising, explosive, flammable</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="common-hazardous-substances">Common hazardous substances<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#common-hazardous-substances" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Hazardous substances at work may include the substances used directly in the work process – such as glue, paints, thinners, solvents and cleaning materials – and those produced by different work activities, such as welding fumes. Health hazards are always present during building services activities due to the nature of the activities and may include other hazards, such as vibration, dust (possibly including asbestos), cement and solvents.</p>
<p>The Control of Substances Hazardous to Health (COSHH) Regulations 2002 provide a framework that helps employers assess risk and monitor effective controls. A COSHH assessment is essential before work starts and should be updated as new substances are introduced. Hazardous substances include:</p>
<ul>
<li>any substance that gives off fumes that may cause headaches or respiratory irritation</li>
<li>acids that cause skin burns or respiratory irritation (e.g. battery acid, metal-cleaning materials)</li>
<li>solvents that cause skin and respiratory irritation (e.g. for PVC tubes and fittings)</li>
<li>synthetic fibres that cause eye or skin irritation (e.g. thermal insulation, optical fibres)</li>
<li>cement and wood dust that may cause eye irritation and respiratory irritation</li>
<li>fumes and gases that cause respiratory irritation (e.g. soldering, brazing and welding fumes, overheating or burning PVC)</li>
<li>asbestos.</li>
</ul>
<p>The COSHH Regulations require employers to assess risk and ensure the prevention or adequate control of exposure to hazardous substances by measures other than the provision of personal protective equipment (PPE) 'so far as is reasonably practicable'.</p>
<p>As for any risk, the acknowledged hierarchy of control measures listed on page 31 should be used to assess the precautions to be taken when working with hazardous substances.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="key-terms">KEY TERMS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#key-terms" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Toxic: Poisonous.</p>
<p>Hazardous substance: Something that can cause ill health to people.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="industry-tip">INDUSTRY TIP<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#industry-tip" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Toxic substances can enter the body by ingestion (swallowing), inhalation (breathing) and absorption (for example, through the skin and eyes).</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="health-and-safety">HEALTH AND SAFETY<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#health-and-safety" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Make sure you can recognise a hazard and are able to know what you can do to reduce the risk before handling hazardous substances.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="activity">ACTIVITY<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#activity" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Think of some common electrical components that could contain substances hazardous to health, and produce a factsheet detailing precautions such as disposal methods or handling measures.</p>
<p>The City &amp; Guilds Textbook: Electrical Installations Book 1</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="key-term">KEY TERM<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#key-term" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Asbestos: a rock-like mineral, which can be used to strengthen materials or provide good fire resistance.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="asbestos-encountered-in-the-workplace">Asbestos encountered in the workplace<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#asbestos-encountered-in-the-workplace" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Asbestos is the single greatest cause of work-related deaths in the UK. It is a naturally occurring substance, which is obtained from the ground as a rock-like ore, normally through open-pit mining.</p>
<p>Asbestos was used extensively as a building material in the UK from the 1950s through to the mid-1980s. It was used for a variety of purposes and was ideal for fireproofing and insulation. Any building built before the year 2000 (houses, factories, offices, schools, hospitals, etc.) may contain asbestos.</p>
<p>Asbestos materials in good condition are safe, unless the asbestos fibres become airborne, which happens when materials are damaged due to demolition or remedial works on or in the vicinity of asbestos ceiling tiles, asbestos cement roofs and wall sheets, sprayed asbestos coatings on steel structures, and asbestos lagging. In older buildings the presence of asbestos in and around boilers and hot water pipes, and in structural fire protection, must always be anticipated when undertaking electrical work. It is difficult to identify asbestos by colour alone and laboratory tests are normally required for positive identification.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="industry-tip">INDUSTRY TIP<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#industry-tip" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Access the Control of Asbestos Regulations 2012 by searching the GOV.UK website.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="key-term">KEY TERM<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#key-term" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Abraded: scraped or worn away by friction.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="health-and-safety">HEALTH AND SAFETY<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#health-and-safety" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Any potential contact with asbestos should be treated seriously as the health risks can be severe.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="what-to-do-if-the-presence-of-asbestos-is-suspected">What to do if the presence of asbestos is suspected<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#what-to-do-if-the-presence-of-asbestos-is-suspected" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>If asbestos is discovered during a work activity, work should be stopped and the employer or duty holder informed immediately. The Control of Asbestos Regulations 2012 affect anyone who owns, occupies, manages or otherwise has responsibilities for the maintenance and repair of buildings that may contain asbestos. The regulations cover the need for a risk assessment, and the need for method statements for the removal and disposal of asbestos, air monitoring and the control measures required. These control measures include personal protective equipment and training.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="implications-of-being-exposed-to-asbestos">Implications of being exposed to asbestos<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#implications-of-being-exposed-to-asbestos" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Asbestos commonly comes in the form of chrysotile (white asbestos), amosite (brown asbestos) and crocidolite (blue asbestos). Chrysotile is the common form of asbestos and accounts for 90–95% of all asbestos in circulation. When abraded or drilled, asbestos produces a fine dust with fibres small enough to be taken into the lungs. Asbestos fibres are very sharp and can lead to mesothelioma (cancer of the lining of the lung), lung cancer, asbestosis (scarring of the lung), diffuse pleural thickening (thickening and hardening of the lung wall) and death.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="the-requirement-for-first-aid-facilities">The requirement for first aid facilities<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#the-requirement-for-first-aid-facilities" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>In the event of injury or sudden illness, failure to provide correct first aid could result in death. Employers must ensure that an employee who is injured or taken ill at work receives immediate attention.</p>
<p>The Health and Safety (First-Aid) Regulations 1981 require employers to provide adequate and appropriate equipment, facilities and personnel to ensure their employees receive immediate attention if they are injured or taken ill at work. These Regulations apply to all workplaces, including those with fewer than five employees and to the self-employed.</p>
<p>Chapter 1 Health and safety and industry practices</p>
<p>What is 'adequate and appropriate' will depend on the circumstances in the workplace, and employers should carry out an assessment of first aid needs to determine what to provide. There are a number of factors to be considered:</p>
<ul>
<li>number of employees</li>
<li>type of work being undertaken</li>
<li>unusual hazards</li>
<li>'off-site' workers</li>
<li>out of hours or shift patterns</li>
<li>nearest emergency services.</li>
</ul>
<p>This will determine whether trained first aiders are needed, what should be included in a first aid box and whether or not a first aid room is required. The HSE suggests at least one appointed first aider where a low-risk business, such as a shop or office, has fewer than 25 staff members.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="the-first-aid-box">The first aid box<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#the-first-aid-box" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>There is no standard list of items that need to be contained in a first aid box and the contents depend on what the employer or the 'person in control of the site' assesses the needs to be. However, tablets or medicines should not be kept in first aid boxes. It is sensible to have an 'appointed person' to look after the first aid equipment and replenish when required.</p>
<p>Emergencies can occur at any time and there may well be an immediate need for items without having to search for them. Items in first aid boxes should not be taken for other uses. Items are needed for particular reasons and therefore misuse will decrease supplies.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="fire-safety">Fire safety<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#fire-safety" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Most fires are preventable and by adopting the right behaviours and procedures, prevention can easily be achieved.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="how-combustion-takes-place">How combustion takes place<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#how-combustion-takes-place" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>A fire needs three elements to start:</p>
<ul>
<li>a source of ignition (heat)</li>
<li>a source of fuel (something that burns)</li>
<li>oxygen.</li>
</ul>
<p>If any one of these elements is removed, a fire will not ignite or will cease to burn.</p>
<ul>
<li>Sources of ignition include heaters, lighting, naked flames, electrical equipment, smokers' materials (cigarettes, matches) and anything else that can get very hot or cause sparks.</li>
<li>Sources of fuel include wood, paper, plastic, rubber or foam, loose packaging materials, waste rubbish, combustible liquids and furniture.</li>
<li>Sources of oxygen include the air surrounding us.</li>
</ul>
<p>A fire safety risk assessment (using the same approach as used in the health and safety risk assessment – see pages 26–28) should be used to determine</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="industry-tip">INDUSTRY TIP<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#industry-tip" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Access the Health and Safety (First-Aid) Regulations 1981 by searching the GOV.UK website.</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251222-c774e262.jpeg" alt="img-49.jpeg">
Figure 1.28 A well-stocked first aid box</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251222-b0bad9dd.jpeg" alt="img-50.jpeg">
Figure 1.29 The fire triangle</p>
<p>The City &amp; Guilds Textbook: Electrical Installations Book 1</p>
<p>the risks. Based on the findings of the assessment, employers must ensure that adequate and appropriate fire safety measures are in place to minimise the risk of injury or loss of life in the event of a fire. These findings must be kept up to date.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="dangers-of-working-with-heat-producing-equipment">Dangers of working with heat-producing equipment<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#dangers-of-working-with-heat-producing-equipment" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The use of heat-producing equipment (hot work) is a common occurrence in building services work activities. Hot work is work that might generate sufficient heat, sparks or flame to cause a fire. It includes welding, flame cutting, soldering, brazing, grinding and other equipment that incorporates a flame, such as boilers or furnaces.</p>
<p>The flames, sparks and heat produced during the hot work are ignition sources that can cause fires and explosions in many different situations. For example:</p>
<ul>
<li>sparks produced during hot work can land on combustible materials and cause fires and explosions</li>
<li>hot work performed on tanks and vessels with residual flammable substances and vapours can cause the tanks to explode.</li>
</ul>
<p>To help prevent fire in the workplace, the risk assessment should identify what could cause a fire to start (the sources of ignition (heat or sparks), the substances that burn) and the people who may be at risk.</p>
<p>Once the risks have been identified, appropriate action can be taken to control them. Actions should be based on whether the risks can be avoided altogether or, if this is not possible, how they can be reduced. The checklist below will help with an appropriate action plan.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="industry-tip">INDUSTRY TIP<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#industry-tip" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The Regulatory Reform (Fire Safety) Order 2005 covers general fire safety in England and Wales and can be accessed by searching the GOV.UK website.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="activity">ACTIVITY<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#activity" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Walk around your own house or place of work and make a list of potential sources of fire then apply the checklist above to them. As an example, electric fires can create a fire risk if clothes are draped over them.</p>
<ul>
<li>Keep sources of ignition and flammable substances apart.</li>
<li>Avoid accidental fires (e.g. make sure heaters cannot be knocked over).</li>
<li>Ensure good housekeeping at all times (e.g. avoid build-up of rubbish that could burn).</li>
<li>Consider how to detect fires and how to warn people quickly if a fire starts (e.g. install smoke alarms and fire alarms or bells).</li>
<li>Have the correct fire-fighting equipment available.</li>
<li>Keep fire exits and escape routes clearly marked and unobstructed at all times.</li>
<li>Ensure workers receive appropriate training on procedures and fire drills.</li>
<li>Review and update the risk assessment on a regular basis.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="procedures-on-discovery-of-fires-on-site">Procedures on discovery of fires on site<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#procedures-on-discovery-of-fires-on-site" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>How people react in the event of fire depends on how well they have been prepared and trained for a fire emergency. It is therefore imperative that all employees (and visitors and contractors) are familiar with the company procedure to follow in the event of an emergency. A basic procedure is as follows.</p>
<ol>
<li>On discovery of a fire, raise the alarm immediately.</li>
<li>If staff are trained and it is considered safe to do so, attempt to fight the fire using the equipment provided.</li>
</ol>
<p>Chapter 1 Health and safety and industry practices</p>
<p>3 If fire-fighting fails, evacuate (leave the area) immediately.
4 Ensure that no one is left in the fire area and close doors on exit in order to prevent the spread of fire.
5 Go straight to the designated assembly point. These points are specially chosen as they are in locations of safety and where the emergency services are not likely to be obstructed on arrival.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="health-and-safety">HEALTH AND SAFETY<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#health-and-safety" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Remember, NEVER ignore a fire alarm, even if it has gone off many times before that day. It may be the last one you ignore.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="different-classifications-of-fires">Different classifications of fires<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#different-classifications-of-fires" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>All fires are grouped into classes, according to the types of materials that are burning.</p>
<p>Figure 1.30 is a guide to the different types of fire and the types of extinguisher that should be used.</p>
<table><thead><tr><th>Fire classification</th><th>Water</th><th>Foam</th><th>Powder</th><th>CO2</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>Class A – Combustible materials such as paper, wood, cardboard and most plastics</td><td>✓</td><td>✓</td><td>✓</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>Class B – Flammable or combustible liquids such as petrol, kerosene, paraffin, grease and oil</td><td></td><td>✓</td><td>✓</td><td>✓</td></tr><tr><td>Class C – Flammable gases, such as propane, butane and methane</td><td></td><td></td><td>✓</td><td>✓</td></tr><tr><td>Class D – Combustible metals, such as magnesium, titanium, potassium and sodium</td><td></td><td></td><td>Specialist dry powder</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>Class F – Cooking oils and fats</td><td></td><td>Specialist wet chemical (yellow)</td><td></td><td></td></tr></tbody></table>
<p><span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">△</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\triangle</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8889em; vertical-align: -0.1944em;"></span><span class="mord">△</span></span></span></span></span>  Figure 1.30 Fire classification and the correct extinguisher to be used</p>
<p>Fires involving equipment such as electrical circuits or electronic equipment are often referred to as Class E fires, although the category does not officially exist under the BS EN 3 rating system. This is because electrical equipment is often the cause of the fire, rather than the actual type of fire. Most modern fire extinguishers specify on the label whether they should be used on electrical equipment. Normally carbon dioxide or dry powder are suitable agents for putting out a fire involving electricity.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="manual-handling">Manual handling<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#manual-handling" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Manual handling is one of the most common causes of injury at work and causes over a third of all workplace injuries. Manual handling injuries can occur almost anywhere in the workplace and heavy manual labour, awkward postures or previous or existing injury can increase the risk. Work-related manual handling injuries can have serious implications for both the employer and the person who has been injured.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="key-term">KEY TERM<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#key-term" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Manual handling: the movement of items by lifting, lowering, carrying, pushing or pulling by human effort alone.</p>
<p>The City &amp; Guilds Textbook: Electrical Installations Book 1</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="industry-tip">INDUSTRY TIP<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#industry-tip" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Access the Manual Handling Operations Regulations 1992 by searching the GOV.UK website.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="manual-handling-techniques">Manual handling techniques<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#manual-handling-techniques" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>The introduction of the Manual Handling Operations Regulations 1992 saw a change from reliance on safe lifting techniques to an analysis, using risk assessment, of the need for manual handling. The regulations established a clear hierarchy of manual handling measures:</p>
<ol>
<li>Avoid manual handling operations, so far as is reasonably practicable, by re-engineering the task to avoid moving the load or by mechanising the operation.</li>
<li>If manual handling cannot be avoided, a risk assessment should be made.</li>
<li>Reduce the risk of injury, so far as is reasonably practicable, either by the use of mechanical aids or by making improvements to the task (e.g. by using two persons), the load and the environment.</li>
</ol>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251222-1243522a.jpeg" alt="img-51.jpeg">
Stage 1 - Think before lifting</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251222-2d9b41c6.jpeg" alt="img-52.jpeg">
Stage 2 - Stand close to the load
Stage 3 - Bend your knees, not your back
Stage 4 - Grip the load at the base
Stage 5 - Straighten the knees
Stage 6 - Walk carefully
Stage 7 - Bend knees to lower the item</p>
<p>▲ Figure 1.31 Correct manual handling technique</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="how-to-manually-handle-loads-using-mechanical-lifting-aids">How to manually handle loads using mechanical lifting aids<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#how-to-manually-handle-loads-using-mechanical-lifting-aids" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Even if mechanical handling methods are used to handle and transport equipment or materials, hazards may still be present in the four elements that make up the mechanical handling:</p>
<ul>
<li>The handling equipment – mechanical handling equipment must be suitable for the task, well maintained and inspected on a regular basis.</li>
<li>The load – the load needs to be prepared in such a way as to minimise accidents, taking into account such things as security of the load, flammable materials and stability of the load.</li>
<li>The workplace – if possible, the workplace should be designed to keep the workforce and the load apart.</li>
<li>The human element – employees who use the equipment must be properly trained.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="activity">ACTIVITY<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#activity" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>What should you check before moving an object from one place to another by manual handling?</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="industry-tip">INDUSTRY TIP<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#industry-tip" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>When you are manually handling a load, always make sure the route you will be taking is clear and all obstacles are removed. Never try to lift more than you can handle. Use safe handling techniques. Get someone to help you or use mechanical assistance to move the object.</p>
<p>Chapter 1 Health and safety and industry practices</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="6-using-access-equipment-and-working-in-confined-spaces-or-excavations">6 USING ACCESS EQUIPMENT AND WORKING IN CONFINED SPACES OR EXCAVATIONS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#6-using-access-equipment-and-working-in-confined-spaces-or-excavations" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="working-at-height">Working at height<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#working-at-height" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Working at height remains one of the biggest causes of fatalities and major injuries within the construction industry with almost 20% of fatalities resulting from falls from ladders, stepladders and through fragile roofs (figures taken from the HSE website, February 2022). Work at height means work in any place, including at or below ground level (e.g. in underground workings), where a person could fall a distance liable to cause injury.</p>
<p>The Work at Height Regulations 2005 require duty holders to ensure that:</p>
<ul>
<li>all work at height is properly planned and organised</li>
<li>those involved in work at height are competent</li>
<li>the risks from work at height are assessed and appropriate work equipment is selected and used</li>
<li>the risks of working on or near fragile surfaces are properly managed</li>
<li>the equipment used for work at height is properly inspected and maintained.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="access-equipment-for-different-types-of-work-at-height">Access equipment for different types of work at height<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#access-equipment-for-different-types-of-work-at-height" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Many different types of access equipment are used in the building services industry, such as mobile elevating work platforms (MEWPs), ladders, mobile tower scaffolds, tube and fitting scaffolding, and personal suspension equipment (harnesses).</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="mobile-elevating-work-platforms">Mobile elevating work platforms<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#mobile-elevating-work-platforms" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>There is a wide range of MEWPs (vertical scissor lift, self-propelled boom, vehicle-mounted boom and trailer-mounted boom) and if any of these is to be used it is important to consider:</p>
<ul>
<li>the height from the ground</li>
<li>whether the MEWP is appropriate for the job</li>
<li>the ground conditions</li>
<li>training of operators</li>
<li>overhead hazards such as trees, steelwork or overhead cables</li>
<li>the use of a restraint or fall arrest system</li>
<li>closeness to passing traffic.</li>
</ul>
<hr>
