<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="industry-tip">INDUSTRY TIP<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#industry-tip" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<p>Access the Work at Height Regulations 2005 by searching the HSE website.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="health-and-safety">HEALTH AND SAFETY<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#health-and-safety" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<p>MEWPs should not be used during periods of high wind speeds.</p>
<p>45</p>
<p>The City &amp; Guilds Textbook: Electrical Installations Book 1</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251222-9a8ab19c.jpeg" alt="img-53.jpeg">
Figure 1.32 A vertical scissor lift</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251222-1defd719.jpeg" alt="img-54.jpeg">
Figure 1.33 The correct angle for a ladder is 4:1</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="activity">ACTIVITY<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#activity" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>A wooden ladder is found to have a split in it. What action should you take?</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="ladders">Ladders<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#ladders" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>It is recommended that ladders are only used for low-risk, short-duration work (between 15 and 30 minutes depending upon the task). Common causes of falls from ladders are:</p>
<ul>
<li>overreaching – maintain three points of contact with the ladder</li>
<li>slipping from the ladder – keep the rungs clean, wear non-slip footwear, maintain three points of contact with the ladder, make sure the rungs are horizontal</li>
<li>the ladder slips from its position – position the ladder on a firm, level surface, secure the ladder top and bottom, check the ladder daily</li>
<li>the ladder breaks – position the ladder properly using the 1:4 rule (four units up for every one unit out), do not exceed the maximum weight limit of the ladder, only carry light materials or tools.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="stepladders">Stepladders<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#stepladders" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Many of the common causes of falls from ladders can also be applied to stepladders. If stepladders are used, ensure that:</p>
<ul>
<li>they are suitable, in good condition and inspected before use</li>
</ul>
<p>Chapter 1 Health and safety and industry practices</p>
<ul>
<li>they are sited on stable ground</li>
<li>they are faced onto the work activity</li>
<li>knees are never above the top tread of the stepladder</li>
<li>the stepladder is open to the maximum</li>
<li>wooden stepladders (or ladders) are not painted as this may hide defects.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="scaffolding">Scaffolding<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#scaffolding" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Some work activities, such as painting, roof work, window replacement or brickwork, are almost certainly more conveniently undertaken from a fixed external scaffold. Tube and fitting scaffolding must only be erected by competent people who have attended recognised training courses. Any alterations to the scaffolding must also be carried out by a competent person. Regular inspections of the scaffold must be made and recorded.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="safety-checks-and-safe-erection-methods-for-access-equipment">Safety checks and safe erection methods for access equipment<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#safety-checks-and-safe-erection-methods-for-access-equipment" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The Work at Height Regulations 2005 require that all scaffolding and equipment that is used for working at height, where a person could fall two metres or more, is inspected on a regular basis, using both formal and pre-use inspections to ensure that it is fit for use. A marking, coding or tagging system is a good method of indicating when the next formal inspection is due. However, regular pre-use checks must take place as well as formal inspections.</p>
<p>The following safety checks must be carried out.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="safety-checks-for-mewps">Safety checks for MEWPs<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#safety-checks-for-mewps" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>MEWPs must only be operated by trained and competent persons, who must also be competent to carry out the following pre-use checks.</p>
<ul>
<li>The ground conditions must be suitable for the MEWP, with no risk of the MEWP becoming unstable or overturning.</li>
<li>Check for overhead hazards such as trees, steelwork and overhead cables.</li>
<li>Guard rails and toe boards must be in place.</li>
<li>Outriggers should be fully extended and locked in position.</li>
<li>The tyres must be properly inflated and the wheels immobilised.</li>
<li>Check the controls to make sure they work as expected.</li>
<li>Check the fluid and/or battery charge levels.</li>
<li>Check that the descent alarm and horn are working.</li>
<li>Check that the emergency or ground controls are working properly.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="safety-checks-for-ladders-and-stepladders">Safety checks for ladders and stepladders<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#safety-checks-for-ladders-and-stepladders" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Users must check that:</p>
<ul>
<li>ladders and stepladders are of the right classification (e.g. trade or industrial)</li>
<li>the styles, rungs or steps are in good condition</li>
<li>the feet are not missing, loose, damaged or worn</li>
<li>rivets are in place and secure</li>
<li>the locking bars are not bent or buckled.</li>
</ul>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251222-bf9450f0.jpeg" alt="img-55.jpeg">
Figure 1.34 The correct use of a stepladder</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="industry-tip">INDUSTRY TIP<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#industry-tip" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>PASMA requires scaffolding to be checked by a trained person every 7 days.</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251222-002e8511.jpeg" alt="img-56.jpeg"></p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251222-bc65c856.jpeg" alt="img-57.jpeg">
Figure 1.35 Tags to record that a ladder inspection has taken place</p>
<p>The City &amp; Guilds Textbook: Electrical Installations Book 1</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="safety-checks-for-tube-and-fitting-scaffolds">Safety checks for tube and fitting scaffolds<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#safety-checks-for-tube-and-fitting-scaffolds" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Toe boards, guard rails and intermediate rails must be in place to prevent people and materials from falling.</li>
<li>The scaffold must be on a stable surface and the uprights must be fitted with base plates and sole plates.</li>
<li>Safe access and exit ladders must be in place and secured.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="safety-checks-for-prefabricated-mobile-scaffold-towers">Safety checks for prefabricated mobile scaffold towers<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#safety-checks-for-prefabricated-mobile-scaffold-towers" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Mobile scaffold towers are a convenient means of undertaking repetitive tasks in the building services industry. The erection and dismantling must only be undertaken by a competent person.</p>
<p>The following pre-use checks will ensure safe use.</p>
<ul>
<li>The maximum height-to-base ratios must not be exceeded.</li>
<li>Diagonal bracing and stabilisers must not be damaged or bent.</li>
<li>The brace claws must work properly.</li>
<li>Internal access ladders must be in place.</li>
<li>Wheels must be locked when work is in progress.</li>
<li>The working platform must be boarded, with guard rails and toe boards fitted.</li>
<li>The towers must be tied in windy conditions.</li>
<li>The platform trap door must be operating correctly.</li>
<li>Rivets must be checked visually to ensure they are in place and not damaged.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="working-in-excavations-and-confined-spaces">Working in excavations and confined spaces<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#working-in-excavations-and-confined-spaces" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Every year people are killed or seriously injured by collapses and falling materials while working in excavations. These excavations may be required in the course of ground source heating projects or the installation of drains and soakaways, septic tanks, electrical distribution networks and retaining structures.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="how-to-prepare-excavations-for-safe-working">How to prepare excavations for safe working<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#how-to-prepare-excavations-for-safe-working" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The hazards associated with excavations are:</p>
<ul>
<li>excavations collapsing and burying or injuring people working in them</li>
<li>material falling from the sides into any excavation</li>
<li>people or plant falling into excavations</li>
<li>contact with underground services (e.g. electricity, high-pressure water and gas)</li>
<li>undermining other structures</li>
<li>exhaust fumes from petrol or diesel-engine equipment such as compressors or generators.</li>
</ul>
<p>Planning is the key to the safety of any excavation. Before work commences a decision will be required on what temporary support will be needed and what precautions need to be taken. The equipment and precautions needed (trench sheets, props, baulks, etc.) should be available on site before work starts.</p>
<p>Chapter 1 Health and safety and industry practices</p>
<p>The sides of the excavation must be prevented from collapsing either by battering at an angle of between 5° and 45° or by shoring (supporting) the sides up with timber, sheeting or a proprietary support system. In granular soils, the angle of slope (batter) should be less than the natural angle of repose of the material being excavated. In wet ground, a considerably flatter slope will be required. Loose materials may fall from spoil heaps into the excavation, therefore edge protection should include toe boards or other means to protect against falling materials. Head protection should be worn in excavations.</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251222-a70a7900.jpeg" alt="img-58.jpeg">
Figure 1.36 Excavation showing support for services and safety guards</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="making-excavations-safe">Making excavations safe<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#making-excavations-safe" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>To prevent people from falling into an excavation, the edges should be protected in one of the following ways:</p>
<ul>
<li>with guard rails and toe boards inserted into the ground immediately next to the supported excavation side</li>
<li>by a fabricated guard rail assembly that connects to the sides of the trench box</li>
<li>by using the trench support system itself (e.g. using trench box extensions or trench sheets longer than the trench depth).</li>
</ul>
<p>A competent person who fully understands the dangers and necessary precautions should inspect the excavation at the start of each shift and after any event that may have affected its strength or stability, or after a fall of rock or soil.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="health-and-safety">HEALTH AND SAFETY<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#health-and-safety" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Gas can accumulate in underground workings. Always beware of this and test the atmosphere in the underground workings first.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="key-terms">KEY TERMS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#key-terms" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Granular soils: gravel, sand or silt (coarse-grained soil) with little or no clay content. Although some moist granular soils exhibit apparent cohesion (grains sticking together forming a solid), they have no cohesive strength. Granular soil cannot be moulded when moist and crumbles easily when dry.</p>
<p>Batter: the slope angle of the trench walls of an excavation, in relation to the horizontal surface, to prevent the walls collapsing.</p>
<p>Repose: the angle to the horizontal at which the material in the cut face is stable and does not fall away. Different materials have different angles of repose – for example, 90° for solid rock and 30° for sand.</p>
<p>The City &amp; Guilds Textbook: Electrical Installations Book 1</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="health-and-safety">HEALTH AND SAFETY<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#health-and-safety" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Never take a chance with an excavation. It only takes a second for an unsafe working area to collapse and suffocate you.</p>
<p>A record of the inspections will be required and any faults that are found should be corrected immediately.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="working-in-a-confined-space">Working in a confined space<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#working-in-a-confined-space" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>A confined space is a place which is substantially enclosed (though not always entirely) and where serious injury can occur from hazardous substances or conditions within the space or nearby (e.g. lack of oxygen). Examples include chambers, tanks, vessels, furnaces, boilers or cisterns, inspection chambers, pits, roof spaces and under suspended timber floors. Entry into a confined space requires the correct equipment, including PPE and a harness. Activities below ground require a descent control and rescue system.</p>
<p>The two main hazards associated with confined spaces are the presence of toxic or other dangerous substances and the absence of adequate oxygen.</p>
<p>The Confined Space Regulations 1997 detail the specific controls that are necessary when people enter confined spaces. These can be summarised as follows.</p>
<ul>
<li>Avoid entry to confined spaces (e.g. by doing the work from the outside).</li>
<li>If entry to a confined space is unavoidable, follow a safe system of work which should include rigorous preparation, isolation, air testing and other precautions, and the use of a confined space entry permit.</li>
<li>Put in place adequate emergency arrangements before the work starts.</li>
</ul>
<p>Adequate ventilation, sufficient lighting, the provision of the correct PPE, emergency evacuation procedures and medical conditions must all be catered for. Lone working should not be allowed. Section 706 of BS 7671 The IET Wiring Regulations, 18th Edition gives the requirements for supplies to portable electrical equipment used in confined spaces that are restrictive and/or conducting.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="7-electrical-safety-on-site">7 ELECTRICAL SAFETY ON SITE<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#7-electrical-safety-on-site" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Modern living is shaped by electricity. It is a safe, clean and immensely powerful source of energy and is in use in every factory, office, workshop and home in the country. However, this energy source also has the potential to be very hazardous, with a possibility of death, if it is not handled with care. The Electricity at Work Regulations 1989 were made under the Health and Safety at Work etc. Act 1974 (HSW Act) and came into force on 1 April 1990.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="common-electrical-dangers-on-site">Common electrical dangers on site<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#common-electrical-dangers-on-site" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The 1989 Regulations are goal-setting in that they specify the objectives concerning the design, specification and construction of, and work activities on, electrical systems, in order to prevent injury caused by electricity. They do not specify the means for achieving these objectives. The 1989 Regulations are supported by a Memorandum of Guidance, HSR25 (2nd edition 2007).</p>
<p>Electrical injuries can be caused by a wide range of voltages, and are dependent upon individual circumstances, but the risk of injury is generally greater with</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="industry-tip">INDUSTRY TIP<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#industry-tip" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Access the Electricity at Work Regulations 1989 by searching the GOV.UK website.</p>
<p>Guidance on following these regulations is contained in HSE document HSR25.</p>
<p>Chapter 1 Health and safety and industry practices</p>
<p>higher voltages. Alternating current (AC) and direct current (DC) electrical supplies can cause a range of injuries including:</p>
<ul>
<li>electric shock</li>
<li>electrical burns</li>
<li>loss of muscle control</li>
<li>fires arising from electrical causes</li>
<li>arcing and explosion.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="electric-shock">Electric shock<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#electric-shock" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Electric shocks may arise either by direct contact with a live part or indirectly by contact with an exposed conductive part (e.g. a metal equipment case) that has become live as a result of a fault condition.</p>
<p>Faults can arise from a variety of sources:</p>
<ul>
<li>broken equipment case exposing internal bare live connections</li>
<li>cracked equipment case causing 'tracking' from internal live parts to the external surface</li>
<li>damaged supply cord insulation, exposing bare live conductors</li>
<li>broken plug, exposing bare live connections.</li>
</ul>
<p>The magnitude (size) and duration of the shock current are the two most significant factors determining the severity of an electric shock. The magnitude of the shock current will depend on the contact voltage and impedance (electrical resistance) of the shock path. A possible shock path always exists through ground contact (e.g. hand-to-feet). In this case:</p>
<p>shock path impedance = body impedance + any external impedance</p>
<p>A more dangerous situation is a hand-to-hand shock path, where the current flow is through the heart. This is when one hand is in contact with an exposed conductive part (e.g. an earthed metal equipment case), while the other simultaneously touches a live part. In this case the current will be limited only by the body impedance.</p>
<p>As the voltage increases, so the body impedance decreases, which increases the shock current. When the voltage decreases, the body impedance increases, which reduces the shock current. This has important implications concerning the voltage levels that are used in work situations and highlights the advantage of working with reduced low-voltage (110 V) systems or battery-operated hand tools.</p>
<p>At 230 V, the average person has a body impedance of approximately 1300 Ω. At mains voltage and frequency (230 V–50 Hz), currents as low as 50 milliamps (0.05 A) can prove fatal, particularly if flowing through the body for a few seconds.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="electrical-burn">Electrical burn<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#electrical-burn" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Burns may arise due to:</p>
<ul>
<li>the passage of shock current through the body, particularly if at high voltage</li>
<li>exposure to high-frequency radiation (e.g. from radio transmission antennas).</li>
</ul>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251222-6891d0fe.jpeg" alt="img-59.jpeg">
Figure 1.37 Approach someone who appears to be electrocuted with caution: they may still be holding a live part, putting you at risk</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="key-term">KEY TERM<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#key-term" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Impedance: measure of the opposition presented to an alternating current when a voltage is applied.</p>
<p>The City &amp; Guilds Textbook: Electrical Installations Book 1</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="loss-of-muscle-control">Loss of muscle control<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#loss-of-muscle-control" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>People who experience an electric shock often get painful muscle spasms that can be strong enough to break bones or dislocate joints. This loss of muscle control often means the person cannot 'let go' or escape the electric shock. The person may fall if they are working at height or be thrown into nearby machinery and structures.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="fire">Fire<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#fire" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Electricity is believed to be a factor in the cause of many fires in domestic and commercial premises in Britain each year. One of the principal causes of such fires is wiring with defects such as insulation failure, the overloading of conductors, lack of electrical protection, or poor connections.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="arcing">Arcing<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#arcing" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Arcing frequently occurs due to a short circuit (conductive bridge between live parts) caused while working on live equipment (either intentionally or unintentionally). Arcing generates UV radiation, causing severe sunburn. Molten metal particles are also likely to be deposited on exposed skin surfaces.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="explosion">Explosion<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#explosion" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>There are two main electrical causes of explosion:</p>
<ul>
<li>short circuit due to an equipment fault</li>
<li>ignition of flammable vapours or liquids caused by sparks or high surface temperatures.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="controlling-current-flow">Controlling current flow<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#controlling-current-flow" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>It is necessary to include devices in circuits to control current flow – that is, to switch the current on or off by making or breaking the circuit. This may be required:</p>
<ul>
<li>for functional purposes (to switch equipment on or off)</li>
<li>for use in an emergency (switching off in the event of an accident)</li>
<li>so that equipment can be switched off to prevent its use and allow maintenance work to be done safely on the mechanical parts</li>
<li>to isolate a circuit, installation or piece of equipment to prevent the risk of shock where exposure to electrical parts and connections is likely for maintenance purposes.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="key-terms">KEY TERMS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#key-terms" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p><strong>Switching</strong>: cutting off the supply of electricity, stopping equipment functioning.</p>
<p><strong>Isolation</strong>: disconnecting and separating from all sources of electrical energy.</p>
<p>The preparation of electrical equipment for maintenance purposes requires effective disconnection from all live supplies and the means for securing that disconnection (by locking off).</p>
<p>There is an important distinction between switching and isolation. <strong>Switching</strong> is cutting off the supply. <strong>Isolation</strong> is the secure disconnection and separation from all sources of electrical energy. A variety of control devices are available for switching, isolation or a combination of these functions, some incorporating protective devices. Before starting work on a piece of isolated equipment, checks</p>
<p>Chapter 1 Health and safety and industry practices</p>
<p>should be made to ensure that the circuit is dead, using an approved testing device.</p>
<p>In the case of portable equipment connected via a supply cord and plug, removal of the plug from the socket provides a ready means of isolation.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="electrical-supply-for-tools-and-equipment">Electrical supply for tools and equipment<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#electrical-supply-for-tools-and-equipment" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Portable electric tools can provide valuable assistance with much of the physical effort required in electrotechnical activities. These tools can use different sources of electrical supply (mains or battery) and different means of maintaining safety in relation to that electrical supply.</p>
<p>Basic equipment construction is aimed at preventing the risk of electric shock. The Construction of Electrical Equipment for Protection against Electric Shock is summarised below.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="class-i">Class I<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#class-i" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The basic insulation may be an air gap and/or some form of insulating material. External conductive parts (e.g. the metal case) must be earthed by providing the supply through a three-core supply lead incorporating a protective conductor. The most important aspect of any periodic inspection or testing of Class I equipment is to check the integrity of this protective conductor. There is no recognised symbol for Class I equipment, though some appliances may show the symbol in Figure 1.38.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="class-ii">Class II<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#class-ii" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Class II equipment has either no external conductive parts apart from fixing screws (insulation-encased equipment) or there is adequate insulation between any external conductive parts and the internal live parts to prevent the former becoming live as a result of an internal fault (metal-encased equipment). Periodic inspection or testing needs to focus on the integrity of the insulation. Class II equipment is identified by the symbol shown in Figure 1.39.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="class-iii">Class III<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#class-iii" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>This method of protection is not designed to prevent shock but to reduce its severity and therefore make the shock more survivable. The supply (no greater than 50 V AC) must be provided from a separated extra-low-voltage (SELV) source such as a safety isolating transformer conforming to BS EN 61558, or a battery. Class III equipment is identified by the diamond symbol and the safety isolating symbol by two interlinked circles, as shown in Figure 1.40.</p>
<p>Another way of reducing the risk of electric shock is by using a reduced low-voltage system. This is not a Class III system but is a safer arrangement than using mains-operated (230 V) equipment because of the lower potential shock voltage. Supply is provided via a mains powered (230 V) step-down transformer with the centre point of the secondary winding connected to earth.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="activity">ACTIVITY<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#activity" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Discuss why light switches are unsuitable as devices for isolation.</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251222-428aa1a5.jpeg" alt="img-60.jpeg">
Figure 1.38 This symbol may appear on Class I earthed items</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251222-2edfc5bd.jpeg" alt="img-61.jpeg">
Figure 1.39 This symbol may appear on Class II items</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251222-f034f4ca.jpeg" alt="img-62.jpeg">
Figure 1.40 This symbol may appear on Class III items</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251222-3ac8745b.jpeg" alt="img-63.jpeg"></p>
<p>The City &amp; Guilds Textbook: Electrical Installations Book 1</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="low-voltage-electrical-supplies-for-tools-and-equipment">Low-voltage electrical supplies for tools and equipment<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#low-voltage-electrical-supplies-for-tools-and-equipment" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>The human body's impedance increases with lower touch voltages, particularly below 50 V. Although 50 V can be dangerous in certain circumstances, if the system voltage can be reduced to around this level, then the magnitude (size) of any current flow through the body will be significantly reduced.</p>
<p>The most common low-voltage system of this type in use in the UK uses a 230/110 V double-wound step-down transformer with the secondary winding centre-tapped and connected to earth (CTE). While the supply voltage for equipment supplied from such a transformer is 110 V, the maximum voltage to earth is 55 V (63.5 V for a 110 V three-phase system). This is covered in BS 7671 The IET Wiring Regulations, 18th Edition (Regulation 411.8 Reduced low-voltage systems). Overcurrent protection for the 110 V supply may be provided by fuses at the transformer's 110 V output terminals or by a thermal trip to detect excessive temperature rise in the secondary winding. The latter method is generally employed for portable units. Such reduced voltage supplies may be provided:</p>
<ul>
<li>through fixed installations (workshops, plant rooms, lift rooms or other areas where portable electrical equipment is in frequent use)</li>
<li>through small portable transformers designed to supply individual portable tools. (See BS 4363: 1998 and BS 7375: 1996, which give a specification for the distribution of electricity on building and construction sites, based on the use of 230/110 V CTE transformers.)</li>
</ul>
<p>One additional advantage of using a reduced low-voltage system is that this safeguard applies to all parts of the system on the load side of the transformer, including the flexible leads, as well as the tools, hand lamps, and so on.</p>
<p>Alternatively, cordless or battery-powered tools offer a convenient way of providing a powered hand tool without the inconvenience of using a mains supply and without the hazard of trailing power leads.</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251222-35fe9d2d.jpeg" alt="img-64.jpeg">
Figure 1.41 Portable CTE transformer and drill</p>
<p>Chapter 1 Health and safety and industry practices</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251222-8aafe5ad.jpeg" alt="img-65.jpeg">
Figure 1.42 Schematic diagram for a 110/55 V transformer</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="how-to-conduct-a-visual-inspection-of-portable-electrical-equipment">How to conduct a visual inspection of portable electrical equipment<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#how-to-conduct-a-visual-inspection-of-portable-electrical-equipment" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>To maintain the safety and integrity of tools and equipment, regular in-service inspection and testing should be undertaken to confirm that the equipment remains in a safe condition. Portable appliance testing (PAT) is the term used to describe the examination of electrical appliances and equipment to ensure they are safe to use. There are three categories of in-service inspection or testing for portable tools and equipment:</p>
<ul>
<li>user checks (pre-use inspections) – users play an important role by checking equipment before use for signs of damage or obvious defects liable to affect safety in use</li>
<li>periodic formal inspection or checks</li>
<li>periodic combined inspection and testing.</li>
</ul>
<p>The user checks are a visual check only. They should deal with the following inspection requirements separately for the equipment, supply lead and plug.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="visual-inspection-of-equipment">Visual inspection of equipment:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#visual-inspection-of-equipment" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>Equipment should be manufactured to relevant standards (BS or BS EN).</li>
<li>The casing should have no visible damage and be free from dents and cracks.</li>
<li>The switches should operate correctly.</li>
<li>The supply lead should be secure and correctly connected.</li>
<li>Equipment should be suitable for the task.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="visual-inspection-of-supply-leads">Visual inspection of supply leads:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#visual-inspection-of-supply-leads" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>Supply leads should be manufactured to relevant standards (BS or BS EN).</li>
<li>They should be suitable for the environment.</li>
<li>They should be free from cuts or fraying.</li>
<li>There should be no visible exposed conductor insulation (damaged sheath) or exposed live conductors.</li>
<li>There should be no signs of damage to the cord sheath.</li>
<li>There should be no joints evident.</li>
</ul>
<p>The City &amp; Guilds Textbook: Electrical Installations Book 1</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251222-e0408880.jpeg" alt="img-66.jpeg">
Figure 1.43 A correctly wired 13 A plug</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="visual-inspection-of-supply-lead-plugs">Visual inspection of supply lead plugs:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#visual-inspection-of-supply-lead-plugs" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Supply lead plugs should be manufactured to relevant standards (BS or BS EN).</li>
<li>The insulation should have no damage.</li>
<li>The cord or cable connections should be correct and secure.</li>
</ul>
<p>The user checks must be backed up by periodic inspection and, where appropriate, testing. At that time, a thorough examination is undertaken by a nominated person, competent for that purpose. Schedules giving details of inspection and maintenance periods, together with records of the inspection, should form part of the procedure.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="what-to-do-when-portable-electrical-equipment-fails-visual-inspection">What to do when portable electrical equipment fails visual inspection<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#what-to-do-when-portable-electrical-equipment-fails-visual-inspection" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Most electrical safety defects can be found by visual examination, but some types of defect, such as a broken earth conductor, can only be found by testing. However, it is essential to understand that visual examination is an essential part of the process because some types of electrical safety defect cannot be detected by testing alone.</p>
<p>A relatively brief user check, based upon simple training and the use of a brief checklist, is a very useful part of any electrical maintenance regime. If the user checks detailed above are carried out, 95% of all faults will be identified and the appropriate action taken. No record is needed if there are no defects found. However, if equipment is found to be unsafe, it must be removed from service immediately. It must be labelled to show that it must not be used and the fault must be reported to a responsible person.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="safe-isolation">SAFE ISOLATION<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#safe-isolation" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Isolation can be very complex due to the differing industrial, commercial and domestic working environments, some of which require experience and knowledge of the system processes. This section deals with a basic practical procedure for isolation and for the securing of isolation. It also looks at the reasons for safe isolation and the potential risks involved during the isolation process.</p>
<p>Safe operating procedures for the isolation of plant and machinery during both electrical and mechanical maintenance must be prepared and followed. Wherever possible, electrical isolators should be fitted with a means by which the isolating mechanism can be locked in the open/off position. If this is not possible, an agreed procedure must be followed for the removal and storage of fuse links. Regulation 12 of the Electricity at Work Regulations 1989 requires that, where necessary to prevent danger, suitable means (including, where appropriate, methods of identifying circuits) must be available for:</p>
<ul>
<li>cutting off the supply of electrical energy to any electrical equipment</li>
<li>the isolation of any electrical equipment.</li>
</ul>
<p>Chapter 1 Health and safety and industry practices</p>
<p>The aim of Regulation 12 is to ensure that work can be undertaken on an electrical system without danger, in compliance with Regulation 13 (work when equipment has been made dead).</p>
<p>Terms used in Regulation 12 are defined below.</p>
<ul>
<li>Cutting off the supply – Depending on the equipment and the circumstances, this may be no more than normal functional switching (on/off) or emergency switching by means of a stop button or a trip switch.</li>
<li>Isolation – The disconnection and separation of the electrical equipment from every source of electrical energy in such a way that this disconnection and separation is secure.</li>
<li>From every source of electrical energy – Many accidents occur due to a failure to isolate all sources of supply to or within equipment (e.g. control and auxiliary supplies, uninterruptable power supply (UPS) systems or parallel circuit arrangements giving rise to back feeds).</li>
<li>Secure – Keeping safe; achieved by locking off with a safety lock (i.e. a lock with a unique key). The posting of a warning notice also serves to alert others to the isolation.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="industry-tip">INDUSTRY TIP<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#industry-tip" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Access Regulations 12 and 13 of the Electricity at Work Regulations 1989 by searching the GOV.UK website.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="how-to-undertake-a-basic-practical-procedure-for-isolation">How to undertake a basic practical procedure for isolation<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#how-to-undertake-a-basic-practical-procedure-for-isolation" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Being able to perform safe isolation is a key skill every electrician needs. Be sure to do this under supervision by a skilled person such as your tutor.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="gather-together-equipment">Gather together equipment<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#gather-together-equipment" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>You will need the following equipment for this task:</p>
<ul>
<li>a voltage indicator which has been manufactured and maintained in accordance with Health and Safety Executive (HSE) Guidance Note GS38</li>
<li>a proving unit compatible with the voltage indicator</li>
<li>a lock and/or multi-lock system (there are many types of lock available)</li>
<li>warning notices which identify the work being carried out</li>
<li>relevant personal protective equipment (PPE) that adheres to all site PPE rules.</li>
</ul>
<p>The equipment shown in Figure 1.44 can be used to isolate various main switches and isolators. To isolate individual circuit breakers with suitable locks and locking aids, you should consult the manufacturer's guidance.</p>
<p>When working on or near electrical equipment and circuits, it is important to ensure that:</p>
<ul>
<li>the correct point of isolation is identified</li>
<li>an appropriate means of isolation is used</li>
<li>the supply cannot inadvertently be reinstated while the work is in progress</li>
<li>caution notices are applied at the point(s) of isolation</li>
<li>conductors are proved to be dead at the point of work before they are touched</li>
<li>safety barriers are erected as appropriate when working in an area that is open to other people.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="activity">ACTIVITY<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#activity" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Check your approved voltage indicator for any damage and for compliance with GS38.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="health-and-safety">HEALTH AND SAFETY<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#health-and-safety" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>When more than one person is working on an isolated circuit, a multi-locking system is used so that the circuit cannot be energised until all locks are removed.</p>
<p>The City &amp; Guilds Textbook: Electrical Installations Book 1</p>

<p>Chapter 1 Health and safety and industry practices</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="carry-out-the-practical-isolation">Carry out the practical isolation<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#carry-out-the-practical-isolation" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>The method of isolation is outlined below.</p>
<ol>
<li>Identify – identify equipment or circuit to be worked on and point(s) of isolation.</li>
<li>Isolate – switch off, isolate and lock off (secure) equipment or circuit in an appropriate manner. Retain the key and post caution signs with details of work being carried out.</li>
<li>Check – check the condition of the voltage indicator leads and probes. Confirm that the voltage indicator is functioning correctly by using a proving unit.</li>
<li>Test – using the voltage indicator, test the outgoing terminals of the isolation switch. Take precautions against adjacent live parts where necessary.</li>
</ol>
<p>During single-phase isolation, there are three tests to be carried out (L = line, N = neutral, E = earth):</p>
<p>L – N    L – E    N – E</p>
<p>During three-phase isolation, there are 10 possible tests (if the neutral is present):</p>
<p>L1 – N    L2 – N    L3 – N
L1 – E    L2 – E    L3 – E
L1 – L2    L1 – L3    L2 – L3
N – E</p>
<ol start="5">
<li>Prove – using the voltage indicator and proving unit, prove that the voltage indicator is still functioning correctly.</li>
<li>Confirm – confirm that the isolation is secure and the correct equipment has been isolated. This can be achieved by operating functional switching for the isolated circuit(s). The relevant inspection and testing can now be carried out.</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="reinstate-the-supply">Reinstate the supply<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#reinstate-the-supply" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>When the 'dead' electrical work is completed, you must ensure that all electrical barriers and enclosures are in place and that it is safe to switch on the isolated circuit.</p>
<ol>
<li>Remove the locking device and danger/warning signs.</li>
<li>Reinstate the supply.</li>
<li>Carry out system checks to ensure that the equipment is working correctly.</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="implications-of-safe-isolation">Implications of safe isolation<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#implications-of-safe-isolation" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>When you isolate an electricity supply, there will be disruption. So, careful planning should precede isolation of circuits. For example, when isolating a section of a nursing home where elderly residents live, you will need to consult the nursing home staff, to consider all the possible consequences of isolation and to prepare a procedure.</p>
<p>The following questions are useful:</p>
<ol>
<li>How will the isolation affect the staff and other personnel? For example, think about loss of power to lifts, heating and other essential systems.</li>
<li>How could the isolation affect the residents and clients? For example, some residents may rely on oxygen, medical drips and ripple beds to aid circulation.</li>
</ol>
<hr>
<p><strong>ACTIVITY</strong>
Discuss why the N or E probe is connected before the line when carrying out this test.</p>
<p>The City &amp; Guilds Textbook: Electrical Installations Book 1</p>
<p>These critical systems usually have battery back-up facilities for short durations.</p>
<p>3 How could the isolation affect the members of the public? For example, fire alarms, nurse call systems, emergency lighting and other systems may stop working.</p>
<p>4 How can an isolation affect systems? For example, IT programs and data systems could be affected; timing devices could be disrupted. In this scenario, you must make the employers, employees, clients, residents and members of the public aware of the planned isolation.</p>
<p>Alternative electrical back-up supplies may be required in the form of generators or uninterruptable power supply systems.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="risks-involved-in-isolation-procedures">Risks involved in isolation procedures<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#risks-involved-in-isolation-procedures" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Before any isolation is carried out, you must assess the risks involved. This section deals with the practical implications and the risks involved during the isolation procedure, if risk assessment and method statements are not followed.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="who-is-at-risk-and-why">Who is at risk and why?<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#who-is-at-risk-and-why" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>If isolation is not carried out safely, what are the possible risks when performing inspection and testing tasks?</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="risks-to-you">Risks to you<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#risks-to-you" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Risks to you might include:</p>
<ul>
<li>shock – touching a line conductor (e.g. if isolation is not secure)</li>
<li>burns – resulting from touching a line conductor and earth, or arcing</li>
<li>arcing – due to a short circuit between live conductors, or an earth fault between a line conductor and earth</li>
<li>explosion – arcing in certain environmental conditions (e.g. in the presence of airborne dust particles or gases) may cause an explosion.</li>
</ul>
<p>Things that can cause risk to you include:</p>
<ul>
<li>inadequate information to enable safe or effective inspection and testing (i.e. lack of diagrams, legends or charts)</li>
<li>poor knowledge of the system you are working on (and so not meeting the competence requirements of Regulation 16 of EAWR)</li>
<li>insufficient risk assessment</li>
<li>inadequate test instruments (not manufactured or maintained to the standards of GS38).</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="risks-to-other-tradespersons-customers-and-clients">Risks to other tradespersons, customers and clients<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#risks-to-other-tradespersons-customers-and-clients" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Risks to other tradespersons, customers and clients might include:</p>
<ul>
<li>switching off electrical circuits – for example, switching off a heating system might cause hypothermia (resulting from being too cold); if lifts stop, people may be trapped</li>
</ul>
<p>Chapter 1 Health and safety and industry practices</p>
<ul>
<li>applying potentially dangerous test voltages and currents</li>
<li>access to open distribution boards and consumer units</li>
<li>loss of production, service or equipment – for example, essential supplies, or lights for access.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="risks-to-members-of-the-public">Risks to members of the public<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#risks-to-members-of-the-public" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Risks to members of the public might include prolonged loss of essential power supply, causing problems, for example, with safety and evacuation systems, such as fire alarms and emergency exit and corridor lighting.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="risks-to-buildings-and-systems-within-buildings">Risks to buildings and systems within buildings<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#risks-to-buildings-and-systems-within-buildings" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Risks to buildings and systems within buildings might involve applying excessive voltages to sensitive electronic equipment, for example:</p>
<ul>
<li>computers and associated IT equipment</li>
<li>residual current devices (RCDs) and residual current operated circuit breakers with integral overcurrent protection (RCBOs)</li>
<li>heating controls</li>
<li>surge protection devices.</li>
</ul>
<p>There might also be risk of loss of data and communications systems.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="activity">ACTIVITY<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#activity" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Write down a list of the risks associated with isolation and the effects isolation can have on people, livestock, systems and buildings. You could think about:</p>
<ul>
<li>Who is at risk if inspection and testing is not carried out correctly?</li>
<li>What might happen if you need to switch off a socket-outlet circuit – for example, in a hospital?</li>
<li>What must you do if you encounter a computer server that requires a permanent supply and you need to switch off the main supply to enable safe testing procedures?</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="health-and-safety">HEALTH AND SAFETY<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#health-and-safety" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Although safety services usually have back-up supplies such as batteries, these may only last for a few hours. Other safety or standby systems may have generator back-up, but this will also require isolation, leaving the building without any safety systems.</p>
<p>61</p>

<p>SCIENTIFIC AND MATHEMATICAL PRINCIPLES OF ELECTRICAL INSTALLATION</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="introduction">INTRODUCTION<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#introduction" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Working with electricity safely and effectively involves a good understanding of maths. Using formulae and understanding mathematical principles are important throughout, from designing circuits to inspection and testing.</p>
