<p>Chapter 2 Scientific and mathematical principles of electrical installation</p>
<p>Then:</p>
<div class="math math-display"><span class="katex-display"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" display="block"><semantics><mrow><mfrac><mn>560</mn><mn>20</mn></mfrac><mo>=</mo><mfrac><mn>4</mn><msub><mi>I</mi><mn>1</mn></msub></mfrac></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\frac {560}{20} = \frac {4}{I _ {1}}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 2.0074em; vertical-align: -0.686em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mopen nulldelimiter"></span><span class="mfrac"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 1.3214em;"><span style="top: -2.314em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 3em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord">20</span></span></span><span style="top: -3.23em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 3em;"></span><span class="frac-line" style="border-bottom-width: 0.04em;"></span></span><span style="top: -3.677em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 3em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord">560</span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.686em;"><span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mclose nulldelimiter"></span></span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span><span class="mrel">=</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 2.1574em; vertical-align: -0.836em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mopen nulldelimiter"></span><span class="mfrac"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 1.3214em;"><span style="top: -2.314em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 3em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.07847em;">I</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.3011em;"><span style="top: -2.55em; margin-left: -0.0785em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">1</span></span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.15em;"><span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span><span style="top: -3.23em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 3em;"></span><span class="frac-line" style="border-bottom-width: 0.04em;"></span></span><span style="top: -3.677em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 3em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord">4</span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.836em;"><span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mclose nulldelimiter"></span></span></span></span></span></span></div>
<p>So:</p>
<div class="math math-display"><span class="katex-display"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" display="block"><semantics><mrow><msub><mi>I</mi><mn>1</mn></msub><mo>=</mo><mfrac><mrow><mn>4</mn><mo>×</mo><mn>20</mn></mrow><mn>560</mn></mfrac><mo>=</mo><mn>0.14</mn><mtext>&nbsp;A</mtext></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">I _ {1} = \frac {4 \times 20}{560} = 0.14 \text{ A}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8333em; vertical-align: -0.15em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.07847em;">I</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.3011em;"><span style="top: -2.55em; margin-left: -0.0785em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">1</span></span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.15em;"><span></span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span><span class="mrel">=</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 2.0074em; vertical-align: -0.686em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mopen nulldelimiter"></span><span class="mfrac"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 1.3214em;"><span style="top: -2.314em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 3em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord">560</span></span></span><span style="top: -3.23em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 3em;"></span><span class="frac-line" style="border-bottom-width: 0.04em;"></span></span><span style="top: -3.677em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 3em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord">4</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span><span class="mbin">×</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span><span class="mord">20</span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.686em;"><span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mclose nulldelimiter"></span></span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span><span class="mrel">=</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6833em;"></span><span class="mord">0.14</span><span class="mord text"><span class="mord">&nbsp;A</span></span></span></span></span></span></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="transformer-power-ratings">Transformer power ratings<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#transformer-power-ratings" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>As a transformer is not a load, simply a method of changing voltage and current, it is rated in kVA. This is because certain loads may include a power factor, which can increase the current demand by the load. As a result, the rating of the transformer is given in volt amperes (VA) instead of kilowatts (kW). So when selecting a transformer for a particular load, the actual current drawn by the load must be multiplied by the voltage.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="6-electronic-components-used-in-electrotechnical-systems-and-equipment">6 ELECTRONIC COMPONENTS USED IN ELECTROTECHNICAL SYSTEMS AND EQUIPMENT<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#6-electronic-components-used-in-electrotechnical-systems-and-equipment" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="the-function-of-electronic-components-in-electrical-systems">The function of electronic components in electrical systems<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#the-function-of-electronic-components-in-electrical-systems" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Most electronic systems use many different electrical components in their power supply and in their operational systems.</p>
<p>Security alarm systems use full-wave rectification and smoothing through capacitors to supply a 12 V operating system. In addition, the closed-loop system uses transistor and similar technology to convert low-level signals from components such as passive infrared (PIR) detectors into an alarm output signal to components that operate the alarm.</p>
<p>Thyristors or SCRs are used extensively in motor speed control, circuits for heating and other applications, where motors and pumps require variable output. The ability to control an output waveform is essential in controlling the motor speed.</p>
<p>Heating control systems use a number of components. The most important element of any form of heating control is probably the ability to sense temperature in the airspace or water systems that are being heated.</p>
<p>A thermistor is used to determine accurately the temperature of the space or heating medium. The heating control system then uses feedback from the sensor to determine how much heat needs to be passed. The temperature is controlled via valves and/or variable speed pumps.</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251222-1f8ac84f.jpeg" alt="img-151.jpeg"></p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251222-e33c94ba.jpeg" alt="img-152.jpeg"></p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251222-3df6c5d1.jpeg" alt="img-153.jpeg">
Figure 2.69 A range of different alarm detection devices using different technologies</p>
<p>The City &amp; Guilds Textbook: Electrical Installations Book 1</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251222-0096dc3d.jpeg" alt="img-154.jpeg">
Figure 2.70 Typical thermistor-based space temperature detector</p>
<p>Diacs and triacs are used in lighting control circuits. The ability to trigger the device through a separate voltage allows dimming to be provided via proprietary dimming systems (Figure 2.71).</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251222-5d5cfee1.jpeg" alt="img-155.jpeg">
Figure 2.71 Typical diac and triac controlled dimming arrangement</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="industry-tip">INDUSTRY TIP<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#industry-tip" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Always take care when handling or replacing electronic components or circuit boards as many can be damaged by static electricity. It is always important to ensure that static risks are minimised by earthing yourself to the equipment before handling components.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="activity">ACTIVITY<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#activity" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>How could a capacitor, zener diode and resistor be used to smooth the output of a full-wave bridge rectifier?</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="how-electronic-components-work">How electronic components work<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#how-electronic-components-work" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>In today's world of micro-components, it is becoming increasingly common to replace a whole circuit board rather than replacing single components. Nevertheless, it is far easier to diagnose faults in electrical systems if you understand how particular electronic components function.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="diodes">Diodes<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#diodes" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>A diode is a silicon P-N junction, which allows current flow in one direction, but not the other. When current flows through a diode, it is called 'forward bias'. When current is restricted, it is called 'reverse bias'. There are several types of diode, from the simple one just described used for rectification or signalling, to:</p>
<ul>
<li>a zener diode, which only allows current flow when a set voltage is reached</li>
<li>a light-emitting diode (LED), which emits light when current flows through it</li>
<li>a photo diode, which allows forward bias current flow when it detects light.</li>
</ul>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251222-dcad05b0.jpeg" alt="img-156.jpeg">
Figure 2.72 Symbols for different types of diode</p>
<p>Chapter 2 Scientific and mathematical principles of electrical installation</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="diacs">Diacs<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#diacs" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>A diac is a junction of two zener diodes, with two terminals. It works on AC circuits, hence the name diode for AC. A diac will not allow current flow unless a pre-set voltage is reached. Once this voltage is reached, current can flow in both directions. Current will continue to flow until the voltage falls below the level set, at which point the diac restricts current flow.</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251222-8bea17c7.jpeg" alt="img-157.jpeg">
Figure 2.73 Symbol for a diac</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="thyristors">Thyristors<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#thyristors" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>A thyristor is a solid-state switch that allows current flow between two of its terminals if a small current is sensed on the third. There are two types: silicon-controlled rectifiers (SCR) and triacs.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="scrs">SCRs<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#scrs" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>The SCR is similar to the diode, in that current can only flow between the anode and cathode in one direction. However, it also has a gate terminal, which activates the switch when a small current is sensed on that terminal. Essentially, it allows a large current to be controlled by a small current. The SCR will continue to allow current flow between anode and cathode until the gate current is stopped. It does not require a constant gate terminal current, except when allowing the main current to pass.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="triacs">Triacs<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#triacs" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>A triac has three terminals, one called the gate. If the gate senses a very small control current, AC is allowed to flow between the other two main terminals (known as  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msub><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">M</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">T</mi></mrow><mn>1</mn></msub></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\mathrm{MT}_1</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8333em; vertical-align: -0.15em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">MT</span></span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.3011em;"><span style="top: -2.55em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight">1</span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.15em;"><span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span>  and  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msub><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">M</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">T</mi></mrow><mn>2</mn></msub></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\mathrm{MT}_2</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8333em; vertical-align: -0.15em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">MT</span></span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.3011em;"><span style="top: -2.55em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight">2</span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.15em;"><span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span> ). If the gate current is removed, the device will stop current flow when the alternating cycle reaches  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>0</mn><mi mathvariant="normal">V</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">0\mathrm{V}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6833em;"></span><span class="mord">0</span><span class="mord mathrm" style="margin-right: 0.01389em;">V</span></span></span></span></span> .</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="transistors">Transistors<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#transistors" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>The transistor is the fundamental building block of modern electronics and the reason why electronic systems are now so affordable.</p>
<p>The three terminals on a bipolar transistor are known as base (B), collector (C) and emitter (E).</p>
<p>A transistor may be used either as a switch or an amplifier. When the base of an NPN transistor is grounded (0 V), no current flows between emitter and collector, so the transistor is off. If the base voltage is increased above 0.6 V, a current will flow from emitter to collector and the transistor is on. If the base current varies in value, the emitter to collector current will follow this pattern of variation with a larger or smaller current flow; in this situation, the transistor acts as an amplifier.</p>
<p>A PNP transistor operates in the same way as an NPN transistor but with current flow allowed in the reverse direction.</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251222-41adb00c.jpeg" alt="img-158.jpeg">
Figure 2.74 Symbol for a triac</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="activity">ACTIVITY<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#activity" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>What effect would varying the trigger angle have on a triac?</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251222-87659e94.jpeg" alt="img-159.jpeg">
Figure 2.75 Symbol for a PNP transistor</p>
<p>The City &amp; Guilds Textbook: Electrical Installations Book 1</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251222-5a25ea56.jpeg" alt="img-160.jpeg">
Figure 2.76 An NPN and a PNP transistor, showing the polarity of each device</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251222-4bb267a3.jpeg" alt="img-161.jpeg"></p>
<p>Another type of transistor is the field effect transistor (FET), which has terminals marked gate, source and drain. The FET is much cheaper to produce as it requires less silicon. It also has the major advantage of operating at virtually no current on the gate terminal as long as a voltage above  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>0.6</mn><mi mathvariant="normal">V</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">0.6\mathrm{V}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6833em;"></span><span class="mord">0.6</span><span class="mord mathrm" style="margin-right: 0.01389em;">V</span></span></span></span></span>  is present.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="resistors">Resistors<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#resistors" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251222-f4c78ef7.jpeg" alt="img-162.jpeg">
<span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">△</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\triangle</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8889em; vertical-align: -0.1944em;"></span><span class="mord">△</span></span></span></span></span>  Figure 2.77 Symbols for different types of resistor</p>
<p>Resistors are used to control or reduce current flow in electronic circuits. With a sufficiently high resistance, they can also be used as voltage dividers on certain circuits to allow a fixed voltage, less than the input voltage, to be obtained. Fixed-value resistors are either made from carbon film with an insulated coating, as shown in Figure 2.78, or are wire wound for larger power applications.</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251222-88097671.jpeg" alt="img-163.jpeg">
<span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">△</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\triangle</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8889em; vertical-align: -0.1944em;"></span><span class="mord">△</span></span></span></span></span>  Figure 2.78 Section through a carbon-film resistor</p>
<p>Chapter 2 Scientific and mathematical principles of electrical installation</p>
<p>Carbon-film resistors are colour-coded to indicate their value and tolerance as shown in Figure 2.79.</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251222-3f6ce2f2.jpeg" alt="img-164.jpeg">
<span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">△</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\triangle</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8889em; vertical-align: -0.1944em;"></span><span class="mord">△</span></span></span></span></span>  Figure 2.79 Resistor colour-coding system</p>
<p><span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">∇</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\nabla</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6833em;"></span><span class="mord">∇</span></span></span></span></span>  Resistor colour values</p>

<p>Wire-wound resistors are normally coded in order to establish the value. For example, a 2R resistor is  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>2</mn><mi mathvariant="normal">Ω</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">2\Omega</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6833em;"></span><span class="mord">2Ω</span></span></span></span></span> , whereas 2R2 is  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>2.2</mn><mi mathvariant="normal">Ω</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">2.2\Omega</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6833em;"></span><span class="mord">2.2Ω</span></span></span></span></span> .</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="thermistors">Thermistors<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#thermistors" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>A thermistor is a type of resistor in which the resistance varies significantly with temperature. This variation is so well defined that there is a definite temperature-related use for them. Thermistors typically achieve high precision within a limited temperature range, typically  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>∼</mo><msup><mn>90</mn><mo lspace="0em" rspace="0em">∘</mo></msup><mi mathvariant="normal">C</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\sim 90^{\circ}\mathrm{C}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.3669em;"></span><span class="mrel">∼</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6833em;"></span><span class="mord">9</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord">0</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.6741em;"><span style="top: -3.063em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">∘</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mord mathrm">C</span></span></span></span></span>  to  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msup><mn>130</mn><mo lspace="0em" rspace="0em">∘</mo></msup><mi mathvariant="normal">C</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">130^{\circ}\mathrm{C}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6833em;"></span><span class="mord">13</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord">0</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.6741em;"><span style="top: -3.063em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">∘</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mord mathrm">C</span></span></span></span></span> .</p>
<p>Thermistors are widely used as temperature sensors, self-resetting overcurrent protectors for self-regulating heating elements and current inrush limiters.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="activity">ACTIVITY<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#activity" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>A resistor is identified by the colour bands red, violet, orange and gold. What is its value?</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251222-dd35a7be.jpeg" alt="img-165.jpeg">
<span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">△</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\triangle</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8889em; vertical-align: -0.1944em;"></span><span class="mord">△</span></span></span></span></span>  Figure 2.80 Symbol for a thermistor</p>

<p>The City &amp; Guilds Textbook: Electrical Installations Book 1</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251222-393bffcd.jpeg" alt="img-167.jpeg">
<span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">△</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\triangle</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8889em; vertical-align: -0.1944em;"></span><span class="mord">△</span></span></span></span></span>  Figure 2.82 Symbol for a capacitor</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="activity">ACTIVITY<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#activity" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Name five different types of capacitor.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="industry-tip">INDUSTRY TIP<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#industry-tip" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>After disconnecting a laptop supply plug, or the plug for an electronic appliance, you may notice that the power LED indicator light stays on for a few seconds. This happens because of what is known as stray capacitance. Conductors in the circuit are in opposition, much like the plates of a capacitor, and these can also store charge, which is discharged when the circuit power is removed.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="industry-tip">INDUSTRY TIP<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#industry-tip" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Three-phase rectification requires three diodes for half-wave and six diodes for full-wave rectification.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="photoresistors">Photoresistors<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#photoresistors" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>These are resistors that vary in resistance, depending on the amount of light falling on them. They are often referred to as photocells and are used to control lighting as day/night switches.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="variable-resistors-or-potentiometers">Variable resistors or potentiometers<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#variable-resistors-or-potentiometers" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>These resistors are used to vary resistance in a circuit manually. Their applications are wide, including use as sound volume controllers and speed controllers.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="capacitors">Capacitors<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#capacitors" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Capacitors are widely used in electrical circuits in many common electrical devices. A capacitor is a passive two-terminal electrical component used to store energy electrostatically in an electric field, rather than by chemical reaction, as in a battery. (Originally capacitors were known as condensers, but the original term has now been widely superceded.)</p>
<p>Capacitors vary widely, but all contain at least two electrical conductors separated by a dielectric (insulating layer), which acts as an insulator between the conducting plates. The plates are usually made from foils. The capacitance is varied by the area of the plates and the size of gap between the plates. The narrow gaps that are used require a very high dielectric strength.</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251222-5456da5d.jpeg" alt="img-168.jpeg">
<span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">△</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\triangle</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8889em; vertical-align: -0.1944em;"></span><span class="mord">△</span></span></span></span></span>  Figure 2.83 Construction of a typical capacitor</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="rectifiers">Rectifiers<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#rectifiers" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>A rectifier is an electrical device that typically uses diodes to convert alternating current (AC), which periodically reverses direction as it cycles, to direct current (DC), which flows in only one direction.</p>
<p>Half-wave and full-wave rectifiers are available.</p>
<p>Chapter 2 Scientific and mathematical principles of electrical installation</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="half-wave-rectification">Half-wave rectification<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#half-wave-rectification" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>In half-wave rectification of a single-phase supply, either the positive or negative half of the AC wave is passed, while the other half is blocked. Half-wave rectification requires a single diode in a single-phase supply, or three in a three-phase supply.</p>
<p>As only one half of the input waveform reaches the output, the mean voltage is lower than full-wave rectification.</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251222-835129c4.jpeg" alt="img-169.jpeg"></p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251222-5b682d2a.jpeg" alt="img-170.jpeg">
Input AC</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251222-05bda4b2.jpeg" alt="img-171.jpeg">
Half wave rectified DC
Figure 2.84 Half-wave rectification</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="full-wave-rectification">Full-wave rectification<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#full-wave-rectification" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>A full-wave rectifier converts the whole of the input, both positive and negative components of the waveform, to one of constant polarity at its output. Full-wave rectification output gives a pulsating DC waveform with a higher average output voltage than its half-wave counterpart.</p>
<p>The unit works with two diodes and a centre-tapped transformer, or four diodes in a bridge configuration, as shown in Figure 2.85 on the next page.</p>
<p>The City &amp; Guilds Textbook: Electrical Installations Book 1</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251222-cbebe214.jpeg" alt="img-172.jpeg">
Two-diode method with centre-tapped transformer</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251222-ecfbabbc.jpeg" alt="img-173.jpeg">
Four-diode or bridge rectifier</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251222-59b47f6a.jpeg" alt="img-174.jpeg">
Input AC</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251222-e2d8f213.jpeg" alt="img-175.jpeg">

Figure 2.85 Full-wave rectification using two diode and bridge arrangements</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="invertors">Invertors<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#invertors" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>An invertor works in the opposite way to a rectifier by converting DC to AC. Invertors that use electronic components to convert DC to AC are known as static invertors as they do not move (unlike coupling an AC generator to a DC motor which does move).</p>
<p>By using SCRs in a DC circuit connected to a transformer, the SCRs can switch a large current, using a small signal current in opposite directions which is the same as AC.</p>
<p>Chapter 2 Scientific and mathematical principles of electrical installation</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251222-280a8d69.jpeg" alt="img-176.jpeg">
Figure 2.86 A simple invertor circuit using SCRs</p>
<p>Invertors are commonly used to convert, or invert, the DC produced by photovoltaic cells on the roof of a building to AC, which can be fed into the building's electricity supply.</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251222-087539a3.jpeg" alt="img-177.jpeg">
Figure 2.87 Photovoltaic cells on the roof of a building</p>
<p>The City &amp; Guilds Textbook: Electrical Installations Book 1</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="types-of-electrical-and-electronic-equipment-common-in-dwellings">Types of electrical and electronic equipment common in dwellings<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#types-of-electrical-and-electronic-equipment-common-in-dwellings" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>With constant changes in technology, the types of electrical systems found in dwellings are constantly changing and evolving. As well as standard power and lighting circuits, dwellings often feature the additional systems as detailed in the table below.</p>
<table><thead><tr><th>Type of system</th><th>Purpose</th><th>Additional information</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>Power over Ethernet (PoE)</td><td>This is a system where two or four pairs of an ethernet cable (Cat 5 or above) are used to power devices, meaning the device does not need a separate power supply source. Voltages are typically between 42.5–57 V with currents of 600 mA. Typically, PoE is used to power items such as internet-based telephones, network data switches, Internet Protocol (IP) cameras, wireless access points (WAP) and access control systems.</td><td>Where four-pairs are used as power, this is classed as 4PPoE Type 4. This is often used where higher power applications are required, such as Pan, Tilt, Zoom (PTZ) cameras. Lower power applications use two-pairs as power, and this is classed as 2PPoE Type 3.</td></tr><tr><td>Security surveillance systems</td><td>Most commonly used in dwellings, Internet Protocol (IP) cameras are used for security surveillance purposes where cameras are connected by WIFI. Most modern cameras can be set to operate when something triggers the proximity sensor in the camera. Many older systems would be Closed Circuit Televisual (CCTV) systems, which require wiring both for signal and power to the cameras. This requires either two separate cables for power and data or a single cable known as a ‘shotgun cable’ (i.e. a coaxial cable for the video) and a pair of cores for power.</td><td>Many IP/WIFI cameras are app-based for setting up and viewing. Whilst some have internal memory for storing images, most utilise a subscription service where images are stored centrally, on the internet, for retrieval using the app. Because loss of internet will lead to loss of surveillance, where high security is needed, wired or wireless systems will be preferable, where images are stored on a secure on-site hard drive.</td></tr><tr><td>Fire detection</td><td>Part B of the Building Regulations sets out the grade of fire detection system required based on the type of dwelling (i.e. bungalow, three-storey, etc.) and its use, for instance, as a HMO or student accommodation. <strong>Grade D</strong> systems are where the smoke and heat detectors have internal battery backup, but also have 230 V power supplies from a local circuit, such as a lighting circuit. D1 systems have tamper-proof batteries and D2 systems have user-replaceable batteries. <strong>Grade F</strong> systems are simple, standalone battery-supplied detectors that operate independently. F1 battery detectors have tamper-proof batteries and F2 detectors have user-replaceable batteries.</td><td>There are several types of detectors used, depending on the location:</td></tr><tr><td>• Optical smoke detectors see the presence of smoke.</td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>• Ionised smoke detectors sense the chemicals in smoke.</td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>• Fixed heat detectors activate when a certain temperature is reached.</td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>• Rate of heat rise detectors are triggered when a sudden rise in heat is detected.</td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>Access systems</td><td>Access control systems are systems that often control a door or gate. They can be intercom/telephone systems where a visitor calls the house or flat and the occupant can remotely release the door lock or open the gate. Many of these also incorporate cameras to establish visual identity. IP/WIFI doorbell systems are also common, where the doorbell doesn’t only activate a chime but can also alert a person in several ways. These ways include app alerts on a mobile phone, smart device or speaker alerts and computer notifications. Most also have video capture as well as two-way conversation capabilities.</td><td>Many access control systems that are used to unlock doors or operate electric gates will also have some form of key system, where the owner/occupant can enter or leave by entering a PIN code on a keypad, or by using electronic key fobs or remote-control devices.</td></tr></tbody></table>
<p>Chapter 2 Scientific and mathematical principles of electrical installation</p>
<table><thead><tr><th>Broadband, wired and wireless networks</th><th>Part R of the Building Regulations requires new or significantly redeveloped dwellings (and other buildings) to be provided with a network termination point, linked to an access point and service provider by ducting to the service provider chamber in the road. This is to enable the delivery of high-speed broadband. The broadband is then connected to a router, which can then be connected to devices using a wired Local Area Network (LAN) or a Wireless Local Area Network (WLAN), commonly called WIFI. Wired networks usually use ethernet (CAT) cable, terminating using RJ45 connectors into the back of the router, and equipment such as Personal Computers (PCs). Wired LANs provide a more secure and reliable network which is unlikely to drop out from interference, which can happen to wireless (WIFI) networks. WIFI networks can be affected by electromagnetic interference (EMI) and placing a router near electronic equipment such as televisions, microwave ovens or fridges can cause serious interference with the signals, leading to more internet drop-outs. Figure 2.89 Broadband router with wired RJ45 connections</th><th>Routers normally transmit WIFI using two frequencies, 2.4GHz and 5GHz, with later models also using 6GHz. Many items that require the internet to function, such as wireless heating or lighting controls, mainly use the 2.4GHz frequency, but more modern items, such as video doorbells, use dual bands. This can create issues when a smart doorbell needs to contact a remote chime, and if the doorbell keeps changing frequencies, it can lead to poor communications. It is therefore sometimes better to partition the network and use the 2.4GHz channel for the Internet of Things (IoT) connections and the 5GHz channel for connecting PCs, phones and tablets. Partitioning can be done by changing the network names in the admin settings on the router.</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>Lighting controls</td><td>With the desire for home automation growing, wireless switching on and off of lighting is becoming more and more common. Wireless switching devices or lamps can be used to dim, control or change the colour of household lights by using an app or remote control. Many are also compatible with voice-activated systems.</td><td>Wireless switching devices need to be hard-wired to the lighting circuits and can function as one-way, two-way or intermediate switches, depending on the type bought. If wireless lighting control is to be retrofitted, then switches can be replaced with smart switches, but these often require neutrals to be present at the switch point. Another method to retrofit is to use smart lamps with existing switches.</td></tr><tr><td>Heating controls</td><td>Much like the lighting controls discussed above, heating control systems have removed the need for wiring between certain heating system components, and are instead being replaced with wireless and app-controlled systems. Simple app controls replace the thermostat wiring, but more complex systems can replace wiring between zone valves, with some removing all wiring (except boiler and pump supply), and using wirelessly-controlled radiator valves to adjust individual room heat settings.</td><td>Figure 2.90 A smart thermostat</td></tr></tbody></table>
<p>The City &amp; Guilds Textbook: Electrical Installations Book 1</p>
<p>When installing smart systems, it is important to recognise, check and where required, update the following:</p>
<ul>
<li>Firmware – this is the equipment’s permanent internal software that is designed to operate the equipment.</li>
<li>App control – ‘app’ is short for ‘application’ and is the software used to control a device. Manufacturers of smart equipment develop their own apps which are often only compatible with their own devices. Third-party developed apps can often control an array of equipment from different manufacturers. For example, a homeowner may have several types of smart-plug, but might wish to control them using either one app, or by using one voice control smart device such as Alexa, Google Nest or Siri.</li>
<li>End of Life Agreement (EoL) – manufacturers will update their firmware and app control software to support smart equipment and allow it to continue to be compatible and function, even when the tablet or smartphone’s own operating system is updated. At some point, the manufacturer will stop this support as other, newer equipment supersedes older technology. This becomes an ‘end of life’ of the equipment.</li>
</ul>

<p>16 Which of the following is the correct transposition of the formula in order to determine <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>L</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">L</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6833em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal">L</span></span></span></span></span>?</p>
<div class="math math-display"><span class="katex-display"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" display="block"><semantics><mrow><mi>R</mi><mo>=</mo><mfrac><mrow><mi>ρ</mi><mi>L</mi></mrow><mi>A</mi></mfrac></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">R = \frac {\rho L}{A}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6833em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.00773em;">R</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span><span class="mrel">=</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 2.0463em; vertical-align: -0.686em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mopen nulldelimiter"></span><span class="mfrac"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 1.3603em;"><span style="top: -2.314em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 3em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathnormal">A</span></span></span><span style="top: -3.23em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 3em;"></span><span class="frac-line" style="border-bottom-width: 0.04em;"></span></span><span style="top: -3.677em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 3em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathnormal">ρ</span><span class="mord mathnormal">L</span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.686em;"><span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mclose nulldelimiter"></span></span></span></span></span></span></div>

<p>149</p>
<p>CHAPTER 3</p>
<p>ELECTRICAL TECHNOLOGY</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="introduction">INTRODUCTION<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#introduction" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Large amounts of information need to be absorbed and understood by everyone within the construction industry. Most of this information is guidance or commentary on Regulations. However, there are also laws covering electrical work and the way it is carried out that need to be obeyed.</p>
<p>The law will be satisfied if the installer complies with various documents, including BS 7671:2018 (2022) The IET Wiring Regulations, 18th Edition amendment 2, the Institute of Engineering and Technology (IET) Guidance Notes and other related guidance. The first part of this chapter will help you to identify the relevant duties set out in <strong>statute law</strong> and commercial contract law (<strong>civil law</strong>) and to know how to carry out those duties.</p>
<p>The rest of the chapter deals with technical considerations of working in the electrical industry.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="key-terms">KEY TERMS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#key-terms" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p><strong>Statute</strong>: a law made by Parliament as an Act of Parliament.</p>
<p><strong>Civil law</strong>: law that deals with disputes between individuals and/or organisations, in which liability is decided and compensation is awarded to the victim.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="industry-tip">INDUSTRY TIP<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#industry-tip" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>You can access information relating to the IET Wiring Regulations on the IET Electrical website: just search for IET Electrical.</p>
<p>T Level mapping grids are available on the Hodder Education website. These map the book to the occupational specialisms: 8710-353 (Electrical Engineering) and 8710-352 (Electrical and Electronic Equipment).</p>
<p>Learning objectives</p>
<p>This table shows how the topics in this chapter meet the outcomes of the different qualifications.</p>
