<p>Chapter 3 Electrical technology</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="1-regulations-related-to-electrical-activities">1 REGULATIONS RELATED TO ELECTRICAL ACTIVITIES<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#1-regulations-related-to-electrical-activities" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>In Chapter 1, we looked at the many Statutory and Non-statutory Regulations, Guidance material and Codes of Practice relating to working in the construction industry. Below is a reminder of some of those Regulations and other documents relating specifically to electrical installation work.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="statutory-regulations">Statutory regulations<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#statutory-regulations" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>A Statutory Regulation is easily distinguishable from other regulations because its full title usually contains the word 'Regulations' and always has an SI (Statutory Instrument) number. Statutes (Acts of Parliament) are known as primary legislation. They lay down the general framework of the law, which is added to over the years through numerous Regulations. Statutory Regulations are known as secondary legislation.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="health-and-safety-at-work-etc-act-1974">Health and Safety at Work etc. Act 1974<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#health-and-safety-at-work-etc-act-1974" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The Health and Safety at Work etc. Act 1974 (HSW Act) is the primary legislation covering occupational health and safety in Great Britain. This Act has been amended over the years by various pieces of legislation to enforce health and safety law in Great Britain.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="principles-of-the-hsw-act">Principles of the HSW Act<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#principles-of-the-hsw-act" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>All workers have a right to work in places where risks to their health and safety are properly controlled. Health and safety is about stopping anyone getting hurt at work or becoming ill through work. It sets down employers' responsibilities for health and safety, but also requires employees to help keep themselves and others safe. The HSW Act requires employers to do the following.</p>
<ul>
<li>Assess risks in the workplace and to put in place measures to prevent harm and to inform all concerned about who is responsible for the removal or reduction of the risks.</li>
<li>Consult with workers and health and safety representatives to protect employees from harm in the workplace.</li>
<li>Provide free health and safety training to enable employees to do their jobs safely.</li>
<li>Provide, free of charge, any equipment or personal protective equipment (PPE) required for employees to do their jobs, and ensure it is properly maintained and remains functional.</li>
<li>Provide adequate welfare facilities such as toilets, washing facilities and drinking water.</li>
<li>Provide adequate first aid facilities, as appropriate for the type of work being carried out.</li>
<li>Report deaths and major injuries at work to the Health and Safety Executive (HSE) Incident Contact Centre.</li>
<li>Report other injuries, diseases and dangerous incidents under the Reporting of Injuries, Diseases and Dangerous Occurrences Regulations 1995 (RIDDOR).</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="industry-tip">INDUSTRY TIP<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#industry-tip" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>You can access the Health and Safety at Work etc. Act 1974 (HSW Act) by searching the GOV.UK website.</p>
<p>The Health and Safety at Work (Northern Ireland) Order 1978 applies in Northern Ireland and can also be accessed by searching the GOV.UK website.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="industry-tip">INDUSTRY TIP<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#industry-tip" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>You can access the Reporting of Injuries, Diseases and Dangerous Occurrences Regulations 1995 (RIDDOR) by searching the HSE website.</p>
<p>The City &amp; Guilds Textbook: Electrical Installations Book 1</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="industry-tip">INDUSTRY TIP<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#industry-tip" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Display a printed or electronic copy of the current insurance certificate where all employees can read it easily.</p>
<ul>
<li>Have insurance that covers employees in case they get hurt at work or become ill through work.</li>
<li>Work with any other employers or contractors sharing the workplace or providing employees (such as agency workers), so that everyone’s health and safety is protected.</li>
</ul>
<p>The HSW Act requires employees to:</p>
<ul>
<li>follow the training received when using any equipment supplied by the employer</li>
<li>take reasonable care of their own and other people’s health and safety</li>
<li>co-operate with the employer on health and safety matters</li>
<li>tell someone (the employer, supervisor or health and safety representative) if they think the work or inadequate precautions are putting anyone’s health and safety at serious risk.</li>
</ul>
<p>If an employee has concerns about health and safety in the workplace:</p>
<ul>
<li>They should talk to their employer, supervisor or health and safety representative.</li>
<li>They should seek advice from the general information about health and safety at work on the HSE website.</li>
</ul>
<p>If, after talking with their employer, they are still worried, an employee can contact their local enforcing authority for health and safety and the Employment Medical Advisory Service (EMAS) via the HSE website.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="key-terms">KEY TERMS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#key-terms" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p><strong>Duty holder</strong>: any person or organisation holding a legal duty under the Health and Safety at Work etc. Act 1974.</p>
<p><strong>Competency</strong>: the degree to which a person has the ability to complete something.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="industry-tips">INDUSTRY TIPS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#industry-tips" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>You can access the Electricity at Work Regulations 1989 by searching the GOV.UK website.</p>
<p>The EAWR apply to workplaces and not private homes, except where businesses are run from home.</p>
<p>The HSE publication HSR25 (Figure 3.1) interprets the regulations and gives guidance on how to meet the requirements. It can be accessed by searching the HSE website.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="electricity-at-work-regulations-1989">Electricity at Work Regulations 1989<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#electricity-at-work-regulations-1989" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The Electricity at Work Regulations 1989 (EAWR) are made under the HSW Act. This means that breaches in the EAWR will result in action being taken under the HSW Act.</p>
<p>In addition to the duties imposed by the HSW Act, the EAWR impose duties on <strong>duty holders</strong> in respect of systems, electrical equipment and conductors, and work activities on or near electrical equipment under their control. Managers of mines and quarries are also included, despite mines and quarries having other special regulations.</p>
<p>The EAWR cover the principles of electrical safety that apply to work activities and systems, including anything that influences them, equipment, isolation and safety systems, and the <strong>competency</strong> of those working with electricity.</p>
<p>The EAWR apply beyond those situations that we traditionally associate with the dangers of electricity, including voltages outside the scope of <strong>BS 7671</strong> (see below). The EAWR cover battery operated systems to extra high voltage transmission supplies.</p>
<p>The HSE produces a memorandum of guidance (HSR25) (Figure 3.1), which is free and provides guidance on how each Regulation should be interpreted. Each Regulation covers a specific topic, as follows:</p>
<ul>
<li>Regulation 4, Systems, work activities and protective equipment</li>
<li>Regulation 5, Strength and capability of electrical equipment</li>
</ul>
<p>Chapter 3 Electrical technology</p>
<ul>
<li>Regulation 6, Adverse or hazardous environments</li>
<li>Regulation 7, Insulation, protection and placing of conductors</li>
<li>Regulation 8, Earthing or other suitable precautions</li>
<li>Regulation 9, Integrity of referenced conductors</li>
<li>Regulation 10, Connections</li>
<li>Regulation 11, Means for protecting from overcurrent</li>
<li>Regulation 12, Means for cutting off the supply and for isolation</li>
<li>Regulation 13, Precautions for work on equipment made dead</li>
<li>Regulation 14, Work on or near live conductors</li>
<li>Regulation 15, Working space, access and lighting</li>
<li>Regulation 16, Persons to be competent to prevent danger and injury.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="electricity-safety-quality-and-continuity-regulations-2002">Electricity Safety, Quality and Continuity Regulations 2002<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#electricity-safety-quality-and-continuity-regulations-2002" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>The Electricity Safety, Quality and Continuity Regulations 2002 (ESQCR) impose requirements regarding the installation and use of electric lines and the apparatus of electricity suppliers, including provisions for connection with earth. The safety aspects of these regulations are administered by the HSE. All other aspects are administered by Government and the industry.</p>
<p>The ESQCR may impose requirements, usually on supply companies or those associated with the supply of electricity, in addition to those of the EAWR. Designers of installations have a responsibility to ensure they meet the ESQCR.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="provision-and-use-of-work-equipment-regulations-1998">Provision and Use of Work Equipment Regulations 1998<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#provision-and-use-of-work-equipment-regulations-1998" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>The Provision and Use of Work Equipment Regulations 1998 (PUWER) ensure that work equipment, such as electric drills and cutters, as constructed or adapted, is suitable for the task and safe to use, taking into account all the risks of using it in a specific work environment. This applies to any equipment, machinery, appliance, apparatus or tool for use at work.</p>
<p>For example, in order to be fit for purpose, construction site equipment needs to cope with a wide range of weather conditions including wet weather. Equipment also needs to be robust enough and sufficiently protected to withstand mechanical impact or abrasion.</p>
<p>It should help to reduce, to as low a level as possible, the risk of electric shock through external influences, including from reduced low-voltage systems such as the 110 V system used on UK construction sites. This may mean that additional protection must be provided.</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251222-8e04acf6.jpeg" alt="img-181.jpeg">
Figure 3.1 Memorandum of guidance (HSR25)</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="industry-tip">INDUSTRY TIP<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#industry-tip" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The ESQCR can be accessed by searching the GOV.UK website.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="industry-tip">INDUSTRY TIP<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#industry-tip" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>A copy of the Provision and Use of Work Equipment Regulations can be downloaded free of charge from the HSE website.</p>
<p>The City &amp; Guilds Textbook: Electrical Installations Book 1</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="industry-tip">INDUSTRY TIP<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#industry-tip" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>You can access the Control of Substances Hazardous to Health Regulations by searching the GOV.UK website.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="key-term">KEY TERM<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#key-term" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p><strong>Nanotechnology</strong>: where a material or substance is created by changing matter at an atomic or molecular level. In this way, science may create new materials or substances that are stronger or more suited to a particular application. Nanotechnology is widely used in medical applications but may also be found in everyday products such as sunscreen, cosmetics and paints, finishes and surface coatings on everyday products.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="key-term">KEY TERM<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#key-term" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p><strong>Asphyxiating gas</strong>: a gas that can cause suffocation. If someone is suffering asphyxia, they are unable to breathe.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="control-of-substances-hazardous-to-health-coshh-regulations-2002">Control of Substances Hazardous to Health (COSHH) Regulations 2002<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#control-of-substances-hazardous-to-health-coshh-regulations-2002" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The law requires employers to control substances that are hazardous to health and to protect employees and other persons from the hazards of substances used at work, by risk assessment, control of exposure, health surveillance and incident planning. The COSHH regulations contain very detailed information relating to each type of harmful substance, depending on its physical state and how it will harm individuals or groups of people.</p>
<p>The COSHH regulations cover:</p>
<ul>
<li>chemicals and products containing chemicals</li>
<li>dusts, fumes, vapours and mists</li>
<li>nanotechnology</li>
<li>gases and asphyxiating gases</li>
<li>biological agents (germs) and germs that cause diseases.</li>
</ul>
<p>The COSHH regulations do not cover lead, asbestos or radioactive substances, which are dealt with under separate Regulations.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="duties-of-employers">Duties of employers<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#duties-of-employers" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>In order to reduce the exposure of workers to hazardous substances, employers are required to do the following:</p>
<ul>
<li>Identify the health hazards – using information about any chemicals or substances used in the workplace that might be a hazard.</li>
<li>Decide how to prevent harm to health – using risk assessments to determine who may be harmed by a chemical or substance and how someone might be harmed.</li>
<li>Provide control measures to reduce harm to health – looking at the potential for harm and introducing protection measures, such as local exhaust ventilation (LEV), respiratory protective equipment (RPE) or personal protective equipment (PPE).</li>
<li>Make sure protective measures are used – including ensuring that workers are informed of the risks associated with a hazard, what the protective measures are and how to comply with them, and the health and safety and disciplinary consequences of failing to use the measures.</li>
<li>Keep all control measures in good working order – all measures must function correctly and any failing or potential failing must be reported and rectified. Equipment that is not in good working order must be taken out of service until a repair has taken place.</li>
<li>Provide information, instruction and training for employees and others – this is vitally important to ensure that those who work with or are potentially exposed to harmful substances understand what they are being exposed to, know what to do to prevent a situation getting out of control and becoming an emergency, and know how to deal with particular situations or emergencies.</li>
</ul>
<p>Chapter 3 Electrical technology</p>
<ul>
<li>Provide health monitoring in appropriate cases – this applies to people who regularly work with or who may have been accidentally exposed to a harmful substance. If adverse effects on health become apparent, the relevant healthcare can then be undertaken.</li>
<li>Plan for emergencies – providing an emergency contingency plan so that workers and managers know exactly what to do should the need arise.</li>
</ul>
<table><thead><tr><th>Company name</th><th></th><th>Department/site</th><th></th><th>Assessment discussed with employees (include date)</th><th></th><th></th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>Potential hazard</td><td>Potential harm and those affected</td><td>Existing measures</td><td>Additional measures required</td><td>Who</td><td>When</td><td>Check</td></tr><tr><td>Oil-based fluid and fine particle in lathe sumps</td><td>Dermatitis Metal workers and turners</td><td>Fluid stops when machine stops 0.4 mm nitrile gloves</td><td>Improve washing facilities Apply barrier cream before and after work</td><td></td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td></td><td></td><td>Check oil temperature and particle concentration</td><td>Check appearance daily Fit sump thermometer</td><td></td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td></td><td></td><td>Change and launder overalls once a week</td><td>Keep oily rags out of pockets</td><td></td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>Also</td><td>Action taken</td><td>Action needed</td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>---</td><td>---</td><td>---</td><td>---</td><td>---</td><td>---</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>Thorough examination and test for COSHH compliance</td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>Supervision</td><td>Yes</td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>Instruction and training</td><td>Yes</td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>Emergency plans</td><td>Spillage clearance</td><td>Practice</td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>Health surveillance</td><td></td><td>Improve record-keeping</td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>Monitoring</td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>Review date:</td><td>Review observations/actions Any significant changes:</td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td></tr></tbody></table>
<p>Figure 3.2 Typical COSHH risk assessment form</p>
<p>The City &amp; Guilds Textbook: Electrical Installations Book 1</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="industry-tip">INDUSTRY TIP<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#industry-tip" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The HSE website contains many Guidance documents, which are free to download.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="key-terms">KEY TERMS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#key-terms" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>National Standard: based on International Standards produced by the International Electrotechnical Commission (IEC), member nations create their own versions specific to their needs. Other CENELEC countries use the term 'rules' rather than 'regulations'. For example, the national wiring standard in the Republic of Ireland is the National Rules for Electrical Installations (ET101).</p>
<p>CENELEC: the Comité Européen de Normalisation Electrotechnique, which is the European Committee for Electrotechnical Standardization.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="activity">ACTIVITY<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#activity" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Look at the numbering system within Part 7 of BS 7671 and consider why the numbers are not in a regular sequence as they are in other Parts of the document.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="published-guidance-and-codes-of-practice">Published Guidance and Codes of Practice<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#published-guidance-and-codes-of-practice" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Guidance on the legal requirements of certain Statutory Regulations and how to interpret them, and Approved Codes of Practice (ACoPs), are published or approved by the HSE and the relevant Secretary of State. These documents often contain a copy of the legislation they are giving guidance on. They have a special legal status in law. Where a duty holder does not follow the Guidance or Code of Practice, they must show that their course of action or omission is no less safe.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="non-statutory-regulations">Non-statutory Regulations<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#non-statutory-regulations" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Not all documents using the term 'regulations' are Statutory Instruments. For example, BS 7671:2018 (2022) The IET Wiring Regulations, 18th Edition amendment 2, commonly called the IET Wiring Regulations, are non-statutory. They form the National Standard in the UK for low-voltage electrical installations. They deal with the design, selection, erection, inspection and testing of electrical installations operating at a voltage up to 1000 V AC and 1500 V DC. Work undertaken in accordance with BS 7671 is almost certain to meet the requirements of the Electricity at Work Regulations 1989. BS 7671 is supported by a number of Guidance Notes published by the IET.</p>
<p>Other non-statutory rules include the rules and requirements of regulating bodies such as the NICEIC, the National Association of Professional Inspectors and Testers (NAPIT), the Electrical Contractors' Association (ECA) and trades unions such as Unite. Individuals and enterprises that want to belong to these organisations must comply with the relevant organisation's rules. In certain circumstances, compliance with such rules, such as those for competent person schemes (CPSs), assists in compliance with specific statutory regulations or requirements.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="bs-7671-2018-2022-the-iet-wiring-regulations-18th-edition">BS 7671:2018 (2022) The IET Wiring Regulations, 18th Edition<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#bs-7671-2018-2022-the-iet-wiring-regulations-18th-edition" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>BS 7671:2018 (2022) The IET Wiring Regulations, 18th Edition amendment 2 is the basis for all other guidance documentation, such as the IET On-Site Guide or the eight IET Guidance Notes (GNs). BS 7671 is broken down into seven parts with further appendices providing information relating to the seven parts. The parts are in a logical order relating to the design and installation of an electrical installation.</p>
<ul>
<li>Part 1: Scope, Object and Fundamental Principles – sets out what the standard covers (scope), why it is setting out (object) and what risks need addressing (fundamental principles).</li>
<li>Part 2: Definitions – provides detailed descriptions of technical words and phrases, including abbreviations and symbols, used in the document.</li>
<li>Part 3: Assessment of General Characteristics – details what a designer must assess prior to designing an electrical installation and before any equipment is installed.</li>
<li>Part 4: Protection for Safety – provides detail on methods that may or must be used for protecting against particular risks electricity may pose, such as electric shock, fire or overcurrent.</li>
</ul>
<p>Chapter 3 Electrical technology</p>
<ul>
<li>Part 5: Selection and Erection – gives detail on what particular equipment can be used and how it should be installed.</li>
<li>Part 6: Inspection and Testing – gives criteria for what should be inspected and tested for every new or existing electrical installation.</li>
<li>Part 7: Special Installations or Locations – sets out requirements where a particular location provides greater risk. In these locations, all relevant previous Regulations still apply but, because of the risk, some changes are needed to overcome the risk.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="iet-on-site-guide">IET On-Site Guide<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#iet-on-site-guide" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The purpose of the IET On-Site Guide is to provide guidance on the design, installation and inspection and testing of standard installations such as those in dwellings, shops and small offices. By following the guidance given, the need for complex design calculations is reduced.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="iet-students-guide-to-the-wiring-regulations">IET Students' Guide to the wiring regulations<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#iet-students-guide-to-the-wiring-regulations" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>While this Guide is intended for students learning about electrical installations, the title should not put off more experienced electricians as it simplifies a lot of the technical aspects of BS 7671 and provides good guidance on the electrical industry, basic design procedures, good working practices and common calculations.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="iet-guidance-notes">IET Guidance Notes<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#iet-guidance-notes" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The IET Guidance Notes (GN) are intended to provide more detailed guidance on aspects of BS 7671 but the numbering of the eight GNs does not necessarily reflect the Parts of BS 7671. The eight Guidance Notes are:</p>
<ul>
<li>GN1: Selection and Erection</li>
<li>GN2: Isolation and Switching</li>
<li>GN3: Inspection and Testing</li>
<li>GN4: Protection Against Fire</li>
<li>GN5: Protection Against Electric Shock</li>
<li>GN6: Protection Against Overcurrent</li>
<li>GN7: Special Locations</li>
<li>GN8 Earthing and Bonding</li>
</ul>
<p>The IET also provide specific Guidance documents on aspects of electrical installation work such as:</p>
<ul>
<li>Guide to Consumer Units</li>
<li>Considerations for DC Installations</li>
<li>Installation of Electric Vehicle Charging installations</li>
<li>In-service Inspection and Testing of Electrical Equipment</li>
<li>Guide to the Building Regulations</li>
<li>Guide to Emergency Lighting Installations</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="industry-tip">INDUSTRY TIP<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#industry-tip" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Although the use of the IET On-Site Guide will nearly always lead to compliance with BS 7671, it may not provide the most economical design. For example, using tables within the guide may lead to an electrician installing a particular size cable for a particular circuit but with more rigorous design, a smaller cable may be suitable leading to savings in cost. In many cases in these types of installations, however, the cost saving from the cable may be less than the cost for the time designing!</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="key-term">KEY TERM<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#key-term" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Economical: good value for money.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="industry-tip">INDUSTRY TIP<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#industry-tip" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The IET also publish a comprehensive suite of Codes of Practice known as IET Standards. A full list of these can be found by searching for IET Standard.</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251222-7e81c5c0.jpeg" alt="img-182.jpeg">
Figure 3.3 IET Code of Practice for In-service Inspection and Testing of Electrical Equipment</p>
<p>The City &amp; Guilds Textbook: Electrical Installations Book 1</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="applying-statutory-regulations">Applying Statutory Regulations<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#applying-statutory-regulations" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Statutory Regulations cover the whole range of areas dealt with by the law. Each set of regulations lays down the detailed requirements that have to be met to comply with a specific Act of Parliament. In construction-related industries, most legislation focuses on health and safety.</p>
<p>Statutory Regulations place specific requirements on duty holders to do something, provide something or declare something.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="hse-inspections">HSE inspections<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#hse-inspections" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>HSE inspectors routinely inspect places of work. Although it is unusual to call unannounced, they have the right to enter and inspect any workplace without giving notice.</p>
<p>On a routine visit, rather than responding to a complaint or particular incident, inspectors inspect the workplace, work activities, and methods and procedures used for the management of health and safety, and check compliance with health and safety law relevant to the specific workplace. The inspector is empowered to talk to employees and their representatives, and take photographs and samples.</p>
<p>Where breaches in requirements are observed, the inspector can serve the following, depending on the severity of the breach.</p>
<ul>
<li>Informal warning – where the breach is minor, the inspector can explain on site what is required to the duty holder (usually the employer), following up with written advice explaining best practice and the legal requirements.</li>
<li>Improvement notice – where the breach is more serious, the notice will state what has to be done, why, and when the remedial action has to be completed by. The inspector can take further legal action if the notice is not complied with within the time period specified. The duty holder has the right to appeal to an industrial tribunal.</li>
<li>Prohibition notice – where there is a risk of serious personal injury, the inspector can stop the activity immediately or after a specific period. The activity cannot be resumed until remedial action has taken place. The duty holder has the right of appeal to an industrial tribunal.</li>
<li>Prosecution – in certain circumstances, the inspector may consider prosecution necessary to punish offenders and deter other potential offenders.</li>
</ul>
<p>In addition, particular pieces of legislation may carry specific penalties, such as unlimited fines and custodial sentences. These measures are generally taken to court by an enforcing authority. In cases of health and safety legislation violation, this is done by the HSE.</p>
<p>When cases go to court, specialist lawyers are called on to work through the complexities of the relevant area of law. Often the evidence of expert witnesses is sought to obtain professional opinions on the subject. The outcome will be an acquittal or a sentence with remedial or corrective action.</p>
<hr>
<p><strong>HEALTH AND SAFETY</strong></p>
<p>In the case of health and safety law, non-compliance can impact on an organisation's reputation. For example, some clients monitor HSE incidents before appointing contractors and sub-contractors. More significant failures can result in fines and, for the most serious cases, prison sentences.</p>
<hr>
<p><strong>ACTIVITY</strong></p>
<p>Look at the press release section of the HSE website and see the types of incidents that regularly occur including the amount of prosecutions per month. From all of the prosecutions over a six-month period, what is the ratio of employers prosecuted compared with individuals?</p>
<p>Chapter 3 Electrical technology</p>
<p>In general, employers are responsible for the actions of their employees and, where these result in breaches in legislation or accidents, it is the employer that is punished. However, where a breach is entirely due to an employee, the employer has the right to impose its own disciplinary processes, which, at worst, may result in a finding of gross misconduct and dismissal.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="breaches-of-non-statutory-regulations">Breaches of Non-statutory Regulations<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#breaches-of-non-statutory-regulations" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Breaches of Non-statutory Regulations, such as British Standards (BSs) and supporting guidance, usually amount to a breach of contract and often revolve around quality. Contractual requirements for the provision of services or standards usually exceed any legal requirements. When requirements have been breached, financial compensation for damages is often sought.</p>
<p>In Figure 3.5, showing the hierarchy of work-related legislation and guidance, it might appear that British Standards and Guidance documents are less important than Statutory Regulations. However, the best practices contained in these examples of non-statutory documents are actually used as benchmarks in legal proceedings. Failure to meet them can often result in a breach of legal requirements.</p>
<p>This will lead to the statutory enforcement system and criminal courts. For example, a breach of the non-statutory IET Wiring Regulations may have a significant effect on safety, ultimately breaching statutory legislation.</p>
<p>Even if a breach of non-statutory regulations is not a legal issue, the consequences can be far-reaching. The industry may lose faith in the offending organisation's ability to perform, resulting in loss of customers and tenders. In the case of the rules of trade and similar organisations, breaches may result in expulsion from the relevant organisation.</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251222-acf45f21.jpeg" alt="img-183.jpeg">
Figure 3.4 Standards required by Statutory and Non-statutory Regulations</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="industry-tip">INDUSTRY TIP<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#industry-tip" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Best practice that includes standards of excellence not reasonably expected in a normal contract is often referred to as 'Rolls Royce standard'.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="key-term">KEY TERM<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#key-term" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Expulsion: the action of forcing someone to leave an organisation.</p>
<p>The City &amp; Guilds Textbook: Electrical Installations Book 1</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251222-5ee52636.jpeg" alt="img-184.jpeg">
Figure 3.5 Hierarchy of work-related legislation and guidance</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="2-technical-information">2 TECHNICAL INFORMATION<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#2-technical-information" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>There are many different sources of technical information available, including reference books, textbooks and commentaries, to help you interpret different elements of electrical engineering. They are aimed at different levels, from the trainee to the experienced engineer. It is important to recognise the different types and levels of information available so that it can be used to best effect.</p>
<p>In addition to industry information, guidance and documentation, technical information needed to carry out installation work can also be contained in the form of drawings and specifications.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="health-and-safety">HEALTH AND SAFETY<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#health-and-safety" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Under health and safety legislation, the employing organisation is obliged to provide sufficient information and training to protect those accessing their premises from harm. For example, a specialist chemical manufacturing company must advise or train all those who access their site (including visitors) on what to do if they are exposed to specific chemicals. Simply washing with a seemingly harmless substance such as water after exposure to a chemical may, for instance, be at least inadequate and at worst even dangerous.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="sources-of-technical-information">Sources of technical information<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#sources-of-technical-information" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Most electrotechnical information is found in book or electronic (ebook) format, although some can be delivered verbally. It can provide, for example, support and calculations to solve particular problems or commentary on compliance with legal requirements. Sources include:</p>
<ul>
<li>technical specifications</li>
<li>continuous professional development (CPD) presentations</li>
<li>Guidance and Approved Codes of Practice (ACoPs)</li>
<li>Government websites</li>
<li>technical standards</li>
<li>technical information and guidance from professional institutions.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="technical-specifications">Technical specifications<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#technical-specifications" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>As part of the manufacturing process, multi-national manufacturers employ engineering specialists to carry out testing and development on their products, giving them a level of expertise that is not normally found in such depth anywhere else in the industry. As a result, they are well equipped to provide the technical specifications in addition to the installation, operation, maintenance and safety information they supply with their products. Examples could be lighting manufacturers or manufacturers of protective devices.</p>
<p>Chapter 3 Electrical technology</p>
<p>Their technical information is usually available as free downloads from the internet and they often provide free <strong>seminars</strong> and training to the electrotechnical industry based around the solutions that their products provide. The information will obviously be biased towards their own products, but nevertheless can be very useful. Many of these seminars are CPD-accredited with trade institutions and training organisations.</p>
<p><strong>ACTIVITY</strong></p>
<p>Search the internet for manufacturers of electrical equipment such as cable management systems and see what courses they offer. These are sometimes listed as continuing professional development (CPD) seminars. See what other support and literature these manufacturers offer.</p>
<p>The employing organisation can often hold significant information relating to a particular site or installation.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="continuing-professional-development-presentations">Continuing professional development presentations<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#continuing-professional-development-presentations" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Continuing professional development (CPD) seminars at a workplace or institution are common ways of giving information and know-how to the end user. They are often presented by an industry specialist and acknowledged expert in the field. However, seminars can also present updates to standards and upcoming changes in Statutory and Non-statutory Regulations, all of which can have a significant effect on working methods.</p>
<p>Such presentations no longer need to be attended in person. They can also be delivered live or recorded for a web-based audience via a webinar. After a presentation, viewers can send queries to the organiser, which are then dealt with by the speaker in a short question-and-answer session. Webinars are often left posted on the internet so they can be referred to later.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="guidance-and-acops">Guidance and ACoPs<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#guidance-and-acops" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>These types of documents are provided to help interpret the law. Approved Codes of Practice, more commonly known as ACoPs, have a special status in law and may contain a copy of the Statutory Regulations they refer to. They have been approved by the relevant Secretary of State and, in the case of health and safety issues, by the Health and Safety Executive (HSE).</p>
<p><strong>INDUSTRY TIP</strong></p>
<p>The HSE and Electrical Safety First also publish many guidance documents and leaflets to help employers and employees understand their duties under specific Statutory Regulations and achieve best practice in their area. Check the Electrical Safety First Best Practice Guides by searching the Electrical Safety First website.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="technical-standards">Technical standards<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#technical-standards" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>British Standards (BSs) are documents published to provide industry specific guidance and, in some instances, information on Regulations. Each British</p>
<p><strong>KEY TERM</strong></p>
<p><strong>Seminar</strong>: an educational meeting or discussion for training.</p>
<p><strong>INDUSTRY TIP</strong></p>
<p>You can find a wide range of electrotechnical webinars available on the IET website.</p>
<p><strong>KEY TERM</strong></p>
<p><strong>ACoPs</strong>: Approved Codes of Practice issued by the Health and Safety Executive.</p>
<p><strong>INDUSTRY TIP</strong></p>
<p>Electrical Safety First is the campaigning name of the Electrical Safety Council and is the UK's leading charity on electrical safety. They work closely with industry bodies publishing all types of electrical safety information for both consumers and industry experts. See what they do by searching the Electrical Safety First website.</p>
<p>161</p>
<p>The City &amp; Guilds Textbook: Electrical Installations Book 1</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="key-term">KEY TERM<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#key-term" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Harmonised document: agreed by member nations, such as members of CENELEC, who jointly agree what rules or regulations should be in place for a particular risk or situation. For example, HD 60364-4-41 Protection Against Electric Shock is what Chapter 41 of BS 7671 is based on.</p>
<p>Standard gives information and the minimum best practice for a particular industry, put together by representatives and experts from the given industry.</p>
<p>British Standard European Norms (BS ENs) are similar documents but contain information and guidance from corresponding European Norms, based on good practice agreed across Europe. The UK is a member of CENELEC (the European Committee for Electrotechnical Standardization) and can therefore influence the content of electrotechnical ENs. However, UK legislation remains more important. For example, statutory requirements in the Electricity Safety, Quality and Continuity Regulations 2002 override certain continental European practices. Other UK documents, such as BS 7671, are based on harmonised documents (HDs) from International Standards.</p>
<p>Other technical standards include the National Engineering Specification (NES), which was developed from former Government department standards. These standards are now maintained by private companies and licensed to the relevant industry.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="technical-information-and-guidance-from-professional-institutions">Technical information and guidance from professional institutions<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#technical-information-and-guidance-from-professional-institutions" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Most professional institutions provide support and publish technical information for their members. This type of information has usually been accumulated over many years by practitioners in the industry and then put together by respected members of the institution, so it is full of useful technical advice.</p>
<p>Some institutions give general advice on design or installations – for example, the Plumbing Engineering Services Design Guide from the Chartered Institute of Plumbing and Heating Engineering, or the wide range of Chartered Institution of Building Services Engineers (CIBSE) guides.</p>
<p>Other institutions focus on particular elements of electrotechnical engineering, providing technical solutions to particular tasks or advice on developing specific systems of work. They include application manuals and guidance publications – for example, the IET series of guidance notes, which provide commentary on different areas of the Wiring Regulations. In addition to the IET, there are many other authors and publishers who provide commentary and guidance on BS 7671.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="types-of-drawings">Types of drawings<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#types-of-drawings" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Numerous sets of drawings are produced to communicate information about individual systems or collections of systems within a project. They include:</p>
<ul>
<li>plans or layout drawings</li>
<li>schematic (block) diagrams</li>
<li>wiring diagrams</li>
<li>circuit diagrams.</li>
</ul>
<p>Drawings usually use British Standard symbols. However, in order to represent the wide variety of materials and equipment available, non-standard symbols may also be used. A legend or key explains them.</p>
<p>Chapter 3 Electrical technology</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="plans-or-layout-drawings">Plans or layout drawings<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#plans-or-layout-drawings" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Plans or layout drawings are used to locate individual systems within the overall project and give an indication of the scale of the project. In addition, there may be drawings to show specific fixing, assembly and/or completion details. This is often the case where complex construction, lifting or use of a crane is required. These details may be provided in elevation, plan or both. They will then become part of the contractor's method statement when the project goes into the construction phase. Figure 3.6 is an example.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="schematic-diagrams">Schematic diagrams<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#schematic-diagrams" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Schematic diagrams, sometimes referred to as block diagrams, can serve many purposes, but are primarily provided to show the overall functionality of a system, including interfaces and operational requirements. This means they are intended to show a sequence of control and connection but not necessarily scale or actual positions in the wiring. For example, if a three-plate lighting system were drawn as a wiring diagram, the light would be wired before the switch even though the switch controls the light. A schematic would show the switch before the light as a sequence of control. Schematic or block diagrams are typically used to show distribution systems and circuits in large electrical installations having many remote distribution boards.</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251222-c6494217.jpeg" alt="img-185.jpeg">
Figure 3.6 Plan drawing of a building</p>

The City &amp; Guilds Textbook: Electrical Installations Book 1</p>

<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="wiring-diagrams">Wiring diagrams<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#wiring-diagrams" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Wiring diagrams are generally provided to show in detail how a system or collection of systems is put together. This type of drawing shows locations, routing, the length of run and types of systems cabling. These types of diagrams are sometimes mistakenly referred to when it is actually a circuit diagram that is required.</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251222-15bfcdf2.jpeg" alt="img-187.jpeg">
Figure 3.8 Typical wiring diagram</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251222-31539b2d.jpeg" alt="img-188.jpeg">
Figure 3.9 Typical circuit diagram</p>
<p>The City &amp; Guilds Textbook: Electrical Installations Book 1</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="key-term">KEY TERM<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#key-term" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Diagnostic: concerned with identifying problems.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="circuit-diagrams">Circuit diagrams<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#circuit-diagrams" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Circuit diagrams contain information on how circuits and systems operate. They can be provided as detailed layouts, although some information such as length of run may be omitted for clarity. In most instances, these diagrams are used for diagnostic purposes so that designers, installers and maintainers understand how their actions may influence a particular component or arrangement.</p>
<p>At different stages of work, the information on the drawings and diagrams is given in different levels of detail. The information becomes more detailed and accurate as the project develops.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="levels-of-drawing">Levels of drawing<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#levels-of-drawing" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>There are five main levels of drawing:</p>
<ul>
<li>sketch drawings</li>
<li>design and tender drawings</li>
<li>contract drawings</li>
<li>working or construction drawings</li>
<li>as fitted or installed drawings.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="key-term">KEY TERM<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#key-term" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Fluid: open to change or development.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="sketch-drawings">Sketch drawings<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#sketch-drawings" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Sketch drawings are often hand-drawn sketches to help the designer demonstrate ideas and interpretations. They are usually drawn in the early stages of a project when the scheme and designs are still fluid. As a result, they can be subject to multiple developments as every stakeholder is adding input to and potentially changing the scheme.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="key-term">KEY TERM<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#key-term" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Contractual variation: where changes to the original agreed contract take place and are documented using drawings and variation orders.</p>
<p>Sketch drawings are also often used at later stages of a project. Once the contractors have produced their working drawings, the designer may issue new sketch drawings for particular design details. These drawings become a contractual variation for that portion of the works and are recorded as a variation by the contract administrator.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="design-and-tender-drawings">Design and tender drawings<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#design-and-tender-drawings" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Design and tender drawings are produced by a designer to communicate the main design intent of the works. Although they are generally intended to be read in conjunction with the specification and other written documents, it is often easier to show the geographical scope of works by hatching out or blanking out areas not covered on a drawing.</p>
<p>Design drawings are usually first exchanged between designers to ensure co-ordination, and then to communicate items for consideration under the Construction (Design and Management) Regulations 2015 (CDM 2015) with other designers and stakeholders, including the client.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="key-term">KEY TERM<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#key-term" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Eradicate: remove or get rid of.</p>
<p>At the design stage of a project, the designer has a duty to eradicate hazards (whether notifiable under the CDM Regulations or not) where possible. A number of hazards may be unavoidable and these need to be pointed out to contractors. Residual hazards should be identified on the drawings or schedules. The Health</p>
<p>Chapter 3 Electrical technology</p>
<p>and Safety Executive (HSE) prefers residual hazards or hazard reduction strategies to be indicated on drawings.</p>
<p>The design drawings are then put together with any stakeholder comments and issued with the specifications and schedules as tender drawings. Details of the potential hazards and hazard reduction strategies on the drawings help contractors (tenderers) to understand any potential difficulties or additional requirements for completing the task safely. Allowances can then be incorporated into the pre-construction health and safety plan so that construction is carried out in a safe manner.</p>
