<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="contract-drawings">Contract drawings<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#contract-drawings" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Following tender award, the tender drawings usually form part of the contract on which the scope and detail of work has been priced. These drawings are usually re-issued, containing any contractual variations issued during the tender period. They are then referred to as contract drawings.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="construction-or-working-drawings">Construction or working drawings<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#construction-or-working-drawings" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Construction or working drawings are usually produced by the building services sub-contractor. They are usually drawn at a very large scale and contain additional information not given on the previous drawings (e.g. on fixings, expansion measures, etc.). This level of detail allows installation exactly to the drawing.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="industry-tip">INDUSTRY TIP<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#industry-tip" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Specialist shop drawings are a variant of construction drawings. They are normally produced so that manufacturers, suppliers and/or consultants can agree before manufacture takes place.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="as-fitted-or-installed-drawings">As fitted or installed drawings<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#as-fitted-or-installed-drawings" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>In building services, as fitted or installed drawings are normally produced by the sub-contractor or installer.</p>
<p>These drawings should represent what has been installed, but also contain information on any hazards and risk reduction strategies employed, and instructions on how to clean, maintain or deconstruct the works if necessary. They become part of a wider set of operation and maintenance manuals (O&amp;M).</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="using-symbols-in-drawings">Using symbols in drawings<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#using-symbols-in-drawings" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>It is important that drawings are easy to understand, and that includes the symbols used. British Standard symbols should be used wherever possible. Where no standard symbol is available, a specialist symbol can be used which is created by the person making the drawings. Whether the symbols are British Standard or not, they should be explained in a key or legend. In particular areas, such as lighting design, a more detailed legend specifying fitting type, manufacturer, source, output and catalogue reference number of products might be required to assist the reader to understand the type and quality of the component as well as how many are needed and where they are to be located.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="health-and-safety">HEALTH AND SAFETY<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#health-and-safety" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Pre-construction health and safety plans highlight particular hazards that may not be obvious to persons tendering or designing. It is the duty of the client or their representatives to highlight these using their detailed knowledge of these hazards. An example could be that a light is required on the outside of a building – but the building is perched on the side of a cliff, meaning the use of ladders is impossible. This specific and unusual hazard should be highlighted in the pre-construction health and safety plan.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="industry-tip">INDUSTRY TIP<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#industry-tip" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>On many smaller projects the general contractor usually refers to contract drawings as construction drawings (i.e. drawings of what the contractor tendered for and will install).</p>
<p>However, in building services engineering, contractually there is a considerable difference between a design drawing or a briefly amended contract drawing and a construction or working drawing.</p>
<p>167</p>
<p>The City &amp; Guilds Textbook: Electrical Installations Book 1</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251222-f8d03931.jpeg" alt="img-189.jpeg">
Figure 3.10 Examples of British Standard symbols for electrical installation drawings</p>
<p>Unless a project is very small and positions are obvious, the actual positions of items indicated by symbols have to be interpreted by the installer from scale working drawings. If the scale of a drawing is 1:100, for example, a 4 mm symbol if scaled up would be 400 mm across. This is obviously not what is intended and where four or five different symbols come together it would be difficult to position them correctly even at a larger scale of 1:50. Working drawings are normally provided at 1:50, often with dimensioned values, to allow the installer to interpret them more easily.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="key-term">KEY TERM<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#key-term" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Computer-aided design (CAD) software: specialist software for producing drawings, which has a library of symbols and features, such as walls and doors, that can be dragged and dropped into the drawing. In the days before CAD, a draughtsperson would have to painstakingly draw every detail on every drawing by hand.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="understanding-scale-in-drawings">Understanding scale in drawings<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#understanding-scale-in-drawings" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Most drawings are produced at a scale that allows the information to be readable. In order to determine an appropriate scale, it is essential to know the size of the actual object, room or building. Next, it is important to decide on the size of paper for the drawing. Very little detail can be communicated on smaller sheets of paper such as A4 or A3, but A2, A1 and A0 drawings need to be printed and copied on expensive specialist equipment.</p>
<p>Drawings can be created with computer-aided design (CAD) software and stored on networks, so they can also be communicated electronically. Electronic media is not, however, always practical on site and paper documents are still important.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="improve-your-maths">IMPROVE YOUR MATHS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#improve-your-maths" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Drawing scales are represented as a ratio. The first number of the ratio represents the measurement of the object on the drawing, while the second number represents its actual size. For example, on a scale of 1:50, a line on a drawing measuring  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>40</mn><mrow><mtext>&nbsp;</mtext><mi mathvariant="normal">m</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">m</mi></mrow></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">40 \mathrm{~mm}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6444em;"></span><span class="mord">40</span><span class="mord"><span class="mspace nobreak">&nbsp;</span><span class="mord mathrm">mm</span></span></span></span></span></span>  (4 cm) represents a wall 50 times bigger in reality, so the wall is actually:</p>
<p><span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>40</mn><mrow><mtext>&nbsp;</mtext><mi mathvariant="normal">m</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">m</mi></mrow><mo>×</mo><mn>50</mn><mo>=</mo><mn>2000</mn><mrow><mtext>&nbsp;</mtext><mi mathvariant="normal">m</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">m</mi></mrow></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">40 \mathrm{~mm} \times 50 = 2000 \mathrm{~mm}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.7278em; vertical-align: -0.0833em;"></span><span class="mord">40</span><span class="mord"><span class="mspace nobreak">&nbsp;</span><span class="mord mathrm">mm</span></span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span><span class="mbin">×</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6444em;"></span><span class="mord">50</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span><span class="mrel">=</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6444em;"></span><span class="mord">2000</span><span class="mord"><span class="mspace nobreak">&nbsp;</span><span class="mord mathrm">mm</span></span></span></span></span></span>  or  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>2</mn><mrow><mtext>&nbsp;</mtext><mi mathvariant="normal">m</mi></mrow></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">2 \mathrm{~m}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6444em;"></span><span class="mord">2</span><span class="mord"><span class="mspace nobreak">&nbsp;</span><span class="mord mathrm">m</span></span></span></span></span></span></p>
<p>Or to look at it the other way round, a  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>4</mn><mi mathvariant="normal">m</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">4\mathrm{m}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6444em;"></span><span class="mord">4</span><span class="mord mathrm">m</span></span></span></span></span>  (4000 mm) wall in reality is 50 times smaller on a drawing so the line length would be:  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mfrac><mrow><mn>4000</mn><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">m</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">m</mi></mrow></mrow><mn>50</mn></mfrac><mo>=</mo><mn>80</mn><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">m</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">m</mi></mrow></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\frac{4000\mathrm{mm}}{50} = 80\mathrm{mm}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1.1901em; vertical-align: -0.345em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mopen nulldelimiter"></span><span class="mfrac"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.8451em;"><span style="top: -2.655em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 3em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">50</span></span></span></span><span style="top: -3.23em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 3em;"></span><span class="frac-line" style="border-bottom-width: 0.04em;"></span></span><span style="top: -3.394em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 3em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">4000</span><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mathrm mtight">mm</span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.345em;"><span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mclose nulldelimiter"></span></span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span><span class="mrel">=</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6444em;"></span><span class="mord">80</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">mm</span></span></span></span></span></span>  Typical drawing scales frequently used are:</p>
<p>1:20 - where 50 mm on a drawing is 1000 mm in reality
1:50 - where 20 mm on a drawing is 1000 mm in reality
1:100 - where 10 mm on a drawing is 1000 mm in reality
1:500 - where 2 mm on a drawing is 1000 mm in reality.</p>
<p>Chapter 3 Electrical technology</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="industry-tip">INDUSTRY TIP<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#industry-tip" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Drawings may have to be reduced to fit on sheets of A3 until the full versions have been printed out, as many sites have easy access to an A3 printer but not to larger ones.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="paper-sizes">Paper sizes<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#paper-sizes" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>In order to understand drawings at different scales and reductions, it is helpful to understand paper sizes.</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251222-20f86d4c.jpeg" alt="img-190.jpeg">
Figure 3.11 The relationship between different paper sizes; all measurements are in millimetres</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="activity">ACTIVITY<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#activity" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>A wall measures 6 cm on a 1:50 scale drawing. What is the true length of the wall?</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="industry-tip">INDUSTRY TIP<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#industry-tip" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>It is tempting to view drawings using tablets or smartphones. Just remember, though, that viewing electronic drawings doesn't necessarily show them at the proper scale. This is where printed drawings are particularly useful, and potentially worth the significant cost.</p>
<p>The City &amp; Guilds Textbook: Electrical Installations Book 1</p>
<p>Paper sizes are based on proportions referred to as the golden rectangle. Size A0 is twice the size of A1, A1 is twice the size of A2, and so on through the range of paper sizes. The numbers increase as the paper size gets smaller.</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251222-a17015d2.jpeg" alt="img-191.jpeg">
Figure 3.12 The relationship between the scale of a drawing and the actual paper size</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="improve-your-maths">IMPROVE YOUR MATHS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#improve-your-maths" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>As the size of paper reduces, the width of one size becomes the length of the next size down. This is a 71% reduction in size. Reducing by two paper sizes – for example, from A0 to A2 – produces an overall 50% (70.07% of 70.07%) reduction in size.</p>
<p>It is important to select a scale that is clear at the paper size you intend to use. For example, drawings of a whole building of 30 × 50 m, at a scale of 1:100, will fit onto A1 reasonably well, leaving enough space for title blocks and additional notes. The layout of the building will be 500 × 300 mm on paper. In this example, it is possible to fill the paper further using a scale of 1:75.</p>
<p>Chapter 3 Electrical technology</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251222-6d6e63f0.jpeg" alt="img-192.jpeg">
Figure 3.13 Measuring equipment is vital when creating or interpreting scale drawings. The tape measure (left) shows actual size 1:1, the vernier callipers (right) measure accurate sizes of materials such as cables, pipes, and so on, whereas the scale rule (middle) measures distances to various different scales</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="reduction">Reduction<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#reduction" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>When drawings can be stored and viewed on screen, they are often only printed out for use by installers on site. Often paper copies are reduced in size for storage on A3 sheets. Then the user can quickly identify the drawing on paper before calling up the relevant drawing on screen. The readability on A3 will depend on the size and scale of the original. For example:</p>
<p>1:50 at an original paper size of A1 will become 1:100 on A3
1:50 at an original paper size of A0 will become 1:100 at A2 or 1:141 at A3.</p>
<p>The greater the reduction, the less readable the drawings become.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="3-how-electricity-is-supplied">3 HOW ELECTRICITY IS SUPPLIED<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#3-how-electricity-is-supplied" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Electricity is supplied throughout Great Britain by National Grid, which was formerly the Central Electricity Generating Board (CEGB). National Grid owns and maintains the high-voltage electricity transmission system in England and Wales, as well as operating the system across Great Britain. As electricity cannot be stored in significant amounts, National Grid is responsible for balancing supply with demand.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="industry-tip">INDUSTRY TIP<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#industry-tip" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>You can access more information about National Grid Electricity via their website.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="key-term">KEY TERM<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#key-term" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Supply with demand: producing electricity (the supply) at the rate it is being used (demand).</p>
<p>The City &amp; Guilds Textbook: Electrical Installations Book 1</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="electricity-generating-methods">Electricity generating methods<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#electricity-generating-methods" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Electricity in Great Britain is generated in a number of ways:</p>
<ul>
<li>nuclear power</li>
<li>coal-fired power</li>
<li>gas-fired power</li>
<li>renewable energy</li>
<li>other technologies.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="key-term">KEY TERM<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#key-term" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Base load: basic amount of electricity.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="nuclear-power">Nuclear power<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#nuclear-power" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The nuclear industry is responsible for generating a large proportion of the base load of electricity needed in Great Britain. Nuclear reactors are used to provide the base load because they cannot easily be turned on or off. The nuclear industry currently has 16 reactors.</p>
<p>Nuclear fission, which takes place in the reactors, creates heat. The heat is used to create high-pressure steam, which turns turbines coupled to generators to create electricity.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="coal-fired-power">Coal-fired power<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#coal-fired-power" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Coal is used as a fuel to heat up water to create high-pressure steam. This steam turns turbines coupled to generators to create electricity. Traditionally, coal-fired power stations were the primary source of power generation in Britain. With the decline of coal production, rising costs of importing coal and changes in legislation relating to emissions, this source of energy has been squeezed by other producers. In addition, coal is a fossil fuel, which cannot be replaced.</p>
<p>As a result of all these factors, large-scale providers of coal-fired electricity are now looking at more carbon-efficient schemes such as large-scale biomass to reduce their carbon footprint.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="key-term">KEY TERM<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#key-term" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Carbon footprint: a measure of carbon dioxide emissions from burning fossil fuels during the production and transportation process. This may be offset by the amount of carbon released naturally by decay. For example, biomass fuel is made from plant material that would release carbon dioxide as it rots naturally if left – so burning it efficiently as a fuel, and gaining use from it as a fuel, means the carbon footprint is reduced making it carbon efficient.</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251222-184643ba.jpeg" alt="img-193.jpeg">
Figure 3.14 The coal-fired Drax Power Station in North Yorkshire, England</p>
<p>Chapter 3 Electrical technology</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="gas-fired-power">Gas-fired power<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#gas-fired-power" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Gas is used to create steam that can be used to generate electricity in the same way as coal.</p>
<p>Demand for gas-fired power in Britain has increased as the demand for coal-fired power has declined. Gas is a fossil fuel, like coal, but it is now the largest producer of electricity in Britain.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="renewable-energy">Renewable energy<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#renewable-energy" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Renewable technologies account for an ever-growing share of British electricity production. These include wind turbines, solar photovoltaic panels, and so on. Building energy targets and targets for reducing atmospheric carbon dioxide levels mean that the renewable and green energy sectors are set to increase in importance. These are covered in more detail in Book 2.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="other-technologies">Other technologies<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#other-technologies" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Other technologies for producing electricity, including small-scale generation and hydro-electricity, represent less than 3% of electricity production in Britain.</p>
<p>Pumped storage systems allow hydro-electric power to meet demand at peak times. The system uses off-peak electricity to pump water from a low level to a higher level, where it can be stored. At peak demand times, the stored water is released through turbines to create electricity. The cycle can then begin again.</p>
<p>The table shows the proportion of fuels used in the UK to generate electricity, as of April 2017.</p>
<table><thead><tr><th>Fuel</th><th>Percentage of overall UK electricity production</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>Coal</td><td>2%</td></tr><tr><td>Oil</td><td>3%</td></tr><tr><td>Gas</td><td>41%</td></tr><tr><td>Nuclear</td><td>24%</td></tr><tr><td>Renewables</td><td>30%</td></tr></tbody></table>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="transmission-voltages">Transmission voltages<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#transmission-voltages" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Large-scale electricity generation is carried out by producing superheated steam, which is then released through turbines to drive large, high-voltage alternators, which turn the kinetic energy into electrical energy.</p>
<p>The energy output from the alternators is fed to transformers that raise the voltage from 20–30 kV up to 275 kV (275 000 V) or 400 kV (400 000 V). Transmission voltages need to be this high in order to minimise power losses through the cable (I²R losses) and keep cable sizes manageable.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="industry-tip">INDUSTRY TIP<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#industry-tip" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Such high voltages cause other issues, such as electromagnetic noise or interference. This is significant in Britain and Northern Ireland as the method of power distribution is predominantly overhead, with transmission lines suspended from tall pylons.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="industry-tip">INDUSTRY TIP<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#industry-tip" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Building energy targets aim to reduce the amount of energy consumed by a building. These are detailed in Part L of the Building Regulations (England): Conservation of Fuel. More detail on part L can be seen by searching the GOV.UK website.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="activity">ACTIVITY<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#activity" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>What is the power loss in a cable having 0.2 Ω resistance when:</p>
<ul>
<li>10 A is drawn through the cable</li>
<li>20 A is drawn through the cable?</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="key-term">KEY TERM<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#key-term" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>I²R losses: power losses caused by the current heating the cable and the heat energy being lost.</p>
<p>173</p>
<p>The City &amp; Guilds Textbook: Electrical Installations Book 1</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251222-eda8e221.jpeg" alt="img-194.jpeg">
Figure 3.15 An electricity pylon with insulators</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="key-term">KEY TERM<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#key-term" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Arc: in this instance, an electrical breakdown of a gas that produces an ongoing plasma discharge, resulting from a current through a normally non-conductive medium such as air.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="health-and-safety">HEALTH AND SAFETY<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#health-and-safety" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Electrical arcs are extremely dangerous to work around. Anyone approaching extra high-voltage cables could be electrocuted without touching the conductor. Intruders in high-voltage substations have died without actually touching the equipment, due to electrocution caused by a lightning-bolt-type shock from the equipment.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="activity">ACTIVITY<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#activity" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>What would be the losses for a cable having a 10 Ω resistance used to supply a community consuming 20 000 kW?</p>
<p>Pylons are large metal structures that keep high-voltage and extra-high-voltage cables away from people for safety and convenience. They also require inspection and maintenance because they are exposed to all weather conditions and a great deal of wear and tear.</p>
<p>At high voltage, electricity can be conducted through the air for very short distances. The higher the voltage, the greater the arc length can be.</p>
<p>In sites where there is high-voltage equipment, appropriate insulators are used to prevent short circuits between the site structure and the conductors that carry the current. The higher the voltage being handled, the greater the length of the insulators required.</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251222-e3ea8bd0.jpeg" alt="img-195.jpeg">
Figure 3.16 Insulators used on high-voltage equipment have to be very large</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="improve-your-maths">IMPROVE YOUR MATHS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#improve-your-maths" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="power-losses-in-a-cable">Power losses in a cable<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#power-losses-in-a-cable" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<p>A transmission cable has a given resistance due to its cross-sectional area (csa) and length (R). We could say that the cable's resistance is 20 Ω. If a locality served by the cable has an overall consumption of 1 MW (1 000 000 W) and the supply cable voltage is 400 V, the current drawn through the cable would be:</p>
<div class="math math-display"><span class="katex-display"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" display="block"><semantics><mrow><mfrac><mrow><mn>1</mn><mtext> </mtext><mn>000</mn><mtext> </mtext><mn>000</mn></mrow><mn>400</mn></mfrac><mo>=</mo><mn>2500</mn><mtext> </mtext><mi mathvariant="normal">A</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\frac{1\,000\,000}{400} = 2500\,\mathrm{A}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 2.0074em; vertical-align: -0.686em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mopen nulldelimiter"></span><span class="mfrac"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 1.3214em;"><span style="top: -2.314em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 3em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord">400</span></span></span><span style="top: -3.23em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 3em;"></span><span class="frac-line" style="border-bottom-width: 0.04em;"></span></span><span style="top: -3.677em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 3em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord">1</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.1667em;"></span><span class="mord">000</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.1667em;"></span><span class="mord">000</span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.686em;"><span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mclose nulldelimiter"></span></span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span><span class="mrel">=</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6833em;"></span><span class="mord">2500</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.1667em;"></span><span class="mord mathrm">A</span></span></span></span></span></div>
<p>So the loss would be:</p>
<div class="math math-display"><span class="katex-display"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" display="block"><semantics><mrow><msup><mn>2500</mn><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>×</mo><mn>20</mn><mo>=</mo><mn>125</mn><mtext> </mtext><mn>000</mn><mtext> </mtext><mn>000</mn><mtext> </mtext><mi mathvariant="normal">W</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">2500^2 \times 20 = 125\,000\,000\,\mathrm{W}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.9474em; vertical-align: -0.0833em;"></span><span class="mord">250</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord">0</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.8641em;"><span style="top: -3.113em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight">2</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span><span class="mbin">×</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6444em;"></span><span class="mord">20</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span><span class="mrel">=</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6833em;"></span><span class="mord">125</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.1667em;"></span><span class="mord">000</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.1667em;"></span><span class="mord">000</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.1667em;"></span><span class="mord mathrm" style="margin-right: 0.01389em;">W</span></span></span></span></span></div>
<p>which means the loss is greater than the consumption.</p>
<p>If the voltage is 400 kV (400 000 V), then:</p>
<div class="math math-display"><span class="katex-display"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" display="block"><semantics><mrow><mfrac><mrow><mn>1</mn><mtext> </mtext><mn>000</mn><mtext> </mtext><mn>000</mn></mrow><mrow><mn>400</mn><mtext> </mtext><mn>000</mn></mrow></mfrac><mo>=</mo><mn>2.5</mn><mtext> </mtext><mi mathvariant="normal">A</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\frac{1\,000\,000}{400\,000} = 2.5\,\mathrm{A}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 2.0074em; vertical-align: -0.686em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mopen nulldelimiter"></span><span class="mfrac"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 1.3214em;"><span style="top: -2.314em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 3em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord">400</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.1667em;"></span><span class="mord">000</span></span></span><span style="top: -3.23em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 3em;"></span><span class="frac-line" style="border-bottom-width: 0.04em;"></span></span><span style="top: -3.677em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 3em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord">1</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.1667em;"></span><span class="mord">000</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.1667em;"></span><span class="mord">000</span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.686em;"><span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mclose nulldelimiter"></span></span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span><span class="mrel">=</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6833em;"></span><span class="mord">2.5</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.1667em;"></span><span class="mord mathrm">A</span></span></span></span></span></div>
<p>So the loss would be:</p>
<div class="math math-display"><span class="katex-display"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" display="block"><semantics><mrow><msup><mn>2.5</mn><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>×</mo><mn>20</mn><mo>=</mo><mn>125</mn><mtext> </mtext><mi mathvariant="normal">W</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">2.5^2 \times 20 = 125\,\mathrm{W}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.9474em; vertical-align: -0.0833em;"></span><span class="mord">2.</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord">5</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.8641em;"><span style="top: -3.113em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight">2</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span><span class="mbin">×</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6444em;"></span><span class="mord">20</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span><span class="mrel">=</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6833em;"></span><span class="mord">125</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.1667em;"></span><span class="mord mathrm" style="margin-right: 0.01389em;">W</span></span></span></span></span></div>
<p>which is much more acceptable as a standing loss.</p>
<p>Chapter 3 Electrical technology</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="balancing-the-load">Balancing the load<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#balancing-the-load" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Electricity is not easily stored, so National Grid has to assess power supplies to cope with peak demand times as well as off-peak times. It is a complex task to predict load profiles, negotiate on- and off-grid time for generators and manage any export of electricity to or import from France and/or Ireland.</p>
<p>At a local level, substation transformers need to keep loads balanced as closely as possible across the three phases. If this isn't achieved, the transformer becomes less efficient. This is why three phase distribution boards should have their loads balanced as closely as possible over the three phases. Consumers may be fined by the distribution network operator (DNO) if their loading isn't well balanced.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="distribution-voltages-and-networks">Distribution voltages and networks<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#distribution-voltages-and-networks" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Once the electricity has been transmitted to the particular region in which it is required, National Grid depends on historical infrastructure to transform it from  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>400</mn><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">k</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">V</mi></mrow></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">400\mathrm{kV}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6944em;"></span><span class="mord">400</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm" style="margin-right: 0.01389em;">kV</span></span></span></span></span></span>  or  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>275</mn><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">k</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">V</mi></mrow></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">275\mathrm{kV}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6944em;"></span><span class="mord">275</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm" style="margin-right: 0.01389em;">kV</span></span></span></span></span></span>  to a distribution voltage of  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>132</mn><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">k</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">V</mi></mrow></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">132\mathrm{kV}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6944em;"></span><span class="mord">132</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm" style="margin-right: 0.01389em;">kV</span></span></span></span></span></span> .</p>
<p>At this point, distribution is handed to one of the 14 regional distribution network operators (DNOs) to manage and maintain. As the regions are quite large, high voltages such as  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>132</mn><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">k</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">V</mi></mrow></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">132\mathrm{kV}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6944em;"></span><span class="mord">132</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm" style="margin-right: 0.01389em;">kV</span></span></span></span></span></span>  are required to minimise losses. At these supply voltages, cables are still generally on pylons, although some of the infrastructure is buried underground.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="key-term">KEY TERM<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#key-term" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Load profiles: when and where electricity will be needed.</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251222-e61dd6c3.jpeg" alt="img-196.jpeg">
Figure 3.17 Transmission and distribution voltages</p>
<p>Because the switchgear and transformer areas are very large, voltages of  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>132</mn><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">k</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">V</mi></mrow></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">132\mathrm{kV}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6944em;"></span><span class="mord">132</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm" style="margin-right: 0.01389em;">kV</span></span></span></span></span></span>  are generally difficult to manage and maintain close to towns and cities. In order to make localised distribution more manageable, the voltage is reduced to  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>33</mn><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">k</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">V</mi></mrow></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">33\mathrm{kV}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6944em;"></span><span class="mord">33</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm" style="margin-right: 0.01389em;">kV</span></span></span></span></span></span> . In rural areas, supplies are distributed through cables on wooden, or similar, poles,</p>
<p>The City &amp; Guilds Textbook: Electrical Installations Book 1</p>
<p>the height of which can be as little as 6–7 m. These power lines run alongside roads and across fields. In urban areas the cables are usually buried underground or can be supplied on small overhead pylons.</p>
<p>These supply cables terminate at primary substations. These substations are large and unsightly due to the size of the switchgear they accommodate, so they are normally located in areas around the edges of cities that are not commercially sensitive, although some are integrated into city centres. Primary substations transform the electricity to lower voltages for distribution. Some industrial users want electricity at 33 kV, while other specialist plants such as chemical works use 132 kV.</p>
<p>Primary substations also distribute 11 kV or 6.6 kV supplies to ‘domestic’ transformers located closer to the consumers. These supplies are usually distributed via cables buried underground in towns and cities or on wooden poles in more rural areas. Many public or large buildings take their electricity at high voltage (usually 11 kV) due to the size of their demand, which usually has to be in excess of 500 kVA.</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251222-2ab562c9.jpeg" alt="img-197.jpeg">
Figure 3.18 A primary substation</p>
<p>Local transformers, which are usually 1000 kVA (1 MVA) or even 500 kVA, serve individual buildings or residential areas. These transformers can be smaller, especially when pole-mounted, where they are limited to around 200 kVA. From this point, electricity is supplied to the consumer either as a single-phase 230 V or a three-phase 400 V system.</p>
<p>Chapter 3 Electrical technology</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251222-94a1c542.jpeg" alt="img-198.jpeg">
Figure 3.19 Electricity generation, transmission, distribution and use</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="4-intake-and-earthing-arrangements">4 INTAKE AND EARTHING ARRANGEMENTS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#4-intake-and-earthing-arrangements" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>The type and rating of electricity supply to an existing installation, given by the distribution network operator (DNO), has a great bearing on the design of an installation. The type and rating of equipment, for example, and the methods of protection against electric shock are areas greatly affected by the supply to an installation. For new buildings, those factors will influence the type of supply requested.</p>
<p>Three factors relating to the supply are:</p>
<p>the number of live conductors
the maximum current rating
the earthing system used.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="live-conductors">Live conductors<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#live-conductors" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Supplies to small domestic-type installations are normally single-phase  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>230</mn><mi mathvariant="normal">V</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">230\mathrm{V}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6833em;"></span><span class="mord">230</span><span class="mord mathrm" style="margin-right: 0.01389em;">V</span></span></span></span></span> , meaning there are two live conductors (line and neutral). Where supply has two live conductors, it is described as two-wire.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="industry-tip">INDUSTRY TIP<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#industry-tip" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Always remember that a neutral carries a current so it is classed as a live conductor.</p>
<p>The City &amp; Guilds Textbook: Electrical Installations Book 1</p>
<p>Larger installations, which need more than 100 A, will normally be given a three-phase supply, allowing the larger load to be spread over the three phases at the substation transformer and keeping the system more efficient. This will be explained further in Book 2, Chapter 2.</p>
<p>The table shows the live conductor arrangement within the UK.</p>
<table><thead><tr><th>Type</th><th>Arrangement</th><th>Where</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>Single-phase</td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>230 V L–N</td><td>Two-wire</td><td>Dwellings, small shops or small commercial buildings</td></tr><tr><td>Three-phase</td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>400 V L–L</td><td>Three-wire</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>(no neutral)</td><td>Very uncommon as supplies to installations, as all circuits must be three-phase balanced loads</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>Three-phase and neutral</td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>230 V L–N : 400 V L–L</td><td>Four-wire</td><td>Larger retail outlets, larger commercial or industrial buildings</td></tr></tbody></table>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="key-terms">KEY TERMS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#key-terms" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p><strong>Maximum demand</strong>: the full load current of an installation assuming all circuits are drawing their design current at one time. As most installations do not actually do this, designers apply diversity.</p>
<p><strong>Diversity</strong>: allows the designer to use skill and experience to calculate what the full load may be, given that some circuits operate at certain times (e.g. lighting) while others operate for very short times (e.g. hand driers in toilet facilities). The result of applying diversity to the maximum demand is usually used to determine the supply characteristics.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="industry-tip">INDUSTRY TIP<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#industry-tip" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Typical current ratings of DNO service fuses are 63 A, 80 A, 100 A, 125 A, 150 A, 200 A, 300 A, 400 A and 500 A.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="current">Current<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#current" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Another factor that affects the supply is the current rating known as <strong>maximum demand</strong>. Most normal-sized dwellings in the UK will have a maximum demand less than 100 A and many houses in a road or estate will be supplied from a single substation transformer. Most commonly, house supplies are rated at 80 A.</p>
<p>Larger installations, which have a maximum demand over 100 A, will likely be supplied using three phases in order to spread the load over the supplier's equipment. Where a building or facility needs a supply over 400–500 A per phase, it will likely have its own substation transformer installed on site.</p>
<p>The maximum demand for an electrical installation will be limited by the rating of the DNO's service fuse so where an installation is to be added to, a check must always ensure that the supply has enough capacity for the extra load.</p>
<p>Where a new building is to be given a new supply, the DNO must be told what the proposed maximum demand for the electrical installation is so they can provide an adequate supply. This would be the job of the installation designer to provide this using <strong>diversity</strong>.</p>
<p>The DNO's service fuse will be fitted inside the electrical service head (cut-out) which is the enclosure the supply cable terminates into before the tails go to the meter. Most DNO fuses will be in a fuse carrier that is 'sealed' to the service head, meaning it can only be removed or replaced by a person approved by the DNO or the DNO themselves. The seal is a small wire that, with a special sealing crimp tool, locks the fuse to the service cut-out so it has to be broken if the fuse is removed. Connections to meters will also be sealed in this way. If you need to remove a fuse from a service head, you must always contact the DNO.</p>
<p>It is always important to know the supply rating, but it is not always easy to see what the DNO fuse rating is. In this situation, you should always contact the DNO who can tell you all the supply details such as rating.</p>
<p>Chapter 3 Electrical technology</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="earthing-arrangement">Earthing arrangement<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#earthing-arrangement" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>For earthing systems, the following letters are used:</p>
<ul>
<li>T = terre (earth)</li>
<li>N = neutral</li>
<li>C = combined</li>
<li>S = separate</li>
<li>I = isolated (referring to the connection of the source to earth).</li>
</ul>
<p>Five types of earthing system are defined in BS 7671:</p>
<ul>
<li>TN-S</li>
<li>TN-C</li>
<li>TN-C-S</li>
<li>TT</li>
<li>IT.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="tn-systems">TN systems<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#tn-systems" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>TN systems are configurations where the distribution network operator (DNO) provides the means of earthing. The two types commonly used in the UK are TN-S and TN-C-S.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="tn-s-systems">TN-S systems<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#tn-s-systems" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>A TN-S earthing configuration has only one neutral-to-earth connection, which is as near as practicable to the source (supply transformer). In low-voltage supplies, the consumer's earth terminal is connected to the metallic sheath of the supply cable.</p>
<p>Figure 3.21 shows that the earthing conductor is connected to the DNO's supply cable metallic sheath. This sheathing provides a separate route back to the substation transformer. Because the return path is usually a material such as steel, the DNO will normally declare a maximum external earth fault loop impedance <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><msub><mi>Z</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">e</mi></msub><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">(Z_{\mathrm{e}})</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1em; vertical-align: -0.25em;"></span><span class="mopen">(</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.07153em;">Z</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.1514em;"><span style="top: -2.55em; margin-left: -0.0715em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mathrm mtight">e</span></span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.15em;"><span></span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mclose">)</span></span></span></span></span> of <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>0.8</mn><mtext> </mtext><mi mathvariant="normal">Ω</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">0.8\,\Omega</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6833em;"></span><span class="mord">0.8</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.1667em;"></span><span class="mord">Ω</span></span></span></span></span>.
<img src="assets/images/image-20251222-00429f20.jpeg" alt="img-199.jpeg">
▲ Figure 3.20 TN-S system arrangement, showing the neutral-to-earth connection, separate supply cables throughout their length and the earth-to-neutral connection close to the supply</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="key-term">KEY TERM<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#key-term" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Earthing system: the arrangement by which an electrical installation is connected to a means of earthing.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="industry-tip">INDUSTRY TIP<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#industry-tip" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>TN-C is not generally permitted in the UK and IT systems are specialist systems. These therefore do not form part of your current course and no more detail is given below.</p>
<p>The City &amp; Guilds Textbook: Electrical Installations Book 1</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251222-b095e885.jpeg" alt="img-200.jpeg">
Figure 3.21 Single phase TN-S system, showing intake equipment (the supply company switch is not always installed)</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="tn-c-s-systems">TN-C-S systems<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#tn-c-s-systems" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>This configuration is now very common throughout the UK as it allows the DNO to provide a low-voltage supply with a reliable earthing arrangement to many installations across the country.</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251222-d0ef920d.jpeg" alt="img-201.jpeg">
Figure 3.22 TN-C-S arrangement</p>
<p>The TN-C-S arrangement is also widely known as protective multiple earthing (PME). This is because, on the supply side of the system, it relies on the neutral being earthed close to the source of supply and at points throughout the distribution system. There is also a neutral-to-earth connection at the intake of the installation.
