As the DNO uses the combined neutral and earth return path (known as a protective earthed neutral or PEN), the maximum external earth fault loop impedance declared by the DNO is <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>0.35</mn><mtext> </mtext><mi mathvariant="normal">Ω</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">0.35\,\Omega</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6833em;"></span><span class="mord">0.35</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.1667em;"></span><span class="mord">Ω</span></span></span></span></span>.</p>
<p>Chapter 3 Electrical technology</p>
<p>There may be a number of consumers using the supply cable. A rise in current flow will create a voltage rise in the PEN, which needs multiple connections to the general mass of earth along the supply route.</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251222-1424d7b4.jpeg" alt="img-202.jpeg">
Figure 3.23 Single phase TN-C-S (PME) arrangement</p>
<p>Although TN-C-S, or PME, is the most common earthing configuration in the UK, there are risks associated with it. If the PEN conductor were to become open-circuit in the supply, current flowing through the installation would not have a path back to the substation through the supplier's cable. Instead, current might try to follow an alternative path through the earthing system of the installation, which could include service pipework or the general mass of earth. This is known as neutral current diversion.</p>
<p>Unfortunately, it could be people who make that link between the earthed metallic equipment and the earth.</p>
<p>As a result, certain installations such as petrol filling stations and some construction sites and caravan parks cannot be supplied by TN-C-S arrangements. Even in domestic or commercial installations, some restrictions may apply, such as certain outbuilding supplies. Where this occurs, TT systems may be preferred.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="health-and-safety">HEALTH AND SAFETY<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#health-and-safety" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Never disconnect any bonding to metal pipes or other extraneous parts without isolating the supply first. Due to the supply, and what is known as diverted neutral current, there could be a voltage present on any earthed parts. If you disconnect the bond, you will receive a lethal current as you become part of the circuit.</p>
<p>The City &amp; Guilds Textbook: Electrical Installations Book 1</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="tt-systems">TT systems<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#tt-systems" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>A TT system is configured in very much the same way as a TN-S system in terms of the earthing of the supply source. However, a TT system does not provide the consumer with an earth connection. Instead, the earth for the installation has to be supplied by the consumer, usually by driving earth rods or burying metallic plates or strips into the ground to provide a</p>
<p>path of low enough impedance through the ground to give protection.</p>
<p>TT systems are usually installed either where a TN-C-S arrangement is not permitted (e.g. in a petrol filling station or in rural installations where the supply is provided on overhead poles) or where there is little or no opportunity to provide other types of system.</p>
<p>As the earth return path uses the general mass of earth, external earth fault loop impedance values  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><msub><mi>Z</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">e</mi></msub><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">(Z_{\mathrm{e}})</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1em; vertical-align: -0.25em;"></span><span class="mopen">(</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.07153em;">Z</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.1514em;"><span style="top: -2.55em; margin-left: -0.0715em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mathrm mtight">e</span></span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.15em;"><span></span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mclose">)</span></span></span></span></span>  may be very high where different soil types exist, meaning further shock protection measures such as RCDs may be required to provide automatic disconnection of supply (ADS).</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251222-ab69fc7e.jpeg" alt="img-203.jpeg">
▲ Figure 3.24 TT arrangement</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="industry-tip">INDUSTRY TIP<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#industry-tip" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>If the external earth fault loop impedance is too high for a conventional test instrument to measure, the consumer's earth electrode resistance is measured, which includes the resistivity of the soil around it. As this method does not provide a measurement of the earth return path  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><msub><mi>Z</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">e</mi></msub><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">(Z_{\mathrm{e}})</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1em; vertical-align: -0.25em;"></span><span class="mopen">(</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.07153em;">Z</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.1514em;"><span style="top: -2.55em; <p><img src="assets/images/image-20251222-f21f72bd.jpeg" alt="img-204.jpeg">
▲ Figure 3.25 Single-phase TT arrangement, including earth electrode and RCD</p>
<p>Chapter 3 Electrical technology</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="consumers-installations">CONSUMERS' INSTALLATIONS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#consumers-installations" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>An installation is made up of many parts and in certain ways to make them safe and functional. These include:</p>
<ul>
<li>Consumer's Unit (CU) or distribution board (DB)
circuits</li>
<li>earthing, bonding and protection</li>
<li>isolation and switching.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="consumer-s-unit-cu">Consumer's Unit (CU)<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#consumer-s-unit-cu" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Generally, the first unit in an installation, where the supply is split into circuits, is called the Consumer's Unit (CU). This may sometimes be referred to as a distribution board or DB and sometimes as a consumer control unit (CCU). The CU will have protective devices inside. They control and protect the circuits and could include:</p>
<ul>
<li>circuit breakers (CB)</li>
<li>residual current breakers with overload (RCBO)
fuses.</li>
</ul>
<p>The CU will also have a main switch, which can be used to isolate the entire installation. In a domestic dwelling, the main switch must be double-pole, meaning it isolates both line and neutral. In some three-phase installations that are part of a TN earthing arrangement, the main switch may be three-pole, switching the three-line conductors only. In this situation, the neutral can be isolated by a link in the CU.</p>
<p>Three-phase installations having a TT earthing arrangement must have four-pole switches isolating all live conductors.</p>
<p>The main switch in a CU within a house must be the type that is rated to switch the full load current. Some isolator devices which act as main switches are not rated for full load current and, if they are used regularly to switch full load, they will eventually fail.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="modules-and-ways">Modules and ways<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#modules-and-ways" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>When you install a distribution board or CU, the numbers of circuit breakers or main switches that can be installed are described differently:</p>
<ul>
<li>Modules - describes the number of components that can be fitted into the unit. For example,</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="industry-tip">INDUSTRY TIP<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#industry-tip" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>You may hear CUs called many different things such as fuse boards, DBs or distribution boards. Distribution board is often the name given to further units on the end of a distribution circuit. A distribution circuit is a circuit that supplies a distribution board whereas a final circuit is one that supplies current-using equipment such as lights and heaters or socket outlets.</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251222-ca7ebba6.jpeg" alt="img-205.jpeg">
Figure 3.26 Circuit arrangements in a typical installation</p>
<p>The City &amp; Guilds Textbook: Electrical Installations Book 1</p>
<p>a main switch controls both line and neutral so is classed as a two-module device. A circuit breaker is single-pole, so it is one module. If you needed a CU to control six circuits and have a main switch, you would need an eight-module board.</p>
<ul>
<li>Ways – describes the number of circuits that can be controlled. A six-way single-phase board could house six circuit breakers as well as the main switch. A six-way three-phase board can house six three-phase circuit breakers or 18 single-phase circuit breakers. It could also house a combination of the two such as 2 × three-phase (six ways) and 12 × single-phase (12 ways).</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="industry-tip">INDUSTRY TIP<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#industry-tip" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>It is good practice, within a consumer unit, to position the biggest load next to the main switch. This will reduce any possibility of overheating the busbar.</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251222-57b90bab.jpeg" alt="img-206.jpeg">
▲ Figure 3.27 A six-way distribution board with eight modules</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="split-way">Split-way<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#split-way" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Some CUs are known as split-way boards. This means that some of the modules can be protected by one RCD or switch and the others by another RCD or switch. Split-way boards should always have one main switch that can isolate all circuits. The advantage of split-way boards is that any fault on one circuit will only trip part of the installation protected by one of the RCDs.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="industry-tip">INDUSTRY TIP<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#industry-tip" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>It is common practice, when connecting a split-way CU, to connect the upstairs lights on the same RCD as the downstairs socket outlets, and the downstairs lights and upstairs socket outlets on the other RCD. That way, if one RCD cannot be re-set, at least a table lamp supplied by the sockets could provide lighting if the lights in that area have failed.</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251222-a36eaeea.jpeg" alt="img-207.jpeg">
▲ Figure 3.28 A split-way board showing three ways protected by one RCD and three ways protected by another. In total, the DB is 12 module</p>
<p>Chapter 3 Electrical technology</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="different-types-of-circuit">Different types of circuit<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#different-types-of-circuit" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>BS 7671 The IET Wiring Regulations state:</p>
<p>The number and type of circuits required for lighting, heating, power, control, signalling, communication and information technology, etc. shall be determined from knowledge of:</p>
<p>(i) location of points of power demand
(ii) loads to be expected on the various circuits
(iii) daily and yearly variations in demand
(iv) any special conditions, such as harmonics
(v) requirements for control, signalling, communication and information technology, etc.
(vi) anticipated future demand if specified.</p>
<p>This requirement demonstrates the importance of dividing an electrical installation into different circuit types to meet the different functions of a complete working electrical installation.</p>
<p>By dividing circuits into types based on location and expected loads, system reliability can be enhanced and cable kept to sensible sizes. This is because different types of load may require different types of protective device. The designer will need to assess the current demand, taking diversity into account.</p>
<p>Circuits can be categorised in the following way:</p>
<ul>
<li>Lighting circuits – provided in all installations. They are low-power circuits with an almost constant load when lights are operating. For more detail, see the section on lighting circuits below.</li>
<li>Power circuits – provided for socket-outlet circuits. They require larger protective devices due to the demand for current and, in most instances, require RCD protection due to the additional risk presented by the portable equipment connected to the socket outlets. For more detail, see the section on power circuits, starting on page 188.</li>
<li>Alarm and emergency systems – require additional protective measures, which include separating them from other circuits so that they are not affected by any faults on those other circuits. Further protection by wiring the circuit in fireproof cabling, may be considered.</li>
<li>Data and control circuits – normally wired in different types of cable to a low-voltage electrical system. However, the electrical supplies need more rigorous cabling and earthing arrangements to reduce interference between the different wiring systems and to meet electromagnetic compatibility (EMC) requirements.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="lighting-circuits">Lighting circuits<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#lighting-circuits" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Lighting circuits are generally rated at 6 A but can, in some installations, be rated at 10 A or 16 A. Consideration must be given to the type of lighting point used for higher rated circuits due to requirements of Section 559, Luminaire and Lighting Systems in BS 7671.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="industry-tip">INDUSTRY TIP<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#industry-tip" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The whole nature of electrical sub-distribution and final distribution for commercial installations has changed in the last few years. There is a demand for more residual current device (RCD) protection of final circuits, more metering and often more control to meet energy-saving targets.</p>
<p>185</p>
<p>The City &amp; Guilds Textbook: Electrical Installations Book 1</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="key-terms">KEY TERMS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#key-terms" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Composite cables: multi-cored cables, in which the cores are surrounded by a sheath providing mechanical protection.</p>
<p>Conduit method: the common term used when the circuit is wired in single-core cable. This could be in trunking or conduit, but it means that some cables do not need to be broken at the light point and can be wired directly to the point where they need to be terminated.</p>
<p>Depending on the type of wiring system, lighting circuits may be wired:</p>
<ul>
<li>three-plate – for circuits wired in composite cable such as thermosetting insulated and sheathed flat profile cable, commonly found in domestic dwellings</li>
<li>conduit method – for circuits wired in single-core cables within a suitable containment system.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="three-plate">Three-plate<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#three-plate" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Because composite cables limit the freedom to take a single conductor between one point and another, lighting circuits wired in composite cables require more joints within the circuit. These additional joints in the cable are called loop-ins and are usually in the form of a third live terminal within a light point such as a ceiling rose. As the rose contains a third terminal, the system gets the name 'three-plate'. Although it is traditional to install the three-plate at the light point, this is not necessarily the case in all situations. Some installers will install the three-plate at a switch, normally when the wiring in the ceiling is difficult to access such as in multi-storey flats or flat roofs.</p>
<p>Figure 3.29 shows both the connections, and that a two-core with circuit protective conductor (cpc) cable is used to connect the various points. Other light points can be installed on the circuit by looping off the ceiling rose. The circuit can be modified to allow two-way switching. Two-way switching is where one light point or luminaire can be controlled by two switches.</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251222-70cc06f3.jpeg" alt="img-208.jpeg">
Figure 3.29 A three-plate one-way lighting circuit</p>
<p>Linking the two switches using a three-core and cpc cable allows the circuit to be opened or closed from either switch. Two-way switches do not actually open and close, but divert the current from the common terminal (C) to either terminals L1 or L2. The two cables that link terminals L1 and L2 between the switches are called strappers. To allow the light point or luminaire to be controlled from one</p>
<p>Chapter 3 Electrical technology</p>
<p>or more further switches, the strappers need to be interrupted by one or more intermediate switches as shown.</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251222-b0dfc98e.jpeg" alt="img-209.jpeg">
Figure 3.30 A three-plate circuit controlled via two-way switches</p>
<p>With three-plate systems, it can be seen from the diagrams that cable cores need jointing to enable them to be extended to a further point. One example of this is the common connection between the two-way lighting that requires jointing in the intermediate switch.</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251222-65045827.jpeg" alt="img-210.jpeg">
Figure 3.31 Three-plate with intermediate switching</p>
<p>The City &amp; Guilds Textbook: Electrical Installations Book 1</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="industry-tip">INDUSTRY TIP<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#industry-tip" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Lighting systems wired in single-core cables can reduce the amount of jointing in cables as cables can be wired to the point where they are required.</p>
<p>More and more, three-plate wiring is being carried out at the switch. This allows a neutral at the switch, which could be required where home automation devices are used. This method also has the advantage of leaving fewer connections at the light point where specific light fittings are installed instead of ceiling roses and these light fittings do not have the provision for a permanently live connection.</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251222-701bc827.jpeg" alt="img-211.jpeg">
Figure 3.32 Two-plate intermediate circuit using single-core cables</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="power-circuits">Power circuits<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#power-circuits" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Power circuits generally supply socket outlets but may also supply individual appliances. Power circuits may be wired in two ways:</p>
<ul>
<li>ring-final</li>
<li>radial.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="ring-final-circuits">Ring-final circuits<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#ring-final-circuits" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Ring-final circuits are the traditional means of wiring socket-outlet circuits within the UK. The reason for their use was to provide a high number of conveniently placed outlets adjacent to the loads. The circuit load is shared by two conductors in parallel. This also assists in improving voltage drop as the conductors being in parallel reduce the overall resistance.</p>
<p>Ring-final circuits are able to supply an unlimited number of outlets serving a maximum floor area of <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>100</mn><msup><mi mathvariant="normal">m</mi><mn>2</mn></msup></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">100\mathrm{m}^2</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8141em;"></span><span class="mord">100</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">m</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.8141em;"><span style="top: -3.063em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight">2</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span>. Permanent loads, such as immersion heaters, should not be connected to a ring-final circuit. Ring-final circuits supplying kitchens should be arranged to have the loads equally distributed around the circuit. The plugs and fused spur units are normally fitted with 3 A or 13 A fuses.</p>
<p>With technology reducing the consumption of appliances and equipment, the need for a ring-final circuit is being questioned as they do have several</p>
<p>Chapter 3 Electrical technology</p>
<p>disadvantages. If a ring-final circuit becomes open circuit, this may not necessarily be detected by the user as power will still be distributed to all socket outlets. Circuit conductors may then become overloaded leading to the possibility of fire. Earth fault loop impedances and circuit resistance values between live conductors may also increase due to this, leading to increased disconnection times. Testing continuity of ring-final circuits is also more time-consuming than testing the continuity of radial circuits. Designers today are very likely to specify radial socket-outlet circuits with a reduced nominal rating of protective device due to these reasons. This also reduces the inconvenience of many socket outlets being lost due to a single circuit failure.</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251222-6239eebe.jpeg" alt="img-212.jpeg">
Figure 3.33 Ring-final circuit showing spurs and radial circuit showing branch</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="radial-circuits">Radial circuits<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#radial-circuits" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Radial circuits may be selected to supply multiple socket outlets for the reasons given above, and they are also chosen as a means of supplying individual appliances or dedicated fixed appliance circuits.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="wiring-systems-for-different-environments">Wiring systems for different environments<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#wiring-systems-for-different-environments" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Different types of wiring system are available because not all systems are suitable for all environments or compatible with all types of construction.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="domestic-installations">Domestic installations<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#domestic-installations" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>These installations tend to use twin and earth cables (referenced as 6242Y by wholesalers) or similar types of sheathed cable. This type of cable is ideal because it is compatible with the building products used and the finishes expected by the end user. It is also easy to install because it is flexible and can be bent and shaped into tight locations. Although other types of cables could be used, the relatively low cost of this type is also important in the domestic market, which is very cost sensitive.</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251222-f1414f43.jpeg" alt="img-213.jpeg">
Figure 3.34 Twin and earth cable</p>
<p>The City &amp; Guilds Textbook: Electrical Installations Book 1</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="industry-tip">INDUSTRY TIP<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#industry-tip" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Holes for cables in joists should be drilled as level as possible, to allow ease of drawing in. Holes drilled at sharp angles will abrade the cables and damage the outer sheath.</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251222-0c41c580.jpeg" alt="img-214.jpeg">
▲ Figure 3.35 Installation method when crossing joists</p>
<p>There are various types of containment systems suitable for PVC/PVC 6242Y wiring systems. However, these tend to be used in non-domestic circumstances (see page 194).</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="commercial-installation">Commercial installation<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#commercial-installation" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>There are so many different types of commercial building that this category probably includes the widest range of electrical installations. Commercial installations can be found in large converted houses, listed buildings, purpose-built portal frame buildings, multi-storey offices and shopping complexes with pre-tensioned concrete structures. In all these scenarios the installations need to be compatible with the structure and the finished layouts need to be either as cost effective or as sympathetic to the aesthetics of the building as possible.</p>
<p>Any, or all, of the following systems may need to be considered in commercial installations.</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251222-ec8331c9.jpeg" alt="img-215.jpeg">
▲ Figure 3.36 Prysmian FP200 fire-resistant cable</p>
<p>Supply distribution systems are usually found in the 'back-of-house' areas or common structural cores of commercial buildings where special finishes to the building fabric are not required. In such functional areas it would not be unusual to see steel wire armoured (SWA) cable with low smoke and fume sheathing, which is usually described as XLPE SWA LSF cabling.</p>
<p>Fire alarm and similar systems need to be wired in fire-resistant cabling such as mineral-insulated, copper-clad cables (MICC), a soft-skinned fire-resistant cable such as FP200 or, where enhanced cabling is required by Building Regulations, FP200 plus or similar products.</p>
<p>Chapter 3 Electrical technology</p>
<p>Example of dual supply - Mains with standby LV generation
<img src="assets/images/image-20251222-c1bcb27f.jpeg" alt="img-216.jpeg">
<span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">△</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\triangle</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8889em; vertical-align: -0.1944em;"></span><span class="mord">△</span></span></span></span></span>  Figure 3.37 Typical fire-fighter lift arrangement using 2-hour fire-resistant cabling (source: BSI)</p>
<p>Safety of life systems are fire resistant, usually for 120 minutes. They include FP600 ranges of cabling, which are tried and tested for fire-fighting equipment, sprinkler pumps, lifts, and so on. These systems are usually separated from other systems so that they are not affected by faults on any of the other systems.</p>
<p>For systems in public areas, it is likely that the installation will be in recessed conduits and that single cables will be concealed in the structure. Office developments often have raised floors and power is provided through floor boxes plugged into underfloor 63A busbar systems. With the rise in prefabrication of site services, modular wiring (often known as 'plug and play' systems) may even be used.</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251222-bf74f739.jpeg" alt="img-217.jpeg">
<span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">△</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\triangle</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8889em; vertical-align: -0.1944em;"></span><span class="mord">△</span></span></span></span></span>  Figure 3.38 The Kitemark is used to identify that products, for example fire alarms, conform to a particular specification or standard (source: BSI)</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251222-60defed5.jpeg" alt="img-218.jpeg">
<span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">△</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\triangle</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8889em; vertical-align: -0.1944em;"></span><span class="mord">△</span></span></span></span></span>  Figure 3.39 Prysmian FP600 fire-resistant armoured cables</p>
<p>The City &amp; Guilds Textbook: Electrical Installations Book 1</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251222-47b416c2.jpeg" alt="img-219.jpeg">
<span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">△</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\triangle</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8889em; vertical-align: -0.1944em;"></span><span class="mord">△</span></span></span></span></span>  Figure 3.40 Underfloor busbar and plug-in floor box arrangement</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="industry-tip">INDUSTRY TIP<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#industry-tip" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Modular installations are sometimes referred to as 'plug and play' systems.</p>
<p>Modular wiring is part of a larger modular construction manufactured off site. It includes pipework, ductwork and cabling. The modular construction is then brought to site and installed at an appropriate time in the construction programme. This reduces the number of skilled operatives needed to install the electrical system, as well as labour time generally. This often reduces costs. Modular wiring cannot be used for fire-fighting or safety of life systems as these must be kept separate from other systems.</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251222-cedf2bd5.jpeg" alt="img-220.jpeg">
<span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">△</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\triangle</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8889em; vertical-align: -0.1944em;"></span><span class="mord">△</span></span></span></span></span>  Figure 3.41 Modular wiring diagram</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="activity">ACTIVITY<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#activity" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Which section of BS 7671 specifically deals with agricultural installations?</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="agricultural-installations">Agricultural installations<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#agricultural-installations" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>These installations require the wiring system to be resistant to the elements, livestock and vermin. As there is an increased risk of damage, armoured cables, conduit and sealed trunking systems are used. PVC conduit is more suitable as it will not corrode.</p>
<p>Chapter 3 Electrical technology</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="industrial-installations">Industrial installations<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#industrial-installations" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>These installations are often located in harsh environments. Large amounts of SWA cable are installed on ladder racking along main routes from switch rooms. Where individual cables drop to serve distribution boards or other equipment, they are usually supported in baskets or trays.</p>
<p>Local wiring from distribution boards is normally fed to the relevant outlet through thermoplastic singles in conduit and trunking systems or through thermoplastic SWA cabling on ladder and basket arrangements.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="single-insulated-cables">Single insulated cables<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#single-insulated-cables" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Wiring systems using single insulated cables are common in industrial and commercial environments. The insulation is generally thermoplastic or LSF XLPE (low smoke and fume cross-linked polyethylene cable). These types of wiring systems are vulnerable to mechanical damage, so they must be contained in either complete trunking or a conduit system.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="installations-in-hazardous-environments">Installations in hazardous environments<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#installations-in-hazardous-environments" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Hazardous environments require robust cabling systems to prevent any possibility of ignition or triggering an explosion. The majority of large supply cables are SWA cables on ladder racking.</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251222-f1cc84b3.jpeg" alt="img-221.jpeg">
Figure 3.43 Ladder racking containing SWA cable</p>
<p>Where fire resistance is required, however, mineral-insulated, copper-clad (MICC) cables are used to provide strength, integrity and fire resistance.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="industry-tip">INDUSTRY TIP<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#industry-tip" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Cable basket is a lightweight system that normally clips together.</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251222-94440551.jpeg" alt="img-222.jpeg">
Figure 3.42 Steel wire armoured (SWA) cable</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="activity">ACTIVITY<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#activity" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Single core cables must not be drawn into a conduit system until it is completed. Why is this?</p>
<p>The City &amp; Guilds Textbook: Electrical Installations Book 1</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251222-25d712aa.jpeg" alt="img-223.jpeg">
▲ Figure 3.44 An oil refinery is obviously a hazardous environment with the risk of explosion</p>

▲ Figure 3.45 A petrol forecourt, although familiar, is still a hazardous environment due to the risk of ignition</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="containment-systems">Containment systems<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#containment-systems" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Most containment systems are not exclusive to a particular type of wiring system or installation.</p>
<p>Cable baskets can be used to contain many types of cable that have more than basic insulation, including PVC/PVC 6242Y cables, MICC, soft-skinned fireproof cables and, on a smaller scale, steel wire armoured cables. Cable baskets are often used for Category 5A and Category 6 TCP/IP data cabling.</p>
<p>Chapter 3 Electrical technology</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251222-e3ab293a.jpeg" alt="img-225.jpeg">
Figure 3.46 IT cables on basket</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251222-af5d2a3e.jpeg" alt="img-226.jpeg">
Figure 3.47 Methods of fixing baskets</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251222-0d0dbcc9.jpeg" alt="img-227.jpeg"></p>
<p>Ladder racking and tray work containment systems are predominantly for industrial installations, although tray work can also be used for smaller armoured cables and MICC and other soft-skinned cables. There are various types and grades of tray work to suit different cables and installations.</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251222-dfbed0a5.jpeg" alt="img-228.jpeg">
Figure 3.48 Returned flange trawwork</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="industry-tip">INDUSTRY TIP<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#industry-tip" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Trays can be bent, using a tray bender. Ladder is too heavy to be bent and manufactured fittings are used.</p>
<p>The City &amp; Guilds Textbook: Electrical Installations Book 1</p>
<p>Ladder racking is used almost exclusively for armoured cables and typically where large amounts of heavy cables are installed because it is strong enough to withstand the weight.</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251222-32f9e4af.jpeg" alt="img-229.jpeg">
▲ Figure 3.49 Ladder racking</p>
<p><strong>ACTIVITY</strong>
State the sizes (diameters) of metal conduit available.</p>
<p><strong>Conduit systems</strong>
In the UK, conduit systems are used in a number of ways. They include complete systems for single thermoplastic or XLPE cables with just basic insulation. This gives mechanical protection to prevent damage to the insulation and reduces the risks of shock or fault hazard.</p>
<p>Conduit systems can be made of plastic, galvanised metal, stainless steel or black enamelled steel. Where there is risk of damp or corrosion, PVC or galvanised conduit should be selected. Where strong mechanical protection is required, galvanised conduit is normally used.</p>
<p><strong>INDUSTRY TIP</strong>
Always try to draw all cables into conduit simultaneously, to prevent damage. Trunking systems allow easy access, to enable the addition of extra cables at a later date.</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251222-b777a19d.jpeg" alt="img-230.jpeg">
▲ Figure 3.50 Black enamel finished metal conduit and coupling</p>
<p>Conduit systems are also used in part for protection of wiring system 'drops' to electrical equipment, so that walls or sections of building work can be completed and the cables pulled in later.</p>
<p>196</p>
<p>Chapter 3 Electrical technology</p>
<p>Couplings are used to connect lengths of conduit. Where a conduit enters a box that does not have a threaded entry, it is terminated by a coupling and a brass bush to complete the mechanical connection.</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251222-9cd39062.jpeg" alt="img-231.jpeg">
Figure 3.51 This stop end box has been converted into a back entry box using a conduit coupling and male bush arrangement. In proprietary assemblies, the box would have a manufactured thread into which a conduit with a male thread could be screwed</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251222-dacc280e.jpeg" alt="img-232.jpeg"></p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251222-8e288e19.jpeg" alt="img-233.jpeg">
Figure 3.52 Systems of joining conduits including back entry boxes, which can be manufactured or fabricated</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251222-5fa4c597.jpeg" alt="img-234.jpeg"></p>
<p>Where two systems cannot be screwed together, a running coupling might be fabricated on site using two couplings, a nipple, a locknut and a length of conduit with an extra long thread. However running couplings create a potential weakness in the conduit and are best avoided.</p>
<p>Spacer-bar saddles are the most commonly used method of securing conduit. Distance saddles are used where conduit is fixed to uneven or damp surfaces. Where hygiene is important, hospital saddles are used to allow easy cleaning of the shaped saddle and around the conduit.</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251222-7a82a4ff.jpeg" alt="img-235.jpeg">
Figure 3.53 A spacer-bar saddle</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251222-ca2c7b3b.jpeg" alt="img-236.jpeg">
Figure 3.54 A hospital saddle</p>
<p>The City &amp; Guilds Textbook: Electrical Installations Book 1</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="trunking-systems">Trunking systems<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#trunking-systems" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>In the UK, most of the wiring contained in trunking systems is single insulated cable. However, trunking systems can be used to carry many different types of cables, depending only on whether they will fit. The systems are available in a range of shapes with different numbers and profiles of compartments. Standard earth fault loop impedance values are often less on site than calculated. This is because conduit and trunking systems, and their support systems, can work as parallel conductors in real life, but cannot realistically be calculated.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="industry-tip">INDUSTRY TIP<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#industry-tip" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Mini-trunking is just a small version of larger PVC trunking. It can be supplied with a self-adhesive backing, to allow it to be fixed easily to a wall.</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251222-d4fb6321.jpeg" alt="img-237.jpeg">
▲ Figure 3.55 A floor trunking system with a bend and jointing section</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251222-684dda2b.jpeg" alt="img-238.jpeg">
▲ Figure 3.56 Dado trunking in cross section</p>
<p>Dado trunking systems are often found in offices where there are large numbers of data and power outlets. They provide a multi-compartment system allowing data, telephone and power cables to be kept separate and distributed around the work space. They also offer flexibility in that the positions of outlets can easily be changed, to a degree, any time after installation to meet changing requirements.</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251222-0e21c05d.jpeg" alt="img-239.jpeg">
▲ Figure 3.57 Dado trunking profile</p>
<p>Chapter 3 Electrical technology</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="fixings">Fixings<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#fixings" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>The choice of fixings depends very much on the combined weight of the containment system and the cables in it. Often, many kilograms of cable need to be supported. For example, larger cable such as four-core  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>240</mn><msup><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">m</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">m</mi></mrow><mn>2</mn></msup></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">240\mathrm{mm}^2</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8141em;"></span><span class="mord">240</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">mm</span></span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.8141em;"><span style="top: -3.063em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight">2</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span>  steel wire armoured cable can weigh in the region of  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>13</mn><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">k</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">g</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">/</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">m</mi></mrow></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">13\mathrm{kg / m}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1em; vertical-align: -0.25em;"></span><span class="mord">13</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">kg/m</span></span></span></span></span></span> . So a simple fixing with a round headed wood screw and wall plug is often not enough.</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251222-b4874352.jpeg" alt="img-240.jpeg">
Figure 3.58 Simple wood screws and plugs are often not strong enough to fix containment systems and the cables in them</p>
<p>It is quite likely that specialist advice from proprietary fixings manufacturers will be required, along with confirmation from the structural engineer that the floor above can cope with the loading from below. Where the load is considerable, substantial fixings such as anchor bolts or anchor brackets will be required.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="determining-minimum-current-carrying-capacity">Determining minimum current-carrying capacity<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#determining-minimum-current-carrying-capacity" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Both BS 7671 and the IET On-Site Guide provide tables for the maximum permissible current-carrying capacity for a range of conductor sizes. These tables do not, however, take into consideration all of the factors that affect the ability of a conductor to carry current. Calculations therefore need to be carried out to determine the suitable cable cross-sectional area (csa).</p>
<p>The following procedures use information from the IET On-Site Guide as it provides a simplistic approach for simple single circuit design. More complex circuit design procedures are covered in Book 2, Chapter 5.</p>
<p>Before looking at the procedure for selecting the correct conductor csa, we will consider the factors that affect the ability of a conductor to carry current.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="conductor-insulation">Conductor insulation<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#conductor-insulation" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>It is the conductor insulation that governs the overall capacity of a conductor, as it is the weak point. Copper can carry large currents before it reaches melting point but the insulation cannot. General thermoplastic insulation has a maximum operating temperature of  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msup><mn>70</mn><mo lspace="0em" rspace="0em">∘</mo></msup><mi mathvariant="normal">C</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">70^{\circ}\mathrm{C}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6833em;"></span><span class="mord">7</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord">0</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.6741em;"><span style="top: -3.063em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">∘</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mord mathrm">C</span></span></span></span></span>  so it is this temperature that sets the current limit. It is assumed that the initial temperature of any conductor, and therefore insulation, is  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msup><mn>30</mn><mo lspace="0em" rspace="0em">∘</mo></msup><mi mathvariant="normal">C</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">30^{\circ}\mathrm{C}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6833em;"></span><span class="mord">3</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord">0</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.6741em;"><span style="top: -3.063em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">∘</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mord mathrm">C</span></span></span></span></span>  before any current is put through the conductor. As soon as current flows, the conductor temperature increases. The amount of current that will cause the temperature to reach  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msup><mn>70</mn><mo lspace="0em" rspace="0em">∘</mo></msup><mi mathvariant="normal">C</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">70^{\circ}\mathrm{C}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6833em;"></span><span class="mord">7</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord">0</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.6741em;"><span style="top: -3.063em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">∘</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mord mathrm">C</span></span></span></span></span>  is the upper limit of the conductor.</p>
<p>Table F6 of the IET On-Site Guide, or the extract on the next page, shows that a single-phase  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>4</mn><msup><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">m</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">m</mi></mrow><mn>2</mn></msup></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">4\mathrm{mm}^2</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8141em;"></span><span class="mord">4</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">mm</span></span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.8141em;"><span style="top: -3.063em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight">2</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span>  flat-profile cable installed in free air (method C, column 6) has a tabulated capacity of 37 A. This essentially means that, given no further influences, 37 A would cause the conductor's temperature to rise from  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msup><mn>30</mn><mo lspace="0em" rspace="0em">∘</mo></msup><mi mathvariant="normal">C</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">30^{\circ}\mathrm{C}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6833em;"></span><span class="mord">3</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord">0</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.6741em;"><span style="top: -3.063em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">∘</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mord mathrm">C</span></span></span></span></span>  to  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msup><mn>70</mn><mo lspace="0em" rspace="0em">∘</mo></msup><mi mathvariant="normal">C</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">70^{\circ}\mathrm{C}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6833em;"></span><span class="mord">7</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord">0</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.6741em;"><span style="top: -3.063em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">∘</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mord mathrm">C</span></span></span></span></span> .</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251222-8f726cf8.jpeg" alt="img-241.jpeg">
Figure 3.59 Anchor bolt fixing</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251222-827c1471.jpeg" alt="img-242.jpeg">
