<p>Chapter 3 Electrical technology</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="isolation-and-switching">Isolation and switching<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#isolation-and-switching" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>A typical electrical installation will contain many different switches or isolators. It is very important to know what the purpose of the device is in order to select the right type of device. <strong>BS 7671</strong> requires isolation and switching devices for the following reasons.</p>
<ul>
<li><strong>Isolation</strong> – a means of cutting off electricity to all or part of an installation to allow safe electrical work to be carried out.</li>
<li><strong>Switching for mechanical maintenance</strong> – a means of safely stopping a machine, equipment or appliance from operating in any way to allow safe non-electrical work that does not involve exposure to potentially live parts.</li>
<li><strong>Emergency switching</strong> – a means of quickly stopping a machine, equipment or appliance from operating in the event of an emergency.</li>
<li><strong>Functional switching</strong> – a means of controlling a machine, equipment or appliance such as turning it on or off.</li>
<li><strong>Undervoltage protection</strong> – a means of stopping a machine, equipment or appliance from automatically restarting following a loss or drop in voltage where sudden restarting could cause danger.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="selecting-a-switch-or-isolator">Selecting a switch or isolator<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#selecting-a-switch-or-isolator" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Before we look at the reasons for using a switch or isolator we need to understand the difference between them.</p>
<p>Isolators are rated for the current that can pass through them under normal load conditions but not the ability to switch that load. For example, a 63 A isolator could safely carry 63 A through it continually but it may not be capable of switching 63 A. If an isolator is to be used, equipment should always be powered down first.</p>
<p>This is because arcing takes place every time a device is operated under load. The amount of arcing depends on the type of load and some loads, such as inductive loads like motors, cause bigger arcs than resistive loads, such as immersion heaters. This arcing could destroy device contacts or, as a minimum, create high resistance to the contacts, which in turn creates excessive heat through constant use.</p>
<p>Switches, however, are designed to break the full load current without deterioration to the contacts.</p>
<p>If a device that is classed as an isolator is to be used, or positioned where it can be used by unskilled (electrically) persons, as a switch (on-load), then it must be de-rated, in accordance with the manufacturers' instructions, as a switch. This means that a 63 A isolator may only be rated to switch 20 A.</p>
<p>Isolators and switches are often categorised in the following way.</p>
<ul>
<li><strong>SP-N (single pole and neutral)</strong> – a device that opens the line conductor only but the neutral can be isolated by a link.</li>
<li><strong>Double-pole</strong> – a device that opens the line and neutral conductors.</li>
<li><strong>Triple-pole</strong> – a device that opens the three-line conductors of a three-phase system and not the neutral.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="key-terms">KEY TERMS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#key-terms" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p><strong>Switch</strong>: a device which is capable of opening the circuit under full load conditions.</p>
<p><strong>Isolator</strong>: a device used to open and cut the supply to a circuit allowing electrical work to be undertaken. May not necessarily be capable of opening the circuit under loaded conditions.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="health-and-safety">HEALTH AND SAFETY<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#health-and-safety" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>A skilled person (electrically) is a person who has the sufficient education and experience to understand the risks and avoid the hazards that electricity creates.</p>
<p>The City &amp; Guilds Textbook: Electrical Installations Book 1</p>
<ul>
<li>TP-N (triple pole and neutral) – a device that opens the three-line conductors and the neutral can be isolated by a link.</li>
<li>Four-pole – a device that opens all three-line conductors and the neutral.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="isolation">Isolation<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#isolation" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Isolation must be provided for all installations in the form of a main switch. The type of installation will affect the type of isolator used.</p>
<p>Suitable devices for isolating installations</p>
<table><thead><tr><th>Installation type</th><th>Supply and earthing arrangement</th><th>Type of device as a minimum</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>Dwelling and light commercial</td><td>Single-phase: TT, TN-S, TN-C-S</td><td>Double-pole switch capable of full load switching Must be rated to switch full load current</td></tr><tr><td>Commercial and industrial</td><td>Three-phase: TN-S, TN-C-S</td><td>TP-N device remote from CU Triple-pole within CU</td></tr><tr><td>Commercial and industrial</td><td>Three-phase: TT</td><td>Four-pole</td></tr></tbody></table>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="industry-tip">INDUSTRY TIP<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#industry-tip" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Local isolation is technically a myth as any device that is located within an installation, and is open to use by unskilled (electrically) persons, should be a switch, not an isolator.</p>
<p>Isolation may also be achieved for individual circuits by the protective device for the circuit.</p>
<p>In all situations, the device used for isolation must be capable of being secured in the open position. For main switches and circuit breakers, this is normally achieved with a padlock and, if necessary, a special locking device (Figure 3.69). Where circuits are protected by fuses, the fuse must be capable of being fully removed and it should be kept by the person who undertakes isolation. Devices are available which block off the fuseway meaning other fuses cannot be inserted while the circuit is securely isolated.</p>
<p>Whenever an electrically skilled person works on all or part of a circuit, the circuit should always be isolated at the start (origin) of the circuit.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="switching-for-mechanical-maintenance">Switching for mechanical maintenance<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#switching-for-mechanical-maintenance" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Mechanical maintenance covers many tasks carried out on a variety of different items of equipment. Provided that the work does not involve exposure to electrical terminals, it can be done by unskilled (electrically) persons. This work could include, among many other tasks:</p>
<ul>
<li>changing or adjusting drive belts on a machine</li>
<li>installing or altering the pipework to a gas cooker</li>
<li>cleaning air filters inside an air handling unit (AHU).</li>
</ul>
<p>For these situations, a device capable of switching full load current must be located 'local' to the equipment. Ideally, the device must be in a position where the person carrying out the mechanical maintenance can keep the switch under their effective supervision so nobody else can switch it on. Common devices for this purpose include:</p>
<ul>
<li>fused spur connection units</li>
<li>double-pole switches</li>
<li>plugs and socket outlets.</li>
</ul>
<p>Chapter 3 Electrical technology</p>
<p>If the device cannot be easily supervised then the device should be lockable – for example, a lockable rotary switch – to remove the risk of someone else switching it back on.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="emergency-switching">Emergency switching<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#emergency-switching" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Emergency switching devices must be capable of cutting off full load current. If a resident within a dwelling is concerned about the safety of an electrical system, for example following a major water leakage, they are able to cut off the supply easily.</p>
<p>In other installations where items such as rotating machines can cause a danger, emergency switching is normally provided by stop buttons. When installing stop buttons to a machine or workshop, consider the following.</p>
<ul>
<li>Stop buttons must be near to the risk where someone using the machine can easily reach it if they are in danger.</li>
<li>Stop buttons must not be capable of being reset from another place unless the reset is by a key switch.</li>
<li>If this is not the case, the stop button should latch in the off position. This ensures that the person resetting the circuit has to be where the danger happened so they can see that the danger has been removed before resetting the circuit.</li>
<li>Where the stop button could be reset by untrained persons, such as in a school workshop, it should be key operated.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="functional-switching">Functional switching<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#functional-switching" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Functional switching is probably the most common type of switch found in an installation. Functional switching allows equipment to be switched on or off as needed. It should be in a convenient place where manual operation is required. An example would be a light switch for a room, located by the entrance door to that room.</p>
<p>Where a room has more than one entrance, two-way and/or intermediate switching would normally be provided.</p>
<p>Functional switches may also be in the form of:</p>
<ul>
<li>timeclocks</li>
<li>passive infra-red (PIR) sensors</li>
<li>plugs and socket outlets (rated at or below 32 A)</li>
<li>switches on socket outlets</li>
<li>contactors</li>
<li>standard switches</li>
<li>push switches</li>
<li>switched fused connection units.</li>
</ul>
<p>Devices that should never be used as a functional switch include:</p>
<ul>
<li>fuses</li>
<li>luminaire connections such as plug-in ceiling roses</li>
<li>unswitched fused connection units</li>
<li>socket outlets rated above 32 A.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="industry-tip">INDUSTRY TIP<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#industry-tip" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>In domestic dwellings, the main switch can act as an emergency switch, which is why it is normally coloured red.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="key-term">KEY TERM<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#key-term" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Passive infrared (PIR): a sensor that detects movement.</p>
<p>The City &amp; Guilds Textbook: Electrical Installations Book 1</p>
<p>Where a functional switch is controlling discharge luminaires, like fluorescent fittings, the switch must be rated high enough to manage the surge current that happens when the load is first switched on. For example, a 6 A lighting circuit with fluorescent lights will typically have 10 A switches for this reason. Care must also be taken when selecting dimmer switches as some do not perform well when underloaded as well as overloaded.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="using-the-iet-on-site-guide">Using the IET On-Site Guide<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#using-the-iet-on-site-guide" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The IET On-Site Guide (OSG) is an essential companion to BS 7671, in that it describes technical regulations and best practices in an easier to follow format.</p>
<p>It is important to understand that using the information and tables within the OSG to design an electrical installation will always lead to compliance with BS 7671, but it may not lead to the cheapest design. This is because circuit design and selection tables are based on maximum circuit or supply values, such as external earth fault loop impedances (Zₐ) being at their maximum recommended values.</p>
<p>In reality, many of the actual values are lower, so detailed calculations of values may produce smaller cable sizes or longer permitted circuit lengths. However, considering the OSG is intended for single-phase dwellings or small commercial installations, the differences are relatively minimal.</p>
<p>Where a statement in the OSG links directly to a requirement in BS 7671, the regulation number is shown in the margin.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="structure-of-the-on-site-guide">Structure of the On-Site Guide<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#structure-of-the-on-site-guide" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The OSG is broken into 12 sections and also has 12 appendices. The details contained in each of these is shown in the table below.</p>
<table><thead><tr><th>Section 1</th><th>Introduction</th><th>This section details what the OSG is intended to cover (its scope). It also contains details relating to the relationship between building regulations for the different nations in the UK. There is a useful section (1.3) which details the information needed before starting work on an installation.</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>Section 2</td><td>The electrical supply</td><td>This section details the different supply arrangements, including:</td></tr><tr><td>• earthing arrangements</td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>• suppliers' equipment</td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>• consumer unit assemblies</td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>• separation of gas installation systems</td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>• portable generator earthing arrangements, including the need for certain arrangements to have earth electrodes.</td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>Section 3</td><td>Protection</td><td>This section gives an overview of all the different types of protective device and the types of protection they provide.</td></tr><tr><td>It details how these devices are used to comply with the requirements for Fault Protection by Automatic Disconnection of Supply (ADS).</td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>This section also summarises the requirements of Chapter 41 of BS 7671, including how to arrange an installation to provide ADS and the application of RCDs, why they are installed and what requirements they meet.</td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>There is a great deal of detail on how surge protection devices are used for protecting installations and equipment, including where they should be installed.</td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>With arc fault detection devices (AFDD) becoming a requirement, rather than a recommendation, in BS 7671, this section also contains information on their use.</td><td></td><td></td></tr></tbody></table>
<p>Chapter 3 Electrical technology</p>
<table><thead><tr><th>Section 4</th><th>Earthing and bonding</th><th>There is a difference in the needs for earthing and bonding, even though the cables used to have the same identification colours. Earthing and circuit protective conductor cross-sectional areas are simply sized in accordance with the size of the corresponding line conductor csa and this is reflected in Tables 4.4(i) and (ii). This section also gives details of where main or supplementary bonding is required, or situations where they are not required. Where bonding is required, tables in Section 4 give minimum conductor sizes for given situations. Where installations form part of a TT earthing arrangement, Section 4 also gives guidance on the earth electrodes used.</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>Section 5</td><td>Isolation and switching</td><td>Section 5 gives a summary of the requirements for installing devices to facilitate: • isolation • switching for mechanical maintenance • emergency switching • functional switches • firefighters switching. The most common devices installed are either functional switches and switching for mechanical maintenance, as these are most often used to control appliances and loads such as lighting control, socket outlets, fused connection units, or appliance switches. Isolation is generally provided at the origin of every installation and the origin of every circuit.</td></tr><tr><td>Section 6</td><td>Labelling</td><td>This section simply contains information of where any label, notice or chart is required, with some samples.</td></tr><tr><td>Section 7</td><td>Final circuits</td><td>This section is very detailed in circuit design procedures without the need for calculations. Table 7.1(i) provides minimum conductor cross-sectional areas (csa) for circuits based on circuit protective device ratings (In), circuit lengths and the installation earthing arrangement. This table is based on assumed loadings lower than the protective device, as given in the first table in this section which is not numbered. Also in this section, you will find other details relating to the selection and erection of final circuits including: • grouping of circuits • general final circuit requirements (socket outlet and lighting) • requirements for RCDs • choice of protection, including short circuit/breaking capacities of protective devices • installation conditions, including: • protection of wiring in floors, ceilings, and walls • segregation of circuits to minimise breakdown of insulation and the risk of shock (not for electromagnetic reasons) • separation from other services • high protective conductor currents and how these impact circuit arrangements • electrical supplies to furniture, which includes items such as kitchen cabinets, and display units in shops • additions and alterations to existing installations and circuits • the use of non-standard cables such as SY and CY flexible cables • wiring systems in escape routes.</td></tr><tr><td>Section 8</td><td>Locations containing a bath or shower</td><td>This section gives an outline, in simple terms, of the requirements of Section 701 of BS 7671, as these are one of the most common special locations. It is a special location as there is a greater risk of electric shock due to the environment, i.e. steam and humidity. It gives useful advice on how to arrange circuits and earthing or bonding in these locations to reduce the risks.</td></tr><tr><td>Section 9</td><td>Inspection and testing</td><td>This section sets out simplified general requirements of initial verification including the: • procedures and purpose • inspection checklist • general testing requirements • testing checklist.</td></tr></tbody></table>
<p>The City &amp; Guilds Textbook: Electrical Installations Book 1</p>
<table><thead><tr><th>Section 10</th><th>Guidance on initial testing of installations</th><th>This section gives a very detailed ‘how to’ guide to inspection and testing, including detailed explanations on how to conduct each test necessary on most installations.</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>Section 11</td><td>Operations of RCDs</td><td>This section gives advice on the need for RCDs to comply with BS 7671, including where they are used for additional protection, or to meet disconnection times, as there is a difference in relation to the maximum residual current ratings (I_{Rn}). This section also gives guidance on the use of the integral test button.</td></tr><tr><td>Section 12</td><td>Prosumers’ installations</td><td>This section introduces the new Part 8 of BS 7671. Electrical installations were treated as electrical consumers, as they used electricity from the supply. Now that many installations have methods of generating electricity, or producing it, they are classed as prosumers. These installations have electrical management systems that can cut the supply when enough power is being generated by photovoltaic (PV) solar cells on the roof or micro-wind turbines. Even an electric vehicle, plugged in and charged, can be used to feed in electricity, to be used by appliances, heating or lighting, when needed.</td></tr></tbody></table>
&lt;h2&gt;Appendices&lt;/h2&gt;
|  The appendices in the OSG provide useful tables and information linked to the sections and BS 7671.  |   |   |
| --- | --- | --- |
|  Appendix A | Maximum demand and diversity | There are two main tables in this appendix. They both give advice on how to apply diversity to the maximum demand. Diversity is the understanding that not all loads will be on fully all the time.
<p><strong>Table A1</strong> provides guidance on the application of diversity for a final circuit, based on the equipment it serves.</p>
<p><strong>Table A2</strong> provides guidance on how to apply diversity to an installation or a distribution circuit based on the connected final circuits, what they supply, and the type of installation.  |
|  Appendix B | Maximum permissible measured earth fault loop impedance | This appendix contains seven tables which detail the maximum permissible values of earth fault loop impedance when measured during inspection and testing.</p>
<p>When circuit impedance is measured, either by adding R_{1} + R_{2} to Ze, or by direct measurement using an earth loop impedance tester, the circuit is not under loaded conditions and therefore it is at a lower temperature. As a lower temperature means a lower resistance/impedance, the values given in the tables in this appendix are adjusted to suit this when compared to those in BS 7671.</p>
<p>The tables in Appendix B are adjusted to 80% of those in BS 7671.  |
|  Appendix C | Selection and type of cable for uses and external influences | This appendix gives guidance on the types of standard cables available and their particular uses.</p>
<p>It also gives guidance on the effects on cable insulation or sheathing with commonly used materials, such as expandable polystyrene foams, natural rubber grommets, or wood preservers, among other things.</p>
<p>This appendix also gives advice on protecting exposed metalwork against corrosion.  |</p>
&lt;h2&gt;INDUSTRY TIP&lt;/h2&gt;
<p>One reason users of installations did not formerly use the integral test button to test their RCDs every three months was because they didn't want to have to keep re-setting clocks. The recommended time between tests was then changed to six months, to coincide with the changing of the clocks between GMT and BST.</p>
<p>226</p>
<p>Chapter 3 Electrical technology</p>
<table><thead><tr><th>Appendix D</th><th>Methods of support for cables and wiring systems</th><th>This appendix deals with recommendations relating to the supporting of cables, as well as the supporting of wiring systems such as conduit and trunking. This information is contained in the following tables: • Table D1: spacings between supports for cables depending on their diameter and whether they are run horizontally or vertically. • Table D2: maximum length of span and heights above ground for cables spanning buildings or supports outside. These are dependent on the method by which the cable is supported and whether there are vehicle movements below. • Table D3: spacings for supports for conduits, depending on the type of conduit, the conduit diameter and if the conduit is run vertically or horizontally. • Table D4: spacings for support of trunking, based on the type of trunking, the trunking csa and if the trunking is run horizontally or vertically • Table D5: this gives the recommended radius of bends made to cables, based on the cable type and diameter.</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>Appendix E</td><td>Cable capacities for trunking and conduit</td><td>This appendix gives guidance on the maximum number of cables that can be drawn into a section of conduit or trunking, depending on several factors, such as the length of run, number of bends and diameter – or dimension – of the conduit or trunking respectively. The six tables in total are all paired together, so one table gives factors for the cables, based on their csa, and these factors are used to obtain a figure based on the total intended cables. The paired table gives a factor based on the maximum capacity of the conduit or trunking allowing for an air gap inside the wiring system. As an example, Table E1 gives factors for cables in short straight runs, and the paired table E2 gives the overall factor for the short straight runs of conduit. To determine how many 1.5mm2 stranded cables can be run in a 20mm conduit, you must: 1 Determine the factor for a 20mm short straight run of conduit from Table E2 – this is 460. 2 Now determine the factor for a stranded 1.5mm2 cable from Table E1 – this is 31. 3 Apply 460/31 = 14.83 Which means no more than 14 whole cables should be accommodated into this 20mm conduit. The other table pairs are: • Tables E3 and E4 for longer runs of conduit with or without bends. • Tables E5 and E6 for cables installed in trunking.</td></tr><tr><td>Appendix F</td><td>Current-carrying capacities and voltage drop for copper conductors</td><td>This appendix provides details on the procedure used to calculate the minimum csa of a live conductor for current-carrying capacity and voltage drop. This is an economical alternative to the table method used in Section 7 (Final circuits) of the OSG. The procedure based on the On-Site Guide tables and method is detailed earlier in this chapter within this book, on page 199.</td></tr><tr><td>Appendix G</td><td>Certification and reporting</td><td>This appendix gives all the relevant samples of documentation used when issuing: • an Electrical Installation Certificate (EIC) • a Minor Electrical Installation Works Certificate (Minor Works) • an Electrical Installation Condition Report (EICR). The appendix gives detailed clarification on situations where each document is issued, what further documents are needed to accompany them, such as schedules of circuits and results. The samples also show how they should be completed with samples for each.</td></tr><tr><td>Appendix H</td><td>Standard circuit arrangements</td><td>This appendix gives guidance on how particular circuits are arranged to minimise the risk of overloading them, and these are intended to be used alongside the tables in Section 7. Much of the information in this appendix is guidance, but if followed, will lead to compliance with BS 7671. This appendix also gives guidance on heights of accessories to comply with building regulations, and suggested number of socket outlets for dwellings, based on the room usage.</td></tr></tbody></table>
<p>The City &amp; Guilds Textbook: Electrical Installations Book 1</p>
<p>|  Appendix I | Resistance of copper and aluminium cables | This appendix is used to calculate circuit resistances including R_{1} + R_{2} values for circuits. There are three tables in this appendix, with Tables I2 and I3 complementing the main Table I1. The intended use of each table is:</p>
<ul>
<li>Table I1: to calculate the resistance of a circuit based on the csa of line and protective conductors, as well as the conductor material. The values are given in milliohms per meter of circuit at 20°C.</li>
<li>Table I2: this table provides factors that need to be applied to calculated values from Table I1 when undertaking testing of a circuit at a temperature other than 20°C to allow a comparison of test data to calculated data.</li>
<li>Table I3: this table provides factors to be applied to a calculated value of R_{1} + R_{2} from Table I1 when designing a circuit, as this table corrects the value to circuit operating temperature based on how the cpc interacts with the live conductors and the type of insulation around the conductors. It must be noted that a common mistake made is the application of all three tables together and this must be avoided as:</li>
<li>Table I1 and I2 are used when testing</li>
<li>Table I1 and I3 are used when designing.  |
| --- | --- | --- |
|  Appendix J | Selection of devices for isolation and switching | This appendix reproduces a table from Chapter 53 of BS 7671 which details the suitability of different devices for the application of isolation, emergency switching and functional switching. It is critical that this table is used in conjunction with the notes below the table, and with knowledge of the related BS and BS EN numbers relating to the devices.  |
|  Appendix K | Identification of conductors | This appendix gives guidance on the correct methods used to identify conductors, based on a conductor's function and circuit type, such as single-phase, three-phase, AC, DC, etc.  |
|  Appendix L | Degrees of protection provided by enclosures (IP codes) | This appendix gives basic information on the format of the IP code system, as well as the most commonly used IP codes and the level of protection each code relates to.  |</li>
</ul>

<p>ELECTRICAL INSTALLATION</p>
<p>CHAPTER 4</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="introduction">INTRODUCTION<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#introduction" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>When you are undertaking the installation of wiring systems and electrical equipment, it is important to make sure that you show good workmanship and adopt the correct standards right from the start. When working on site, you may see incorrect and unsafe practices.</p>
<p>In this chapter, you will learn:</p>
<ul>
<li>the tools that you are expected to know about and their functions</li>
<li>how to use these tools</li>
<li>some of the basic installation practices.</li>
</ul>
<p>This chapter will focus not just on domestic wiring techniques but also on some of those practices found in commercial and industrial types of installation.</p>
<p>This chapter also introduces you to the fundamentals of proving that your installation has been installed correctly by performing necessary tests on the installation before a live supply is connected.</p>
<p>This is essential as it helps to identify errors and omissions before putting people at risk.</p>
<p>Learning objectives</p>

<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="1-tools-used-to-install-wiring-systems">1 TOOLS USED TO INSTALL WIRING SYSTEMS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#1-tools-used-to-install-wiring-systems" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="hand-tools">Hand tools<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#hand-tools" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The majority of electrical installation work involves the use of hand tools. Hand tools can be split into two main groups:</p>
<p>T Level mapping grids are available on the Hodder Education website. These map the book to the occupational specialisms: 8710-353 (Electrical Engineering) and 8710-352 (Electrical and Electronic Equipment).</p>
<p>The City &amp; Guilds Textbook: Electrical Installations Book 1</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="key-term">KEY TERM<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#key-term" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Marking out: when measurements are identified on the walls and ceilings to ensure that equipment and accessories are installed in the correct place.</p>
<ul>
<li>those used in the preparation for installation tasks</li>
<li>those used in the installation of wiring systems and electrical equipment.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="preparation-hand-tools">Preparation hand tools<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#preparation-hand-tools" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>At the start of any installation work, it is important to identify where all the components will be positioned and where cables will run. This often involves a process of marking out.</p>
<p>The types of hand tool used for marking out include:</p>
<ul>
<li>Rule – this is used to measure distances and can be of either a rigid or flexible construction (Figure 4.1). The rigid type is often incorrectly referred to as a ruler, and the flexible design is often referred to as a tape measure.</li>
</ul>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251222-acd3cf91.jpeg" alt="img-265.jpeg">
▲ Figure 4.1 Types of rule</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="industry-tip">INDUSTRY TIP<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#industry-tip" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Chalk lines are used instead of drawing lots of pencil lines over a client's wall, as chalk is easier to clean off later.</p>
<ul>
<li>Level – when we install components, we only have a short time to make sure that they are installed correctly and look presentable. The client has more time to study the quality of our work! Therefore, it is important to make sure that all items are correctly installed. A level will enable you to see whether you are mounting items straight, both vertically and horizontally. However, it is worth noting that some buildings are not built straight and the use of a level can emphasise this. On some occasions, positioning by eye can give a better result.</li>
</ul>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251222-2ef89fde.jpeg" alt="img-266.jpeg">
▲ Figure 4.2 Level</p>
<p>Chapter 4 Electrical installation</p>
<ul>
<li>Laser level – this is a variation of the traditional level. It projects a line that can enable multiple items to be mounted to a common datum line. Not all construction sites permit the use of laser levels as they can cause issues with people's vision. Suitable eye protection must be used when using them.</li>
</ul>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251222-8d013e8b.jpeg" alt="img-267.jpeg">
Figure 4.3 A laser level</p>
<ul>
<li>Water level – this is used to ensure two points are at the same level, when they are perhaps on different walls or even in different rooms. Two water gauges are connected by a hose of any length. As water will maintain the same level, this ensures two points are at the same height.</li>
<li>Plumb line – this is normally used to see if something is installed on a perfect vertical line, but it can also be used to create a horizontal guide line. The cord can be coated in a chalk-like powder and then held firmly in place at either end. If it is stretched and allowed to snap back, it leaves a faint chalk line, which can be used as a reference for measurements.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="installation-hand-tools">Installation hand tools<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#installation-hand-tools" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>After the initial marking out has been performed, installation work can start. Sometimes, the installation process can be split into two tasks:</p>
<ul>
<li>fabrication and installation of containment systems</li>
<li>wiring.</li>
</ul>
<p>Fabrication and assembly of the containment system uses tools that are designed for cutting metals and plastics.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="hand-saws">Hand saws<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#hand-saws" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>There are various different types of hand saw used in our industry, and each has a different purpose. It is important to choose the correct saw for the job, as an incorrect tool can result in a poor installation.</p>
<ul>
<li>Cross cut saw – this is a general-purpose saw used for cutting timber.</li>
</ul>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251222-a852095e.jpeg" alt="img-268.jpeg">
Figure 4.5 Cross cut saw</p>
<ul>
<li>Floorboard saw – this has a specially shaped blade with teeth on both the straight and curved edges to enable access points to be cut in floorboards.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="key-terms">KEY TERMS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#key-terms" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p><strong>Datum line</strong>: a reference point or line from which multiple measurements are made.</p>
<p><strong>Containment system</strong>: conduit or trunking installed to provide a level of mechanical protection to cables.</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251222-bd389218.jpeg" alt="img-269.jpeg">
Figure 4.4 Plumb line</p>
<p>The City &amp; Guilds Textbook: Electrical Installations Book 1</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="industry-tip">INDUSTRY TIP<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#industry-tip" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>You do not need to get all the tools at once. Start off with the basic tools such as pliers, cutters, screwdrivers, knife and hammer. Later on, add a level, square, and so on. Tools are expensive, but if you buy good quality they will last a very long time.</p>
<p>Look on the internet for electrician's tools and investigate the range of options available to you. Take care to buy quality tools, as sometimes cheaper alternatives may not have the same insulation properties.</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251222-36f337d9.jpeg" alt="img-270.jpeg">
Figure 4.6 Floorboard saw (photo courtesy of Axminster Tool Centre Ltd.)</p>
<ul>
<li>Hacksaw – this is used for cutting metal, and comes in both junior and regular sizes.</li>
</ul>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251222-33ab139f.jpeg" alt="img-271.jpeg">
Figure 4.7 Hacksaws</p>
<ul>
<li>Coping saw – this type of saw has a very small blade and can be used for performing very precise cuts. It is generally used for cutting mouldings.</li>
</ul>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251222-7e17c948.jpeg" alt="img-272.jpeg">
Figure 4.8 Coping saw</p>
<ul>
<li>Keyhole saw (also called a pad saw) – this saw is used to cut holes that need to be larger than a drill bit, and is often used to cut holes in plasterboard for recessed pattresses.</li>
</ul>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251222-e286e415.jpeg" alt="img-273.jpeg">
Figure 4.9 Keyhole saw</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="key-term">KEY TERM<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#key-term" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Pattress: the recessed container behind an electrical fitting, such as a socket, sometimes referred to as a back box.</p>
<p>Chapter 4 Electrical installation</p>
<p>Like any other tool, a saw must be kept sharp and in good condition. Missing teeth can result in a bad cut or a weakened blade.</p>
<p>The number and shape of teeth change according to the purpose of each type of saw. The number of teeth on a blade is referred to as the teeth per inch, or TPI; the softer the material that is being cut, the lower the TPI.</p>
<p>When cutting through mild steel (such as conduit and trunking), the TPI must be about 24 to 32 – this is the type of blade fitted to most hacksaws. Missing teeth or a bent blade can result in the blade becoming jammed and then breaking, so it is important to inspect your blade prior to use.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="files">Files<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#files" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>When working with any metal, you should remove all sharp edges and any rough bits, which are generally referred to as burrs. As with hand saws, there are different types of file for different purposes.</p>
<ul>
<li>Hand file – normally a rectangular shape with one smooth edge. This smooth edge enables the file to be used in corners, without cutting both edges at the same time.</li>
</ul>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251222-cf4aa861.jpeg" alt="img-274.jpeg">
Figure 4.10 Hand file</p>
<ul>
<li>Half round file – particularly useful for filing internal curves.</li>
</ul>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251222-888b188b.jpeg" alt="img-275.jpeg">
Figure 4.11 Half round file</p>
<ul>
<li>Three square file (also known as a triangular file) – this file is in the shape of a triangle and is especially good for filing into corners.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="health-and-safety">HEALTH AND SAFETY<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#health-and-safety" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Never use a file without a handle. Check the files you use to make sure the handles are on tightly.</p>
<p>237</p>
<p>The City &amp; Guilds Textbook: Electrical Installations Book 1</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251222-cfef0012.jpeg" alt="img-276.jpeg"></p>
<p>Figure 4.12 Three square file (photo courtesy of Axminster Tool Centre Ltd.)</p>
<ul>
<li>Knife file – these are very thin and can fit into small gaps.</li>
</ul>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251222-c6cd94e4.jpeg" alt="img-277.jpeg"></p>
<p>Figure 4.13 Knife file</p>
<ul>
<li>Square file – normally used to file slots or key ways.</li>
</ul>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251222-abfdb8b8.jpeg" alt="img-278.jpeg"></p>
<p>Figure 4.14 Square file (photo courtesy of Axminster Tool Centre Ltd.)</p>
<p>238</p>
<p>Chapter 4 Electrical installation</p>
<p>Files are not just described by their shape or purpose. They are also identified by coarseness – some files remove a lot of metal but leave a rough finish and others remove less but leave a very smooth finish.</p>
<p>The coarseness is identified as a grade of cut and the levels include:</p>
<ul>
<li>very smooth (finishing cut)</li>
<li>smooth (dressing cut)</li>
<li>second cut</li>
<li>bastard</li>
<li>rough.</li>
</ul>
<p>As with any hand tool, it is important to make sure your cutting tool is safe to use. So, every file should be fitted with a handle which is secure and the faces should be kept clean with a stiff wire brush. Damaged or blocked teeth on the file will result in an uneven cut, which may cause slippage that results in injury to the user.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="wire-strippers">Wire strippers<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#wire-strippers" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Wire strippers provide a safe and reliable method of removing the insulation from a wire or cable without damaging the conductor. Wire strippers come in various designs, but the common principle is that the cutting jaws only cut into the insulating material and not into the conductor.</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251222-68a37fd6.jpeg" alt="img-279.jpeg">
Figure 4.15 Wire strippers</p>
<p>Wire strippers can be either manually set (by a screw or dial) or automatically set. Side cutters can also be used but these often damage the conductor.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="cable-cutters">Cable cutters<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#cable-cutters" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>There are a variety of different tools that can be used to cut cables, the most common being side cutters. Side cutters are probably one of the most important tools that electricians have in their tool kit. These are used for cutting cables to length, cutting sleeving and cutting nylon tie-wraps, for example. They work on a compression-force basis and are shaped so that the cutting point is along one side.</p>
<p>The City &amp; Guilds Textbook: Electrical Installations Book 1</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251222-6f733fcb.jpeg" alt="img-280.jpeg">
Figure 4.16 Side cutters (photo courtesy of Axminster Tool Centre Ltd.)</p>
<p>Depending on the size of the cutters, cable sizes up to  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>16</mn><msup><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">m</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">m</mi></mrow><mn>2</mn></msup></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">16\mathrm{mm}^2</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8141em;"></span><span class="mord">16</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">mm</span></span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.8141em;"><span style="top: -3.063em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight">2</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span>  can be cut easily. However, larger cables require larger types of cutters. These range from cable loppers, up to hydraulic, manual pump cutters for cables up to  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>300</mn><msup><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">m</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">m</mi></mrow><mn>2</mn></msup></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">300\mathrm{mm}^2</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8141em;"></span><span class="mord">300</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">mm</span></span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.8141em;"><span style="top: -3.063em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight">2</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span> .</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="screwdrivers">Screwdrivers<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#screwdrivers" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>An electrician will use a selection of different sized screwdrivers. They will all have one thing in common in that they will all be of approved standards.</p>
<p>The most common screwdrivers used include:</p>
<ul>
<li>terminal (3–3.5 mm)</li>
<li>large flat (4–5 mm)</li>
<li>pozi-drive (PZ2)</li>
<li>and, more recently, a consumer unit screwdriver.</li>
</ul>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251222-02192191.jpeg" alt="img-281.jpeg">
Figure 4.17 Electrician's screwdrivers</p>
<p>Chapter 4 Electrical installation</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="electrician-s-knife">Electrician's knife<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#electrician-s-knife" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>The electrician's knife is available in various arrangements but usually has a folding blade. The most common use of the electrician's knife is for stripping the outer sheaths of some cables; the blade generally has a shaped section to aid the removal of certain cable sheaths, such as on armoured or some types of mineral-insulated (MI) cables.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="health-and-safety">HEALTH AND SAFETY<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#health-and-safety" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>It is dangerous to use a disposable knife blade when stripping cables as the blade can break, creating sharp shards.</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251222-fc97602e.jpeg" alt="img-282.jpeg">
Figure 4.18 Electrician's knives (photo courtesy of Axminster Tool Centre Ltd.)</p>
<p>An electrician's knife should never be used for stripping the insulation from cables or for cutting cables to length. It should always be used pointing away from the body.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="specialist-tools">Specialist tools<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#specialist-tools" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Certain activities require tools that are specifically designed for the task and are only used for this task. For example, when working with steel conduit, it is necessary to use stocks and dies, along with reamers and engineer's squares. These and other tools are explained later in the chapter.</p>
<p>The City &amp; Guilds Textbook: Electrical Installations Book 1</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251222-bea9f43a.jpeg" alt="img-283.jpeg"></p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251222-59f70398.jpeg" alt="img-284.jpeg"></p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251222-fff0c3b0.jpeg" alt="img-285.jpeg"></p>

Figure 4.19 A selection of electrical tools</p>
<p>Chapter 4 Electrical installation</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="wrenches">Wrenches<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#wrenches" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>A wrench is used to tighten nuts and/or bolts. They are often used in place of spanners, as one tool can be used on a variety of different sizes of nuts and bolts.</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251222-24ed4b6d.jpeg" alt="img-289.jpeg">
Figure 4.20 A selection of wrenches</p>
<p>Some typical wrenches used in our industry include:</p>
<ul>
<li>Pipe wrenches – the jaws on these wrenches are designed to fit around a selection of different nuts and bolts, and so they are ideal for tightening lock nuts and cable glands.</li>
<li>Footprints – some larger cables require glands that are in excess of 60 mm in diameter and these are often too big for a pipe wrench. Footprints can be set to larger sizes and are well suited for tightening these larger glands and nuts.</li>
<li>Bush spanners – when installing metal conduit, it is important to ensure that all connections are tight. Some of the assembly components are called bushes. These are often small and in positions that are not accessible to pipe wrenches and footprints. A bush spanner is designed to fit into these small areas, enabling the bush to be correctly tightened.</li>
</ul>
<p>It is important to select the correct wrench for the job and to set it to the correct size. Incorrect use can damage the nut or bolt being tightened.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="industry-tip">INDUSTRY TIP<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#industry-tip" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Some tool suppliers offer special deals to students. Ask at your centre if such a deal exists. It could save you a lot of money.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="industry-tip">INDUSTRY TIP<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#industry-tip" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>All adjustable spanners (wrenches) may mark the nuts they tighten as they are not such a good fit as a spanner.</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251222-b0039c44.jpeg" alt="img-290.jpeg">
Figure 4.21 Bush spanner</p>
<p>The City &amp; Guilds Textbook: Electrical Installations Book 1</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="industry-tip">INDUSTRY TIP<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#industry-tip" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Hammers are still often referred to in imperial weights such as pounds and ounces. 4 ounces is 110 g and 32 ounces is 907 g.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="hammers">Hammers<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#hammers" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>There are several different types of hammer that can be used in our industry and these include:</p>
<ul>
<li>Claw hammer – this is the electrician’s general-purpose hammer. It is used for driving and removing nails and tacks. It typically weighs between 16 and 28 ounces.</li>
<li>Ball peen (or pein) hammer – this hammer is typically used when bending and forming metal. It weighs between 4 and 32 ounces.</li>
<li>Engineer’s hammer – sometimes referred to as a baby sledgehammer, this can be used during light demolition work. It typically weighs from one to five pounds.</li>
</ul>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251222-f15781f4.jpeg" alt="img-291.jpeg">
Figure 4.22 A selection of hammers</p>
<p>The most common mistake that people make when using a hammer is that they do not grip it at the correct place. The handle is designed to be gripped at a point furthest away from the head of the hammer, enabling the full force to be applied.</p>
<p>If a hammer has a split or damaged handle, or shows signs of damage to the head, it should not be used – it should be replaced immediately. Never hit the heads of two hammers together as this may result in parts breaking off.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="industry-tip">INDUSTRY TIP<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#industry-tip" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Under the Provision and Use of Work Equipment Regulations (1998) your employer has a duty to ensure all tools provided to perform your job are maintained in a safe manner.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="basic-safety">Basic safety<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#basic-safety" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>When using any hand tool it is important to ensure that you take basic safety requirements into account. Ask yourself these questions:</p>
<ul>
<li>Is the tool in good condition?</li>
<li>Is the tool sharp?</li>
<li>Is the tool the correct one for the job?</li>
<li>Do I know how to use the tool?</li>
<li>Is the tool safe to be used?</li>
</ul>
<p>The key point when using any tool is to check to see if it is safe to be used. A cold chisel that has started to bend over where it is hit with the hammer is displaying ‘mushrooming’. These bent-over pieces can break off, cutting your hand or, even worse, ending up in your eye.</p>
<p>244</p>
<p>Chapter 4 Electrical installation</p>
<p>Blunt tools require more force to perform cutting functions – which can lead to dangerous slips. If a saw blade is blunt, you may be tempted to apply more pressure, which in the case of a hacksaw could shatter the blade. The blade may also become hot, with the potential to burn you.</p>
<p>Using a screwdriver as a chisel or lever is not a correct use of the tool. The shaft of the screwdriver may snap or slip. You could also damage the handle, so that next time you use the screwdriver it ends up sticking into your hand.</p>
<p>Buying cheap tools can be a false economy; cheap tools tend to break easily, whereas good-quality tools often last a lifetime if looked after and used properly.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="power-tools">Power tools<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#power-tools" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Though most tasks can be performed using hand tools, the work is often performed more quickly with <strong>power tools</strong>.</p>
<p>Power tools can be hand held or can be larger machines that are mounted on a workbench or bolted to the ground.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="safety-checks-for-power-tools">Safety checks for power tools<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#safety-checks-for-power-tools" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>When using power tools it is important to make additional safety checks to those already mentioned in connection with hand tools.</p>
<p>The use of electrical energy adds extra risk. Additional checks should include these questions:</p>
<ul>
<li>Is the item of equipment correct for the job?</li>
<li>Is the casing of the tool without damage?</li>
<li>Is the flex of the tool (if fitted) undamaged?</li>
<li>Is the plug (if fitted) undamaged?</li>
<li>Is the start/stop button in good condition?</li>
<li>Are all guards in place (where fitted)?</li>
<li>Is there a means of stopping the tool in case of emergency?</li>
</ul>
<p>If you answer 'no' to any of these questions, the tool should not be used and the person responsible, such as your supervisor, should be notified immediately.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="drills">Drills<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#drills" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>There are several different types of drill that can be used in our industry for different tasks. It is important to recognise the best drill for the job, making sure it is safe to use.</p>
<p>All drills have some common parts, such as a <strong>chuck</strong> and a <strong>bit</strong> (with some requiring a special tool called a chuck key to tighten and loosen the jaws of the chuck). In the past, the chuck key was often lost or misplaced, so some modern drills have a chuck that can be tightened by hand without the use of a special tool or key. It is important to make sure that, when securing a bit in the chuck, it is positioned straight and in the centre so that it does not wobble or come loose. For more about drill bits see pages 247–49.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="health-and-safety">HEALTH AND SAFETY<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#health-and-safety" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<p>Any tool is only as safe as the person using it. Using the wrong tool for the job increases the risk of injury and damage.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="key-terms">KEY TERMS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#key-terms" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<p><strong>Power tool</strong>: any tool that uses electrical energy in order to work. The electrical energy can be obtained from batteries or from a mains supply.</p>
<p><strong>Chuck</strong>: the part of the drill used for holding the drill bit.</p>
<p><strong>Bit</strong>: the part of the drill that does the cutting.</p>
<p>245</p>
<p>The City &amp; Guilds Textbook: Electrical Installations Book 1</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="key-term">KEY TERM<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#key-term" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Swarf: chips and curly turnings of excess metal and wood produced when drilling.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="electric-hand-drill">Electric hand drill<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#electric-hand-drill" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>This is the most common type of drill and can be mains powered from either 230 V or 110 V AC, as well as being available in battery form. This drill is probably the most versatile as it is a general-purpose tool.</p>
<p>The hand drill, as its name suggests, is portable and can be used in most positions. Consideration should be given to dust and swarf that may be generated during the drilling process – make sure suitable precautions are taken to minimise risk of injury. Battery-powered hand drills can also be used as electric screwdrivers, as long as they have a torque setting or clutch that slips and stops rotation once the screw is tight.</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251222-e264d614.jpeg" alt="img-292.jpeg">
▲ Figure 4.23 Electric hand drills</p>
