<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="industry-tip">INDUSTRY TIP<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#industry-tip" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Only use drill bits that are sharp. Make sure the drill is turning in the right direction.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="right-angled-electric-drill">Right-angled electric drill<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#right-angled-electric-drill" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The right-angled electric drill is a variation of the electric hand drill. This tool is often used when making alterations to an existing property and new holes need to be cut through the joists. The spacing of the joists often prevents access by a regular hand drill and so a right-angled drill is required.</p>
<p>The chuck is positioned at right angles to the rest of the body of the drill, so the space required for access is only that of the chuck and drill bit. Generally, this is less than the spacing of the joists.</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251222-313fd80d.jpeg" alt="img-293.jpeg">
▲ Figure 4.24 Using a right-angled drill</p>
<p>Chapter 4 Electrical installation</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="hammer-drill">Hammer drill<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#hammer-drill" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>For drilling into masonry walls or floors and ceilings, cutting is more efficient when accompanied by a controlled impact. This is achieved by the use of a hammer-action drill. Some electric hand drills have this option built in and it can be easily selected.</p>
<p>When in hammer mode, the chuck is subjected to a set level of vibration which is transmitted to the drill bit. This helps the drill knock the bit into the masonry. This function must not be used when drilling through timber or steel as it will damage the drill bit as well as the material. Masonry drill bits (for use in hammer mode) are designed and built to withstand these stresses.</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251222-953cc517.jpeg" alt="img-294.jpeg">
Figure 4.25 Hammer drill</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="pillar-drill">Pillar drill<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#pillar-drill" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Where drilling needs to be very accurate and consistent, a pillar drill is often used. The pillar drill has an adjustable table which can be positioned at various heights. The table is used to clamp the material to be drilled so that it does not move, so a hole can be drilled in a precise location.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="drill-bits">Drill bits<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#drill-bits" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>A drill bit is the item that is positioned in the chuck to perform the cutting process. Bits come in various shapes and sizes according to the material to be cut. When drill bits are used for cutting the wrong material they can become blunt, very hot and damaged.</p>
<p>When a drill bit becomes blunt, it is tempting to press down harder on the drill to make the bit cut. This increases the risk of injury – the bit could shatter. In addition, a blunt drill bit can become so hot that it melts, further increasing the risk of injury.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="industry-tip">INDUSTRY TIP<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#industry-tip" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>SDS drills are extremely powerful and used when extra power is required, for heavy duty jobs. They are supplied with special bits for drilling and cutting concrete. The actual meaning of SDS is disputed and you can find a variety of explanations. The original term was German.</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251222-4c27e0ce.jpeg" alt="img-295.jpeg">
Figure 4.26 Pillar drill (photo courtesy of Axminster Tool Centre Ltd.)</p>
<p>The City &amp; Guilds Textbook: Electrical Installations Book 1</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251222-f5cb2e13.jpeg" alt="img-296.jpeg">
Figure 4.27 Note the special design of the brad point drill bit that feeds cut wood away from the drill bit point</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251222-7f97ac1f.jpeg" alt="img-297.jpeg">
Figure 4.28 Hole saws for cutting holes of different sizes</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="key-term">KEY TERM<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#key-term" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>HSS: high-speed steel.</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251222-0c75799a.jpeg" alt="img-298.jpeg">
Figure 4.29 Note the design of the HSS drill bit, which minimises friction when cutting</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251222-8461a4b4.jpeg" alt="img-299.jpeg">
Figure 4.30 Note the special design of the masonry drill bit, which pushes masonry dust away from the drill bit</p>
<p>All drill bits are designed to cut in a clockwise direction. If a reversible drill is used, care should be taken to ensure correct rotation. A drill bit should never be run in reverse as this will damage it.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="brad-point-bit">Brad point bit<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#brad-point-bit" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Brad point drill bits are specifically designed for drilling into wood and have a cutting face that includes a centre spike. This spike cuts a pilot hole for the drill to follow, making sure the drill bit stays on track. Without this centre spike, the drill bit could go off track due to the grain in the wood.</p>
<p>The flutes (which allow the cut wood to be fed out of the hole) are also of a wide design – the debris must be removed quickly from the hot tip or it may catch fire.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="hole-saw">Hole saw<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#hole-saw" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>As the name suggests this is a saw bit for cutting holes. There are two types: one for wood and the other for steel. Both types fit onto an arbor which holds the saw in place. The arbor is fitted with a pilot drill to make sure the saw acts around a central point.</p>
<p>A hole saw is ideal for cutting holes in sheet material or housings where the material is relatively thin and the hole size is larger than that of a conventional drill bit. Some of the more common sizes are 16 mm, 20 mm, 25 mm, 32 mm and 60 mm diameter saws.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="metal-drill-bit">Metal drill bit<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#metal-drill-bit" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Metal drill bits are sometimes referred to as HSS (high-speed steel) bits. These are intended to be strong enough to cut through steel and often have extra coatings, such as metal carbide, to make them resistant to wear.</p>
<p>The cutting face on an HSS bit is straight and there are two parts. A sharp HSS bit should look like a figure 8, when viewed from the cutting end. The cutting faces are set at an angle from the horizontal and the back of the face should be lower than the front, to ensure only the cutting edge is in contact with the material being cut. If the back edge of the cutting face is too high, it will rub against the material, causing excess heat and stopping the cutting by the drill bit.</p>
<p>HSS bits can be used to cut alloys such as aluminium, but they need to be run at a different speed.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="masonry-drill-bit">Masonry drill bit<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#masonry-drill-bit" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Use of an HSS bit on masonry will quickly blunt the bit, depending on the make of bit and the masonry being drilled. The flutes on an HSS bit are designed to remove swarf not masonry dust particles.</p>
<p>A masonry drill bit is designed with a larger cutting face diameter to that of the drill bit shaft. This enables the masonry dust to be pushed away from the cutting face and along the flutes.</p>
<p>The cutting face of a masonry bit is made from a hardened material that is designed to cut into hard materials and to withstand high temperatures.</p>
<p>Chapter 4 Electrical installation</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="core-bit">Core bit<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#core-bit" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>To produce a large hole in a masonry wall, a core cutter is used. This is similar in design to a hole saw but is specifically designed to cut large holes in masonry. The cutting edge is either fitted with tungsten carbide teeth or is diamond coated.</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251222-605aa2f5.jpeg" alt="img-300.jpeg">
Figure 4.31 Core drill bit</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="electric-screwdriver">Electric screwdriver<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#electric-screwdriver" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>There is increasing pressure in electrical installation to work faster. Electric screwdrivers help to achieve this. They come in all shapes and sizes, but all have the following common characteristics:</p>
<ul>
<li>bi-directional for tightening and loosening</li>
<li>adjustable torque setting to make sure screws are not over tightened</li>
<li>variable speed, generally controlled by the start button.</li>
</ul>
<p>Some electric screwdrivers can also be used as electric hand drills, if they have a drill setting. However, not all electric drills can be used as electric screwdrivers. If there is any doubt, they should not be used as screwdrivers.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="industry-tip">INDUSTRY TIP<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#industry-tip" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Most battery-operated drills have a screwdriver function. Be careful when using them not to over-tighten the screw as you will either snap the screw head off or split the box you are fitting.</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251222-ef92eb86.jpeg" alt="img-301.jpeg">
Figure 4.32 Electric screwdriver</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251222-fafd03db.jpeg" alt="img-302.jpeg">
Figure 4.33 Drill used as a screwdriver</p>
<p>The City &amp; Guilds Textbook: Electrical Installations Book 1</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="health-and-safety">HEALTH AND SAFETY<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#health-and-safety" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>When at work and at your training centre you must wear appropriate PPE. Failure to do so may have you removed from site or your assessment may be cancelled. Not only must you wear it, but it must be worn correctly. A safety helmet worn back to front is no good at all.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="personal-protective-equipment-ppe">Personal protective equipment (PPE)<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#personal-protective-equipment-ppe" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The use of power tools always presents a safety risk to the person using the tool and those around them. Consideration should always be given to the use of additional PPE.</p>
<p>When drilling, you should think about the damage that you may be doing to your ears, eyes, hands and lungs – always consider the use of ear protection, gloves and face masks. As a minimum, eye protection should be worn when using power tools. See pages 31–37 for more details about choosing appropriate PPE.</p>
<p>Before any drilling is undertaken, checks should always be made to ensure that you are not going to drill into something unexpected behind the surface being worked on. Always be alert when drilling as hidden dangers often lurk, such as buried cables, pipes or even asbestos.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="the-safe-use-of-power-tools">The safe use of power tools<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#the-safe-use-of-power-tools" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The aim of the Provision and Use of Work Equipment Regulations (PUWER) 1998 is to ensure that the equipment used to perform work is without risk to health and safety. In general terms, PUWER require that equipment which is provided for work activities is:</p>
<ul>
<li>suitable for the intended use</li>
<li>safe for use and maintained in a safe condition</li>
<li>used only by people that have received training on how to use the equipment correctly and safely</li>
<li>accompanied by suitable safety measures, such as guards, marking and warning signs.</li>
</ul>
<p>It is the responsibility of both the employer providing the tool and the employee using the tool to check the equipment is safe, appropriate for the job and used correctly.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="industry-tip">INDUSTRY TIP<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#industry-tip" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>BS EN 60309 plugs and sockets are often referred to as commando sockets and plugs.</p>
<p>Most plug-in power tools on a construction site are supplied from a 110 V AC supply and use a yellow BS EN 60309 plug-and-socket arrangement for connection. The reason for the colour coding on the plug-and-socket arrangement is to ensure that the operator knows what voltage is required and available. The colours of the plugs and sockets used under BS EN 60309 are:</p>
<ul>
<li>purple – this is used on voltages below 50 V AC</li>
<li>yellow – this is used on 110 V AC centre-tapped sources</li>
<li>blue – this is used on 230 V AC standard single-phase supplies</li>
<li>red – this is used on 400 V AC three-phase supplies.</li>
</ul>
<p>As well as the colour coding, plugs and sockets have notches and bumps called keys which limit their connection. So, it is not possible to plug a piece of 110 V equipment into either a 230 V or 400 V supply. If a BS EN 60309 plug has been cut off and replaced with a standard BS 1363 13 A three-pin plug, you should not use the equipment and should bring it to the attention of your supervisor.</p>
<p>Chapter 4 Electrical installation</p>
<p>Section 704 in BS 7671 provides further information regarding the installation requirements for temporary power supplies and installations to be used by site workers during the construction stage.</p>
<p>Hazards associated with the use of electric power tools are shown in the table.</p>
<table><thead><tr><th>Hazard</th><th>Source</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>Impalement</td><td>If the bit of a hand drill is of the wrong type or blunt, the operator may be tempted to push too hard. Should the drill bit snap it may injure the operator.</td></tr><tr><td>Particles in the eye</td><td>When cutting wood, metal or other material with a power tool, debris such as wood splinters and swarf can be thrown up. If the operator is not wearing suitable eye protection they may get particles in the eye. Brick dust can cause severe damage, even blindness.</td></tr><tr><td>Electric shock</td><td>Power tools that are plugged into the mains are more likely to cause electric shocks than battery-operated ones. Some people do not realise the purpose of the protective device in a plug and may try to by-pass it if it keeps tripping or ‘blowing’. They do not appreciate that the device is there to keep them safe in the event of an electrical fault.</td></tr><tr><td>Damaged leads, plugs and equipment casings can lead to electric shock. If a tool is not suitable for the particular work environment, this increases the risk of an incident happening. Only power tools designed for construction sites should be used on construction sites.</td><td></td></tr></tbody></table>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="working-at-height">Working at height<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#working-at-height" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Working at height is obviously hazardous in itself and can compound hazards associated with the activity being performed.</p>
<p>The Work at Height Regulations 2005 were outlined, along with clarification of what working at height entails, on pages 45–48. The regulations apply when a person is working at any level, where if they fell from that level, they could be injured. Working on ladders or steps is a common feature of working at height, but this could also include working at ground level near an excavation.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="ladders">Ladders<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#ladders" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>The HSE provides guidance for working on steps and ladders. Essentially, ladders should only be used as a means of access or where the work activity lasts for a short period of time typically not longer than 30 minutes and only for light loads not exceeding 10 kg mass.</p>
<p>251</p>
<p>The City &amp; Guilds Textbook: Electrical Installations Book 1</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="industry-tips">INDUSTRY TIPS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#industry-tips" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Even if a ladder is destroyed, this should be recorded within the ladder register.</p>
<p>If a ladder fails an inspection at any time it must be labelled and removed from service immediately; this includes failure of a user inspection.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="activity">ACTIVITY<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#activity" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Make a list of the checks you would make before using a wooden stepladder.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="health-and-safety">HEALTH AND SAFETY<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#health-and-safety" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The safety of others is a major responsibility that must be taken very seriously. Someone else's life will depend on you regularly on a construction site. At the same time, your life is in the hands of others and the way they behave. Always act responsibly!</p>
<p>Ladders come in various forms including:</p>
<ul>
<li>wooden</li>
<li>aluminium</li>
<li>fibre glass</li>
<li>single extension</li>
<li>double extension</li>
<li>triple extension.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="inspection-of-ladders">Inspection of ladders<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#inspection-of-ladders" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Each ladder should carry a unique identification mark which is recorded on the company ladder register. The ladder register is used to record each ladder, along with the details of inspections, defects and actions taken. In addition, the record includes an entry every time someone takes a ladder and returns it.</p>
<p>Ladders should be inspected every three months as part of a routine inspection. They should also be checked annually by performing a thorough examination. This means looking carefully at the physical condition and noting any defects, such as splits, wear and corrosion. In addition, the user should always check the condition of the ladder before each use.</p>
<p>When using a ladder it is good practice to ensure that:</p>
<ul>
<li>it is placed on a firm and level surface</li>
<li>the top and bottom of the ladder are secured or footed</li>
<li>a stepladder is spread to its fullest extent</li>
<li>there is a handrail or a hold at least 1 m above the top platform of a stepladder</li>
<li>the ladder does not overreach</li>
<li>tools are not left on the platform of steps.</li>
</ul>
<p>Footing is when another person secures the bottom of a ladder by placing their foot on the bottom rung to make sure it stays in place and does not move.</p>
<p>When climbing a stepladder, both hands should be used and the user should face the steps, making sure that three points of contact are maintained whenever possible. Nobody should pass below the ladder when work is going on.</p>
<p>Blocks or boards should not be used to extend the height of a ladder. If a ladder cannot reach the desired height, a longer ladder should be used instead. When using a ladder to access a working platform such as scaffolding, the ladder must be secured at both the top and bottom, and must extend beyond the working platform to provide a handrail. This helps with safe mounting and dismounting.</p>
<p>Figure 4.34 shows a typical installation of an access ladder on scaffolding. You will notice that the knee barrier has not been shown on the scaffolding. This would be at a height of 0.5 m above the working platform.</p>
<p>252</p>
<p>Chapter 4 Electrical installation</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251222-f8a7fe16.jpeg" alt="img-303.jpeg">
Figure 4.34 Correct use of a ladder to access a working platform (scaffold clamps and fixings have been omitted for clarity)</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="other-working-platforms">Other working platforms<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#other-working-platforms" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Installation often requires work at a height that would be accessible with a stepladder, but the duration of the work can be longer than 30 minutes. In such a case, an alternative form of access would be needed, such as a low-level working platform, a set of podium steps, a hop-up or trestle. The most common form of low-level access aid used in electrical installation work is the hop-up.</p>
<p>A hop-up platform has a typical construction of wood, aluminium or fibreglass and is designed to provide a working platform at a slightly raised level. Hop-ups do not have guards or rails and so will not prevent a fall; it is for this reason that they are not permitted on many construction sites.</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251222-857c3fae.jpeg" alt="img-304.jpeg">
Figure 4.35 Hop-up</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="industry-tip">INDUSTRY TIP<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#industry-tip" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>If you are in any doubt as to the best access equipment to use, consult the Work at Height Access Equipment Information Toolkit, or the WAIT tool, on the HSE website.</p>
<p>The City &amp; Guilds Textbook: Electrical Installations Book 1</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="the-risk-assessment">The risk assessment<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#the-risk-assessment" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Unless the various hazards are controlled and managed, working in the electrical installation business can be very dangerous. If people are not aware of the hazards around them, the risks increase. Everyone should be aware of the hazards and risks involved in the workplace. A risk assessment enables risks and hazards to be identified. Action plans are then put in place to prevent the risk from becoming a reality.</p>
<p>Most companies have standard risk assessments for the more routine work activities, such as use of hand tools and power tools, but it is important to understand that hazards and risks change depending on the circumstances of the individual job. Sadly, some companies perceive performing risk assessments as a necessary health and safety chore, rather than a business tool to help them plan and improve working processes. A lot of risk assessments are written and then stored away in a file on a shelf somewhere within the company. This is not the correct use of a risk assessment – it is intended to be a 'live' document which is constantly updated.</p>
<p>The HSE defines a risk assessment as a careful examination of what, in terms of work, could cause harm to people, so that precautions can be put in place to prevent that harm. Workers (and others) have a right to be protected from harm caused by a failure to take reasonable control measures.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="health-and-safety">HEALTH AND SAFETY<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#health-and-safety" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Remember that a risk assessment is a continuous operation. Re-assess the risks as the work progresses.</p>
<p>There are five steps to a risk assessment:</p>
<ol>
<li>identify the hazard</li>
<li>assess who might be harmed and how</li>
<li>evaluate the risk and decide how to prevent it</li>
<li>document the assessment and solution, and implement</li>
<li>monitor, evaluate and update as required.</li>
</ol>
<p>Risk assessment is a continual process, because circumstances are constantly changing. Therefore, although the five steps are shown as a list above, the process tends to be more of a cycle in practice (Figure 4.36). Pages 25–28 in Chapter 1 give full details of how to carry out a risk assessment.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="activity">ACTIVITY<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#activity" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>When assessing the potential for harm, different locations may change the risk. A simple task, such as changing a lamp, needs to be carried out. Consider how this task differs where the lamp is in the following situations/locations:</p>
<ul>
<li>in a bus shelter</li>
<li>in a 4 m high street light on a busy road</li>
<li>above a furnace in a factory.</li>
</ul>
<p>254</p>
<p>Chapter 4 Electrical installation</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251222-c904223f.jpeg" alt="img-305.jpeg">
Figure 4.36 Five steps of risk assessment</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="2-installation-of-wiring-systems">2 INSTALLATION OF WIRING SYSTEMS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#2-installation-of-wiring-systems" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="materials">Materials<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#materials" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<p>When starting a task, it is important to be able to identify the materials that will be required to complete the work. As well as using your previous experience, you should be able to identify the components that are required by looking at the drawings and specifications. The project specification contains information about the type of finish that is required for the installation work and may include details of preferred manufacturers.</p>
<p>The drawings often include plans showing the positioning of components and accessories, as well as the routes to be followed when the wiring is being installed. This is important as none of the services being run through the installation must cause problems for other systems and services.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="materials-take-off-sheet">Materials take-off sheet<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#materials-take-off-sheet" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<p>As well as showing where components and accessories are to be positioned, the drawings can also be used to create a materials take-off sheet.</p>
<p>The primary function of a materials take-off sheet is to enable components and accessories to be identified at the beginning of a project, to ensure that the correct materials will be available. This, in turn, helps in the preparation of accurate costings, so that a realistic tender or quotation can be produced. It also provides a 'shopping list' so that materials can be ordered prior to starting work, ensuring that all will be available on time and in the correct quantity.</p>
<p>The layout of the list varies from company to company but for each item all lists include:</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="health-and-safety">HEALTH AND SAFETY<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#health-and-safety" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<p>Hazards can appear suddenly. Someone lifting floorboards can create two immediate hazards. The first is a hole in the floor and the second could be nails protruding from the board. These should be remedied immediately.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="health-and-safety">HEALTH AND SAFETY<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#health-and-safety" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<p>Health and safety legislation states that we need to do everything reasonably practicable to protect people from harm. This acknowledges that not all hazards can be removed.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="key-terms">KEY TERMS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#key-terms" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<p>Materials: refers to the accessories, components and cables used during the installation process. It does not refer to tools or equipment as these are not normally purchased specially for a job.</p>
<p>Materials take-off sheet: a list of all the materials required and their quantities, to enable accurate stock control and costing of materials. Sometimes also referred to as a 'materials list', this can be used to record materials used to date and yet to be used on a job.</p>
<p>The City &amp; Guilds Textbook: Electrical Installations Book 1</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="industry-tip">INDUSTRY TIP<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#industry-tip" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Make sure you remember items such as screws and wall plugs when drawing up a materials list. It is difficult to install without them.</p>
<ul>
<li>an identification number, generally an index number</li>
<li>a description of the item</li>
<li>the unit of measure for the item</li>
<li>a quantity.</li>
</ul>
<p>Some companies' lists also include the details of the supplier and a catalogue number for each component. The unit of measure for most components is EA (meaning each) and this means that the quantity is per item and not per packet. When items such as cable are supplied, the unit of measure is m for metres.</p>
<p>When producing the materials take-off sheet it is important to understand that not all materials required are identified on the drawings. Items such as patresses, conduit, trunking, cables, glands and protective devices are not shown on any of the drawings, but they still have to be listed. This is where prior knowledge and experience of installation work helps a lot. For the remainder of the components, it is important to understand how the drawings and specification identify the items to be installed.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="reading-the-drawings">Reading the drawings<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#reading-the-drawings" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>In order to identify the materials to be used in an installation, it is important to be able to read drawings correctly. Standardised symbols are used for drawings in the electrotechnical industry. These symbols can be used to identify components and their locations.</p>
<p>The layout drawing is generally a plan view with a legend or key to clarify the types of components to be installed and their locations. Most designers use IEC 60617 symbols, but as the full range of symbols for this type of drawing are not covered by this standard, the designer may use their own variations. You must clarify with the designer any symbols that are not easily recognisable.</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251222-755b7584.jpeg" alt="img-306.jpeg">
Figure 4.37 One-gang one-way light switch, circuit diagram symbol and plan symbol</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251222-21fb32f6.jpeg" alt="img-307.jpeg"></p>
<p>Some of the common symbols are shown on the inside cover of the Institution of Engineering and Technology (IET) On-Site Guide, but they are not explained. However, the IET On-Site Guide is a good memory jogger when looking at the drawings for an electrical installation.</p>
<p>Most of the symbols used in BS EN 60617 are made up of parts that have different meanings. Designers can add parts together to make a symbol for a component, should there be no symbol for what they are designing. Consider the light switch symbols shown in Figures 4.37 to 4.41.</p>
<p>When you consider a switch, you have to consider what the switch does. This includes:</p>
<p>Chapter 4 Electrical installation</p>
<ul>
<li>ways – is the switch one-way, two-way or intermediate?</li>
<li>gangs – this is the number of actual switches mounted on the plate; a plate containing two switches is two-gang</li>
<li>poles – this is the number of channels that a single switch operates in one switching action. As an example, if a switch operates both a line and neutral, it is double pole.</li>
</ul>
<p>The circle in the plan symbol indicates that the device is a switch. The arm that sticks out of the circle shows how many ways this switch can operate. The flag at the end of the arm indicates the number of poles that the switch operates. The number of gangs is indicated by a number or letter (e.g. 2 for two-gang or M for multi-gang).</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251222-5634949f.jpeg" alt="img-308.jpeg">
Figure 4.38 Three-gang one-way switch, circuit diagram symbol (for one-gang) and plan symbol</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251222-d5114895.jpeg" alt="img-309.jpeg">
Figure 4.39 One-gang one-way double-pole switch, circuit diagram symbol and plan symbol</p>
<p>Some multi-gang switches, often used in industrial and commercial installations, can have as many as 12 switches on the same faceplate! This type of multi-gang switch is normally called a grid switch (Figures 4.40 and 4.41) and is of a modular construction and would need to be assembled on site; generally all the parts are ordered separately.</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251222-99890aa9.jpeg" alt="img-310.jpeg">
Figure 4.40 Multi-gang switch</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251222-0bfd76ee.jpeg" alt="img-311.jpeg">
Figure 4.41 Multi-gang plan symbol</p>
<p>The City &amp; Guilds Textbook: Electrical Installations Book 1</p>
<p>Now you have looked at light switches and their symbols, you will find it easier to interpret other symbols – when a symbol has an arm with a flag on it (similar to that seen on the light switch examples) you know it is showing an accessory that can be switched. For example, Figures 4.42 and 4.43 show a non-switched socket outlet and a switched socket outlet.</p>
<p>For many pieces of electrical equipment, there is no dedicated symbol. Therefore, a lot of generic symbols are used. For example, a square identifies a piece of electrical equipment. When the square contains, for example, a figure 8 or infinity sign, the symbol indicates an electric fan. Always look at the key or legend of the plan to double check the meaning of the symbols used by the designer.</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251222-f8c76a71.jpeg" alt="img-312.jpeg">
▲ Figure 4.42 Non-switched single (one-gang) socket outlet and symbol</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251222-f494981b.jpeg" alt="img-313.jpeg"></p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="industry-tip">INDUSTRY TIP<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#industry-tip" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Socket outlets are not covered by BS EN 60617 so there is no standard symbol. Sometimes the symbol shown is used; sometimes the switch stick extends into the dome.</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251222-c59a4d73.jpeg" alt="img-314.jpeg">
▲ Figure 4.43 Switched twin (two-gang) socket outlet (switches are double pole) and symbol</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251222-d3ebf805.jpeg" alt="img-315.jpeg"></p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="drawing-scales">Drawing scales<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#drawing-scales" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The drawings may show the proposed cable routes that the installer is expected to follow. Using this information, it is possible to approximate the length of cable required.</p>
<p>All drawings and plans are produced to scale, to enable accurate measurements to be made. A scale is simply a ratio that is used to represent life-size structures at a smaller size. The ratio is generally expressed as two numbers and typical scales are:</p>
<ul>
<li>1:20</li>
<li>1:50</li>
<li>1:100</li>
<li>1:500.</li>
</ul>
<p>So, in the case of the third scale ratio above (1:100), one unit on the plan represents 100 life-size units. To apply the scale, make a measurement on the drawing and then multiply this by the second number in the ratio; this will give you the measurement in reality. An alternative method is to use a scaled rule with the same scale ratio as the plan. This will show the correct measurement. For example, on a scaled rule with a scale of 1:100, a measurement of 1 cm is shown as 1 m (100 cm).</p>
<p>Chapter 4 Electrical installation</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="drawing-dimensions">Drawing dimensions<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#drawing-dimensions" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>The correct positioning of materials is important. When a component must be fitted in a certain location, the layout drawing will give a measurement indicating where the component is to be installed. These measurements are generally referred to as dimensions and can be shown in one of two ways:</p>
<ul>
<li>datum form</li>
<li>linear form.</li>
</ul>
<p>Datum dimensioning is used where several accessories need to be installed at different heights and with varied spacing between them. A common start point, the datum, is identified and the dimensions are all measured from there. The common point may be the corner of a room or another fixed point, such as a piece of switch-gear.</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251222-d1bea081.jpeg" alt="img-316.jpeg">
Figure 4.44 Dimensioning to a datum point</p>
<p>Linear dimensioning is used when accessories need to be installed at the same height and at set distances apart. A common method of referencing the accessories is to use the term 'CRS', which means a given dimension is measured from the centre of each component.</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251222-543468c1.jpeg" alt="img-317.jpeg">
Figure 4.45 Linear dimensions</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="key-term">KEY TERM<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#key-term" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>CRS: this means 'centres', indicating that the dimension given is between the centres of equipment.</p>
<p>The City &amp; Guilds Textbook: Electrical Installations Book 1</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="industry-tip">INDUSTRY TIP<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#industry-tip" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Remember the old adage of 'measure twice, cut once'! Errors in component siting will have to be corrected without additional cost to the client.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="industry-tip">INDUSTRY TIP<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#industry-tip" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>A chalk line is a common tool for marking out horizontal and vertical lines. Held taut at both ends and then pinged, a chalked string will leave a faint line across the surface.</p>
<p>Understanding the different dimensioning styles is important, as it affects the actual positioning of the components.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="marking-out">Marking out<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#marking-out" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>When dimensions are given, it is important that these are observed when marking out and performing the first fix. Make sure that you understand all dimensions and have applied them correctly. Clarify any confusions or unclear information with either the site supervisor or the installation designer before proceeding.</p>
<p>Dimensions are not just used to show where components are to be installed; they are also used to plan where walls need to be cut for cables to be installed. These cuts in walls are called chases. If a wall is chased out in the wrong location, it can damage the wall and result in a lot of extra work and expense.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="marking-out-chases">Marking out chases<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#marking-out-chases" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>When cables are placed in walls, they are generally installed within prescribed zones as identified in BS 7671 Regulation group 522.6. The IET On-Site Guide (Chapter 7) refers to these as 'safe zones'. The chasing out of walls is a very dusty and dirty job and it is normally performed for electricians and electrical installers by a builder. However, the builder will only chase out the wall once the information as been drawn on – so it is important to transfer the dimension information correctly onto the wall. To transfer dimensions onto a wall it is common practice to use:</p>
<ul>
<li>a pencil</li>
<li>a straight edge</li>
<li>a long or short level</li>
<li>a tape measure</li>
<li>and a plumb line.</li>
</ul>
<p>Marking out on a finished wall should be kept to a minimum, as unsightly marks have to be removed after the work is completed. Faint pencil marks (that are clear enough to be seen for installation purposes only) should be used. Faint marks are easier to remove if necessary. A useful tool at this stage is a laser level; this projects a level line over a long distance. However, not all construction sites permit the use of laser levels due to health and safety concerns.</p>
<p>On an unfinished wall that needs chasing, it is important to make the marking out clear; often the part of the wall to be removed is indicated by hatching the area. This is when diagonal lines are drawn across the part of the wall to be cut away.</p>
<p>Figure 4.46 shows how a wall may be marked out for a builder to chase out for electrical wiring. Additional information, such as the depth of the chase, may also be advised, but builders generally work to the maximum permissible depth as identified in Part A of the Building Regulations.</p>
<p>Chapter 4 Electrical installation</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251222-0d6a1859.jpeg" alt="img-318.jpeg">
Figure 4.46 A wall section marked out for chasing</p>
<p>Electricians and electrical installers must also observe parts of the Building Regulations with regards to the positioning of certain components. If the installation may be used by a person with disabilities, in order to comply with certain aspects of the Equality Act 2010, Part M of the Building Regulations must be applied.</p>
<p>Part M applies if:</p>
<ul>
<li>a non-domestic building or dwelling is newly erected</li>
<li>an existing non-domestic building is extended or significantly altered</li>
<li>an existing building or part of a building is altered due to a change of purpose or use.</li>
</ul>
<p>This means that new houses must comply, but the regulation does not necessarily apply to changes within an existing home if the purpose of the room is not being changed.</p>
<p>If Part M applies, electrical accessories must be installed on walls in a zone which is from 450 mm to 1200 mm, measured from the finished floor level (as detailed in Section 8 of the approved document M of the Building Regulations).</p>
<p>So, if you are installing within a new dwelling, these heights must be observed. However, if the building is an existing dwelling and the new switch or socket outlet is an addition or alteration to an existing circuit, there is no need to comply with part M if the building did not already comply with it. Another exclusion is a socket outlet for a dedicated piece of equipment, such as a wall-mounted television, which you would not expect to unplug and plug in continually. If this is the case, the height restrictions do not apply as they focus on the general-purpose socket outlets.</p>
<p>Think about the purpose of a ground-floor conversion or extension when wiring. If the extension or conversion is for a person with disabilities, consideration should be given to the application of the minimum and maximum heights.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="industry-tip">INDUSTRY TIP<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#industry-tip" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The parts of the Building Regulations referred to in this book relate to the Building Regulations in England. Wales, Scotland and Northern Ireland may reference different parts and have slightly different standards.</p>
<ul>
<li>For Scotland, see: <a href="http://www.gov.scot/Topics/Built-Environment/Building/Building-standards" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">www.gov.scot/Topics/Built-Environment/Building/Building-standards</a></li>
<li>For Wales, see: <a href="https://law.gov.wales/economy-and-development/town-and-country-planning/building-regulations" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">https://law.gov.wales/economy-and-development/town-and-country-planning/building-regulations</a></li>
<li>For Northern Ireland, see: <a href="http://www.finance-ni.gov.uk/articles/building-regulations-northern-ireland" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">www.finance-ni.gov.uk/articles/building-regulations-northern-ireland</a></li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="industry-tip">INDUSTRY TIP<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#industry-tip" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>There are detectors available which will detect live cables and metal within a wall.</p>
<p>The City &amp; Guilds Textbook: Electrical Installations Book 1</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="industry-tip">INDUSTRY TIP<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#industry-tip" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>First fixing refers to the initial installing of boxes and cables and so on. Second fixing, the connection of accessories, occurs when the plastering and other work has been completed.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="installing-wiring-systems">Installing wiring systems<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#installing-wiring-systems" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>There are many types of wiring systems used. A wiring system could be a cable on its own or a means of containing or managing the cable. Some of the terms you may hear include the following.</p>
<ul>
<li>Wiring system – this is the term used to describe the type of cable used and the method of supporting it. For example, single-core cable in conduit is a wiring system but, equally, so is a twin and cpc cable clipped to a wall.</li>
<li>Support system – this is the method of supporting a cable and could include systems such as cable tray, basket or simply clips or cleats.</li>
<li>Cable management system or cable containment system – this is a method of supporting and protecting cables, usually by enclosing the cables in conduit, trunking or ducting, for example.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="conduit-systems">Conduit systems<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#conduit-systems" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>In some environments, the installation may be subjected to external influences which may cause damage to the wiring. Damage could result, for example, from impact or corrosion from oils and other solutions. A common method of providing an additional level of mechanical protection from such damage is the use of conduit.</p>
<p>Conduit is available in both steel and PVC and comes in many different forms including:</p>
<ul>
<li>solid steel extruded</li>
<li>solid steel rolled</li>
<li>rigid PVC</li>
<li>flexible steel</li>
<li>flexible PVC.</li>
</ul>
<p>Both steel and PVC conduits come in both light gauge and heavy gauge, providing a degree of flexibility with regards to application and cost. Conduits come in a variety of finishes: PVC is available in various colours and steel can be galvanised or brushed, or finished in black enamel.</p>
<p>Solid steel extruded conduit is seamless (there is no join). This makes it an expensive option and it is only used for special gas-tight, explosion-proof or flame-proof installations. Conduit is typically supplied in 3 m or 3.75 m lengths and, unlike pipework for water and gas services, is identified by the overall external diameter.</p>
<p>Typical conduit external diameters are 16 mm, 20 mm, 25 mm and 32 mm, though it can be supplied in sizes up to and including 63 mm.</p>
<p>Flexible conduit is predominately used in short runs as the level of mechanical protection is greatly reduced by the need for movement. A typical application for flexible conduit is in the final run of containment from wall-mounted conduit to a machine which vibrates, such as a motor.</p>
<p>262</p>
<p>Chapter 4 Electrical installation</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="advantages-of-conduit">Advantages of conduit<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#advantages-of-conduit" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>One of the main advantages of using conduit is the increased mechanical protection that is afforded by the containment. Flexible conduit offers the least level of mechanical protection, followed by PVC conduit, with steel conduit providing the highest level of mechanical protection.</p>
<p>Other advantages of using conduit include the ability to perform rewiring relatively easily, providing all cables are being replaced at the same time – cables should all be drawn into the conduit at the same time and not pulled past one another. BS 7671 Regulation 522.8 states that cables should not be subjected to stress, strain or damage during installation, maintenance or use.</p>
<p>Using steel conduit in an installation can minimise the risk of spread of fire, providing all joints, fittings and accessories are constructed to a minimum of IP33. Another benefit of steel conduit is the fact that steel conducts electrical energy. The conduit can be used as the circuit protective conductor (cpc), provided it is of a suitable size. BS 7671 Regulation 543.1.1 explains how to establish whether the conduit is big enough to act as the circuit protective conductor.</p>
<p>Although steel conduit is rarely used as a sole protective conductor, steel conduit may act as a protective conductor when installed buried in a wall to satisfy the requirements of Regulation group 522.6 of BS 7671, or when acting as a high integrity protective conductor on circuits having high protective conductor currents.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="disadvantages-of-conduit">Disadvantages of conduit<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#disadvantages-of-conduit" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The first disadvantage of using conduit is cost. The time and materials required to install a conduit system are often far greater than that needed to install the cables directly (clipped direct) in the fabric of the building or onto the surface of the building. It is important, therefore, to establish the need for mechanical protection prior to installing.</p>
<p>PVC conduit is directly affected by UV rays and can become discoloured and brittle in direct sunlight. In addition, PVC expands a lot if it gets hot. It becomes very brittle if subjected to temperatures below 4°C and can become very soft if subjected to temperatures above 60°C.</p>
<p>Steel conduit can also be affected by acids, alkalis and corrosive fumes; it is particularly susceptible to rust from moisture which can form on the inside of the conduit.</p>
<p>Steel conduit has one big disadvantage that PVC conduit does not; eddy currents can form in it.</p>
<p>263</p>
<p>The City &amp; Guilds Textbook: Electrical Installations Book 1</p>
<p>When a current passes along a conductor, a moving magnetic field forms around it. If a single current-carrying conductor is placed within a steel conduit, the moving magnetic field can induce an electromotive force, e.m.f., in the steel conduit. This induced e.m.f. can create an eddy current which, in turn, can produce heat as well as the potential for electric shock. Therefore, BS 7671 Regulation 521.5.1 states that, when a circuit is carrying AC current, all circuit conductors must pass through the same conduit. This means that no run of steel conduit has just one line or neutral conductor running through it.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="industry-tip">INDUSTRY TIP<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#industry-tip" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Conduit boxes are often referred to as besa (pronounced 'beezer') boxes.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="accessories">Accessories<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#accessories" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Steel and PVC conduits use some common accessories in their installations, but they also have their own specific accessories.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="conduit-boxes">Conduit boxes<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#conduit-boxes" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>There are various forms of box that are used in the construction of a conduit system.</p>
<ul>
<li>Junction box – this is sometimes called a termination box as it is used at the end of a conduit run. This box has one spout coming out of the side of the box. This type of box can be used when you come to the end of a run or when you need to get tight into a corner.</li>
</ul>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251222-5eb7d045.jpeg" alt="img-319.jpeg">
Figure 4.47 Junction box</p>
<ul>
<li>Through box – this box has two spouts coming out of opposite sides of the box. This type is often used as a through link and can be used over longer runs to make drawing cables easier.</li>
</ul>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251222-7d04cd53.jpeg" alt="img-320.jpeg">
Figure 4.48 Through box</p>
<p>Chapter 4 Electrical installation</p>
<ul>
<li>Angle box – this box has two spouts at 90° to each other. This is useful for going round corners or changing direction in situations away from corners.</li>
</ul>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251222-64f6b176.jpeg" alt="img-321.jpeg"></p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="figure-4-49-angle-box">Figure 4.49 Angle box<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#figure-4-49-angle-box" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
