<li>Tee box – as its name suggests, this box has three spouts forming the shape of the letter 'T'. It has the benefits of both an angle and a through box.</li>
</ul>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251222-563238f7.jpeg" alt="img-322.jpeg"></p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="figure-4-50-tee-box">Figure 4.50 Tee box<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#figure-4-50-tee-box" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Four-way box – this is sometimes called a cross box and it has four spouts at 90° to one another.</li>
</ul>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251222-87b3b817.jpeg" alt="img-323.jpeg"></p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="figure-4-51-four-way-box">Figure 4.51 Four-way box<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#figure-4-51-four-way-box" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The City &amp; Guilds Textbook: Electrical Installations Book 1</p>
<ul>
<li>Tangent-through box – similar to the standard through box, this box has the spouts at one edge. This allows the box to be placed closer to a wall joint or ceiling.</li>
</ul>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251222-8c7728d1.jpeg" alt="img-324.jpeg"></p>
<p>Figure 4.52 Tangent-through box</p>
<ul>
<li>Tangent-angle box – again this is the same as the angle box, but with the spouts positioned towards one side of the box.</li>
</ul>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251222-82c246b4.jpeg" alt="img-325.jpeg"></p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="industry-tip">INDUSTRY TIP<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#industry-tip" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>There is a selection of lids available to fit standard conduit boxes. These range from plain pressed steel covers to hook plates and dome lids.</p>
<p>Figure 4.53 Tangent-angle box</p>
<ul>
<li>Tangent-tee box – this box has the same shape as the tee box but, due to the opposing spouts being on one edge, the conduit can be positioned closer to a ceiling or other edge.</li>
</ul>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251222-95250e53.jpeg" alt="img-326.jpeg"></p>
<p>Figure 4.54 Tangent-tee box</p>
<p>Chapter 4 Electrical installation</p>
<ul>
<li>H-box – this box has four spouts forming a letter ‘H’, with two on either side. It is similar to two tangent-through boxes joined together.</li>
</ul>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251222-516e5c6b.jpeg" alt="img-327.jpeg"></p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="figure-4-55-h-box">Figure 4.55 H-box<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#figure-4-55-h-box" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>U-box – this box allows for a 180° change of direction, by having two spouts on the same side of the box.</li>
</ul>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251222-1f21a667.jpeg" alt="img-328.jpeg"></p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="figure-4-56-u-box">Figure 4.56 U-box<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#figure-4-56-u-box" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Y-box – similar to the U-box, the Y-box allows for a 180° change of direction and has the benefits of a through box. The through spout is centrally located on the opposite side from the other two spouts.</li>
</ul>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251222-c3cdbdb6.jpeg" alt="img-329.jpeg"></p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="figure-4-57-y-box">Figure 4.57 Y-box<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#figure-4-57-y-box" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The City &amp; Guilds Textbook: Electrical Installations Book 1</p>
<ul>
<li>Back-entry box – this type of box is similar to a junction box with the spout or spouts located in the back of the box section. It can house up to four spouts.</li>
</ul>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251222-6284460c.jpeg" alt="img-330.jpeg"></p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251222-e8ed522b.jpeg" alt="img-331.jpeg"></p>

<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="bends-and-elbows">Bends and elbows<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#bends-and-elbows" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>You will learn to fabricate your own bends during assembly. However, pre-manufactured bends and elbows are also available and they tend to be one of two types:</p>
<ul>
<li>inspection joints</li>
<li>non-inspection joints.</li>
</ul>
<p>Inspection joints are usually preferred as these allow the cables to be drawn in easily during installation. However, if the bend is on a short run and within 0.5 m of the accessory, a non-inspection bend can be used.</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251222-3d827b83.jpeg" alt="img-334.jpeg">
Figure 4.59 Inspection elbow bend</p>
<p>Chapter 4 Electrical installation</p>
<p>Whatever type of bend you use, bear in mind compliance with BS 7671 Regulation 522.8.6 (you need to ensure that the cables are not subjected to excessive strain or stress during installation by providing adequate means of access to perform the drawing in of cables). So, if inspection joints are not used, there must be adequate alternative access points along the conduit run. These can be provided by accessory boxes, such as through boxes on long runs.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="joining-components">Joining components<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#joining-components" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Conduit is available in standard lengths of 3 m and 3.75 m; often runs need to be joined. The basic method of joining two runs of conduit together is by use of a coupler.</p>
<p>The coupler that is used on PVC conduit is a piece of tube that has a larger diameter than that of the conduit. The conduit is simply slotted into either side of the coupler and secured in place with adhesive. Note that, under COSHH Regulations, the adhesive that is used in the joining of PVC conduit must be recorded on the National Poison Centre records; this should be done by the supplier or wholesaler selling the adhesive.</p>
<p>In a long run, PVC must be able to expand and contract. When the run of PVC conduit is 5 m or longer, an expansion coupler must be used.</p>
<p>This is similar to a normal PVC conduit coupler but is twice the length and adhesive is only used on one side, allowing the other side to move in and out of the coupler. It is important to ensure the level of penetration is correct, allowing for contraction without leaving the coupler and expansion without buckling.</p>
<p>Steel conduit also uses couplers but the use of adhesive is not permitted. All joints in steel conduit must be tight and electrically sound, so that if one part did become live, the installation would still be connected to earth and the protective devices would operate.</p>
<p>To achieve this, the coupler is slightly larger than the conduit and there is a thread all the way through the inside of the coupler. This means that, once a thread is cut on both pieces of the conduit to be joined, the components can be screwed together.</p>
<p>In some joints it is necessary to have the thread on the outside and this is called a nipple. A nipple has the same size external diameter as the conduit, and the thread is cut along its length. It is normally about the same length as a coupler and can be connected with a coupler.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="erection-components">Erection components<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#erection-components" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>There are various different ways of securing conduit to walls. If the conduit is to be covered by plaster, it is common for a crampet to be used to secure the conduit temporarily in place. This looks like a bent-over floorboard nail.</p>
<p>When the conduit is to be installed on the surface, it is common to use a type of saddle to hold it in place. All of the saddles shown here are available for PVC and steel conduits.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="industry-tip">INDUSTRY TIP<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#industry-tip" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>You can see that it is essential that metal conduit joints are tight. This not only ensures good continuity, but prevents the conduit becoming loose.</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251222-775ea4d9.jpeg" alt="img-335.jpeg">
Figure 4.60 Crampet</p>
<p>The City &amp; Guilds Textbook: Electrical Installations Book 1</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251222-f08cdab7.jpeg" alt="img-336.jpeg">
Figure 4.61 Strap saddle</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251222-dcf659e8.jpeg" alt="img-337.jpeg">
Figure 4.62 Spacer bar saddle</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="industry-tip">INDUSTRY TIP<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#industry-tip" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>The spacer bar stamp normally has a keyhole slot to allow one-handed fitting. The maximum distance between fixings for conduit is set out in Table D3 in the IET On-Site Guide.</p>
<ul>
<li>Strap saddle – this is used when the conduit is to be secured in place directly on the surface, with no gap at the back. It is also referred to as a stamp saddle.</li>
<li>Spacer bar saddle – this is the most common form of saddle and is available for both steel and PVC conduit. It allows the conduit to be positioned slightly away from the surface of the wall. The holes on the saddle part or stamp are designed so that, when the fitting is mounted horizontally, the stamp will drop into place to make installation easier.</li>
<li>Distance saddle – this is similar to the spacer bar saddle, but with a thicker back-plate. It can be used to install conduit on surfaces that are uneven.</li>
<li>Hospital saddle – this is used where it is important to be able to clean behind the conduit. The hospital saddle has no horizontal edges for dirt and dust to accumulate and also moves the conduit away from the wall, just far enough to make cleaning possible. As its name suggests, these are used in some areas of hospitals, but they are also suitable for use in commercial kitchens, along with stainless steel conduit.</li>
</ul>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251222-05c8a2a7.jpeg" alt="img-338.jpeg">
Figure 4.63 Distance saddle</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251222-c5a000cd.jpeg" alt="img-339.jpeg">
Figure 4.64 Hospital saddle</p>
<p>The saddles used on PVC conduit can be different to those for steel conduit. Some do not need screws to fix the saddle part to the back-plate.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="bushes">Bushes<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#bushes" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>For steel conduit there are two types of bush, both of which are made of brass. These are:</p>
<ul>
<li>Male bush – this has the thread on the outside and it is used to thread into a coupler or accessory.</li>
<li>Female bush – this has the thread on the inside and is used where the thread on the conduit protrudes into an accessory and the cable needs to be protected from the rough edges.</li>
</ul>
<p>For PVC conduit, the bushes are combined with the adaptors for securing the conduit. There are two types of bush and adaptor combination:</p>
<ul>
<li>Male adaptor – this uses a part similar to the brass male bush used on steel conduit assemblies and screws into the adaptor.</li>
<li>Female adaptor – this uses a part similar to a lock ring and screws onto a thread already on the adaptor.</li>
</ul>
<p>Chapter 4 Electrical installation</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="sizing-of-conduit">Sizing of conduit<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#sizing-of-conduit" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>When you are installing conduit, consider the fact that the cables will get hot and need to be able to cool, to avoid overheating. There must be sufficient air space around the cables.</p>
<p>The maximum fill capacity for conduit allows for air flow around the conductors.</p>
<p>Appendix E of the IET On-Site Guide has standard tables giving the number of conductors that can be installed in a piece of conduit, taking into account all the relevant factors. The tables take into account the size and type of conductors, the length of the conduit run and how many bends there are in the run (see Chapter 3, pages 212–214).</p>
<p>To use Appendix E, follow this simple and logical approach:</p>
<ol>
<li>Identify all the different sizes of wiring conductors used.</li>
<li>Identify the quantities of each different size.</li>
<li>Using the tables in Appendix E, select the correct cable factor for each size of cable.</li>
<li>Multiply the factor by the number of conductors of that size.</li>
<li>Add the totals together.</li>
<li>Select the conduit with the next factor up from the total value.</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="example">EXAMPLE<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#example" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>An easy way to follow these steps is to use a simple table, filling in the data as you go. The example below is a conduit sizing calculation for three lighting circuits and one ring final circuit, wired using solid copper thermoplastic cables in a run of <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>2.5</mn><mi mathvariant="normal">m</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">2.5\mathrm{m}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6444em;"></span><span class="mord">2.5</span><span class="mord mathrm">m</span></span></span></span></span>. The steel conduit is to be used as the protective conductor for each circuit.</p>
<table><thead><tr><th>Conductor size in mm²</th><th>Number of conductors</th><th>Cable factor</th><th>Total cable factor</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>1.5</td><td>3 × 2 = 6</td><td>27</td><td>6 × 27 = 162</td></tr><tr><td>2.5</td><td>2 × 2 = 4</td><td>39</td><td>4 × 39 = 156</td></tr><tr><td></td><td></td><td>Total</td><td>162 + 156 = 318</td></tr></tbody></table>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="example-of-a-conduit-sizing-calculation">Example of a conduit sizing calculation<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#example-of-a-conduit-sizing-calculation" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The calculation gives an overall conduit factor of 318. Again, using the appropriate table in Appendix E of the IET On-Site Guide, it can be seen that a piece of <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>20</mn><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">m</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">m</mi></mrow></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">20\mathrm{mm}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6444em;"></span><span class="mord">20</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">mm</span></span></span></span></span></span> conduit can be used as it has a spacing factor in excess of the 318 required.</p>
<p>However, if, after checking BS 7671 Regulation 543.1.1, you discovered that <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>20</mn><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">m</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">m</mi></mrow></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">20\mathrm{mm}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6444em;"></span><span class="mord">20</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">mm</span></span></span></span></span></span> conduit did not have sufficient area to act as the protective conductor, you would have to repeat the calculation allowing additional circuit protective conductors for each circuit.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="activity">ACTIVITY<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#activity" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Calculate how many <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>4</mn><msup><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">m</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">m</mi></mrow><mn>2</mn></msup></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">4\mathrm{mm}^2</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8141em;"></span><span class="mord">4</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">mm</span></span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.8141em;"><span style="top: -3.063em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight">2</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span> PVC insulated cables may be installed in a <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>25</mn><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">m</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">m</mi></mrow></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">25\mathrm{mm}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6444em;"></span><span class="mord">25</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">mm</span></span></span></span></span></span> conduit <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>5</mn><mi mathvariant="normal">m</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">5\mathrm{m}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6444em;"></span><span class="mord">5</span><span class="mord mathrm">m</span></span></span></span></span> long, with two bends.</p>
<p>The City &amp; Guilds Textbook: Electrical Installations Book 1</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="preparation-for-conduit-installation">Preparation for conduit installation<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#preparation-for-conduit-installation" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>When installing any form of conduit system, it is important to plan the route effectively and accurately. This often involves positioning accessories in their appropriate locations and using chalk to project straight lines for the conduit to follow.</p>
<p>With the chalk lines in place, the saddles can be positioned along the run to aid with the erection and measurement process. The IET On-Site Guide provides guidance, in Appendix D, on the maximum distance between saddles – this is dependent on the size and type of conduit.</p>
<p>Conduit systems are rarely an exact copy of their dimensioned drawings, as buildings are not often built exactly to the planned dimensions. Marking out the proposed route helps to establish the exact measurements of the conduit system. Once all the accessories and saddles are in place, it is possible to commence building the conduit system.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="cutting-of-conduit">Cutting of conduit<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#cutting-of-conduit" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Cutting PVC conduit is easier than cutting steel conduit; conduit cutters for PVC conduit are readily available and come in several forms. These include the snip style of conduit cutter and the ringing tool style. Both of these tools will cut the conduit, leaving a clean edge on the end with no burrs and minimal deformation of the conduit shape.</p>
<p>Steel conduit is not so easy to cut and typically a hacksaw is used. Ideally, a hacksaw blade should be between 24 and 32 TPI for cutting steel conduit. Other tools that you will require include:</p>
<ul>
<li>graphite pencil for marking out</li>
<li>tape measure</li>
<li>engineer's square</li>
<li>hand file (generally second cut grade)</li>
<li>pipe vice</li>
<li>conduit reamer</li>
<li>appropriate signs and obstacles for making sure the work area is cordoned off.</li>
</ul>
<p>The pipe vice is generally mounted on the tool that is used for bending the steel conduit, called a conduit bender. The pipe vice jaws must be well maintained and clean, or they will damage the conduit. If the vice is mounted on the conduit bender, the conduit may be at an angle, not necessarily horizontal.</p>
<p>Having established how long the conduit should be, measure and mark the conduit using the tape measure and pencil, remembering to allow for 15 mm of thread at each end.</p>
<p>Position the conduit in the pipe vice, allowing sufficient space to perform the cut but ensuring the cut will be close to the vice, so that the conduit does not vibrate excessively while being cut. If the conduit does vibrate too much during cutting, the hacksaw blade can become jammed, damaged or broken.</p>
<p>Chapter 4 Electrical installation</p>
<p>Stand square to the job and make sure your movement is unobstructed. Position the blade next to the mark (on the piece of conduit not required) and grip the hacksaw lightly, applying light pressure on the forward cutting stroke. Use the full length of the blade to cut, as this helps to ensure that the blade does not overheat and become jammed in the cut.</p>
<p>Once the cut has been performed, there will be rough and sharp edges on the outside and on the inside of the conduit. You should never insert your finger into the conduit to check for rough edges. To remove these rough edges, position the required conduit in the pipe vice. Stand square to the conduit. Use a hand file and, with one hand on the file handle and the other hand supporting the file at the other end, draw the file across the cut end of the conduit.</p>
<p>Repeat this until the face of the conduit is smooth and square. To check to see if the face is square to the length of conduit, use an engineer's square. Once the end of the conduit is square, use a hand file to remove the rough burrs on the outside edge.</p>
<p>This time the file must be held at an angle of around 40° to the face. Draw the file across the sharp edge, slowly working around the end of the conduit, to create a slight chamfer. This chamfer will aid with cutting the thread later.</p>
<p>Once the outer sharp edges and burrs have been removed, the inner burrs must also be removed (these could damage the cables as they are installed). You will sometimes see people doing this with a round file but the correct tool to use is a reamer. The reamer is like an oversized drill bit, but it is designed to be inserted into the conduit and rotated by hand until all the sharp edges have been removed.</p>
<p>Simply rotate the reamer through 120° and back again several times to remove all the burrs. Check that the burrs have been removed with a quick visual inspection. Don't touch the end and risk cutting your fingers.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="threading-conduit">Threading conduit<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#threading-conduit" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Once a piece of steel conduit has been sawn to length, it is necessary to cut a thread for the accessory to be mounted on the conduit. The pipe vice is used, and to cut the thread you will also need:</p>
<ul>
<li>a set of stocks and dies</li>
<li>some cutting compound</li>
<li>a soft wire brush.</li>
</ul>
<p>Before cutting the thread, you need to check the die and make sure it is clean and clear of swarf. If the die is not clean it can damage the thread to be cut. The stock and die set should also be checked to make sure everything is tight and has not loosened since last use.</p>
<p>With the die clean and tight, apply a liberal coating of cutting compound to the end of the conduit, making sure it is coated all the way round. The cutting compound acts as both a lubricant and cooling aid during thread cutting and is generally applied using a brush.</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251222-96d982ed.jpeg" alt="img-340.jpeg"></p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251222-05777e76.jpeg" alt="img-341.jpeg">
Figure 4.65 Conduit in pipe vice about to be cut (top) and the edge of the cut conduit being dressed to remove sharp edges (bottom)</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="health-and-safety">HEALTH AND SAFETY<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#health-and-safety" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Use gloves and/or barrier cream to protect your skin from the cutting compound when cutting threads on steel conduit.</p>
<p>273</p>
<p>The City &amp; Guilds Textbook: Electrical Installations Book 1</p>
<p>With the end of the conduit covered in cutting compound, slide the stock and die set over the end, making sure that the guide slides on first. Stand square to the end of conduit and grip the stocks and, using the heals of both hands, press the die onto the end of the conduit. Rotate your hands in a slow clockwise direction, allowing the die to bite into the conduit.</p>
<p>Once the die has started to cut, change your hand movement to a push and pull rotation, and steadily turn the handles through 180°. Repeat this once or twice and then turn the handles in an anticlockwise direction for just half a turn. You will feel a bit of resistance and then the die will come loose. This helps clear the swarf so the die does not jam or overheat.</p>
<p>Repeat this process slowly and steadily. If you rush you will cause the die to overheat and the thread will be damaged. Remember, a superior thread can be cut by using a little care and patience.</p>
<p>Repeat the process of two to three turns forward and then half a turn back until two whole threads protrude from the back of the stock and die. Once you have reached this point, slowly unscrew the stock and die from the conduit, again taking care not to damage the thread. It is tempting to try to spin the stocks and die off the conduit, but this can cause the die to wobble and damage part of the thread.</p>
<p>Once the stock and die have been removed from the conduit, make sure the thread is clean and clear of all swarf. Use a soft wire brush (and safety glasses in case the residue flicks up towards your eyes). With all the swarf removed, use a rag to clean away any excess cutting compound.</p>
<p>The stock and die set should be cleaned in preparation for their next use. Some people do this by banging the tool against the leg of the conduit bender. However, this can result in damage to both the bender and the stock and die set.</p>
<p>In the absence of the tool's correct cleaning brush, a stiff bristle bottle brush makes a suitable alternative. Again making sure your eyes (and the eyes of those around you) are protected, simply push the brush into the die and then withdraw. Repeat this process twice, leaving the die clean and ready for future use.</p>
<p>Before removing the conduit from the vice, check the thread is even and undamaged throughout. You can screw on a coupler to protect the thread if you are not ready to screw on the accessory.</p>
<p>When you have to cut a longer thread, it is important not to let the stocks and die overheat. To help, you can reduce the number of forward turns to one or two half turns forwards for every half turn back.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="acting-a-running-coupler">Acting a running coupler<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#acting-a-running-coupler" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>As mentioned earlier, once you have cut your thread, you normally thread on the accessory. To do this, you have to be able to turn one piece, if not both pieces, of conduit and the accessory. In some circumstances this is not possible – for example, if alterations are being made to a conduit system with bends that cannot be dismantled sufficiently to turn it.</p>
<p>ACTIVITY</p>
<p>What are the common sizes of dies used for threading conduit?</p>
<p>274</p>
<p>Chapter 4 Electrical installation</p>
<p>In this instance, the conduit to be added is built and then joined to the existing assembly using a running coupler. A running coupler is a type of joint that uses:</p>
<ul>
<li>a coupler</li>
<li>a lock nut or ring</li>
<li>(and sometimes) a nipple.</li>
</ul>
<p>A thread must be cut on the conduit to be added that is long enough to thread on both the lock nut or ring and then the coupler. When connecting into an accessory, a nipple must be threaded into the accessory so that half the thread is sticking out. Then the new part of the conduit assembly is offered up to the nipple and the coupler is unscrewed from the conduit. For joining to a second piece of conduit rather than to an accessory, the nipple is not required; the conduit already has another thread to accept the coupler.</p>
<p>As the coupler is unscrewed, it threads onto the second thread so that it can be threaded tightly onto either the accessory or conduit while still being threaded onto the new piece of conduit. To stop this from coming loose, a lock nut or ring is tightened up behind the coupler to hold it in place.</p>
<p>Once in place, the exposed thread must be painted to stop it from corroding. The paint used must complement the conduit finish, for example black enamel.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="bends">Bends<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#bends" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Though there is a wide selection of pre-manufactured bends and accessories, you also need to be able to bend conduit to meet specific circumstances.</p>
<p>Bending conduit is more about technique than brute force. It is vital that you know how to bend the conduit in the correct place. Sometimes people bend the conduit and then cut it to size; this not only creates excess waste, but also takes longer as it creates more work.</p>
<p>Before we look at how to bend conduit, we will study the names of different bends. These include:</p>
<ul>
<li>The set – sometimes referred to as a 'dog-leg', this consists of two bends, each of about  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msup><mn>45</mn><mo lspace="0em" rspace="0em">∘</mo></msup></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">45^{\circ}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6741em;"></span><span class="mord">4</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord">5</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.6741em;"><span style="top: -3.063em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">∘</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span> , on top of one another with one bend going one way and the other in the reverse direction. It is used to bring the conduit out further from the surface that it has been running on and is common at distribution panels and other switchgear.</li>
</ul>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251222-518a63ca.jpeg" alt="img-342.jpeg">
Figure 4.66 Set bend</p>
<p>The City &amp; Guilds Textbook: Electrical Installations Book 1</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251222-95e946a3.jpeg" alt="img-343.jpeg">
Figure 4.67 Kick bend</p>
<ul>
<li>The kick – this is similar to the set, but only has one bend at an angle up to 45°. This is normally used when a conduit runs up a wall and along the roof structure, such as along a rafter.</li>
<li>The bubble set – sometimes referred to as a ‘camel’ set, this is normally used when there is no other option but to run a conduit over another conduit or pipe. The two conduits (or conduit and pipe) should not come into direct contact, and the centre of the bubble should be directly above the centreline of the underlying structure. There should be a minimum of a finger-gap clearance behind the top conduit, but no more clearance than the diameter of the conduit itself.</li>
</ul>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251222-65d24ab7.jpeg" alt="img-344.jpeg">
Figure 4.68 Bubble set bend</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="industry-tip">INDUSTRY TIP<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#industry-tip" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>A door frame is a useful test piece when bending conduit. The door frame should have a 90° internal angle.</p>
<ul>
<li>The 90° bend – this is probably the most common of the bends as conduit often goes around corners of about 90°. Note that very few buildings have exact 90° corners, so the bends must be sized to fit.</li>
</ul>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251222-415bde7f.jpeg" alt="img-345.jpeg">
Figure 4.69 90° bend</p>
<ul>
<li>The swan neck – this bend is normally used where the conduit runs up a wall and over an overhang at the top. It is not a very common bend. Because of the shape of the bend, it can be difficult to remove it from the conduit bender.</li>
</ul>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251222-dffb9713.jpeg" alt="img-346.jpeg">
Figure 4.70 Swan-neck bend</p>
<p>Chapter 4 Electrical installation</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="the-conduit-bender">The conduit bender<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#the-conduit-bender" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Though there are many different types of conduit benders, they all have similar components and work in a similar manner. Learning how to bend conduit using a bender can save time and money – bending conduit is quicker than cutting and applying a thread to use a manufactured bend.</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251222-630fdd8e.jpeg" alt="img-347.jpeg">
Figure 4.71 View of a conduit bender (with part of the frame removed for clarity)</p>
<p>All steel conduit benders have some key components and in the illustration above, the following items can be seen:</p>
<ol>
<li>the roll bar, where the pressure is applied to bend the conduit and which has several holes for the different size conduits</li>
<li>the roller, which sits within the roll bar and can be positioned in the relevant hole depending on the size of conduit to be bent</li>
<li>the former, which is sized to ensure that the minimum bend radius of 2.5 times the conduit diameter is achieved</li>
<li>the stop bar, which consists of a bar with several holes giving different positions for the different size conduits, and the stop used for holding the conduit in place while it is bent.</li>
</ol>
<p>The conduit bender is designed so that the former can be changed and so that the position of the stop and roller can be altered to suit different sizes of conduit. It is important to make sure the former is in place and the correct positions for stop and roller are selected before attempting to bend any conduit.</p>
<p>All conduit benders are built to bend downwards, but when bends have runs of over 1m on either side, the conduit can be fouled by the floor. Therefore, most conduit benders have the ability to bend conduit upwards with the stop bar and</p>
<p>The City &amp; Guilds Textbook: Electrical Installations Book 1</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251222-0a1faaee.jpeg" alt="img-348.jpeg">
▲ Figure 4.72 How to measure for a back of bend</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251222-2c95413f.jpeg" alt="img-349.jpeg">
▲ Figure 4.73 How to position the conduit at the right point for bending</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="activity">ACTIVITY<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#activity" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>What is the minimum internal radius of bend for 16 mm, 25 mm and 32 mm conduit? (Answer in mm.)</p>
<p>roll bar both being able to pivot through angles in excess of 180°. Before setting the equipment to bend upwards, make sure you have sufficient clearance above the conduit bender!</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="b5a8947">Making a 90° bend<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#b5a8947" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Bending a piece of conduit requires good technique. To reduce waste, make sure you get it right first time! Some people bend the conduit and then cut it to size, but this can result in more work and a longer process as two threads must be cut.</p>
<p>In order to avoid this, use a method called 'measuring to the back of bend' (Figure 4.72). First, measure the distance from the conduit or accessory that will accept the bent piece, to the far side of the conduit saddle where the conduit will be after the bend, as shown opposite.</p>
<p>Use this dimension to mark a pencil line on the piece of conduit. The conduit is then inserted into the bender from the former side and rested under the stop bar.</p>
<p>Using an off-cut of the same size of conduit and an engineer's square, move the conduit until the pencil mark lines up with the back of the off-cut, making sure both parts remain square, as shown in the diagram.</p>
<p>With the conduit now in place, remove the engineer's square and the off-cut and use the roll bar to bend the conduit around the former. You can use one hand on the conduit to aid with the bend; this reduces the pressure on the roll bar and, therefore, reduces the potential for damage to the finished conduit. It is important to apply a steady constant pressure and not to swing on the roll bar. Bending your knees as you pull the roll bar can also assist with the bend.</p>
<p>When the roll bar is sticking out horizontally, the conduit bend is about 45°; when the roll bar is parallel with the front legs, the bend is about 90° (Figure 4.73). Remember that the conduit will spring back a little when the pressure is removed, so it is important to check the angle visually. This is done by standing side-on to the bend and squatting down so your eyes are level with the bend. It is tempting just to turn your head to see the angle of the bend, but if your eyes are not horizontal then it will be harder to see if the bend is correct.</p>
<p>It is possible to remove the conduit from the bender to check its shape against its intended location. To increase the bend, the conduit can be repositioned easily in the conduit bender without having to measure everything again.</p>
<p>Though it is possible to correct bends that have been bent too far, this should be avoided as it weakens the conduit and can cause damage. So, take your time and do it right first time. Should you have to correct a bend that has been bent too far, you should position the conduit in the bender in the opposite direction and correct using just your hands (not the roll bar) as this will give you a better idea of how far it has bent.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="a-set">A set<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#a-set" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>There are two types of set: one with angles of 30° and 60°, and the other with angles of 45° each. The set with 30° and 60° angles is the most commonly used as it places less strain on the cables when they are being drawn in. It is this set that we will consider here.</p>
<p>Chapter 4 Electrical installation</p>
<p>If we know what height is required for the set, we can identify the distance between the two bends: the height of the set multiplied by two bends. For example, if the set is required to be 50 mm, the distance between the two bends will be 100 mm (50 × 2 = 100).</p>
<p>Having worked this out, we can mark out the conduit to be bent. Make the first mark where the first bend should go. Then, measure the distance required (from the calculation) and make the second mark (Figure 4.74).</p>
<p>Having made the two marks, position the conduit in the conduit bender with the first mark aligned with the centre of the bender. This can be checked using an engineer's square placed on the conduit. This may not be directly at the top of the bender, as it will depend on whether the conduit sits horizontally within the bender.</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251222-ffe3cc3e.jpeg" alt="img-350.jpeg">
Figure 4.75 Top view showing positioning within bender</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251222-f79ec307.jpeg" alt="img-351.jpeg">
Figure 4.76 Side view showing positioning within bender</p>
<p>Steadily, bend the conduit down to an angle of around 30°, making sure you check the angle as you go.</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251222-c9c459e5.jpeg" alt="img-352.jpeg">
Figure 4.77 Angle of first bend</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="industry-tip">INDUSTRY TIP<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#industry-tip" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>When bending conduit it is virtually impossible not to damage the paint or galvanised finish. The surface should be cleaned and repainted.</p>
<p>The City &amp; Guilds Textbook: Electrical Installations Book 1</p>
<p>Once the first bend has been performed, the conduit must be rotated by <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msup><mn>180</mn><mo lspace="0em" rspace="0em">∘</mo></msup></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">180^{\circ}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6741em;"></span><span class="mord">18</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord">0</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.6741em;"><span style="top: -3.063em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">∘</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span> while still in the bender. Line up the second mark with the centre of the former and proceed as before.</p>
<p>It is important, at this point, to check that the conduit is correctly aligned in the conduit bender. Using a spirit level, ensure that the first bend is sitting perfectly vertical and not leaning to one side or the other. If it is not vertical, the second bend will not line up with the first and the two bends will be offset.</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251222-9aa4277c.jpeg" alt="img-353.jpeg">
Figure 4.78 Top view showing conduit positioned for second bend
Figure 4.79 Side view showing conduit positioned for second bend</p>
<p>With the conduit correctly aligned, the second bend can be performed until the start of the conduit runs parallel with the end of the conduit.</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251222-948c9973.jpeg" alt="img-354.jpeg">
Figure 4.80 Bend until the start and finish are parallel</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="a-bubble-set">A bubble set<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#a-bubble-set" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>This type of bend can be performed in one of two ways. The first is by performing two separate sets; this method can be used where lots of pipes (or other obstacles) are to be crossed in one go.</p>
<p>Chapter 4 Electrical installation</p>
<p>This second, more common, method requires three bends to be made within close proximity to one another. This takes a bit of practice to get right. Start off by placing a 45° bend in the conduit at the point which will be the centre of the bubble set. Then remove the conduit from the conduit bender and place it flat down on a surface to mark out the other two bends. Using a straight edge and tape measure, position the straight edge 30 mm below the inside edge of the first bend, making sure it is kept an even distance from the bend for both straight sections of conduit on either side of the bend. (This dimension will provide a very close bubble set for 20 mm conduit and can be increased if a larger clearance is required.) Mark on the conduit where the straight edge meets the conduit on both sides of the bend.</p>
<p>Using an engineer's square, mark all the way round the conduit with a pencil on each side of the first bend. Now position the conduit back in the conduit bender with the top of the first bend pointing downwards and at the stop end.</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251222-20eb897b.jpeg" alt="img-355.jpeg">
Figure 4.81 Positioning of straight edge for marking the second and third bends</p>
<p>Using the same method for lining up the conduit in the conduit bender as the method for a set, ensure the second mark is positioned correctly on the conduit bender. The second bend of 45° can now be applied.</p>
<p>The third bend is a repeat of the process for the second bend but on the other side of the first bend. With the bends correct, the conduit run before and after the bubble set should line up. Fine adjustment can be performed by replacing the conduit in the conduit bender and adjusting by hand.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="bending-pvc-conduit">Bending PVC conduit<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#bending-pvc-conduit" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The bending of PVC conduit is very similar to bending steel conduit as you use the same bends and measure them out in the same way. The difference is that a conduit bender is not used. Instead, a bending spring is used to help the conduit maintain its shape.</p>
<p>The bending spring is used to support the inside of the conduit to stop it from becoming squashed during the bending process. Bending springs come in two types:</p>
<ul>
<li>white tipped – for light gauge PVC conduit</li>
<li>green tipped – for heavy gauge PVC conduit.</li>
</ul>
<p>Bending springs are designed so that they can be fed easily into the conduit prior to bending. Before use, it is important to attach a means of removing the spring after the bend. Simply tie a piece of string to the loop at one end or, preferably,</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="activity">ACTIVITY<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#activity" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>There is also a bridge set where the middle section is parallel to the fixing surface. Make a sketch of what this would look like.</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251222-2bf22665.jpeg" alt="img-356.jpeg">
Figure 4.82 Bending spring</p>
<p>The City &amp; Guilds Textbook: Electrical Installations Book 1</p>
<p>use a cable. The string or cable should be fed through the centre of the bending spring. This will stop the spring being stretched and damaged during the removal.</p>
<p>Nowadays, some PVC conduits can be cold bent. However, it is sometimes necessary to heat the conduit prior to bending and this can be done in several ways. Some electricians use a heat blanket for PVC conduit; however, simply rubbing the conduit where it will be bent produces enough heat to help with the bend.</p>
<p>Having measured the bend, insert the spring into the conduit so that it is positioned where the bend is to be performed. One way to do this is to measure how much string or cable should be drawn into the conduit to hold the spring in the correct place.</p>
<p>With the spring in place, heat the conduit by simply rubbing your hand up and down the position for the bend. Don't rub too hard or you will get blisters – hands can be protected by using gloves or a cloth. The internal bend radius should be the same as for steel conduit, so an internal radius of 2.5 times the conduit diameter is needed. The easiest way to bend PVC conduit is over the top of the thigh. Remember to remove items such as money, phone and keys from your pockets before starting.</p>
<p>The bend should be performed in one go. So, once the conduit is heated, place your hands 300–400 mm apart on either side of section to be bent, and then bend the conduit over your thigh. The bend will need to go a little past the required angle as the conduit will tend to spring back once released.</p>
<p>If the wrong bending spring is used for a particular type of conduit, the bend can become damaged. Ribbing of the bend happens when the spring creates indentations on the outside of the bend. It can also result in kinks on the inside of the bend where the conduit tries to flatten during the bend.</p>
<p>When creating sets, it sometimes helps to mark a line so that the bends will always be square to one another. The line can be used to make sure that your hands and bending force are in the correct place before you bend. PVC conduit usually has writing along one side and this can be used as a guide. However, it is important to ensure that any lines are removed before installation and any printed writing is positioned to the back of the conduit, out of sight.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="wiring-conduit-systems">Wiring conduit systems<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#wiring-conduit-systems" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>One of the key points to remember when installing a conduit system is that the wiring cannot be installed until the conduit is complete.</p>
<p>Bear in mind that BS 7671 states that we need to protect the insulation of the wiring from damage during installation and maintenance. This is important when guiding wiring into conduit sections. All the wires for a piece of conduit need to be installed, or 'drawn in', at the same time. Wires are fed into the conduit and pulled from the other end at the same time.</p>
<p>The wires are drawn in using a push-and-pull technique that requires a draw tape to be placed in the conduit from the finish end first. A draw tape is a nylon cable</p>
<p>Chapter 4 Electrical installation</p>
<p>that has a metal cap attached to a spring at one end. This end is pushed into the conduit from the finishing end of the run. It is pushed right into the conduit until the end with the metal cap emerges at the beginning of the conduit run. If the conduit run is long, this may have to be done in stages (draw tapes tend to come in 5 m, 10 m and 20 m lengths).</p>
<p>Once the draw tape has been pushed through the conduit, and the end is sticking out of the conduit, the wiring can be attached to the draw tape. The most effective attachment method is to use PVC tape, taping the wires together with staggered starts and leaving one wire longer than the others. This single wire will be used to secure the wiring to the draw tape.</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251222-a86da94c.jpeg" alt="img-357.jpeg">
Figure 4.83 Wires staggered for taping</p>
<p>With the wires grouped together, the long wire can now be secured to the draw tape by feeding it through the hole in the end of the cap and then bending it back on itself to form a tight loop. This loop is then secured in place with more PVC tape. It is important to ensure this attachment is as secure as possible. Depending on the cross-sectional area of the wire, several passes may be made through the hole in the cap on the end of the draw tape.</p>
<p>Once the wiring is secured to the draw tape, it is ready to be drawn into the conduit. This can be a two-person job: one person feeds the wiring into the conduit, guiding the wiring through the conduit, as the other person gently pulls on the draw tape. The draw tape should never be used to pull the wiring into the conduit (without a corresponding push) as this places a strain on the wires. This could generate heat which might damage the wires and, in the case of PVC conduit, the conduit as well.</p>
<p>The push-and-pull technique is repeated until the wiring reaches its destination and the draw tape exits the conduit. Shorter runs, no longer than a metre, with no bends, can be installed without the use of a draw tape. The wiring is still grouped as it would be when using draw tape, but in this case the long wire is simply bent over to form a loop. This presents a curved edge which helps the wires move through the conduit and prevents the wire getting stuck on any edges at accessories or joints.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="trunking-systems">Trunking systems<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#trunking-systems" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>As with conduit systems, there are various forms of trunking system. Trunking is the generic name given to the enclosure of a wiring system that has a rectangular or box section fabrication and a removable lid. The purpose of trunking is to enable wiring to be installed easily and to provide the wiring with a level of mechanical protection.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="industry-tip">INDUSTRY TIP<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#industry-tip" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Do not add extra cables to an already wired conduit as abrasion or similar will occur.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="industry-tip">INDUSTRY TIP<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#industry-tip" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Cables should be fed into the conduit as straight as possible. Mount the drums on a cable rack and ensure they are fed in, not pulled in.</p>
<p>The City &amp; Guilds Textbook: Electrical Installations Book 1</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="industry-tip">INDUSTRY TIP<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#industry-tip" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Mini-trunking is just a version of plastic trunking. It is sometimes supplied with a self-adhesive backing for quick fixing. The surface to be fixed to must be clean and free of dust otherwise it won't stick.</p>
<p>Trunking systems come in two forms:</p>
<ul>
<li>PVC</li>
<li>steel.</li>
</ul>
<p>The different types of trunking that are available and their uses are identified on pages 197–8. Here we will look at terminating steel trunking only. Termination of other trunking, such as lighting trunking and Powertrack, are outside the scope of this course and further training should be sought before attempting this type of work.</p>
<p>There are benefits that trunking can provide which are not available when using conduit. Trunking can be used to install cables and wires alike, and in the same run. Trunking can have wiring added in at a later point, without the need to remove existing wiring. Trunking can be used to contain wiring for different voltage bands and different types of circuit as the trunking can be split into sections. This is called segregation. It is a requirement to remove potential interference from sensitive circuits and circuits of different voltage bands.</p>
<p>In any metallic containment system, line and neutral, or line and switch line conductors must be run together in order to avoid induction of eddy currents in the metal containment system.</p>
<p>Steel trunking comes in a variety of different types of finishes including:</p>
<ul>
<li>hot-dipped galvanised coating</li>
<li>grey enamel on zinc coating</li>
<li>silver enamel on zinc coating</li>
<li>stainless steel.</li>
</ul>
<p>Other finishes are also available to order. Trunking is typically stocked and sold in 3 m lengths, with the exception of lighting trunking which is also stocked and sold in 5 m lengths.</p>
<p>Trunking comes in a variety of different sizes, with some of the more common ones being listed within Appendix E of the IET On-Site Guide. Most suppliers will provide less common types and sizes of trunking, but only on special request and subject to a minimum order quantity.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="sizing-of-trunking">Sizing of trunking<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#sizing-of-trunking" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Even in trunking the cables get hot. There must be sufficient air space around the cables so they do not become overheated.</p>
<p>The maximum fill capacity for trunking differs from that of conduit as trunking is designed to carry both wires and cables. There is a constant fill capacity of 45% which means that air must occupy at least 55% of the internal area of the trunking.</p>
<p>The IET On-Site Guide has standard tables which take into account all the factors that govern how many conductors can be installed in a piece of trunking. The tables take into account the size and type of conductors, but do not consider bends or length as this does not affect the size of trunking to be used. The IET On-Site Guide also does not include the factors for different cables and the trunking manufacturer's data sheets should be consulted in these cases.</p>
<p>Chapter 4 Electrical installation</p>
<p>When using Appendix E, follow this simple and logical approach:</p>
<ol>
<li>Identify the different sizes of the wiring conductors.</li>
<li>Identify the quantities of each different size.</li>
<li>Using the tables in Appendix E, select the correct cable factor.</li>
<li>Multiply the factor by the number of conductors.</li>
<li>Add the totals together.</li>
<li>Select the trunking with the next factor up from the total value.</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="example">EXAMPLE<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#example" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>One easy way to follow these steps is to use a simple table, filling in the data as you go. This example is a trunking sizing calculation for a steel trunking system carrying eight single-phase circuits. Four circuits have conductors with a size of <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>25</mn><msup><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">m</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">m</mi></mrow><mn>2</mn></msup></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">25\mathrm{mm}^2</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8141em;"></span><span class="mord">25</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">mm</span></span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.8141em;"><span style="top: -3.063em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight">2</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span> and the other four are <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>16</mn><msup><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">m</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">m</mi></mrow><mn>2</mn></msup></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">16\mathrm{mm}^2</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8141em;"></span><span class="mord">16</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">mm</span></span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.8141em;"><span style="top: -3.063em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight">2</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span>. The circuits are wired in single-core cables and each circuit needs a circuit protective conductor of the same size as the live conductors.</p>
<table><thead><tr><th>Conductor size in mm²</th><th>Number of conductors</th><th>Cable factor</th><th>Total cable factor</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>16</td><td>4 × 3 = 12</td><td>47.8</td><td>12 × 47.8 = 573.6</td></tr><tr><td>25</td><td>4 × 3 = 12</td><td>73.9</td><td>12 × 73.9 = 886.8</td></tr><tr><td></td><td></td><td>Total</td><td>573.6 + 886.8 = 1460.4</td></tr></tbody></table>
<p>The final result is an overall trunking factor of 1461. Using the appropriate table in Appendix E of the IET On-Site Guide, it can be seen that <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>75</mn><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">m</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">m</mi></mrow><mo>×</mo><mn>50</mn><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">m</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">m</mi></mrow></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">75\mathrm{mm} \times 50\mathrm{mm}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.7278em; vertical-align: -0.0833em;"></span><span class="mord">75</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">mm</span></span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span><span class="mbin">×</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6444em;"></span><span class="mord">50</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">mm</span></span></span></span></span></span> or <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>100</mn><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">m</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">m</mi></mrow><mo>×</mo><mn>38</mn><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">m</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">m</mi></mrow></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">100\mathrm{mm} \times 38\mathrm{mm}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.7278em;
