vertical-align: -0.0833em;"></span><span class="mord">100</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">mm</span></span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span><span class="mbin">×</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6444em;"></span><span class="mord">38</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">mm</span></span></span></span></span></span> trunking can be used – both have a spacing factor in excess of the 1461 required.</p>
<p>Unlike conduit, there are often several choices of trunking size to use. The final choice will have to take into account the installation and aesthetic qualities required.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="trunking-accessories">Trunking accessories<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#trunking-accessories" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Trunking comes in all shapes and sizes, but the most common is the box type. The lid of the trunking forms a slight overlap at either edge, giving strength to the overall construction.</p>
<p>The lid of the trunking can be held in place with different types of fastenings, the most common being the turn buckle. Turn buckles are designed so that a simple hole can be drilled in the lid and the body of the turn buckle inserted into the hole. The body has a head that fits either a large flat screwdriver or, preferably, a pozi-screwdriver, and this needs to be on the outside of the lid. On the inside, the turn buckle has a hole into which a rod is inserted that is slightly smaller than the width of the trunking. This rod grips under the return edge of the trunking when the turn buckle is turned, retaining the lid in place.</p>
<p>Unlike conduit, the main accessories for steel trunking are used to join trunking pieces together rather than to mount accessories. Where accessories are to be connected, a conduit coupler and male bushes are used. The male bush is often tightened using a bush spanner.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="activity">ACTIVITY<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#activity" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>How many <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>16</mn><msup><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">m</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">m</mi></mrow><mn>2</mn></msup></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">16\mathrm{mm}^2</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8141em;"></span><span class="mord">16</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">mm</span></span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.8141em;"><span style="top: -3.063em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight">2</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span> cables could be installed in a 75 mm × 50 mm trunking?</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251222-049ed9b5.jpeg" alt="img-358.jpeg">
Figure 4.84 Steel trunking</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251222-5d784bf2.jpeg" alt="img-359.jpeg">
Figure 4.85 Connection methods</p>
<p>The City &amp; Guilds Textbook: Electrical Installations Book 1</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251222-95f1589e.jpeg" alt="img-360.jpeg">
Figure 4.86 Flat bend</p>
<ul>
<li>The flat bend is simply a 90° bend with the lid on the front of the trunking. This can be used when trunking is run up a wall and then turns to run along the wall.</li>
<li>There are also variations of the flat bend in terms of the position of the lid. The internal bend has the lid positioned on the inside of the bend and the external bend has the lid on the outside.</li>
</ul>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251222-8972fc07.jpeg" alt="img-361.jpeg">
Figure 4.87 External and internal bends</p>
<ul>
<li>As well as the flat bends, there are the relieved bends where, instead of trying to force the wiring around a tight 90° bend, the bend is spaced out as two 45° bends. Again, there is the choice of the lid being on the flat, internal or external faces of the bend.</li>
</ul>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251222-262fba21.jpeg" alt="img-362.jpeg">
Figure 4.89 Tee piece</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251222-db5aae35.jpeg" alt="img-363.jpeg">
Figure 4.90 Relieved tee</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251222-a2ea3f23.jpeg" alt="img-364.jpeg">
Figure 4.88 Flat, internal and external relieved bends</p>
<ul>
<li>The tee piece is used to join a piece of trunking onto the side of another piece of trunking at a perpendicular angle. Unlike the bends, the tee piece only comes in one form, with the lid on the front.</li>
<li>The relieved tee is similar to the relieved bends in that, instead of presenting a sharp 90° bend, it presents two spaced 45° bends to make the bend suit the wiring bend radius.</li>
</ul>
<p>When the installation changes from one size of trunking to another, reducers can be used.</p>
<p>Chapter 4 Electrical installation</p>
<p>When two pieces of trunking are to be joined, it is necessary to use two couplings. A coupling is simply a plate designed to fit inside the trunking and bridge the join. To enable the trunking to be secured, the coupling has two threaded bushes mounted on one side. This removes the need to position a nut inside the trunking and so a short length bolt can be used. The bushes on the inside are sometimes called 'captive nuts' or, more correctly, 'hank bushes'.</p>
<p>When a join is performed, it is important to ensure the electrical continuity of the steel. Trunking manufacturers generally recommend, that to ensure continuity, an earth strap is installed on the outside of the trunking across the gap.</p>
<p>At the end of any run of trunking, an open end is normally present and this needs to be closed off. To do this an end cap is often used, but in some cases it is possible to cut and bend over the lid of the trunking. The end cap has similar bushes to those used in the coupling – a short screw can be screwed into the end cap, through the trunking, once it is in place.</p>
<p>Just as with conduit bends, trunking bends can be fabricated or purchased. Sometimes fabrication is best when a custom angle or a slightly different bend is required. As mentioned earlier, most buildings are not exactly square, meaning that pre-manufactured bends do not always fit properly. It is essential, therefore, to know how to manufacture these bends.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="cutting-trunking">Cutting trunking<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#cutting-trunking" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Trunking is a hollow structure that must be complete to exhibit its full strength. This can be problematic when cutting.</p>
<p>It is important to cut the trunking and the lid separately as, often, the lid needs to be a different size or shape.</p>
<p>Just as when cutting steel conduit, there are certain tools that are required for cutting steel trunking. These include:</p>
<ul>
<li>hacksaw with a blade between 24 and 32 TPI</li>
<li>graphite pencil for marking out</li>
<li>tape measure</li>
<li>engineer's square</li>
<li>hand file (generally second cut grade)</li>
<li>small round file (generally smooth cut grade)</li>
<li>engineer's vice or clamps</li>
<li>steel rule</li>
<li>appropriate signs and obstacles for making sure the work area is cordoned off.</li>
</ul>
<p>You will need plenty of appropriately sized wood to pack the trunking – this prevents it from distorting when it is being clamped for cutting. The wood should be positioned on the clamping side of the cut line, so as not to foul the hacksaw as it cuts.</p>
<p>When cutting trunking, make sure that all cuts are even and square; accurate marking out is essential. To perform a simple cut, first use the tape measure to measure the required length and mark with the pencil. Then, using an engineer's</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="industry-tip">INDUSTRY TIP<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#industry-tip" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Where multiple-compartment trunking is used with segregated circuits, special crossover pieces may be needed to ensure segregation.</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251222-62394507.jpeg" alt="img-365.jpeg">
Figure 4.91 End cap</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="activity">ACTIVITY<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#activity" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>A scriber is used to scratch a mark in galvanised trunking in preparation for cutting. The mark breaks through the galvanized protection. What could happen to the trunking if a mark is made in the wrong place and left there when the trunking is cut in the right place?</p>
<p>287</p>
<p>The City &amp; Guilds Textbook: Electrical Installations Book 1</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251222-2cb84454.jpeg" alt="img-366.jpeg">
Figure 4.92 Using an engineer's square to mark out trunking</p>
<p>square, mark round the trunking making sure that the line is perpendicular to the trunking on all sides.</p>
<p>Once marked out, the trunking must be secured ready for cutting. This can be achieved by placing the trunking in an engineer's vice or by using clamps to secure the trunking onto a work bench. The position of the clamp should be close to the cut line, but not so close as to impede cutting. Trunking should never be held in one hand while cutting with the other.</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251222-ddb37d4a.jpeg" alt="img-367.jpeg">
Figure 4.94 Marking out for a tee piece</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251222-5cd2de45.jpeg" alt="img-368.jpeg">
Figure 4.95 Cut parts for a tee piece</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251222-664114d5.jpeg" alt="img-369.jpeg">
Figure 4.93 A wood packer being used to support trunking</p>
<p>To cut steel trunking, a similar cutting style to that used when cutting steel conduit should be adopted, making sure the hacksaw does the work by using the entire blade length.</p>
<p>Once cut, the engineer's square should be used to check that the edges are square and even. If they are not, they need to be filed. When using the hand file, work evenly across the end of the trunking as this will minimise the amount of noise the filing makes.</p>
<p>Once square, all sharp edges and burrs should be removed from both the outside and inside of the trunking. Internal corners may require the use of the small round file to remove burrs.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="making-a-tee-piece">Making a tee piece<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#making-a-tee-piece" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>To create a tee piece, the same tools as for cutting conduit will be required. Figure 4.94 shows how the trunking should be marked out for cutting. Note the size of the parts to be removed are based on the width of the trunking. The hole in part A should be the same width as the part of part B which is entering part A. The depth of the back and front of part B that needs to be removed is the width of part A minus 5 mm. This allows for the internal bend of the trunking.</p>
<p>Use a junior hacksaw to cut down the edge of part A to the side wall and then use the hand file to remove some of the metal from the back of the bend (where the return edge is to be removed) until it can be bent easily with pliers. Bend this</p>
<p>Chapter 4 Electrical installation</p>
<p>piece back and forth a few times until the edge comes away. The same technique can be used for removing the wall section, but you will need to cut at least one side of the back of part B.</p>
<p>Remember to remove the sharp edges and burrs from your cuts.</p>
<p>The two parts are joined together by slotting part B into part A and then bending the ends of part B over to create flaps. These can be bolted to the wall of the trunking or riveted.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="making-an-internal-bend">Making an internal bend<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#making-an-internal-bend" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>An internal bend is arranged with the lid on the inside. Therefore, the trunking is cut on the inside and the top edges need to be removed.</p>
<p>Mark a line all the way around the trunking, using a pencil and engineer's square. Then, using the width of the trunking as a measurement, measure out and mark a line on both sides of the mark line. Measure 5 mm from either side of the centre line and then mark down as shown in the diagram below left.</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251222-287dd2a0.jpeg" alt="img-370.jpeg">
Figure 4.97 Marking out for internal bend (left), cutting for internal bend (middle), and assembled internal bend (right)</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251222-7abafb7d.jpeg" alt="img-371.jpeg"></p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251222-ec609393.jpeg" alt="img-372.jpeg">
Figure 4.96 Assembled tee piece</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251222-d3daab4a.jpeg" alt="img-373.jpeg"></p>
<p>Using a junior hacksaw, cut the return edges at the outside marks and then file the edges until the return edges can be bent and removed with pliers. Next, cut the walls along the angled lines to form a vee shape.</p>
<p>Once you have cut the trunking, make sure all burrs and sharp edges have been removed and then simply bend one side up, slotting the walls of one side into the other. Bolt or rivet in place.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="making-an-external-bend">Making an external bend<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#making-an-external-bend" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>An external bend is made so that the lid is placed on the outside; the marking and cutting is performed from the back.</p>
<p>Mark a line all the way around the trunking, using a pencil and engineer's square. Then, using the width of the trunking as a measurement, measure out and mark a line on the back on both sides of the mark line.</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251222-114331b2.jpeg" alt="img-374.jpeg">
Figure 4.98 Marking out for external bend (left) and cutting for external bend (right)</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251222-bbf2ca48.jpeg" alt="img-375.jpeg"></p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="industry-tip">INDUSTRY TIP<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#industry-tip" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Making trunking fittings is an important skill, but remember, they will hardly ever match manufactured fittings for appearance although the cost may seem lower.</p>
<p>The City &amp; Guilds Textbook: Electrical Installations Book 1</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251222-af69b558.jpeg" alt="img-376.jpeg">
Figure 4.99 Assembled external bend</p>
<p>Cut right through the trunking at line A and cut through the back only at point B. File between A and B on one of the back corners to weaken it, then bend the flap of metal until it breaks off. File down the edges. File away the corners between A and C and make the resulting slots smooth.</p>
<p>Now slot part AB over part AC and bend the flap up. Bolt or rivet through both walls and the flap to secure in place.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="making-a-flat-bend">Making a flat bend<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#making-a-flat-bend" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>A flat bend is made so that the lid of the trunking is fitted to the top of the trunking; the marking out and cutting is made to one side wall only.</p>
<p>As with all the bends, start off by marking a line, line A, all the way around the trunking using an engineer's square. Then measure and mark, using the width of the trunking as a measurement, a line on either side (lines C and B in the diagram). Also, mark a line 10 mm from line A on one side only. This is line D.</p>
<p>Using a hacksaw, cut down line A leaving one wall intact. Then cut along line B, cutting only one wall. File the back corner between A and B to weaken it. Bend the flap of metal until it breaks off. File down the edge where the metal breaks.</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251222-8742abe6.jpeg" alt="img-377.jpeg">
Figure 4.100 Marking out for flat bend (left), removal of wall (middle) and removal of return lip (right)</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251222-4c1a23b5.jpeg" alt="img-378.jpeg"></p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251222-48dd8c51.jpeg" alt="img-379.jpeg"></p>
<p>Now, using a hacksaw, cut the return edge on line D, use a file to weaken the corner, then bend the flap of metal between A and D until it breaks off. File down the edge where the metal breaks.</p>
<p>Using a hand file, remove the lip between line C and line A. File away the lower corner, leaving a flap on the same side as the removed wall.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="industry-tip">INDUSTRY TIP<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#industry-tip" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The minimum IP rating for metal trunking is IP2X but if used in areas where there is a high risk of spread of fire this is increased to IP33.</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251222-cdc6f606.jpeg" alt="img-380.jpeg">
Figure 4.101 Removal of return edge from flap (left) and assembled flat bend (right)</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251222-0deb2c0e.jpeg" alt="img-381.jpeg"></p>
<p>Now the trunking can be bent along the remaining edge of line A into a 90° bend with the flap bent to seal the bend. The back and flap can be bolted or riveted into place.</p>
<p>Chapter 4 Electrical installation</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="mounting-trunking">Mounting trunking<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#mounting-trunking" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>There are various methods that can be used for mounting trunking. Most trunking is either:</p>
<ul>
<li>surface mounted
or</li>
<li>suspended.</li>
</ul>
<p>Surface mounting simply requires mounting holes to be drilled through the trunking so that it can be screwed to the surface. For suspended mounting, other methods and accessories can be used.</p>
<p>One method is a simple run of conduit which is secured in place to the ceiling and then joined to the trunking using a coupler and male bush arrangement. Another common method uses channelling, normally called uni-strut, and threaded shafts, called studding.</p>
<p>The uni-strut is secured in place and captive nuts are positioned within the uni-strut. The studding is threaded into the uni-strut and is cut to the required length. The trunking is then attached to the studding by use of a trunking suspension bracket. The benefit of this system is that the trunking is installed level and true, despite deviations in the height of the uni-strut mounts.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="pvc-trunking">PVC trunking<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#pvc-trunking" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>The benefit of PVC trunking is that manufacturers can mould many different forms, finishes and colours. For example, skirting board trunking can either replace the skirting board of the room completely or can supplement the existing skirting board. The versatility of PVC trunking means that it is commonly favoured over steel trunking, especially in situations where it is visible.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="cutting-pvc-trunking">Cutting PVC trunking<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#cutting-pvc-trunking" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>PVC trunking can be cut using a variety of different methods, including:</p>
<ul>
<li>trunking snips</li>
<li>electrician's knife</li>
<li>hacksaw.</li>
</ul>
<p>Cutting PVC trunking with trunking snips can be quick, but in colder environments this can cause splitting and cracking. Cutting with snips can also cause the trunking to deform, but this can be overcome by cutting the lid and the trunking at the same time.</p>
<p>An electrician's knife can be used to cut through light gauge trunking, but this can also result in deformation of the trunking (and injury to fingers). However, when removing a part of the trunking wall, scoring the inside edge with an electrician's knife can make the wall weak enough to snap off, leaving a very clean break with few sharp edges to be removed.</p>
<p>Using a hacksaw minimises the risk of deforming the trunking (and of injuring the installer). A trunking mitre block is generally used and this can be secured in an engineer's vice. The mitre block typically has two 45° slots and one at 90°</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="industry-tip">INDUSTRY TIP<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#industry-tip" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>When fixing trunking, round-head screws should be used, as countersunk screws leave a raised edge which could cut into cables.</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251222-495ea719.jpeg" alt="img-382.jpeg">
Figure 4.102 Conduit secured to ceiling using ceiling flange</p>
<p>The City &amp; Guilds Textbook: Electrical Installations Book 1</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251222-24e3607a.jpeg" alt="img-383.jpeg">
Figure 4.103 PVC trunking mitre-cutting block</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="key-term">KEY TERM<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#key-term" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>IP code: international protection code used to identify accessories and equipment according to their resistance to penetration and water ingress.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="key-term">KEY TERM<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#key-term" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Segregation: keeping things apart in different compartments.</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251222-45547236.jpeg" alt="img-384.jpeg">
Figure 4.104 Light gauge and heavy gauge cable tray</p>
<p>meaning that it is not necessary to measure and mark out these cuts. The base of the mitre block has ridges at set intervals and of set sizes, so that the lips of the trunking and lid slot in. This prevents them moving while being cut.</p>
<p>Trunking is normally cut at 45° for corners and at 90° for joins. Lids tend to be cut at 90° as the joints and corners are typically covered with an accessory, forming a moulded section to ensure the relevant IP code rating can be maintained.</p>
<p>It is important to make sure that the trunking has a continuous form around all joins and bends. Lids, however, are cut to stop about 5 mm from each join or bend, allowing a cover to be fitted. This space allows the cover to clip onto the trunking.</p>
<p>To remove a wall of the trunking, simply cut down the sides using a junior hacksaw and then, using a sharp electrician's knife, score the inside wall at the base between the two hacksaw cut lines. Bend back the wall section and snap it off.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="segregated-trunking">Segregated trunking<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#segregated-trunking" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Irrespective of whether the trunking is steel or PVC, it can be split into different sections or compartments. The use of different compartments or sections can assist with segregation of specific circuits, for example keeping data cables segregated from low-voltage power circuits, and keeping band 1 and band 2 circuits separate.</p>
<p>Segregated trunking can even have separate lids for each of the sections, so that only the lid of the partition being worked on is opened. This is particularly useful in rooms where computers are positioned around the perimeter of the room. This type of trunking, when installed on the surface, is commonly referred to as dado trunking.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="cable-tray">Cable tray<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#cable-tray" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Sometimes the size or type of cable and the route or the required bend radius means that the use of trunking or conduit is not practicable. Instead, armoured cables are used in conjunction with cable tray.</p>
<p>Cable tray comes in several forms including:</p>
<ul>
<li>heavy gauge perforated</li>
<li>light gauge perforated</li>
<li>heavy gauge solid</li>
<li>light gauge solid.</li>
</ul>
<p>The choice of cable tray depends on the application, but heavy gauge is used for larger cables or where there is a greater mass of smaller cables to be supported. Heavy gauge cable tray tends to have walls with bent over edges, whereas the walls on light gauge are straight with no returned edge.</p>
<p>The difference between solid and perforated cable tray is simply that the perforated version has a series of slots and holes in the back and walls to enable cable fixings such as P-clips and cable ties to be used to secure the cables in place. The perforations also help with ventilation and cooling.</p>
<p>Chapter 4 Electrical installation</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="cable-tray-accessories">Cable tray accessories<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#cable-tray-accessories" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>As with all other forms of support system, it takes time to fabricate parts during cable tray assembly. Some standard items are pre-manufactured. Some of these accessories are shown here. It is important to note that the end of each run of cable tray is shaped to fit into the next one, providing a standard overlap and creating a much stronger join.</p>
<p>The 90° bend comes in several forms, the first being the flat bend. This is where the cable tray can be connected to another piece that is in the same plane, but at an angle of 90°.</p>
<p>As with trunking, sometimes the flat 90° bend is too sharp for larger cables and, therefore, a relief bend is required to give a slower bend, permitting a larger bending radius.</p>
<p>Often cable tray has to curve upwards or downwards by 90°, for example when the tray has been run along a wall and across a ceiling. In this instance, the bend radius still needs to be observed; either an internal or external bend can be used.</p>
<p>Cable tray also uses the tee piece in both the flat and relieved form, shaped in a similar way to trunking.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="cutting-cable-tray">Cutting cable tray<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#cutting-cable-tray" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Cable tray is available in 3 m lengths and must be cut to length as required. The process for measuring the length required is the same as that for trunking. To cut the tray, it must be supported on a flat surface – use clamps to hold it in place or screw the tray to a wooden surface.</p>
<p>As with some of the earlier containment systems covered in this unit, the accessories for cable tray can also be manufactured if required. When making these joints, all sharp edges and burrs must be removed before cables are installed. The technique used for removing the walls of the cable tray is the same as that used for trunking: a hand file is used to weaken the edge, allowing the walls to be bent off by hand.</p>
<p>The tools needed to cut and form cable tray include:</p>
<ul>
<li>hacksaw with a blade between 24 and 32 TPI</li>
<li>junior hacksaw</li>
<li>graphite pencil for marking out</li>
<li>tape measure</li>
<li>engineer's square</li>
<li>hand file (generally second cut grade)</li>
<li>engineer's vice or clamps</li>
<li>steel rule</li>
<li>appropriate signs and obstacles for making sure the work area is cordoned off.</li>
</ul>
<p>When marking out, most of the dimensions are made from the back of the tray as this provides a flat surface to work on. However, cutting the tray often involves just the walls, so the use of the engineer's square is essential to transfer the measurements to the side walls.</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251222-661d1562.jpeg" alt="img-385.jpeg">
Figure 4.105 Flat bend</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251222-a871bbb4.jpeg" alt="img-386.jpeg">
Figure 4.106 Relieved flat bend</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251222-a5675d30.jpeg" alt="img-387.jpeg">
Figure 4.107 Internal and external bends</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="industry-tip">INDUSTRY TIP<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#industry-tip" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Cables can be mounted on trays by using P clips or cable ties. One cable should not be tied to another as this puts undue strain on the cable and tie.</p>
<p>The City &amp; Guilds Textbook: Electrical Installations Book 1</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="industry-tip">INDUSTRY TIP<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#industry-tip" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>BS 7671:2018 (2022) The IET Wiring Regulations, 18th Edition amendment 2 521.10.202 states:</p>
<p>‘Wiring systems shall be supported such that they will not be liable to premature collapse in the event of a fire.’</p>
<p>This is because wiring systems hanging across access or exit routes may hinder evacuation and firefighting activities in the event of an emergency. As a result, cables installed in or on steel cable containment systems are deemed to meet the requirements of this regulation. However, the use of non-metallic cable clips or cable ties as the only means of support is not suitable where cables are clipped direct to exposed surfaces or suspended under traywork. Suitably spaced steel or copper clips, saddles or ties are examples that will meet the requirements of this regulation.</p>
<p>For joining cable tray, one end of each run of tray is reduced in size so that it can sit inside the other end. This creates an overlap which is typically the same as the width of the tray being used. Therefore, when any join or bend is being manufactured, this is the minimum amount of overlap that is required. Using a junior hacksaw, the walls can be cut and then a hand file used to break or weaken the back of the bend so that the wall can be bent down and removed by hand.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="mounting-of-cable-tray">Mounting of cable tray<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#mounting-of-cable-tray" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>During the erection of cable tray, it is important to ensure it is run level. Pre-manufactured saddles or, preferably, uni-strut and studding can be used. As with trunking, this means that the cable tray can be kept level and adjustment can be made where required.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="cable-basket">Cable basket<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#cable-basket" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Cable basket is also referred to as ‘basket tray’ and is commonly used for the structured cabling of information technology systems. The benefit of this containment system is the ease with which wiring can be installed. It offers little in the form of mechanical protection to the cables. The main purpose of it is to provide support rather than protection.</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251222-acfc5851.jpeg" alt="img-388.jpeg">
Figure 4.108 Cable basket</p>
<p>The cable basket is specifically designed so that cables are just laid within the basket. No further means of securing the cables is required. This enables the addition of further cables at a later point without creating any installation issues. Cable baskets can be run overhead in the space above suspended ceilings or even underneath raised floors in office areas. This is common in open-plan offices in large buildings, where there needs to be a certain amount of flexibility as to the location of the network points.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="ladder-systems">Ladder systems<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#ladder-systems" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Where large cables are to be installed, then the use of cable tray may not be suitable and a more robust containment system is required. The favoured choice</p>
<p>Chapter 4 Electrical installation</p>
<p>for many is ladder racking. It is so-called as it resembles a ladder and the cables are run across what would be called the rungs of a ladder. Due to the nature of how it is manufactured it is not possible to bend this on site, unlike the other containment systems.</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251222-3a979de4.jpeg" alt="img-389.jpeg">
Figure 4.109 Ladder racking carrying SWA cables</p>
<p>Bends in ladder racking must be designed and ordered accordingly, before the ladder racking is installed. Due to the strength of this type of containment it is used predominantly for large power cables.</p>
<p>Ladder racking is similar to cable basket, in that it does not offer much mechanical protection to the cables and so the use of armoured cables is common in such situations.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="busbar-and-powertrack-systems">Busbar and Powertrack systems<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#busbar-and-powertrack-systems" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>In some installations there is a need to provide a level of flexibility regarding where the loads are to be connected to the supply. An example of this is in an open office area with a raised floor and or a suspended ceiling. For an open-plan office area, the system installed needs to be flexible enough to support any arrangement of office layout.</p>
<p>One method of achieving this is with the use of a system called Powertrack, which is made up of modular sections. Each section is a rectangular shape, rather similar to trunking, but inside the casing three conductors are arranged, each connected to connection sockets at regular intervals along their length. These connection points can be connected via a form of plug and socket arrangement to what are called floor points, in the raised floor. The raised floor is made up of a series of tiles mounted on pillars, which are secured to the floor. This arrangement results in sections of floor that can be moved from one position to another very</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="industry-tip">INDUSTRY TIP<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#industry-tip" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The bends in the ladder rack must accommodate the required bending radius of the cables.</p>
<p>The City &amp; Guilds Textbook: Electrical Installations Book 1</p>
<p>easily. The system not only saves time in wiring, but also gives great flexibility in the layout of modern offices.</p>
<p>Powertrack also comes in an arrangement that can be installed above suspended ceilings and is used for connecting office lighting. This makes installation and maintenance of the lighting much safer and more efficient, as a luminaire can be disconnected and then brought down to ground level to be worked on.</p>
<p>Powertrack typically only comes in ratings up to and including 40 A and is single-phase only. Larger applications such as three-phase machinery need a different solution. Rather than running lots of cables the length of a factory, an alternative is the use of busbar trunking. This form of trunking does not house cables. Large copper bars are mounted within the trunking and these are used to carry the current.</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251222-5f2ee743.jpeg" alt="img-390.jpeg">
▲ Figure 4.110 Typical busbar trunking arrangement</p>
<p>Busbar trunking can be designed to carry currents of 2000 A and beyond and so offers a simpler approach to providing high power than cable. In industrial applications, the use of busbar trunking to provide distribution of power to lots of pieces of machinery within the same room is quite common.</p>
<p>Each connection to a final piece of equipment can be made using a variety of different tap-off units, which can include the provision of local isolation and protective devices such as fuses. The final connection to the machinery can also be made using a variety of different cables or installation methods.</p>
<p>Chapter 4 Electrical installation</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="thermoplastic-pvc-cables">Thermoplastic (PVC) cables<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#thermoplastic-pvc-cables" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Thermoplastic cables are commonly referred to as PVC (polyvinyl chloride) cables and they come in various shapes, sizes and forms, including:</p>
<ul>
<li>single-core cable</li>
<li>twin and cpc flat-profile cable</li>
<li>three-core and cpc flat-profile cable</li>
<li>multi-core flexible cable.</li>
</ul>
<p>In domestic installations, the most common cables are the twin and cpc, and the three-core and cpc flat-profile cables.</p>
<p>Cables have three main parts:</p>
<ul>
<li>Sheath – this is on the outside and holds the conductors in one cable, as well as providing minor mechanical protection to the inner conductors</li>
<li>Insulation – this is on the live conductors only and is used to provide basic protection against electric shock, as well as being a means to identify the conductors</li>
<li>Conductor – this is what carries the current and is commonly made from copper, but may be made out of other materials such as aluminium.</li>
</ul>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251222-3d109ee5.jpeg" alt="img-391.jpeg">
Figure 4.111 Flat-profile cables</p>
<p>Conductors can be formed in several ways. Conductors with a cross-sectional area (csa) up to and including <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>2.5</mn><msup><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">m</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">m</mi></mrow><mn>2</mn></msup></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">2.5\mathrm{mm}^2</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8141em;"></span><span class="mord">2.5</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">mm</span></span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.8141em;"><span style="top: -3.063em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight">2</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span> can be formed out of a single piece of copper. Above <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>2.5</mn><msup><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">m</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">m</mi></mrow><mn>2</mn></msup></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">2.5\mathrm{mm}^2</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8141em;"></span><span class="mord">2.5</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">mm</span></span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.8141em;"><span style="top: -3.063em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight">2</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span> csa, conductors tend to be made out of multiple strands of copper. It is important to be able to bend the cable and a solid piece of copper would be hard to bend. However, for conductors of <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>300</mn><msup><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">m</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">m</mi></mrow><mn>2</mn></msup></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">300\mathrm{mm}^2</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8141em;"></span><span class="mord">300</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">mm</span></span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.8141em;"><span style="top: -3.063em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight">2</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span> csa and over, the conductors tend to be solid again; bending is not normally required.</p>
<p>If a cable is to be bent a lot in use, for example in the flex connecting a vacuum cleaner to a plug, the conductor is normally made of many fine strands of copper, each no thicker than a hair. The reason for this is that as the conductors keep getting bent, they will eventually break. In a solid conductor, the circuit would be broken. In a conductor consisting of many strands, if one breaks, it will not significantly change the amount of current the cable can carry.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="stripping-single-core-thermoplastic-cables">Stripping single-core thermoplastic cables<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#stripping-single-core-thermoplastic-cables" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Removal of the thermoplastic sheath, or insulation, is relatively easy with thermoplastic cables.</p>
<p>Use of wire strippers is recommended for single-core conductors. Automatic wire strippers tend to rip the insulation from the conductor and can damage the</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="industry-tip">INDUSTRY TIP<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#industry-tip" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The minimum size of aluminium conductor allowed by BS 7671, is <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>16</mn><msup><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">m</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">m</mi></mrow><mn>2</mn></msup></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">16\mathrm{mm}^2</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8141em;"></span><span class="mord">16</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">mm</span></span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.8141em;"><span style="top: -3.063em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight">2</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span>.</p>
<p>The City &amp; Guilds Textbook: Electrical Installations Book 1</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251222-5ccb6ecc.jpeg" alt="img-392.jpeg">
Figure 4.112 Cable stripper jaws</p>
<p>insulation. Manual wire strippers are preferred and these come in various forms, but all work on a similar principle.</p>
<p>Manual wire strippers all have two blades that cross one another like scissors. The blades each have a notch so that they cut around the conductor in the middle. They also all have a means of adjustment so that different sizes of conductor can be stripped (Figure 4.112).</p>
<p>Before using wire strippers, they must be set to the correct size. This can be done using a scrap or off-cut piece of wire of the correct size. With the jaws of the wire strippers together, turn the adjustment screw until the hole in the jaws is just bigger than the size of the conductor to be stripped. Test the setting on the off-cut piece of wire by placing the wire strippers over the wire and squeezing the handles to close the jaws. Then slightly release the jaws and try to slide the insulation off using the wire strippers to assist.</p>
<p>If the wire strippers are correctly set, the insulation will come off easily and there will be no damage to the copper conductor. If the aperture is set too small, the insulation will slide off easily but the conductor may be damaged. If set too large, the insulation will not come off easily. A simple adjustment of the adjusting screw will correct these problems. Now, with the correct setting, the wires can be stripped safely.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="stripping-flat-profile-thermoplastic-cable">Stripping flat-profile thermoplastic cable<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#stripping-flat-profile-thermoplastic-cable" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Flat-profile cable is stripped in the same way as single-core cables, once the sheath has been removed. There are several ways to do this, but some methods can damage the cables.</p>
<p>First identify how much cable is required within the accessory. A conductor should terminate with ease at any termination point within the accessory. As a rule of thumb, measure the diagonal size of the accessory and then add 10% to allow for termination. However, if the accessory is a distribution panel, wires must be able to reach not just the required position, but also any point on the panel if the sequence of the board were to be changed.</p>
<p>Next, identify how much of the sheath should be removed from the cable. The purpose of the sheath is to provide some mechanical protection for the insulation on the conductors. However, too much sheath within the accessory takes up space and will put excess strain on the conductors. The sheath should be stripped back almost to where the cable enters the accessory, leaving only 10–15 mm, a thumb's width, of sheath within the accessory.</p>
<p>Having decided on the length of sheath required and with the cable in place, score round the sheath so that it can be removed. This can be done with a scriber or, preferably, with an electrician's knife. Care should be taken not to cut into the wires. Use a pair of side cutters to snip down the centre of the cable, splitting the line to one side and the neutral to the other.</p>
<p>Pull the live conductor and sheath apart, tearing the sheath as far as the score mark. Once at the score mark, bend the sheath back and snap it off, leaving a clean finish.</p>
<p>Now the inner wires can be stripped in the same manner as single-core wires, making sure that green and yellow sleeving is applied to the bare copper cpc.</p>
<p>Chapter 4 Electrical installation</p>
<p>An alternative – but less safe – method of removing the sheath is to score round the sheath with an electrician's knife, then to split the sheath by running a knife along the route of the protective conductor. The risk with this method is of damaging the cpc or even the insulation of the conductors.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="stripping-thermoplastic-flexible-cables">Stripping thermoplastic flexible cables<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#stripping-thermoplastic-flexible-cables" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Stripping the actual wires of flexible cables is done in the same way as stripping single-core wires. However, the sheath is stripped in a different way from the other cables already mentioned here.</p>
<p>The outer sheath can be removed with the use of a ringing tool which comes in various shapes and forms, the most basic of which is shown in Figure 4.113. This tool slides over the end of the cable, to the required position, and is then rotated around the cable, cutting it slightly. The ringing tool is removed, the cable is bent to finish the cut and the sheath is then pulled off.</p>
<p>There may be times when a ringing tool is not available, so it is important to know how to do this without a special tool. Thermoplastic has a tendency to split when it is damaged and stretched, and this feature can be used to help strip the sheath.</p>
<p>Bend the cable tightly at the point where the sheath is to be removed. Using a sharp knife gently score the top of the bend, noticing the thermoplastic split open like a little mouth. Gently work the split until the inner cables are visible and then unbend, rotate and re-bend the cable at about 90° from the first point. Repeat the score until again the wires become visible. Taking care not to cut into the wires, repeat the bend and cut until the sheath can be removed. Once the sheath has been removed, the wires can be stripped as mentioned previously.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="terminating-cables">TERMINATING CABLES<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#terminating-cables" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Terminating cables and BS 7671</p>
<p>Section 526 of BS 7671 The IET Wiring Regulations is the key section relating to the terminating and connection of conductors. Below is a regulation-by-regulation discussion of the requirements.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="526-1">526.1<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#526-1" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<p>This requires that all connections shall provide 'durable electrical continuity and adequate mechanical strength and protection'. This is a general requirement and is in keeping with requirements of the EAWR. The subsequent regulations give further information on how this can be achieved.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="526-2">526.2<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#526-2" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<p>This requires that 'the means of connection shall take account of, as appropriate:</p>
<p>i the material of the conductor and its insulation
ii the number and shape of the wires forming the conductor
iii the cross-sectional area of the conductor
iv the number of conductors to be connected together</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251222-cfcb42d6.jpeg" alt="img-393.jpeg">
Figure 4.113 Flexible cable sheath-stripping tool</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="industry-tip">INDUSTRY TIP<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#industry-tip" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The requirement for connections is that they are electrically continuous and mechanically strong. Many purists do not like the use of strip connectors (chocolate blocks) but, like anything else, used correctly they are fine. Given the very large numbers in use, they must have something going for them.</p>
<p>The City &amp; Guilds Textbook: Electrical Installations Book 1</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="key-term">KEY TERM<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#key-term" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Solder creep: sometimes called 'cold flow', 'solder creep' can occur when the termination is under constant mechanical stress and the solder can literally move or 'creep'. Incidence of creep increases with temperature.</p>
<p>v the temperature attained at the terminals in normal service, such that the effectiveness of the insulation of the conductors connected to them is not impaired
vi the provision of adequate locking arrangements in situations subject to vibration or thermal cycling.</p>
<p>Where a soldered connection is used, the design shall take account of creep, mechanical stress and temperature rise under fault conditions.'</p>
<p>There are a large number of considerations covered by this regulation. Take each of these points in turn.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="the-material-of-the-conductor-and-its-insulation">The material of the conductor and its insulation<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#the-material-of-the-conductor-and-its-insulation" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Different metals or, more correctly, dissimilar metals may react with each other, resulting in corrosion of the termination. It is therefore important to make sure that compatible materials are used when terminating cables and conductors. A further discussion of corrosion takes place later in the book.</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251222-b119d932.jpeg" alt="img-394.jpeg">
<span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">△</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\triangle</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8889em; vertical-align: -0.1944em;"></span><span class="mord">△</span></span></span></span></span>  Figure 4.114 Tube lug and bell mouth lug designed to capture all strands of conductor</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251222-67d39726.jpeg" alt="img-395.jpeg">
<span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">△</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\triangle</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8889em; vertical-align: -0.1944em;"></span><span class="mord">△</span></span></span></span></span>  Figure 4.115 Terminals that are not large enough to accommodate all the strands are problematic</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251222-84e460ce.jpeg" alt="img-396.jpeg">
<span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">△</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\triangle</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8889em; vertical-align: -0.1944em;"></span><span class="mord">△</span></span></span></span></span>  Figure 4.116 Ceiling rose showing linked terminals</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="the-number-and-shape-of-the-wires-forming-the-conductor">The number and shape of the wires forming the conductor<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#the-number-and-shape-of-the-wires-forming-the-conductor" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Conductors come in many formats, round or triangular, solid or stranded. It is important to select terminations that are compatible with the cable and/or conductor. Failure to use compatible parts may result in the conductor becoming loose within the termination.</p>
<p>When crimping lugs onto cables, it is important that the correct size lugs and crimp dies are used, to ensure that a sound mechanical and electrical connection is made. Shaped lugs are available to use with triangular and half-round conductors used in some two-, three- and four-core cables. Where flex is being terminated, it is important that the ends are treated, for example, fitting ferrules to ensure that the individual strands are not spread and are all contained within the termination.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="the-cross-sectional-area-of-the-conductor">The cross-sectional area of the conductor<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#the-cross-sectional-area-of-the-conductor" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>The cross-sectional area (csa) of the cable was carefully selected at the design stage, to ensure that the current-carrying capacity of the conductor was adequate for the circuit load. When terminating the cable, it is important to ensure that all strands of the conductor are contained within the terminal, to ensure that the current-carrying capacity is maintained. Terminals need to be large enough to house the conductor and to be suitably rated to carry the circuit load. Failure to meet either of these requirements could result in overheating at the termination that, in turn, may cause damage to the equipment and/or the insulation of the cable. This in turn may pose a fire risk.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="the-number-of-conductors-to-be-connected-together">The number of conductors to be connected together<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#the-number-of-conductors-to-be-connected-together" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>The termination must be suitable for the number of conductors to be connected together. Attempting to fit more conductors into a terminal than it is designed to hold will invariably result in one or more of those conductors not being properly connected and becoming loose over time. In the case of accessories, where more than one conductor is intended to be connected, manufacturers will provide</p>
<p>Chapter 4 Electrical installation</p>
<p>a number of linked terminals to house all of the conductors so that a sound mechanical and electrical connection is made.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="the-temperature-attained-at-the-terminals-in-normal-service-such-that-the-effectiveness-of-the-insulation-of-the-conductors-connected-to-them-is-not-impaired">The temperature attained at the terminals in normal service, such that the effectiveness of the insulation of the conductors connected to them is not impaired<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#the-temperature-attained-at-the-terminals-in-normal-service-such-that-the-effectiveness-of-the-insulation-of-the-conductors-connected-to-them-is-not-impaired" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>The maximum operating temperature of conductors with thermoplastic insulation (usually PVC) is  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msup><mn>70</mn><mo lspace="0em" rspace="0em">∘</mo></msup><mi mathvariant="normal">C</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">70^{\circ}\mathrm{C}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6833em;"></span><span class="mord">7</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord">0</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.6741em;"><span style="top: -3.063em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">∘</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mord mathrm">C</span></span></span></span></span> , whilst the maximum operating temperature of thermosetting cables (XLPE) is  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msup><mn>90</mn><mo lspace="0em" rspace="0em">∘</mo></msup><mi mathvariant="normal">C</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">90^{\circ}\mathrm{C}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6833em;"></span><span class="mord">9</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord">0</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.6741em;"><span style="top: -3.063em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">∘</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mord mathrm">C</span></span></span></span></span> .
