When using thermosetting cables at  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msup><mn>90</mn><mo lspace="0em" rspace="0em">∘</mo></msup><mi mathvariant="normal">C</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">90^{\circ}\mathrm{C}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6833em;"></span><span class="mord">9</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord">0</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.6741em;"><span style="top: -3.063em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">∘</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mord mathrm">C</span></span></span></span></span> , it is important to make sure that the terminals are capable of withstanding this temperature, as the majority of electrical accessories are designed to operate at  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msup><mn>70</mn><mo lspace="0em" rspace="0em">∘</mo></msup><mi mathvariant="normal">C</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">70^{\circ}\mathrm{C}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6833em;"></span><span class="mord">7</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord">0</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.6741em;"><span style="top: -3.063em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">∘</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mord mathrm">C</span></span></span></span></span> . Other specialist cables may operate at higher temperatures, so it is important to check the maximum operating temperature of the terminals.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="the-provision-of-adequate-locking-arrangements-in-situations-subject-to-vibration-or-thermal-cycling">The provision of adequate locking arrangements in situations subject to vibration or thermal cycling<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#the-provision-of-adequate-locking-arrangements-in-situations-subject-to-vibration-or-thermal-cycling" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Where conductors are terminated into machinery, this can cause vibration and may adversely affect the terminations. In such cases, it is common practice to use, for the final connection, one of these options:</p>
<ul>
<li>a flexible cable – where added mechanical protection is required, braided flex such as SY flex can replace standard flex</li>
<li>a flexible conduit – where unsheathed cables make the final connection or where additional mechanical protection is required, the cables can be housed within flexible conduit</li>
<li>an anti-vibration loop in the cable – with cables such as MICC, or other cable types which are not flexible, a loop is included in the cable to allow the cable to absorb any vibration.</li>
</ul>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251222-48803d64.jpeg" alt="img-397.jpeg">
Figure 4.117 Motor connected by means of SY flex (left), by means of flexible conduit (middle) and showing an anti-vibration loop (right)</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251222-a480879a.jpeg" alt="img-398.jpeg"></p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251222-1644b0c3.jpeg" alt="img-399.jpeg"></p>
<p>Thermal cycling can also harm the terminations. It is greatest when cables are run at or near their maximum operating temperature. The effects can be reduced by ensuring that terminations and connections are kept tight.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="health-and-safety">HEALTH AND SAFETY<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#health-and-safety" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>A correctly sized terminal is critical, as ill-fitted examples can cause a fire risk.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="industry-tip">INDUSTRY TIP<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#industry-tip" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>The use of a flexible connection will also allow the motor to be moved when adjustment or alignment is required.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="key-term">KEY TERM<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#key-term" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Thermal cycling: heating and cooling of metal (in this case) which causes expansion and contraction and, eventually, the loosening of terminals.</p>
<p>The City &amp; Guilds Textbook: Electrical Installations Book 1</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="526-3">526.3<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#526-3" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Poor and loose terminations cause many fires of electrical origin. Regulation 526.3 requires every connection or joint to be accessible for inspection, testing and maintenance, with the exception of:</p>
<ul>
<li>joints designed to buried in the ground</li>
<li>a compound-filled joint</li>
<li>an encapsulated joint</li>
<li>a cold tail of a floor or ceiling heating system</li>
<li>a joint made by welding or soldering</li>
<li>a joint made with an appropriate compression tool</li>
<li>spring-loaded terminals complying with BS 5733 and marked with the symbol MF.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="industry-tip">INDUSTRY TIP<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#industry-tip" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>From this regulation it is clear that the practice of using screw terminal junction boxes and placing these in inaccessible places, such as ceiling or floor voids, is not in compliance with BS 7671.</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251222-dab8aa7d.jpeg" alt="img-400.jpeg">
▲ Figure 4.118 Types of connection not required to be accessible</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251222-45ffb0a8.jpeg" alt="img-401.jpeg"></p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="526-4l">526.4L<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#526-4l" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>This requires that the insulation of the cable must not be adversely affected by the temperature attained at a connection. An example of this may be where a cable with an insulation temperature rating of 70°C is connected to a bus-bar which has been designed to run at a higher temperature. In this case the insulation on the cable would be removed from the cable to a suitable distance and replaced with insulation capable of withstanding the higher temperature.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="key-term">KEY TERM<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#key-term" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Live conductor: a conductor intended to be energised in normal service, and therefore includes a neutral conductor.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="526-5">526.5<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#526-5" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>All terminations and joints in live conductors must be enclosed within a suitable enclosure or accessory. There are no exceptions. This requirement applies to both low-voltage and extra-low voltage connections, but sadly it is not uncommon to see poor examples of connections, especially where down-lighters are fitted.</p>
<p>In harmony with regulation 526.5 is regulation 421.1.6, which requires that all enclosures have suitable mechanical and fire-resistant properties.</p>
<p>Chapter 4 Electrical installation</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251222-30e733d7.jpeg" alt="img-402.jpeg">
Figure 4.119 Example of an acceptable connection</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="526-6">526.6<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#526-6" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>This requires that there is 'no appreciable mechanical strain in the connections of conductors.' Mechanical strain may come about due to:</p>
<ul>
<li>the conductor bending too tightly before entering the terminal, causing the termination to be under constant stress. Cables must be installed in accordance with the minimum bend radii, as given in the IET On-Site Guide or IET Guidance Note 1 (GN1).</li>
<li>cables having no form of strain relief fitted. This can exert mechanical forces on the termination, due to the weight of the cable pulling on the termination. Cables should be fixed at the maximum distances given in the IET On-Site Guide or IET GN1. The fitting of suitable cable glands, where cables enter enclosures, provides strain relief on the terminations.</li>
<li>cables terminated without any slack. Under faulty conditions large electromagnetic forces, due to high fault currents, are exerted on the cables, with the highest forces being exerted at the 'crutch point', where cables come together at the outer sheath. If there is little slack in the cables, the forces will be transferred to the terminal.</li>
</ul>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251222-aab4aa85.jpeg" alt="img-403.jpeg">
Figure 4.120 Using a gland to provide strain relief</p>
<p>The City &amp; Guilds Textbook: Electrical Installations Book 1</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="526-7">526.7<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#526-7" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>This requires that, where a joint in a conductor is made within an enclosure, the enclosure must provide adequate mechanical protection as well as protection against relevant external influences. The minimum requirements for an enclosure to meet the requirements for basic protection are that:</p>
<ul>
<li>the bottom sides and face meet at least IP2X or IPXXB</li>
<li>for the top surface, the enclosure must meet IP4X or IPXXD.</li>
</ul>
<p>However it may also be necessary to take into account external influences such as water ingress or dust ingress, depending on the location.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="the-ip-code">The IP Code<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#the-ip-code" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The IP Code is an international code specifically aimed at manufacturers of enclosures and equipment. It applies to degrees of protection provided by electrical equipment enclosures with rated voltages not exceeding 72.5 kV. The abbreviation 'IP' stands for International Protection, so the full title is International Protection Code (IP). The code is defined in IEC 60529 (BS EN 60529).</p>
<p>The three general categories of protection given in the standard are:</p>
<ol>
<li>the ingress of solid foreign objects (first digit)</li>
<li>the ingress of water (second digit)</li>
<li>the access of persons to harmful electrical or mechanical parts.</li>
</ol>
<p>When referring to the IP code in wiring regulations, 'X' is used in place of the first or second numeral, to indicate that:</p>
<ol>
<li>the test is not applicable to that enclosure or</li>
<li>in the case of standards, the classification of protection is not applicable to this standard.</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="code-letters">Code letters<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#code-letters" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>International protection</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="first-numeral-0-6-or-letter-x">First numeral 0-6 or letter X<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#first-numeral-0-6-or-letter-x" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Protection of persons by prevention or limiting ingress of parts of the body</p>
<p>Limitation of the ingress of solid objects</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="second-numeral-0-8-or-letter-x">Second numeral 0-8 or letter X<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#second-numeral-0-8-or-letter-x" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Resistance to the ingress of water</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251222-51469d2b.jpeg" alt="img-404.jpeg">
Figure 4.121 How the IP Coding system works</p>
<p>Chapter 4 Electrical installation</p>
<p>For example, IP2X means that protection against the ingress of solid objects must meet at least IP2 but the requirement for water ingress protection is not applicable in this case. Manufacturers will provide a full code, such as IP44, for the enclosure.</p>

<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="industry-tip">INDUSTRY TIP<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#industry-tip" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Do not use your own finger to test equipment. Use a proper test finger.</p>
<p>The City &amp; Guilds Textbook: Electrical Installations Book 1</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="industry-tip">INDUSTRY TIP<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#industry-tip" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>There is also an IPX9, which relates to high-temperature and high-pressure water jets where the temperature of the jet exceeds 80°C.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="activity">ACTIVITY<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#activity" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>What is meant by the code IP44?</p>
<p>Second numeral 0–8: Ingress of water</p>

<table><thead><tr><th>IP</th><th>Requirement</th><th>Example</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>A</td><td>Penetration of 50.0 mm diameter sphere up to guard face must not contact hazardous parts</td><td>The back of the hand</td></tr><tr><td>B</td><td>Test finger penetration to a maximum of 80.0 mm must not contact hazardous parts</td><td>A finger</td></tr><tr><td>C</td><td>Wire of 2.5 mm diameter × 100.0 mm long must not contact hazardous parts when spherical stop face is partially entered</td><td>A screwdriver</td></tr><tr><td>D</td><td>Wire of 1.0 mm diameter × 100.0 mm long must not contact hazardous parts when spherical stop face is partially entered</td><td>A wire</td></tr></tbody></table>
<p>The IP codes that you are most likely to come across are:</p>
<ol>
<li>For protection against the ingress of solid objects and protection to persons, the codes are IP2X and IP4X, used in relation to barriers and enclosures.</li>
<li>For protection against the ingress of water the codes are IPX4, IPX5, IPX6, IPX7 and IPX8.</li>
<li>For enhanced personal protection, IPXXB and IPXXD, again used in relation to barriers and enclosures.</li>
</ol>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251222-e3097292.jpeg" alt="img-407.jpeg">
▲ Figure 4.124 Cable entry at electrical accessory not meeting the IP code</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251222-af10b66e.jpeg" alt="img-408.jpeg">
▲ Figure 4.125 Non-sheathed cables outside of an enclosure</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="526-8">526.8<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#526-8" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Where the sheath of a cable has been removed the cores of the cable must be enclosed within an enclosure as detailed in 526.5. This also applies to non-sheathed cables, contained within trunking or conduit.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="526-9">526.9<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#526-9" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The group of regulations designated 526.9 relates to the connection of multi-wire, fine-wire and very-fine wire conductors.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="industry-tip">INDUSTRY TIP<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#industry-tip" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>You will find that over the years, many creatures find their way into enclosures. This might seem impossible, but insects are common and mice not unknown.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="activity">ACTIVITY<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#activity" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>When removing knockouts from a plastic box the slot should be as tight to the cable as possible. What tool should be used to cut the slot?</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="industry-tip">INDUSTRY TIP<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#industry-tip" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>When cables enter the top of an enclosure, IP4X must be maintained, meaning there should be no gap larger than 1 mm.</p>
<p>307</p>
<p>The City &amp; Guilds Textbook: Electrical Installations Book 1</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="526-9-1">526.9.1<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#526-9-1" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>To stop the ends of multi-wire, fine-wire and very-fine wire conductors from spreading or separating, this regulation requires that suitable terminals, such as plate terminals, or suitable treating of the ends be undertaken. One suitable method is to fit ferrules on the ends of the conductor. Manufacturers will almost always fit some form of ferrule to the ends of flexes so that the conductor can be terminated in a screw terminal.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="industry-tip">INDUSTRY TIP<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#industry-tip" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Soldering flex forms a hard mass that, when subjected to vibration, may work loose. Most appliances come fitted with a 13A plug but occasionally, a flex with soldered ends is supplied. In this situation, advice from the manufacturer should be followed.</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251222-d57e3b53.jpeg" alt="img-409.jpeg">
▲ Figure 4.126 Ferrule fitted to pendent flex</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="526-9-2">526.9.2<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#526-9-2" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Soldering or tinning of the ends of multi-wire, fine-wire and very-fine wire conductors is not permitted if screw terminals are used.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="activity">ACTIVITY<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#activity" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Why should solid <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>2.5</mn><msup><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">m</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">m</mi></mrow><mn>2</mn></msup></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">2.5\mathrm{mm}^2</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8141em;"></span><span class="mord">2.5</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">mm</span></span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.8141em;"><span style="top: -3.063em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight">2</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span> not be twisted together when terminated at 13A sockets?</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="526-9-3">526.9.3<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#526-9-3" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The connection of soldered and non-soldered ends on multi-wire, fine-wire and very-fine wire conductors is not permitted where there is relative movement between the two conductors.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="connection-methods">Connection methods<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#connection-methods" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Allowable connection methods include:</p>
<ul>
<li>screw</li>
<li>crimped</li>
<li>soldered</li>
<li>non-screw compression.</li>
</ul>
<p>Each method has its advantages and disadvantages.</p>
<p>Chapter 4 Electrical installation</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="screw-terminals">Screw terminals<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#screw-terminals" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>When cables are terminated into electrical equipment, the type of terminal used must be taken into account. Most accessories use a grub screw, which is screwed down onto the conductor to ensure it is retained in place. Problems arise, however, when the terminal is designed to take more than one conductor, or a conductor of a larger csa than the one being installed.</p>
<p>The common types of screw terminal used in the accessories within electrical installations are:</p>
<ul>
<li>square</li>
<li>circular</li>
<li>moving-plate</li>
<li>insulation-displacement</li>
<li>pillar.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="square-base-terminal">Square base terminal<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#square-base-terminal" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>The use of square terminals can be seen in accessories such as socket outlet face-plates, where two or even three cables can be terminated in the same terminal. These terminals are designed to accept up to three cables and, where a single conductor is used, the screw can miss or damage the conductor. To minimise the potential for problems, the end of the conductor is bent over to increase the contact area available for the screw of the terminal.</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251222-73742810.jpeg" alt="img-410.jpeg">
Figure 4.127 Square terminal showing possible problems if conductor is not doubled over</p>
<p>To bend over the end of the conductor, it is necessary to remove twice the normal amount of insulation from the cable. Then a pair of long-nosed pliers is used to fold the exposed conductor in half. It is important to make sure that both sides of the bend are the same length, as shown in the centre diagram of Figure 4.128. If the return edge is too long, as shown in the left diagram of Figure 4.128, the conductor may protrude from the terminal, causing a shock hazard. If it is too short, as shown on the right diagram of Figure 4.128, the bend will be redundant.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="circular-terminal">Circular terminal<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#circular-terminal" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Circular terminals can be seen in accessories such as light switches and ceiling roses, where single cables or small cables are terminated. They are also commonly found in consumer units and distribution boards on both the neutral and earth bars.</p>
<p>Circular bottom terminals are designed to ensure that the conductor is positioned directly beneath the terminal screw, so there is no need to bend the end of the conductor over.</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251222-64ec79d8.jpeg" alt="img-411.jpeg">
Figure 4.128 Bending over the end of a conductor: bend is too big, correct and too small</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251222-df1bc3ac.jpeg" alt="img-412.jpeg">
Figure 4.129 Circular base terminal</p>
<p>The City &amp; Guilds Textbook: Electrical Installations Book 1</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251222-a02ae58b.jpeg" alt="img-413.jpeg">
Figure 4.130 Two types of moving-plate terminal</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251222-fe1faac6.jpeg" alt="img-414.jpeg"></p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="moving-plate-terminal">Moving-plate terminal<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#moving-plate-terminal" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Moving plate terminals are often used on protective devices, such as circuit breakers and fuse holders that are mounted in consumer units and distribution boards.</p>
<p>The option of bending over the end of the conductor depends not only on the size of the conductor, but also on the size and type of the terminal. If the terminal is the type where the bottom moves up towards the top when the screw is tightened, it is not necessary to bend over the conductor, as the terminal tightens evenly. If, however, the terminal has a plate that moves towards the bottom of the terminal as the screw is tightened, small conductors should be doubled over. If there is any doubt, refer to the manufacturer's recommendations.</p>
<p>No matter what type of terminal is being used, different conductor types should never be mixed within the same terminal. If flexible cable is terminated within the same terminal as solid or stranded cable, the screw may fail to clamp on the flexible cable and only a few of the fine strands may be secured. This could result in a poor electrical connection and the wire might come loose.</p>
<p>If there is no option other than to mix flexible cable and solid or stranded conductors in the same terminal, the flexible conductor must be fitted with a ferrule. This is a small, metal tube that is crimped onto the end of a flexible conductor to hold the strands together.</p>
<p>Terminating copper and aluminium conductors within the same terminal should also be avoided due to the electrolytic reaction between the two different metals.</p>
<p>Whatever types of terminal and conductor are being used, always make sure that the screw tightens on the conductor and not the insulation. To ensure this, the insulation should stop at the opening of the terminal. Take care not to stop the insulation too early, leaving the conductor exposed, with the possibility of faults occurring.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="advantages-and-disadvantages-of-screw-terminals">Advantages and disadvantages of screw terminals<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#advantages-and-disadvantages-of-screw-terminals" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>The advantages of screw terminals are:</p>
<ul>
<li>they are cheap to produce</li>
<li>they are reliable</li>
<li>they are easily terminated, with basic tools</li>
<li>the terminals are reusable.</li>
</ul>
<p>The disadvantage of screw terminals are that:</p>
<ul>
<li>over-tightening could result in damage to the terminal or the conductor</li>
<li>under-tightening of the terminals can result in overheating and arcing</li>
<li>terminals can become loose, due to movement of the conductor in use or due to mechanical vibration</li>
<li>terminations need to be accessible for inspection.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="industry-tip">INDUSTRY TIP<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#industry-tip" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Common faults with terminations are exposed conductors or screwing down onto the insulation.</p>
<p>Chapter 4 Electrical installation</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="crimps">Crimps<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#crimps" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Crimps and crimp lugs come in two basic forms, insulated and uninsulated.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="insulated-crimps">Insulated crimps<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#insulated-crimps" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>When using a cable crimp lug, the wire's insulation must be stripped back about 5 mm. This enables the crimp to be installed with the correct amount of conductor within the crimp and with the insulating section being sealed down onto the insulation of the wire.</p>
<p>Crimp lugs come in three colours for the different sizes of wires:</p>
<ul>
<li>red – 1 mm² to 1.5 mm² wires</li>
<li>blue – 1.5 mm² to 2.5 mm² wires</li>
<li>yellow – 4 mm² to 6 mm² wires.</li>
</ul>
<p>The jaws of the crimping tool are shaped to apply a different crimp style and pressure to the conductor and insulation sides of the connection. The crimping tool applies the correct amount of pressure through a ratchet that cannot be defeated unless the correct amount of pressure is used, or the release button is pressed.</p>
<p>Once a crimp has been installed, it must be checked to ensure that the conductor of the wire protrudes from the crimped part of the lug and that the insulation has been trapped on the other end, so that no exposed conductor is showing. Bearing in mind that crimps are used in applications where vibration occurs, they should never be used on solid conductors.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="uninsulated-crimps">Uninsulated crimps<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#uninsulated-crimps" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Uninsulated crimps are used on conductors with cross-sectional areas from <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>6</mn><msup><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">m</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">m</mi></mrow><mn>2</mn></msup></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">6\mathrm{mm}^2</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8141em;"></span><span class="mord">6</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">mm</span></span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.8141em;"><span style="top: -3.063em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight">2</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span> upwards. It is important that the crimp is sized in accordance with the cross-sectional area of the conductors and is compatible with the conductor material being terminated.</p>
<p>Whilst a hand crimper may be suitable for smaller-sized conductors, on larger conductors a hydraulic crimper will be required. Battery-operated crimp tools are available that take all of the hard work out of crimping a lug onto a conductor.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="method">Method<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#method" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Select the correct size cable lug for the conductor. Cable lugs with different-sized holes are available, so be sure to always choose one that has the correct-sized hole for the connection bolt or screw.</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251222-680eb731.jpeg" alt="img-415.jpeg">
Figure 4.131 Insulated crimps</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="activity">ACTIVITY<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#activity" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>It is not unknown for pliers to be used for fitting crimps, instead of the correct crimping tool. List two possible faults that could occur.</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251222-ed5d253a.jpeg" alt="img-416.jpeg">
Figure 4.132 Uninsulated crimps</p>
<p>The City &amp; Guilds Textbook: Electrical Installations Book 1</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251222-1dbd549e.jpeg" alt="img-417.jpeg">
Figure 4.133 Make sure the appropriate lug is selected</p>
<p>Strip enough insulation from the cable so that the copper conductor meets the end of the cable lug, while the sheath of the cable fits tight to the base of the lug.</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251222-6e4fd1d7.jpeg" alt="img-418.jpeg">
Figure 4.134 Measure how much to strip</p>
<p>Ensure that the cable reaches right to the end of the lug tube.</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251222-03213292.jpeg" alt="img-419.jpeg">
Figure 4.135 Fitting the lug to the conductor</p>
<p>Chapter 4 Electrical installation</p>
<p>The cable lug is then crimped to the cable, using a proprietary cable crimper that suits the size of the lug.</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251222-585fe742.jpeg" alt="img-420.jpeg">
Figure 4.136 Lug being crimped to the conductor</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251222-9dcc3908.jpeg" alt="img-421.jpeg">
Figure 4.137 Conductor ready to be connected</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="advantages-and-disadvantages-of-crimped-connections">Advantages and disadvantages of crimped connections<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#advantages-and-disadvantages-of-crimped-connections" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The advantages of crimped connections are that they:</p>
<ul>
<li>are quick and convenient to install</li>
<li>provide a secure termination</li>
<li>do not need to be accessible for inspection.</li>
</ul>
<p>The disadvantages of crimped connections are that:</p>
<ul>
<li>special tools are required</li>
<li>tools for larger sizes are expensive to purchase</li>
<li>crimps cannot be reused.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="soldered-terminations">Soldered terminations<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#soldered-terminations" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>In the past, lugs were soldered to cables, but this has mainly been replaced by the use of crimp lugs.</p>
<p>Soldering is mainly used in the assembly of electronic components and equipment.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="industry-tip">INDUSTRY TIP<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#industry-tip" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Crimped connections are far quicker and cleaner to make than soldered joints. They also avoid the risk of the heat source damaging the insulation or setting fire to the building.</p>
<p>The City &amp; Guilds Textbook: Electrical Installations Book 1</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251222-c533990f.jpeg" alt="img-422.jpeg">
Figure 4.138 Soldering is mainly used with electronic equipment</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="advantages-and-disadvantages-of-soldered-terminations">Advantages and disadvantages of soldered terminations<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#advantages-and-disadvantages-of-soldered-terminations" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The advantages of soldered terminations are that:</p>
<ul>
<li>they provide a good electrical connection</li>
<li>they offer good mechanical strength</li>
<li>large numbers of connections can be made within a small area as the joint area is very small.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="activity">ACTIVITY<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#activity" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>What action should be taken if insulation is damaged during the soldering process?</p>
<p>The disadvantages of soldered terminations are that:</p>
<ul>
<li>a heat source is required</li>
<li>there are hazards associated with molten metals</li>
<li>there may be damage to conductor insulation</li>
<li>there may be damage to components.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="non-screw-compression">Non-screw compression<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#non-screw-compression" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Non-screw compression connectors, including push-fit connectors, have been used in many associated industries such as lighting manufacturing for a number of years and have proved to be robust and reliable, both electrically and mechanically. In recent years these have been used more and more in electrical installations and, depending on choice of connector, can be used for joining:</p>
<ul>
<li>solid conductors to solid conductors</li>
<li>flexible conductors to solid conductors</li>
<li>flexible conductors to flexible conductors.</li>
</ul>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251222-f88f839b.jpeg" alt="img-423.jpeg">
Figure 4.139 A wide range of push fit connectors is available, to cope with various cable types</p>
<p>Chapter 4 Electrical installation</p>
<p>Manufacturers make a range of accessories to go alongside these connectors that ensure the termination of cables can be both speedy and reliable.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="advantages-and-disadvantages-of-non-screw-compression-terminations">Advantages and disadvantages of non-screw compression terminations<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#advantages-and-disadvantages-of-non-screw-compression-terminations" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The advantages of non-screw compression terminations are that:</p>
<ul>
<li>they are quick and convenient to install</li>
<li>they provide a secure termination</li>
<li>they are not affected by vibration</li>
<li>no special tools are required</li>
<li>they are reusable</li>
<li>they are maintenance free.</li>
</ul>
<p>The disadvantage of non-screw terminations are that:</p>
<ul>
<li>they are generally not available for cable sizes exceeding 6 mm²</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="proving-that-terminations-and-connections-are-electrically-and-mechanically-sound">Proving that terminations and connections are electrically and mechanically sound<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#proving-that-terminations-and-connections-are-electrically-and-mechanically-sound" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>It is important that when terminations are complete, they are verified to be both electrically and mechanically sound. The procedures to follow will include both inspection and testing.</p>
<p>Inspection will include checks such as:</p>
<ul>
<li>
<p>making sure that all terminations are tight. This includes both live and protective conductors and can be accomplished by both careful scrutiny and by 'tugging' the conductor to ensure it is securely fastened in the termination</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>checking visually that the electrical connection is made to the conductor rather than the insulation</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>checking visually that conductive parts are not accessible to touch</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>checking that the correct termination methods have been used and that they are suitable for:</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>the type of conductors being terminated</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>the environment in which the termination is to be used.</p>
</li>
</ul>
<p>Testing will need to be carried out to ensure that:</p>
<ul>
<li>conductors are continuous</li>
<li>there are no shorts in the conductors</li>
<li>conductors are connected to the correct points.</li>
</ul>
<p>The appropriate tests would be:</p>
<ul>
<li>continuity, including that of the cpc and ring final circuit conductors</li>
<li>insulation resistance</li>
<li>polarity and phase rotation.</li>
</ul>
<p>It is important that correct inspection and testing procedures are followed.</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251222-3259b06e.jpeg" alt="img-424.jpeg">
Figure 4.140 Termination of PVC cables into purpose-designed box</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="industry-tip">INDUSTRY TIP<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#industry-tip" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Careful and thorough inspection will identify the majority of faults with terminations.</p>
<p>The City &amp; Guilds Textbook: Electrical Installations Book 1</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251222-0068adb7.jpeg" alt="img-425.jpeg">
Figure 4.141 Lug bolted to casing of equipment</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="industry-tip">INDUSTRY TIP<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#industry-tip" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>When high-resistance joints occur, it is unlikely that protective devices such as circuit breakers will operate. If the joint creates arcing, this may be detected by an arc fault detection device (AFDD) if installed.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="key-term">KEY TERM<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#key-term" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Corrosion: the breaking down or destruction of a material, especially a metal, through chemical reactions.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="the-consequences-of-terminations-not-being-electrically-and-mechanically-sound">The consequences of terminations not being electrically and mechanically sound<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#the-consequences-of-terminations-not-being-electrically-and-mechanically-sound" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>If the termination of cables and conductors is not electrically or mechanically sound, the consequences can be disastrous. The cause of terminations not being electrically and mechanically sound is usually high-resistance joints or corrosion.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="the-effects-of-high-resistance-joints">The effects of high-resistance joints<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#the-effects-of-high-resistance-joints" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The most common cause of high-resistance joints is a loose connection. When current is passed across such a joint, it heats up. This is likely to cause damage to the cable insulation and/or the connected electrical equipment. In the worst case, this may result in the overheating of adjacent material, resulting in a possible fire. It is important to make sure that cables are seated properly in the terminals and that the terminals are correctly tightened. Manufacturer's instructions need to be consulted to check whether a torque setting is given for connections, which must then be complied with.</p>
<p>It should be remembered that, even with a sound connection, when current is flowing, the conductors and terminations will heat up, resulting in expansion of the metal, which can lead to loosening of the terminal. This is why terminals, apart from those exempted by regulation 526.3, must be accessible for maintenance and inspection.</p>
<p>Another cause of loose terminations is vibration from such things as machinery. It is important that initial terminations are correctly made and tightened and that regular maintenance is carried out to ensure that loose connections cannot occur.</p>
<p>Corroded terminals will also result in high-resistance joints.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="the-effects-of-corrosion">The effects of corrosion<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#the-effects-of-corrosion" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The most common form of corrosion is rusting, which occurs when iron combines with oxygen and water. Most metals, with the exception of precious metals such as gold and platinum, do not exist in metallic form in nature, but rather exist as ore.</p>
<p>For corrosion to occur four conditions must exist.</p>
<ol>
<li>There must be an anode (corroding) and a cathode (protected) component.</li>
<li>There must be an electrical potential between the anode and the cathode.</li>
<li>The anode and cathode must be connected by a metallic path of low resistance.</li>
<li>The anode and cathode must be immersed in an electrolyte, which is an electrically conductive fluid.</li>
</ol>
<p>When two dissimilar metals, such as aluminium and brass, are in contact with one another points 1, 2 and 3 are met. In the presence of a fluid such as moisture, corrosion will occur. The tendency to corrode can be reduced by plating terminals or using a corrosion inhibitor on the jointed parts. Bimetallic crimps are available for joining aluminium to copper. These are engineered to obtain the best possible</p>
<p>Chapter 4 Electrical installation</p>
<p>transition between the metals and corrosion is reduced by coating the inside of the crimp with grease.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="techniques-and-methods-for-the-safe-and-effective-termination-and-connection-of-cables">Techniques and methods for the safe and effective termination and connection of cables<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#techniques-and-methods-for-the-safe-and-effective-termination-and-connection-of-cables" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>The following section will describe and illustrate the preparation of cables for connection. Various methods will be illustrated. The health and safety requirements for each method and the tools required to terminate will be discussed for each type of cable. The cables covered in this section are:</p>
<ul>
<li>thermosetting insulated cables, including flexes</li>
<li>single and multicore thermoplastic (PVC) and thermosetting insulated cables</li>
<li>PVC/PVC flat profile cable</li>
<li>MICC (with and without PVC sheath)</li>
<li>SWA cables (PILC, XLPE, PVC)</li>
<li>armoured/braided flexible cables and cords</li>
<li>data cables</li>
<li>fibre optic cable</li>
<li>fire-resistant cable.</li>
</ul>
<p>Terminating some of these cables requires the use of glands and shrouds as described below.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="cable-glands">Cable glands<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#cable-glands" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Cable glands are available in a range of sizes and formats and with a bewildering array of designatory letters and numbers: BW, CW, CX, CXT to name but a few. So what do all these letters mean? These tables provide the answers.</p>
<p>First letter</p>
<table><thead><tr><th>Code</th><th>Definition</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>A1</td><td>For unarmoured cable with an elastomeric or plastic outer sheath, with sealing function between the cable sheath and the sealing ring of the cable gland.</td></tr><tr><td>A2</td><td>As type A1, but with seal protection degree IP66 – means 30 bar pressure</td></tr><tr><td>B</td><td>No seal</td></tr><tr><td>C</td><td>Single outer seal</td></tr><tr><td>E</td><td>Double (inner &amp; outer) seal</td></tr></tbody></table>
<p>Second letter</p>
<table><thead><tr><th>Code</th><th>Designation of cable armouring</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>W</td><td>Single wire armour</td></tr><tr><td>Y</td><td>Strip armour used</td></tr><tr><td>X</td><td>Braid</td></tr><tr><td>T</td><td>Pliable wire armour</td></tr></tbody></table>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="industry-tip">INDUSTRY TIP<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#industry-tip" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>PILC (paper insulated lead covered) is limited to older distribution systems and should rarely be seen by a contracting electrician, except where it comes through a floor to a service head. PVC, XLPE and other types of armoured cables are now used in place of PILC.</p>
<p>The City &amp; Guilds Textbook: Electrical Installations Book 1</p>
<p>From the tables, these meanings can be gathered.</p>
<p>BW A gland without seals suitable for single wire armour cable. SWA for indoor use.</p>
<p>CW A gland with a single outer seal for single wire armour cable. SWA for outdoor use.</p>
<p>CX A gland with a single outer seal for braided cables such as SY flex for outdoor use.</p>
<p>Additional letters may be used to signify a method of termination, such as in the designation 'CXT'. In this case the third letter, T, signifies that the braid is formed into a tail (T) and the gland is designed to terminate by this means.</p>
<p>The construction and fitting of each type of gland will be discussed separately, alongside each cable termination type.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="key-term">KEY TERM<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#key-term" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p><strong>CompEx Scheme:</strong> the global solution for validating core competency of employees and contract staff of major users in the gas, oil and chemical sectors. This covers both offshore and onshore activities.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="activity">ACTIVITY<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#activity" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Identify the tool shown in Figure 4.143.</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251222-37c4cc75.jpeg" alt="img-426.jpeg">
▲ Figure 4.143</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251222-265aff7a.jpeg" alt="img-427.jpeg">
▲ Figure 4.142 From left to right BW, CW, CX and CXT gland</p>
<p>When cables are terminated for use in potentially explosive atmospheres, glands must be suitable for the environment and comply with ATEX or IECEx standards. Operatives must be trained and competent to CompEx Scheme standards.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="what-is-the-purpose-of-a-cable-gland">What is the purpose of a cable gland?<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#what-is-the-purpose-of-a-cable-gland" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>A gland can be used to:</p>
<ul>
<li>maintain the IP rating of an enclosure</li>
<li>provide continuity of earth</li>
<li>provide strain relief to terminations.</li>
</ul>
<p>A gland is an integral part of the termination of a cable and so must be fitted correctly. Incorrect fitting could result in:</p>
<ul>
<li>water being allowed to enter an enclosure</li>
<li>the connection to earth not being adequate and posing a shock risk in the event of an earth fault</li>
<li>strain being placed on cables and the cables pulling out of terminals, creating either a short-circuit fault or an earth fault.</li>
</ul>
<p>Chapter 4 Electrical installation</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="shrouds">Shrouds<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#shrouds" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251222-29ad3931.jpeg" alt="img-428.jpeg">
Figure 4.144 A range of shrouds</p>
<p>What does a cable shroud do? A cable shroud can aid the process of keeping the surface of the gland clean and free from the build-up of dirt. It does not, however, necessarily improve the ingress protection (IP) rating of the cable gland. In fact, the gland will invariably have been tested and rated without the installation of a cable shroud. The shroud may provide corrosion protection to cable armour or the sheath, but it must be installed in such a way as not to trap moisture under itself and thus increase the corrosion potential. If the shroud is too loose on the cable sheath, moisture may enter the assembly and, as the fit with the gland is going to be tight, the moisture will be trapped.</p>
<p>Shrouds generally come in PVC or LSF (low smoke and fume) varieties, in a range of sizes to match the gland, and in a range of colours to match the sheath colour of the cable, with black being the most common.</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251222-79e4041c.jpeg" alt="img-429.jpeg">
Figure 4.145 A badly fitted shroud could trap moisture</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="how-to-fit-a-shroud-to-ensure-a-tight-fit-to-the-cable-sheath">How to fit a shroud to ensure a tight fit to the cable sheath<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#how-to-fit-a-shroud-to-ensure-a-tight-fit-to-the-cable-sheath" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>The same method of fitting a shroud can be used with all cables.</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251222-8bcfb099.jpeg" alt="img-430.jpeg">
STEP 1 – Push the shroud lightly on to the cable so that a small bulge appears where the cable end is. Do not push too hard, as this will stretch the shroud and you will end up cutting in the wrong place.</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251222-5bae1faf.jpeg" alt="img-431.jpeg">
STEP 2 – Cut the shroud at the bulge, with a pair of side cutters or, better still, a pair of cable croppers.</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251222-fec89df9.jpeg" alt="img-432.jpeg">
