STEP 3 – Push the shroud onto the cable. The top of the shroud should now be a snug fit to the outer sheath of the cable. Remember, when assembling the gland and shroud combination, the shroud goes on before the gland.</p>
<p>Figure 4.146</p>
<p>The next section describes the common methods of terminating cables.</p>
<p>The City &amp; Guilds Textbook: Electrical Installations Book 1</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="cable-entry-to-an-enclosure">Cable entry to an enclosure<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#cable-entry-to-an-enclosure" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>When a cable enters an enclosure, the integrity of the enclosure should not be compromised. The entry may have to meet one or more of these criteria.</p>
<ul>
<li>The point of entry must not cause damage to the cable. Rough edges should be removed and, as a minimum, rubber grommets should be used on all cable entries. Cable glands are a better alternative.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="industry-tip">INDUSTRY TIP<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#industry-tip" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Grommets are available as open or blind. An open grommet has a hole in the middle. A blind grommet has a thin membrane, through which the cable is pushed, and provides a better seal. Grommet strip is also available for irregular-shaped holes.</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251222-dc03755a.jpeg" alt="img-433.jpeg"></p>
<p>▲ Figure 4.147 Rubber grommet to enclosure. Grommets protect cables from rough edges</p>
<ul>
<li>The entry of the cable should not compromise the IP rating of the enclosure. For basic protection this is:</li>
<li>top surface IP4X – a 1mm diameter wire will not enter</li>
<li>front, sides and bottom, a 12.5 mm diameter object will not enter.</li>
</ul>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251222-979233fb.jpeg" alt="img-434.jpeg"></p>
<p>▲ Figure 4.148 Non-compliance on cable entry</p>
<p>Chapter 4 Electrical installation</p>
<ul>
<li>There may be IP ratings that are applicable for the ingress of water:</li>
<li>for an enclosure outside a building, it is likely to be IPX4 splash proof</li>
<li>for an enclosure where water jets are used, the rating should be IPX5.</li>
</ul>
<p>There may be requirements for fire protection. Where there is a fire risk due to powders or dust being present in locations such as a carpenter's workshop, the minimum IP rating is IP5X.</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251222-ace6355b.jpeg" alt="img-435.jpeg">
Figure 4.149 Splash proof socket</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="terminating-flexes">Terminating flexes<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#terminating-flexes" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Tools required</p>
<ul>
<li>ringing tool (Method 1)</li>
<li>stripping knife (Method 2).</li>
</ul>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251222-79f22ace.jpeg" alt="img-436.jpeg">
Figure 4.150 Ringing tool (Method 1) Stripping knife (Method 2)</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="safety-considerations">Safety considerations<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#safety-considerations" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Cuts to hands from use of knife.</li>
</ul>
<p>The use of gloves and eye protection is recommended.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="activity">ACTIVITY<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#activity" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Use the internet to find a cable coupler suitable for outside use.</p>
<p>The City &amp; Guilds Textbook: Electrical Installations Book 1</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="method">Method<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#method" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Before the flex can be terminated, the outer sheath must be removed.</p>
<p>Two methods of removing the outer sheath are outlined here.</p>
<p>Method 1 – The outer sheath can be removed with the use of a ringing tool. These come in various shapes and forms, the most basic of which is shown in the diagram. This tool slides over the end of the cable to the required stripping position, and is then rotated around the cable, cutting it slightly.</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251222-6d1d43e3.jpeg" alt="img-437.jpeg">
▲ Figure 4.151 Flexible cable sheath stripping tool for use on flex</p>
<p>The ringing tool is removed, the cable is bent to finish the cut and the sheath is then pulled off.</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251222-4a14618e.jpeg" alt="img-438.jpeg">
▲ Figure 4.152 Outer sheath being removed</p>
<p>Method 2 – There may be times when a ringing tool is not available, so it is important to know how to remove the outer sheath without this tool. Thermoplastic has a tendency to split when it is damaged and pressure is applied, and this can be used to help strip the sheath.</p>
<p>Bend the cable into a tight bend at the point where the sheath is to be removed. Using a sharp knife, gently score the top of the bend. The thermoplastic will split open like a little mouth (Figure 4.153).</p>
<p>Chapter 4 Electrical installation</p>
<p>Gently work the split until the inner cables are visible and then unbend, rotate and rebend the cable at about 90° from the first point. Repeat the scoring of the sheath until again the wires become visible. Repeat the bend and cut until the sheath can be removed, being careful, at all times, not to cut into the wires.</p>
<p>Once the sheath has been removed, the wires can be stripped and connected, as detailed in the next section, but remember that the conductors are fine strands and therefore need to be fully contained with a suitable terminal or they need to be treated in some way, such as fitting ferrules, to make them stable.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="fire-resistant-cable">Fire-resistant cable<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#fire-resistant-cable" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="tools-required">Tools required<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#tools-required" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<ul>
<li>stripping knife</li>
<li>spanners or grips to suit gland size.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="safety-considerations">Safety considerations<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#safety-considerations" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<ul>
<li>Cuts to hands from use of knife.</li>
</ul>
<p>The use of gloves and eye protection is recommended.</p>
<p>Fire-resistant cables are stripped in a similar way to flexes. However, take care with the insulation on the inner cores as this is usually silicon rubber rather than PVC, and is easily damaged. Entry to enclosures is usually by means of a plastic gland.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="terminating-single-core-cables">Terminating single-core cables<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#terminating-single-core-cables" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="tools-required">Tools required<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#tools-required" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<ul>
<li>Cable strippers.</li>
</ul>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251222-4578cef3.jpeg" alt="img-439.jpeg">
▲ Figure 4.155 Different types of cable strippers are available</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251222-d7253ae1.jpeg" alt="img-440.jpeg">
▲ Figure 4.153 Bending cable to cause split in sheath</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="activity">ACTIVITY<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#activity" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Use sources of information, such as wholesale catalogues, to find out about different types of fire-resistant cable.</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251222-4ce09d8f.jpeg" alt="img-441.jpeg">
▲ Figure 4.154 Completed FP termination</p>
<p>The City &amp; Guilds Textbook: Electrical Installations Book 1</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251222-343b787d.jpeg" alt="img-442.jpeg">
Figure 4.156 Cable stripper jaws</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251222-5e5b4252.jpeg" alt="img-443.jpeg">
Figure 4.157 Cable-strippers with pre-set holes</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="safety-considerations">Safety considerations<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#safety-considerations" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>There is a risk of injury from slipping with cutters or pliers. The use of gloves and eye protection is recommended.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="method">Method<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#method" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>As single-core cables do not have outer sheaths to remove because they are intended to be installed within trunking or conduit, the termination method is straightforward and requires the minimum of tools. This termination method will therefore also apply to the final connection of other cable types.</p>
<p>Use of wire-strippers is recommended for single-core conductors. Automatic wire-strippers tend to rip the insulation from the conductor and can damage it. Manual wire-strippers are preferred and these come in various forms, but all work on a similar principle.</p>
<p>Manual wire-strippers have two blades that cross one, another like scissors. Each blade has a notch so that together they cut around the conductor in the middle. In addition, wire-strippers also have some means of adjustment so that different sizes of conductor can be stripped.</p>
<p>Before wire-strippers can be used, they must be set to the correct size. This can be done using a scrap or off-cut of wire of the correct size. With the jaws of the wire-strippers together, turn the adjustment screw until the hole in the jaws is just bigger than the conductor to be stripped. Test the setting on the off-cut of wire, by placing the wire-strippers over the wire and squeezing the handles to close the jaws. Then slightly release the jaws and try to slide the insulation off, using the wire-strippers.</p>
<p>If the wire-strippers are correctly set, the insulation will come off easily and there will be no damage to the copper conductor. If the aperture is set too small, the insulation will slide off easily but the conductor may be damaged. If it is set too large, the insulation will not come off easily. A simple adjustment of the adjusting screw will correct these problems. Now, with the correct setting, the wires can be stripped safely.</p>
<p>Other types of wire-stripper will have pre-set stripping holes so that selecting the correct hole will ensure that the depth of cut is correct every time.</p>
<p>Once the conductors are stripped they are ready to be connected to the electrical equipment.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="terminating-pvc-pvc-flat-profile-cable">Terminating PVC/PVC flat profile cable<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#terminating-pvc-pvc-flat-profile-cable" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="tools-required">Tools required<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#tools-required" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<p>Dependent on method used:</p>
<ul>
<li>electrician's knife</li>
<li>side-cutters</li>
<li>pliers.</li>
</ul>
<p>Chapter 4 Electrical installation</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251222-a734bb38.jpeg" alt="img-444.jpeg">
Figure 4.158 Pliers, side-cutters, electrician's knife (from left to right)</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="safety-considerations">Safety considerations<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#safety-considerations" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Cuts to hands from use of knife.</li>
<li>Injury from slipping with cutters or pliers.</li>
</ul>
<p>The use of gloves and eye protection is recommended.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="method">Method<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#method" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Before the conductors can be connected, the outer sheath of the cable must be removed.</p>
<p>First, identify how much of the sheath should be removed from the cable. The purpose of the sheath is to provide some mechanical protection for the insulation on the conductors. Too much sheath, however, takes up space within the accessory and will put excess strain on the conductors. The sheath should, therefore, be stripped back almost to where the cable enters the accessory, leaving only 10–15 mm, a thumb’s width, of sheath within the accessory.</p>
<p>There is more than one way to remove the outer sheath. Each has its advantages and disadvantages but, whichever method is used, care must be taken to avoid damage occurring to either the conductors or the insulation around the conductors.</p>
<p><strong>Method 1</strong> – Having decided on the length of sheath required, and with the cable in place, score the sheath at the point to which it is to be removed. This can be performed with an electrician's knife. Care should be taken not to cut into the cable.</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251222-a5d4a85e.jpeg" alt="img-445.jpeg">
Figure 4.159 Determining the point to which to strip the sheath</p>
<p>The City &amp; Guilds Textbook: Electrical Installations Book 1</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251222-10e9d47a.jpeg" alt="img-446.jpeg">
Figure 4.160 Scoring the outer sheath</p>
<p>From the end of the cable, snip down the centre of the cable, using a pair of side-cutters. Split the line to one side and the neutral to the other.</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251222-c0b50e5e.jpeg" alt="img-447.jpeg">
Figure 4.161 Snipping the end of the cable</p>
<p>Grip each piece of split cable, conductor and sheath and pull them apart, tearing any uncut sheath as you go. Continue up to the score mark.</p>
<p>Chapter 4 Electrical installation</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251222-bb0ff95d.jpeg" alt="img-448.jpeg">
Figure 4.162 Tearing down to the score mark (left) and removing the outer sheath (right)</p>
<p>Once the score mark is reached, the sheath can be removed from the wires. Then, holding the cable in one hand and with the thumb of the other hand placed on the sheath behind the score, jerk the torn sheath to make it break along the score mark, leaving a clean finish.</p>
<p>Method 2 – Snip down the end of the cable with the side-cutters, then use a sharp electrician's knife to slice down the cable. To do this, run the blade along the protective conductor. Note that this can damage the protective conductor or, even worse, the insulation of one of the live conductors if it is not done carefully.</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251222-b0522b5b.jpeg" alt="img-449.jpeg">
Figure 4.163 Running an electrician's knife along the cpc</p>
<p>Method 3 – Snip down the end of the cable and gently pull the cpc with pliers, almost like a cheese wire, to tear the outer sheath as far as the point to which it is to be stripped. Take care not to apply too much force or to damage the cpc, nor to strip too far.</p>
<p>The City &amp; Guilds Textbook: Electrical Installations Book 1</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251222-d791004b.jpeg" alt="img-450.jpeg">
Figure 4.164 Using the cpc to 'cut' the outer sheath</p>
<p>Once you have reached the desired strip position in the outer sheath, use side-cutters to cut away the outer sheath.</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251222-114b33ff.jpeg" alt="img-451.jpeg">
Figure 4.165 Using side-cutters to cut away the outer sheath</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="termination">Termination<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#termination" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Now the inner wires can be stripped in the same manner as for single-core wires, making sure that green and yellow sleeving is applied to the bare copper cpc. The sleeving must cover all of the bare cpc, apart from a small amount at the end, enough to go into the terminal.</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251222-2d7996d8.jpeg" alt="img-452.jpeg">
Figure 4.166 Applying sleeving to bare cpc ready for final termination</p>
<p>Chapter 4 Electrical installation</p>
<p>The conductors can now be terminated into the electrical equipment, as described previously.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="terminating-micc-cable">Terminating MICC cable<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#terminating-micc-cable" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="tools-required">Tools required<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#tools-required" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<ul>
<li>hacksaw or croppers</li>
<li>MICC stripper</li>
<li>pot wrench</li>
<li>pot crimper</li>
<li>combination pliers</li>
<li>stripping knife</li>
<li>spanners or grips to suit gland size</li>
<li>insulation resistance tester</li>
<li>low-resistance ohmmeter or a continuity buzzer.</li>
</ul>

<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="safety-considerations">Safety considerations<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#safety-considerations" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<ul>
<li>Cuts to hands from use of knife.</li>
<li>Cuts from the edges of the stripped copper sheath.</li>
<li>Mineral insulation is in powder form, so could be an irritant if in contact with eyes.</li>
</ul>
<p>The use of gloves and eye protection is recommended.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="method">Method<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#method" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<p>The termination process for MICC cable is by far the most complicated of all the methods discussed here. These are the steps.</p>
<ol>
<li>Prepare the cable.</li>
<li>Fit the shroud.</li>
<li>Remove the outer sheath, if applicable.</li>
<li>Strip the copper sheath.</li>
<li>Fit the gland to the cable.</li>
<li>Fit the pot to the cable.</li>
<li>Test the cable.</li>
</ol>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251222-d4f96d87.jpeg" alt="img-455.jpeg">
▲ Figure 4.169 MICC termination</p>
<p>329</p>
<p>The City &amp; Guilds Textbook: Electrical Installations Book 1</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="industry-tip">INDUSTRY TIP<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#industry-tip" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>You may come across some old MICC (pyrotenax) cable which has gland sizes identified by letters. Although this cable may be 50 years old, the durability of the cable means it is still operational.</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251222-99d698f4.jpeg" alt="img-456.jpeg">
Figure 4.170 Cutting the end of the cable</p>
<p>8 Identify the cores.
9 Fit the gland to the electrical equipment or accessory.
10 Terminate the cores to the electrical equipment.</p>
<p>Pots, seals and glands are sized to fit a particular size of cable. A cable designated 2L1.5 has two cores, light-duty insulation (500V maximum) and a cross-sectional area of  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>1.5</mn><msup><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">m</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">m</mi></mrow><mn>2</mn></msup></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">1.5\mathrm{mm}^2</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8141em;"></span><span class="mord">1.5</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">mm</span></span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.8141em;"><span style="top: -3.063em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight">2</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span> . Termination components are chosen to match these specifications.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="step-1-prepare-the-cable">Step 1 Prepare the cable<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#step-1-prepare-the-cable" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>To ensure easy stripping, the end of the cable must not be crushed in any way. The ideal way of cutting the cable is with a junior hacksaw; however a sharp pair of cable croppers can be used, with care.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="step-2-fitting-the-shroud">Step 2 Fitting the shroud<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#step-2-fitting-the-shroud" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Whilst the shroud can be fitted any time before step 5, it is best to cut the shroud top to the correct size before the outer sheath is removed. See the method of fitting the shroud, as described on page 319.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="step-3-remove-the-outer-sheath-if-applicable">Step 3 Remove the outer sheath if applicable<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#step-3-remove-the-outer-sheath-if-applicable" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Where the cable has an outer PVC sheath, it will need to be removed far enough to allow for termination but still within the length of the shroud. How much to strip can be determined by taking into account:</p>
<ul>
<li>the length of the termination tail
the pot length
the gland length</li>
<li>an allowance to allow the crimper end to fit between the pot and the gland. This will vary with different crimp tools.</li>
</ul>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251222-b1d8ffc7.jpeg" alt="img-457.jpeg">
Figure 4.171 Determining the length to strip</p>
<p>Chapter 4 Electrical installation</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="step-4-strip-the-copper-sheath">Step 4 Strip the copper sheath<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#step-4-strip-the-copper-sheath" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>The next step is to strip the copper sheath. Whilst there is more than one method of doing this, including using side-cutters, the easiest method is to use a specialist tool designed purely for this purpose.</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251222-b178734d.jpeg" alt="img-458.jpeg">
Figure 4.172 Different types of rotary strippers</p>
<p>Each of the tools works on the same principle. A small blade cuts into the metal sheath and peels off a small amount of copper sheath with each rotation.</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251222-7b131855.jpeg" alt="img-459.jpeg">
Figure 4.173 J0I stripper in use</p>
<p>When the correct length of cable is reached, a pair of pliers is used to grip the cable just ahead of the stripper. This stops the stripper moving further down the cable.</p>
<p>The City &amp; Guilds Textbook: Electrical Installations Book 1</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251222-02540ebd.jpeg" alt="img-460.jpeg">
Figure 4.174 Using pliers to end the stripping process</p>
<p>With the pliers in this position the stripper is turned again. As the stripper cannot move down the cable, it cuts a clean square edge to the cable. The sheath is pulled off and the cable is tapped gently to remove any powdered insulation that may be attached to the conductors.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="step-5-fit-the-gland-to-the-cable">Step 5 Fit the gland to the cable<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#step-5-fit-the-gland-to-the-cable" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Push the gland onto the cable but do not tighten it.</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251222-23cb3a6a.jpeg" alt="img-461.jpeg">
Figure 4.175 Cable ready for fitting pot</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251222-b10cdd16.jpeg" alt="img-462.jpeg">
Figure 4.176 Pot wrench that uses the gland</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="step-6-fit-the-sealing-pot-to-the-cable">Step 6 Fit the sealing pot to the cable<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#step-6-fit-the-sealing-pot-to-the-cable" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The sealing pot of the correct size is screwed onto the cable. A pot wrench is specifically designed for this job.</p>
<p>Using the type of pot wrench shown in Figure 4.176 requires that the wrench is tightened against the gland body, with the pot between the gland and the pot wrench.</p>
<p>Chapter 4 Electrical installation</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251222-6cc3fab1.jpeg" alt="img-463.jpeg">
Figure 4.177 One-handed pot wrench</p>
<p>This type of pot wrench does not require a gland to be fitted to the pot. The wheel on the pot wrench locks against the knurled edge of the pot, thus locking the pot to the wrench.</p>
<p>With either type, pressure needs to be applied to get the pot started. As the pot is turned, it cuts a thread on the cable sheath.</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251222-e9ba1f36.jpeg" alt="img-464.jpeg">
Figure 4.178 Pot being fitted</p>
<p>Once the cable end gets to the base of the pot, stop turning.</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251222-6865e36e.jpeg" alt="img-465.jpeg">
Figure 4.179 Inside the pot</p>
<p>The City &amp; Guilds Textbook: Electrical Installations Book 1</p>
<p>If an earth tail pot is used, the earth tail must be aligned in the correct position, relative to the conductors.</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251222-698e683d.jpeg" alt="img-466.jpeg">
▲ Figure 4.180 Alignment of earth-tailed pot</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="industry-tip">INDUSTRY TIP<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#industry-tip" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Do not blow into the pot as this may introduce moisture.</p>
<p>Once the pot is in the correct position, remove the pot wrench. Turn the cable so that the open end is facing downwards, then tap the pot to ensure that any loose material in the sealing pot falls out. Carefully inspect the inside of the sealing pot for any signs of debris.</p>
<p>The pot is now ready to be filled with compound. Place the sealing disc over the conductors and push it down to the bottom end of the pot to place the conductors into the correct position. Fill the pot from one side only, forcing the compound between the conductors and thus expelling any air in the pot and avoiding any air pockets.</p>
<p>The sealing pot must now be sealed with another plastic sealing disc. Place the disc over the conductors and press down to the mouth of the pot. Place the crimper over the pot and screw down until the crimper just touches the pot.</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251222-9e3e427a.jpeg" alt="img-467.jpeg">
▲ Figure 4.181 Crimper in place ready to crimp</p>
<p>Chapter 4 Electrical installation</p>
<p>With a pair of pliers, pull gently on each conductor, in turn, to straighten it.</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251222-03799732.jpeg" alt="img-468.jpeg">
Figure 4.182 Pulling the conductors</p>
<p>Screw the crimper down to force the sealing disc into the pot. Once the crimper is all the way down, unscrew the crimper but take care not to allow the pot to turn, as this will cause a short between the conductors.</p>
<p>Clean off any excess compound and fit stub sleeving to the conductors.</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251222-fd2470e5.jpeg" alt="img-469.jpeg">
Figure 4.183 Fitting stub sleeving</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251222-6abd6d91.jpeg" alt="img-470.jpeg">
Figure 4.184 Finished termination</p>
<p>The City &amp; Guilds Textbook: Electrical Installations Book 1</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="activity">ACTIVITY<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#activity" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>After one pot termination is completed, the cable should be tested. Why is this?</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="industry-tip">INDUSTRY TIP<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#industry-tip" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Carry this test out before crimping the pot up, but make sure that the other end of the cable is not shorted out.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="step-7-test-the-cable">Step 7 Test the cable<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#step-7-test-the-cable" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>To ensure that there are no faults on the cable or cable termination, carry out an insulation resistance test between all conductor combinations and between each conductor and the sheath of the cable.</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251222-0ac269d6.jpeg" alt="img-471.jpeg">
▲ Figure 4.185 Insulation resistance testing</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="step-8-identify-the-cores">Step 8 Identify the cores<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#step-8-identify-the-cores" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The cores of an MICC cable will now need to be identified at both ends. This entails connecting one of the cores to the copper sheath at one end of the cable. Then, using a low-resistance ohmmeter or a continuity buzzer, at the other end of the cable test between the copper sheath of the cable and each of the cores until you identify which is connected to sheath. The cores are then marked up with tape or, if available in the termination kit, the appropriate coloured stub sleeving.</p>
<p>It is important that the previous test has already been completed to ensure that none of the cores is shorted to earth within the pots. This process will be repeated with each of the cores until all cores are identified.</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251222-c61cdca1.jpeg" alt="img-472.jpeg">
▲ Figure 4.186 Connecting one of the cores to the copper sheath at one end</p>
<p>Chapter 4 Electrical installation</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="step-9-fit-the-gland-to-the-electrical-equipment-or-accessory-box">Step 9 Fit the gland to the electrical equipment or accessory box<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#step-9-fit-the-gland-to-the-electrical-equipment-or-accessory-box" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The gland is now fitted to the accessory or electrical equipment by means of a locknut or lock ring.</p>
<p>Using this method may mean that the pot protrudes into the accessory box, making the fitting of the accessory difficult. An alternative method is to fit a coupler to the accessory box by means of a male bush, then connect the gland to this, ensuring that the pot does not protrude into the accessory box.</p>
<p>Once the gland body is fitted tightly to the accessory, the back nut can be tightened, which causes the internal olive to compress and 'bite' into the copper sheath, forming a waterproof seal. After this stage, it is not possible to reposition the gland.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="step-10-terminate-the-cores-to-the-electrical-equipment">Step 10 Terminate the cores to the electrical equipment<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#step-10-terminate-the-cores-to-the-electrical-equipment" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The cable is now ready for final termination.</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251222-582a6bda.jpeg" alt="img-473.jpeg">
Figure 4.187 MICC cable connected to accessory by means of a lock nut (left) and a coupler (right)</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251222-6248f0c0.jpeg" alt="img-474.jpeg"></p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="terminating-steel-wire-armoured-cables-swa-and-aluminium-wire-armoured-awa-cables">Terminating steel wire armoured cables (SWA) and aluminium wire armoured (AWA) cables<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#terminating-steel-wire-armoured-cables-swa-and-aluminium-wire-armoured-awa-cables" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="tools-required">Tools required<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#tools-required" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<ul>
<li>hacksaw (junior or senior, depending on size of cable) or SWA stripper</li>
<li>stripping knife</li>
<li>spanners or grips to suit gland size.</li>
</ul>
<p>The City &amp; Guilds Textbook: Electrical Installations Book 1</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251222-4883d461.jpeg" alt="img-475.jpeg">
Figure 4.188 Alternative tools for terminating SWA cable</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251222-b342c7c3.jpeg" alt="img-476.jpeg"></p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="safety-considerations">Safety considerations<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#safety-considerations" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>Cuts to hands from use of knife or hacksaw.</li>
</ul>
<p>The use of gloves and eye protection is recommended.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="method">Method<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#method" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Steel wire armoured cables are used wherever there is a need for a cable with added mechanical protection. They are found in many industrial installations and are used where cables need to be buried in the ground. Single-core armoured cable has aluminium armour rather than steel wire armour, to reduce induced circulating currents within the armour, an effect known as eddy currents. Larger cables may have aluminium conductors rather than copper conductors, to reduce costs.</p>
<p>Armoured cables are available with thermoplastic (PVC) and thermosetting (XLPE, cross-linked polyethylene) insulation. Whichever type of cable and whichever insulation type, the termination method is the same.</p>
<p>Whilst the armour of the cable is there for mechanical protection of the conductors, it may also be used as a cpc for the circuit. If the armour is not used as a cpc, it must still be connected to the main earth terminal (MET) of the installation, as the armour forms part of the electrical installation.</p>
<p>Armoured cables can be terminated with two different types of gland, BW for indoor use and CW for outdoor use. Each method is described below.</p>
<p>BW glands – these glands are for indoor use as they have no seal. The BW glands are available in two- and three-part configurations.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="industry-tip">INDUSTRY TIP<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#industry-tip" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>When working with XLPE, you may find that it is generally stiffer than PVC.</p>
<p>Chapter 4 Electrical installation</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251222-9bca4ff4.jpeg" alt="img-477.jpeg">
Figure 4.189 Two-part BW gland</p>
<p>The three-part gland has a cone ring as the extra component. The cone ring is tapered so that, as the gland is tightened, the cone ring is forced down onto the cone, tightening against the armour.</p>
<p>CW glands – these glands can be used outside. A CW gland has a seal, which seals the gland to the cable sheath. CW glands are available in three- and four-part configurations; again, the difference is the cone ring.</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251222-d1786d58.jpeg" alt="img-478.jpeg">
Figure 4.190 Four-part CW gland</p>
<p>Whilst the gland may be terminated onto the cable before any connection to the equipment is made, there are occasions when armoured cable has to be installed between fixed points without any tolerance or slack. Larger cables are more difficult to handle, so careful marking out of the cable is important. The following method assumes that the cable is to be fitted to electrical equipment that has already been fixed to a wall.</p>
<p>These are the steps in the process of terminating an armoured cable.</p>
<ol>
<li>Prepare the cable.</li>
<li>Fit the shroud.</li>
<li>Fit the lower part of the gland to the electrical equipment.</li>
</ol>
<p>The City &amp; Guilds Textbook: Electrical Installations Book 1</p>
<p>4 Ensure the gland is earthed as this will in turn earth the armour.
5 Cut the armour to the correct length.
6 Fit the upper part of the gland to the cable.
7 Mark up and remove the outer sheath.
8 Spread the armour strands.
9 Fit the gland parts together.
10 Remove the inner sleeve.
11 Terminate the cores to the electrical equipment.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="step-1-prepare-the-cable">Step 1 Prepare the cable<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#step-1-prepare-the-cable" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The cable is cut to length, allowing enough at the end to terminate into the electrical equipment. Armoured cables are cut with either a hacksaw or with ratchet cutters designed to cut armoured cable.</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251222-7f1446e0.jpeg" alt="img-479.jpeg">
Figure 4.191 Ratchet cutter in use</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="industry-tip">INDUSTRY TIP<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#industry-tip" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The armour of a SWA cable requires earthing by using a banjo or similar, even if it is not used as the cpc for the circuit.</p>
<p>A banjo is a brass fitting with two holes, one for the gland and the other for a small bolt. It is used to ensure the armouring, via the gland, has a reliable connection to the enclosure (if metal) and any protective conductor connected via the nut and bolt.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="step-2-fit-the-shroud">Step 2 Fit the shroud<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#step-2-fit-the-shroud" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Whilst the shroud can be fitted any time before step 8, it is best to cut the shroud top to the correct size before the outer sheath is removed. See the method of fitting the shroud, as described on page 319.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="steps-3-and-4-fit-the-lower-part-of-the-gland-to-the-electrical-equipment-and-earth-the-armour">Steps 3 and 4 Fit the lower part of the gland to the electrical equipment and earth the armour<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#steps-3-and-4-fit-the-lower-part-of-the-gland-to-the-electrical-equipment-and-earth-the-armour" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Steps 3 and 4 are integral in this method of termination. In other methods, where the gland is fitted to the cable before fitting to the enclosure, they are separate steps.</p>
<p>To earth the armour, the brass gland body (lower part) is passed through an earth tag and then into the accessory. It is secured in place with a lock ring or lock nut, using a pipe wrench. Before this can be done, a hole must be drilled into the accessory so that a bolt can be placed through the earth tag and the accessory. The earth 'fly-lead' can then be secured inside the accessory. This enables a connection to the installation earthing to be made.</p>
<p>Chapter 4 Electrical installation</p>
<p>It is important to ensure that the paint is removed from the accessory at the point of connection between the earth tag and the casing. Also, make sure that the bolt is installed with the thread and nut on the inside of the accessory, as this will make the connection tamper-proof.</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251222-ee0ec56d.jpeg" alt="img-480.jpeg">
Figure 4.192 Gland body correctly fitted to steel enclosure</p>
<p>The 'fly-lead' is made up of a suitably sized conductor, fitted with a ring-type crimp connector. This enables the securing bolt to act like a pillar terminal – the crimped end of the fly-lead is connected here, while the other end is terminated as a normal protective conductor. With the gland in place, the shroud can be brought up to cover the gland. There should be no strands of armour visible with the shroud in place.</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251222-a323aa92.jpeg" alt="img-481.jpeg">
Figure 4.193 Armour gland with fly lead</p>
<p>An alternative to using the earth tag is to fit a special nut called a Piranha nut. This replaces the lock ring or lock nut and removes the need for drilling extra holes in the accessory. It also provides a means of connecting an earth lead to the gland.</p>
<p><strong>ACTIVITY</strong>
Why is it necessary to remove any paint around the hole before terminating the cable?</p>
<p>The City &amp; Guilds Textbook: Electrical Installations Book 1</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251222-f39318d6.jpeg" alt="img-482.jpeg">
Figure 4.194 Piranha nuts</p>
<p>One side of the Piranha nut has small, sharp edges, like teeth, which bite into the enclosure as the nut is tightened, giving a good electrical connection. The nut also has threaded holes on each of the nut faces, to allow machine screws to be secured to the nut, thereby providing points for connecting the earthing fly-lead directly to the nut. This method is especially useful when terminating armoured cables into plastic boxes.</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251222-cc7f41ac.jpeg" alt="img-483.jpeg">
Figure 4.195 SWA cable terminated into plastic box</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251222-9d1f09a8.jpeg" alt="img-484.jpeg">
Figure 4.196 Purpose designed earth link plate</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251222-92ae606e.jpeg" alt="img-485.jpeg">
Figure 4.197 Cable held against gland showing mark</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="step-5-cut-the-armour-to-the-correct-length">Step 5 Cut the armour to the correct length<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#step-5-cut-the-armour-to-the-correct-length" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Before step 5 can be completed, the cable needs to be marked at the correct position. For this, the cable is held against the gland body that has been fitted to the electrical enclosure.</p>
<p>A marking is made which is approximately the thickness of one of the armour wires above the base of the cone of the gland.</p>
<p>Chapter 4 Electrical installation</p>
<p>Using a hacksaw, cut all the way around the cable, cutting through the outer sheath; continue cutting until each of the armour wires is cut to a depth of approximately half. Be careful not to cut too deep and thus damage the insulation of the conductors, but make sure that all of the armour wires are cut or nicked.</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251222-53f9835d.jpeg" alt="img-486.jpeg">
Figure 4.198 Cutting the armour</p>
<p>This step may also be accomplished by using an armoured cable-stripper, which looks rather like a pipe-cutter but has a blade to cut the outer sheath and score the armour wires.</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251222-a2b0633b.jpeg" alt="img-487.jpeg">
Figure 4.199 Armoured cable-stripper in use</p>
<p>Remove the outer sheath, down to the cut point, by using a stripping knife. Hold the cable end in one hand, hold the knife across the cable at a slight angle and cut the outer sheath, pushing away from you.</p>
<p>The City &amp; Guilds Textbook: Electrical Installations Book 1</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251222-800c5af6.jpeg" alt="img-488.jpeg">
Figure 4.200 Cutting away the outer sheath (left) and breaking the armours off (right)</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251222-43108666.jpeg" alt="img-489.jpeg"></p>
<p>Now remove the armour wires from the cable. This is achieved by bending the wires back and forth until they snap. Care must be taken to ensure that the armour ends under the sheath are not distorted, otherwise there may be problems when fitting the gland together.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="step-6-fit-upper-part-of-the-gland-to-the-cable">Step 6 Fit upper part of the gland to the cable<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#step-6-fit-upper-part-of-the-gland-to-the-cable" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>At this stage the shroud should have been fitted to the cable. The upper part or parts of the gland should now be slid over the cable.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="industry-tip">INDUSTRY TIP<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#industry-tip" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>To stop the gland sliding down the cable, the gland body can be pushed into the shroud or taped to the cable, with insulation tape.</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251222-e7378709.jpeg" alt="img-490.jpeg">
Figure 4.201 Shroud and gland body on cable</p>
<p>Chapter 4 Electrical installation</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="step-7-mark-up-and-remove-the-outer-sheath">Step 7 Mark up and remove the outer sheath<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#step-7-mark-up-and-remove-the-outer-sheath" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Once again the cable is offered up against the gland body, now fitted to the electrical enclosure, and a mark is made just above the top of the cone.</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251222-7d69b806.jpeg" alt="img-491.jpeg">
Figure 4.202 How to mark up the sheath</p>
<p>At the mark, the outer sheath is cut right round the cable, using a knife, a hacksaw or a SWA stripper. The small piece of sheath is then removed.</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251222-093e7602.jpeg" alt="img-492.jpeg">
Figure 4.203 Cable with sheath removed</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="step-8-spread-the-armour-strands">Step 8 Spread the armour strands<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#step-8-spread-the-armour-strands" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>The armour strands now need to be spread to fit over the cone of the gland. On smaller cables this can be accomplished holding the armour and rotating the cable against the direction of the wind of the armour. On larger cables, the strands may need to be spread apart, using a large, flat screwdriver. It is important to make sure that the ends of each armour strand are straight and that none of them crosses over another.</p>
<p>The City &amp; Guilds Textbook: Electrical Installations Book 1</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251222-f4f14482.jpeg" alt="img-493.jpeg">
Figure 4.204 Armour spread ready for fitting the gland together</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="step-9-fit-the-gland-parts-together">Step 9 Fit the gland parts together<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#step-9-fit-the-gland-parts-together" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The cable is then passed through the gland body so that all the armour strands sit over the cone. The upper part of the gland is slid down the cable and tightened up to grip the armour. If a CW gland is fitted, the uppermost part of the gland is tightened onto the sheath of the cable to form a seal. Finally, the shroud can be fitted over the gland.</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251222-6b1b8344.jpeg" alt="img-494.jpeg">
Figure 4.205 BW gland fitted (left) and CW gland fitted (right)</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251222-fa6fe524.jpeg" alt="img-495.jpeg"></p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="industry-tip">INDUSTRY TIP<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#industry-tip" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The inner sleeve is often referred to as 'bedding'.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="step-10-remove-the-inner-sleeve">Step 10 Remove the inner sleeve<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#step-10-remove-the-inner-sleeve" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The inner sleeve can now be stripped from the cores, in a similar way to stripping the outer sheath from a flexible cable. Care must be taken to avoid damaging the insulation of the inner cores.</p>
<p>Chapter 4 Electrical installation</p>
<p>In some cases, it is better to strip the inner core before fitting the gland together. Then, when passing the cable through the gland body, care must be taken to avoid damaging the insulation of the inner cores on the gland body.</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251222-a40c9ce9.jpeg" alt="img-496.jpeg">
Figure 4.206 Cable fully terminated, CW glands</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="step-11-terminate-the-inner-cores">Step 11 Terminate the inner cores<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#step-11-terminate-the-inner-cores" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The cable is now ready for final termination.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="pilc-cable">PILC cable<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#pilc-cable" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Paper insulated lead covered (PILC) cable is primarily used for power distribution by the distribution network operators (DNO). Therefore, the termination of this type of cable is specialised and will not be a subject of this section.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="termination-of-armoured-or-braided-flex">Termination of armoured or braided flex<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#termination-of-armoured-or-braided-flex" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="tools-required">Tools required<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#tools-required" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<ul>
<li>stripping knife</li>
<li>spanners or grips to suit gland size.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="safety-considerations">Safety considerations<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#safety-considerations" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<ul>
<li>Cuts to hands from use of knife.</li>
</ul>
<p>The use of gloves and eye protection is recommended.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="method">Method<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#method" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<p>The method for the termination of braided flexes is similar to that used for terminating armoured cables.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="industry-tip">INDUSTRY TIP<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#industry-tip" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>If you do need to trim the armour wires, do not use side-cutters as these will distort the armour wires. It is better to use a hacksaw to score the armour wires and then to use pliers to bend the wires to break them. One problem is how to stop the armour wires from moving under the hacksaw blade. The solution is to wrap insulating tape around the armour and to cut through the insulation tape to score the armour wires.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="industry-tip">INDUSTRY TIP<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#industry-tip" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>PILC cable: If you are required to terminate this cable you will need specialist training.</p>
<p>347</p>
<p>The City &amp; Guilds Textbook: Electrical Installations Book 1</p>
<p>These are the steps in the termination process for braided flex.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="step-1-strip-the-outer-sheath">Step 1 Strip the outer sheath<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#step-1-strip-the-outer-sheath" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
