<p>The cable outer sheath is removed at the correct position, ensuring that the outer sheath ends up inside the body of the gland. The outer sheath is removed, using a rotary stripper or an electrician's knife. Care must be taken not to cut too deep, as the braid of the flex is made of fine strands of wire.</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251222-1c74799f.jpeg" alt="img-497.jpeg">
Figure 4.207 Cable with outer sheath removed</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="step-2-fit-the-gland">Step 2 Fit the gland<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#step-2-fit-the-gland" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Armoured or braided flex, such as SY flex, can be terminated using two different types of gland, CX and CXT. Both methods are described below.</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251222-119b105b.jpeg" alt="img-498.jpeg">
Figure 4.209 Terminating CX gland</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="key-term">KEY TERM<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#key-term" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>CXT: the T in CXT means 'tail'.</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251222-35b006fc.jpeg" alt="img-499.jpeg">
Figure 4.208 CX gland</p>
<ul>
<li>Method 1 – the braid is fitted to a CX gland in much the same way as other armoured cables. This type of gland provides a higher degree of interference immunity than a CXT gland.</li>
<li>Method 2 – with a CXT gland, the braid is separated into two pigtails. The best way of doing this is by using a small screwdriver to separate the strands. The strands can then be made into two pigtails.</li>
</ul>
<p>Chapter 4 Electrical installation</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251222-52478f83.jpeg" alt="img-500.jpeg">
Figure 4.210 Braids formed into pigtails</p>
<p>When the gland is fitted to the enclosure, the pigtails fit into slots in the gland and are sandwiched between washers and the locknut.</p>
<p>Whichever gland is used, the braid, even though it is not used as an earth, must be connected to the main earth terminal.</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251222-48105599.jpeg" alt="img-501.jpeg">
Figure 4.211 Ready for final termination</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251222-188a8272.jpeg" alt="img-502.jpeg">
Figure 4.212 CXT gland earthed</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="step-3-remove-the-inner-sleeve">Step 3 Remove the inner sleeve<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#step-3-remove-the-inner-sleeve" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The inner sleeve can now be stripped from the cores in a similar way to stripping the outer sheath from a flexible cable. Care must be taken to avoid damaging the insulation of the outer core.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="step-4-terminate-the-inner-cores">Step 4 Terminate the inner cores<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#step-4-terminate-the-inner-cores" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The cable is now ready for final termination.</p>
<p>The City &amp; Guilds Textbook: Electrical Installations Book 1</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="key-term">KEY TERM<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#key-term" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Cross-talk: a bleeding of signal from one conductor to another, through electro-magnetic induction. Twisting pairs of cable reduces this cross-talk.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="data-cables">Data cables<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#data-cables" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>This section covers the termination of four types of data cables:</p>
<ul>
<li>Cat 5 &amp; Cat 5e</li>
<li>Cat 6</li>
<li>fibre optic.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="the-termination-of-cat-5-cat-5e-and-cat-6-data-cable">The termination of Cat 5, Cat 5e and Cat 6 data cable<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#the-termination-of-cat-5-cat-5e-and-cat-6-data-cable" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>The termination of Cat 5 and Cat 5e cable is the same; the termination of Cat 6 is very similar. These data cables are all twisted-pair type cables and usually contain four pairs (eight cores). Each pair is twisted to reduce cross-talk and each pair within the cable has a different number of twists per metre.</p>
<p>Within a data cable, the pairs are identified by:</p>
<ul>
<li>one cable taking a solid colour with a white stripe</li>
<li>its pair being a white cable with the corresponding colour as its stripe.</li>
</ul>
<p>When terminating these twisted pair cables, it is important that the pairs are not untwisted any more than is necessary to terminate the cores; otherwise cross-talk could be an issue.</p>
<p>For 'electrically noisy environments', shielded twisted pair cables (STP) are available. This section describes how to terminate unscreened twisted pair (UTP) cables that are commonly found within data installations. The table below shows the designations for the basic categories of twisted pair cables, with different configurations of screening.</p>
<p>▼ Types of twisted pair cable</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="industry-tip">INDUSTRY TIP<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#industry-tip" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>These cables are often installed in mini or maxi trunking to avoid clipping.</p>
<table><thead><tr><th>Old name</th><th>New name</th><th>Cable screening</th><th>Pair screening</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>UTP</td><td>U/UTP</td><td>None</td><td>None</td></tr><tr><td>STP</td><td>U/FTP</td><td>None</td><td>Foil</td></tr><tr><td>FTP</td><td>F/UTP</td><td>Foil</td><td>None</td></tr><tr><td>S-STP</td><td>S/FTP</td><td>Braiding</td><td>Foil</td></tr><tr><td>S-FTP</td><td>SF/UTP</td><td>Foil, Braiding</td><td>None</td></tr></tbody></table>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251222-7327aa77.jpeg" alt="img-503.jpeg">
▲ Figure 4.213 Tools for terminating data cable</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="tools-required">Tools required<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#tools-required" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>rotary stripper (Cyclops)</li>
<li>punch down tool.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="removing-the-outer-jacket">Removing the outer jacket<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#removing-the-outer-jacket" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>There is more than one method of removing the outer jacket of the data cable, but it is important to remove no more of the outer jacket than is absolutely necessary; about 50 mm is the ideal amount.</p>
<p>Method 1, using the integral ripcord – Some twisted-pair data cables come with an integral ripcord, which looks like a piece of thread. A pair of side-cutters is used to make a small cut in the end of the cable, to expose the end of the rip cord. With the ripcord held at 90° to the cable jacket, gently pull the ripcord so that it cuts the jacket.</p>
<p>Chapter 4 Electrical installation</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251222-3e11d907.jpeg" alt="img-504.jpeg">
Figure 4.214 Ripcord being pulled</p>
<p>Carry on pulling the ripcord until the intended length of the jacket to remove is reached. Pull the inner cores out from the jacket and use a pair of side-cutters to cut away the jacket.</p>
<p>Method 2, using a rotary stripper – The rotary stripper is passed over the end of the cable, to the point to which the outer jacket is to be stripped. The stripper is rotated to score the outer sheath, which is then removed from the cable.</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251222-5d803930.jpeg" alt="img-505.jpeg">
Figure 4.215 Rotating the stripper</p>
<p>The cable jacket is bent slightly, first one way and then the other, at the score point so that the jacket 'breaks'.</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251222-2f0395aa.jpeg" alt="img-506.jpeg">
Figure 4.216 Bending the cable sheath</p>
<p>The City &amp; Guilds Textbook: Electrical Installations Book 1</p>
<p>The outer jacket can then be pulled off the cable. The cable is now ready for terminating.</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251222-1039fe9f.jpeg" alt="img-507.jpeg">
Figure 4.217 Cable ready for terminating</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="terminating-the-inner-cores">Terminating the inner cores<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#terminating-the-inner-cores" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>As mentioned earlier, inside the cable there are eight colour-coded cores, which are twisted to form four pairs of wires. Each pair has a common colour theme, with one conductor of the pair having a solid colour and the other conductor of the pair having a stripe to match the theme. There are two wiring standards for the connection of an RJ45 connector for twisted-pair cables, T568A and T568B, the difference being the sequence of connection of the cores.</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251222-3f7c977a.jpeg" alt="img-508.jpeg">
Figure 4.218 Wiring connections shown on back of equipment</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251222-d0881c06.jpeg" alt="img-509.jpeg">
Figure 4.219 Sectional view of insulation displacement terminal</p>
<p>While it may not matter which standard is used, it is important to make sure that the same standard is used at both ends of the cable. It is also important to remember that:</p>
<ul>
<li>it is common practice for the UK and Europe to use T568B</li>
<li>there may be a need to match data-cabling that has been installed on an earlier occasion.</li>
</ul>
<p>Twisted-pair data cables are connected by means of insulation displacement connectors (IDC) which do not require the insulation of the cable to be stripped.</p>
<p>This type of termination is common in the telecoms part of the industry and is used where the conductor size is very small, so that it is impractical to use a screw-type terminal. The terminal has two blades, positioned to form a V-shape. As the wire is pushed into the terminal, the blades cut into the insulation until they make contact with the conductor. A special termination tool trims the wire to the correct length, as well as ensuring the wire is pushed far enough into the terminal. These terminals are not very good at withstanding vibration and so are only used for fixed, permanent connections.</p>
<p>Chapter 4 Electrical installation</p>
<p>This type of termination is used with solid-core data-cable.</p>
<p>Terminating to a data outlet plate – Place the data module on a solid surface. Untwist enough of the pair to terminate and lay the core across the appropriate IDC terminal. Using the punch-down tool, press down on each of the cores in turn, pushing the core into the terminal. Make sure the tool is the correct way round so that the tool cuts off any surplus conductor.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="industry-tip">INDUSTRY TIP<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#industry-tip" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Only the final 10–12 mm of a cable pair should be untwisted.</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251222-218a5fea.jpeg" alt="img-510.jpeg">
Figure 4.220 Outlet being terminated</p>
<p>Start with the lower terminals, so that access is easier. Once all pairs are terminated, use a cable tie to secure the cable to the module.</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251222-cad75f9a.jpeg" alt="img-511.jpeg">
Figure 4.221 Finalised module</p>
<p>Terminating to a patch panel – It is normal practice to leave enough slack on the cables to enable the patch panel to be pulled forward, out of the cabinet or rack, so that the terminations can be made on a solid surface. Trying to make the termination unsupported, in mid-air, is likely to result in faulty connections.</p>
<p>Terminate, using a similar method to that employed for terminating the data modules. If the cables approach the patch panel from left to right, then terminate the cables to the ports nearest the left-hand side first, to avoid terminated cables getting in the way of those yet to be terminated.</p>
<p>The City &amp; Guilds Textbook: Electrical Installations Book 1</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="industry-tip">INDUSTRY TIP<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#industry-tip" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>While terminating a group of cables, secure them loosely with a cable tie. Once the cables are terminated, then pull the tie tight.</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251222-c5bc18be.jpeg" alt="img-512.jpeg">
▲ Figure 4.222 Patch panel being terminated</p>
<p>Once a group of cables has been terminated, use a cable tie to secure them.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="industry-tip">INDUSTRY TIP<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#industry-tip" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>It's best that cables do not enter the patch panel termination area from both the left and the right sides, as this will make the fitting of the patch panel into the rack cabinet very difficult.</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251222-f843e53f.jpeg" alt="img-513.jpeg">
▲ Figure 4.223 Finished patch panel</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="industry-tip">IndUSTRY TIP<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#industry-tip" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Cat 6 cable provides higher performance than CAT 5e and features more stringent specifications for cross-talk and system noise.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="cat-6-cable">Cat 6 cable<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#cat-6-cable" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>The method of termination of Cat 6 cable is very similar to that for Cat 5 and Cat 5e cable, but with some noticeable differences. The major difference between terminating Cat 6 cable and Cat 5 cables is the need to ensure that the pairs are separated from each other as much as possible. Within the cable, this is accomplished by means of a divider, which forms an X-shape, with each pair sitting in a separate section. When installing this cable, it is important to ensure that no 'kinks' or tight bends are introduced, to avoid the pairs coming out of their divider-section.</p>
<p>When terminating Cat 6 cables to a patch panel, the individual cables are kept separate from each other.</p>
<p>Chapter 4 Electrical installation</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251222-2de624ca.jpeg" alt="img-514.jpeg">
Figure 4.224 Terminated Cat 6 patch panel</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="industry-tip">INDUSTRY TIP<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#industry-tip" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Cat 6 and Cat 5 patch panels and data outlets are not interchangeable.</p>
<p>Once the cables have been installed they will require testing.</p>
<p>Data cables are always improving. For example, the Cat 7 cable has recently been introduced, which has a larger csa than Cat 5 and individual pair screening.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="fitting-an-rj45-plug-to-a-patch-lead-cat-5e">Fitting an RJ45 plug to a patch lead (Cat 5e)<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#fitting-an-rj45-plug-to-a-patch-lead-cat-5e" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>There may be times when there is a requirement to make up a patch lead. A straight-through patch lead has the same connections at each end. The cable used needs to have cores that are flexible. The plug has insulation-piercing connectors (IPC), which are basically pins that pierce the insulation. An RJ45 plug is not suitable for terminating solid core cable; the termination will suffer premature failure.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="tools-required">Tools required<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#tools-required" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>rotary stripper (Cyclops)</li>
<li>RJ45 modular crimp tool</li>
<li>cutters.</li>
</ul>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251222-7bdbae67.jpeg" alt="img-515.jpeg">
Figure 4.225 Tools required to fit plugs to Cat 5 patch cable</p>
<p>The City &amp; Guilds Textbook: Electrical Installations Book 1</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="method">Method<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#method" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Use a rotary stripper to strip approximately 25 mm of the outer sheath of the cable. The method is the same as for solid-core data-cables.</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251222-81844166.jpeg" alt="img-516.jpeg">
▲ Figure 4.226 Cable with the outer jacket stripped</p>
<p>Untwist each of the cores completely.</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251222-8ec000f1.jpeg" alt="img-517.jpeg">
▲ Figure 4.227 Untwisted cores</p>
<p>Arrange the untwisted cores so that they are in the correct order for the wiring connection required. Once they are arranged, hold them between thumb and forefinger.</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251222-05680686.jpeg" alt="img-518.jpeg">
▲ Figure 4.228 Cores ready for trimming</p>
<p>Trim the cores to approximately 12–13 mm, using a pair of cutters. Make sure the cores are all the same length when held in the correct order.</p>
<p>Chapter 4 Electrical installation</p>
<p>Push the wires into the connector, making sure that they are still in the correct order and that they go right to the ends of the connector. The outer sheath should end up under the locking piece.</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251222-cdf0dd80.jpeg" alt="img-519.jpeg">
Figure 4.229 Ready for crimping</p>
<p>Recheck that the cores are in the correct order. Carefully place the connector into the modular crimp tool and squeeze the handles tightly. The insulation piercing pins will pierce each of the eight wires and the locking tab that holds the outer plastic sheath will engage, securing the plug to the cable. Once both ends are terminated, the lead is ready to use.</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251222-0c0f55c5.jpeg" alt="img-520.jpeg">
Figure 4.230 Plug being crimped</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251222-5e8a1a2b.jpeg" alt="img-521.jpeg">
Figure 4.231 Correctly fitted RJ45 plug</p>
<p>It is recommended that Cat 6 patch leads are purchased, due to the fact that hand-making a Cat 6 patch lead is difficult and the result is likely to be of a poor quality.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="industry-tip">INDUSTRY TIP<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#industry-tip" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The maximum length of Cat 5, Cat 5e and Cat 6 cable, including patch lead, is 100 m between switches.</p>
<p>357</p>
<p>The City &amp; Guilds Textbook: Electrical Installations Book 1</p>

<p>Pins on an RJ45 plug are numbered from left to right, when the plug is held with the latch facing downwards and the pins on top of the plug.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="fibre-optic-cable">Fibre-optic cable<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#fibre-optic-cable" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Fibre-optic cables are used in data and telecoms applications. The most common connector types are:</p>
<ul>
<li>ST – straight tip</li>
<li>SC – subscriber connector</li>
<li>LC – lucent connector, a small form factor SC type connector with a locking mechanism developed by Lucent</li>
<li>FC – fibre connector, less common these days as prone to vibration loosening.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="activity">ACTIVITY<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#activity" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Look on the internet for the different types of UTP terminations available.</p>
<p>Chapter 4 Electrical installation</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251222-0b2daf78.jpeg" alt="img-523.jpeg">
Figure 4.235 SC, LC and ST type connectors</p>
<p>Whatever type of connector is used, the termination process is similar. It is important that all dust is excluded from the termination. The environment when terminating fibre optics must be scrupulously clean. As the process of termination varies slightly from manufacturer to manufacturer, it is important to refer to manufacturer's instructions before terminating the fibre optic.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="tools-required">Tools required<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#tools-required" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>crimp tool</li>
<li>die sets to suit type of connector</li>
<li>stripper tools</li>
<li>kevlar shears</li>
<li>cable holder</li>
<li>cleave tool</li>
</ul>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251222-835d96fd.jpeg" alt="img-524.jpeg">
Figure 4.236 Tools required for the termination of fibre optic cables</p>
<p>The City &amp; Guilds Textbook: Electrical Installations Book 1</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="safety-considerations">Safety considerations<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#safety-considerations" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Never look down the end of a connected fibre, as this could result in serious eye damage. The light transmitted is in the infra-red spectrum and therefore invisible to the eye, but can cause serious damage. Ensure both ends of the fibre are disconnected or that the transmitter is switched off.</p>
<p>When cutting the fibre, small glass shards are produced. If they get into the eye, they are very difficult to flush out. Safety glasses should be worn when terminating fibre-optic cables. Never eat, drink or smoke whilst terminating fibre optics, as this may lead to ingestion of glass particles.</p>
<p>Some termination kits may use adhesives in the termination process so attention will need to be paid to COSHH data sheets.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="method">Method<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#method" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>The method described below uses Lightcrimp Plus SC connectors from Tyco Electronics. As the connectors are pre-polished, there is no need for polishing and adhesives are not used.</p>
<p>Each connector kit consists of:</p>
<p>1 connector assembly
2 crimp eyelet
3 inner eyelet
4 strain relief
5 connector housing
6 clear tubing.</p>
<p>To compensate for small-diameter fibres, the kit also comes with:</p>
<p>7 a bare buffer boot
8 small tubing.</p>
<p>Assembled on to the connector so as to protect the connector is:</p>
<p>9 a termination cover (front of connector)
10 a plunger dust cap (rear of connector).</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251222-b25f07d4.jpeg" alt="img-525.jpeg">
Figure 4.237 Parts of Lightcrimp Plus SC connector</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="industry-tip">INDUSTRY TIP<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#industry-tip" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Beware of glass shards (splinters) when terminating fibre-optic cables.</p>
<p>Chapter 4 Electrical installation</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251222-35bcc0aa.jpeg" alt="img-526.jpeg">
Step 1 – The termination of this fibre-optic cable requires only items 1, 5, 7 and 8 from the connection kit.</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251222-ee0a4823.jpeg" alt="img-527.jpeg">
Step 2 – Before the final termination can be carried out, the cable must be prepared. The first step is to remove the outer cable jacket by scoring with a rotary stripper.</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251222-32f91a0c.jpeg" alt="img-528.jpeg">
Step 3 – The cable is bent carefully so that the outer jacket splits. The outer jacket can now be removed by sliding it from the inner cores.</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251222-b710cd6a.jpeg" alt="img-529.jpeg">
Step 4 – This cable has reinforcing strands to give added strength. These are now cut away with the shears.</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251222-0191579f.jpeg" alt="img-530.jpeg">
Step 5 – The inner jacket is carefully scored with the rotary stripper in much the same way as was the outer jacket.</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251222-5a9d0a3a.jpeg" alt="img-531.jpeg">
Step 6 – The inner jacket can now be removed. Notice the gel on the cable in the picture. This should be wiped away once the inner jacket has been removed.</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251222-00042ae2.jpeg" alt="img-532.jpeg">
Step 7 – The individual fibres are twisted together and must be separated.
Figure 4.238</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251222-dfcfd21e.jpeg" alt="img-533.jpeg">
Step 8 – The individual fibres of the cable are now separated, ready to be terminated.</p>
<p>The City &amp; Guilds Textbook: Electrical Installations Book 1</p>
<p>The next part of the process can be broken down into three sections:</p>
<ul>
<li>Preparation and stripping of the fibre</li>
<li>Cleaving the fibre</li>
<li>Fitting the termination.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="preparation-and-stripping-of-the-fibre">Preparation and stripping of the fibre<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#preparation-and-stripping-of-the-fibre" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251222-47638d8f.jpeg" alt="img-534.jpeg">
Step 1 - Slide the bare buffer boot onto the fibre, small end first. It is best to do this now so that it does not get forgotten. Remove the plunger dust cap from the connector assembly and discard.</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251222-f9a2a0ae.jpeg" alt="img-535.jpeg">
Step 2 - Push the connector assembly into the holder of the cable-holder assembly, with the termination cover facing out. Make sure that the connector butts up against the lip on the arm of the cable-holder assembly.</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251222-b7c4b55c.jpeg" alt="img-536.jpeg">
Step 3 - Insert the small (white) tubing into the plunger of the connector assembly until the tubing reaches the bottom.</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251222-ba6df6f1.jpeg" alt="img-537.jpeg">
Step 4 - Slide the fibre into the channel marked 'BUFFER'. Make sure that the tip of the fibre butts up against the end of the channel. Mark the fibre at each cross-slot of the channel.</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251222-abc58e80.jpeg" alt="img-538.jpeg">
Step 5 - Remove the fibre from the cable holder. The fibre is now ready for stripping.</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251222-81b15219.jpeg" alt="img-539.jpeg">
Step 6 - Using the strip tool, strip the fibre to the first mark. It is recommended that you hold the strip tool at an angle to the fibre and strip the fibre in small sections.</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251222-ad2629be.jpeg" alt="img-540.jpeg">
Step 7 - Once the buffer has been stripped from the fibre, the fibre must be cleaned with an alcohol wipe to remove any fibre residue. The fibre is now ready for cleaving.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="figure-4-239">Figure 4.239<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#figure-4-239" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Chapter 4 Electrical installation</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="cleaving-the-fibre">Cleaving the fibre<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#cleaving-the-fibre" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251222-825dae11.jpeg" alt="img-541.jpeg">
Step 1 – Open the fibre clamp of the fibre-optic cleaver. Press the button, and slide the carriage back (toward the fibre clamp). Then, move the fibre slide back until it stops. Place the stripped fibre into the slot so that the end of the buffer is at the 8mm marking.</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251222-d60aed8a.jpeg" alt="img-542.jpeg">
Step 2 – While applying pressure on the buffer, carefully slide the fibre slide forwards (towards the carriage) until it stops.</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251222-2579c6ee.jpeg" alt="img-543.jpeg">
Step 3 – Gently close the fibre clamp, and slide the carriage forwards. DO NOT touch the button while sliding the carriage. Open the fibre clamp, and move the fibre slide back until it stops. Remove the cleaved fibre, and properly dispose of the scrap fibre.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="industry-tip">INDUSTRY TIP<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#industry-tip" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Do not attempt to clean the fibre after it has been cleaved.</p>
<p>Figure 4.240</p>
<p>The City &amp; Guilds Textbook: Electrical Installations Book 1</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="fitting-the-termination">Fitting the termination<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#fitting-the-termination" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251222-70663e99.jpeg" alt="img-544.jpeg">
Step 1 – Open the cable clamp of the cable-holder assembly, and position the fibre (with the cleaved end facing the connector) inside the clamp. Move the fibre so that the end of the fibre is level with the front of the arm of the cable-holder assembly and, holding the fibre in place, close the clamp.</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251222-7a65a393.jpeg" alt="img-545.jpeg">
Step 2 – Carefully insert the fibre into the plunger of the connector assembly until the fibre reaches the internal fibre. Make sure that the remaining mark on the fibre enters the plunger.</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251222-5e88b742.jpeg" alt="img-546.jpeg">
Step 3 – The resultant bend in the fibre should hold the inserted fibre against the internal fibre. The fibre coating must enter the small tube that was installed in Step 4 of the ‘Preparation and stripping’ section. Make sure that the start of the fibre coating is not caught on the entry of the small tubing.</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251222-2fc2aded.jpeg" alt="img-547.jpeg">
Step 4 – Squeeze the handles of the hand tool until the ratchet releases. Allow the handles to open fully.</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251222-2f76d7bd.jpeg" alt="img-548.jpeg">
Step 5 – Slide the bare buffer boot over the plunger until the boot butts up against the connector assembly. Remove the connector assembly from the cable-holder assembly.</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251222-dba0de62.jpeg" alt="img-549.jpeg">
Step 6 – Align the key of the connector housing with the chamfered edges of the connector assembly. Slide the housing over the assembly until it snaps in place. DO NOT force the components.</p>
<p>With the connector assembly in the cable-holder assembly, position the ferrule or termination cover in the upper cavity of the front die and the plunger in the upper cavity of the rear die.</p>
<p>Gently push the fibre towards the connector assembly to make sure that the fibre is still touching the bottom and, then, slowly squeeze the tool handles together until the ratchet releases. Allow the handles to open fully and remove the connector from the dies.</p>
<p>Position the plunger of the connector assembly in the first (smallest) cavity of the front die, with the knurl against the edge of the groove in the die, and the ferrule or termination cover pointing in the direction of the arrow.</p>
<p>Slowly squeeze the tool handles together until the ratchet releases. Allow the handles to open fully and remove the connector assembly from the die.</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251222-8e5fd1b6.jpeg" alt="img-550.jpeg">
Step 7 – The fibre is now terminated, ready to be tested.</p>
<p>Figure 4.241</p>
<p>Chapter 4 Electrical installation</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="industry-tip">INDUSTRY TIP<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#industry-tip" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The arrows marked on the front die indicate the direction in which the ferrule or termination cover must be pointing when the connector is positioned in that cavity. For proper placement, and to avoid damage to the fibre, observe the direction of the arrows.</p>
<p>After the termination is complete, the ferrule end-face must be inspected for cleanliness, using a 200 × microscope. See the paragraph at the beginning of this section about the dangers of looking down a fibre-optic cable.</p>
<p>It can be seen from the foregoing that the process of terminating a fibre-optic cable is complex, but is a skill well worth obtaining. It is only by following the process and being scrupulously clean, that acceptable terminations can be made.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="what-needs-bonding">What needs bonding?<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#what-needs-bonding" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>BS 7671 The IET Wiring Regulations requires that an extraneous conductive part be connected to the main earthing terminal (MET) by means of a suitably sized protective bonding conductor. An understanding of the term 'extraneous conductive part' helps when deciding whether an item requires bonding or not.</p>
<p>An extraneous conductive part is defined in BS 7671 as:</p>
<ul>
<li>a conductive part</li>
<li>liable to introduce a potential, generally Earth potential, and</li>
<li>not forming part of the electrical installation.</li>
</ul>
<p>By breaking down the definition in this way, it helps us come to a conclusion as to whether or not something requires bonding.</p>
<ul>
<li>A conductive part is generally metallic.</li>
<li>The potential is usually taken as the mass of Earth, hence the capital E in 'Earth potential'.</li>
</ul>
<p>Extraneous conductive parts would include such items as:</p>
<ul>
<li>metallic water installation pipes</li>
<li>metallic gas installation pipes</li>
<li>other metallic installation pipework and ducting</li>
<li>exposed structural metalwork</li>
<li>central heating and air-conditioning systems.</li>
</ul>
<p>When considering items on the list above, always use the criteria that define an extraneous conductive part to decide whether or not the item is an extraneous conductive part in a particular situation. For example, a structural steel beam supported on brick piers would not be regarded as an extraneous conductive part and would not require bonding, but a structural steel beam in contact with the ground is an extraneous conductive part that would require bonding.</p>
<p>Metallic parts of the electrical installation are exposed conductive parts rather than extraneous conductive parts and these require earthing.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="key-terms">KEY TERMS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#key-terms" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p><strong>Bonding</strong>: a term used to describe the connection of extraneous conductive parts to the earthing system.</p>
<p><strong>Earth</strong>: earth with a capital E represents the potential of the ground we stand on.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="industry-tip">INDUSTRY TIP<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#industry-tip" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>BS 7671 also states that, where non-metallic (plastic) pipes enter the building and are connected to metallic pipes within the building, the metal pipes do not normally require bonding, as they are unlikely to be classed as extraneous.</p>
<p>365</p>
<p>The City &amp; Guilds Textbook: Electrical Installations Book 1</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251222-542c4024.jpeg" alt="img-551.jpeg">
Figure 4.242 A clamp used for bonding extraneous conductive parts such as pipework</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="installing-protective-bonding">Installing protective bonding<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#installing-protective-bonding" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>When installing protective bonding to mains services, the following steps should be taken.</p>
<ol>
<li>Select the correct size of protective bonding conductor.</li>
<li>Install the protective bonding conductor.</li>
<li>Make the correct choice of bonding clamp.</li>
<li>Install the bonding clamp.</li>
<li>Terminate the cable.</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="cable-sizes">Cable sizes<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#cable-sizes" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The size of bonding conductor depends on the type of earthing system used.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="tn-s-and-tt-systems">TN-S and TT systems<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#tn-s-and-tt-systems" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>For TN-S and TT systems the following criteria are used to determine the size of protective bonding conductors:</p>
<ul>
<li>half the size of the earthing conductor</li>
<li>a minimum size of <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>6</mn><msup><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">m</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">m</mi></mrow><mn>2</mn></msup></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">6\mathrm{mm}^2</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8141em;"></span><span class="mord">6</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">mm</span></span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.8141em;"><span style="top: -3.063em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight">2</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></li>
<li>a maximum size of <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>25</mn><msup><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">m</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">m</mi></mrow><mn>2</mn></msup></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">25\mathrm{mm}^2</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8141em;"></span><span class="mord">25</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">mm</span></span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.8141em;"><span style="top: -3.063em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight">2</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="tn-c-s-systems">TN-C-S systems<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#tn-c-s-systems" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>For TN-C-S (PME) systems the size of protective bonding conductors is determined in accordance with the size of the supply neutral and Table 54.8 of BS 7671 (reproduced below).</p>
<p>Chapter 4 Electrical installation</p>
