<ul>
<li>Where PME conditions apply, the earthing conductor will be  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>10</mn><msup><mrow><mtext>  </mtext><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">m</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">m</mi></mrow></mrow><mn>2</mn></msup></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">{10}{\mathrm{\;{mm}}}^{2}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8141em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord">10</span></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord"><span class="mord"><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">mm</span></span></span></span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.8141em;"><span style="top: -3.063em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">2</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span>  .</li>
</ul>
<p>BS 7671 does point out that local distributors' network conditions may require a larger conductor for PME systems.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="installation-of-main-protective-bonding-conductors">Installation of main protective bonding conductors<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#installation-of-main-protective-bonding-conductors" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>A main protective bonding conductor of the correct size should be run from the MET to the point of connection to the service to be bonded. The conductor used must be of the correct colour: green and yellow.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="support-of-main-protective-bonding-conductors">Support of main protective bonding conductors<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#support-of-main-protective-bonding-conductors" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Section 522 of BS 7671 requires that all cables are correctly supported throughout their length to avoid mechanical stresses on both the cable and the terminations. Gas, water and other service pipework should not be used as a method of support. Consideration needs to be given to this aspect, especially where the bonding cable is terminated to the service pipework to ensure that the protective bonding conductor does not become disconnected from the pipe clamp.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="point-of-connection">Point of connection<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#point-of-connection" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The connection of the bonding conductor to the service pipes should be:</p>
<ul>
<li>as near as practicable to the point of entry of the service into the building</li>
<li>where practicable, within 600 mm of the service meter or at the point of entry if the service meter is external</li>
<li>to the consumer's pipework – in the case of a water service, after the stopcock</li>
</ul>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251222-ffea4044.jpeg" alt="img-552.jpeg">
<span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">△</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\triangle</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8889em; vertical-align: -0.1944em;"></span><span class="mord">△</span></span></span></span></span>  Figure 4.243 Clipped bonding conductor</p>
<p>The City &amp; Guilds Textbook: Electrical Installations Book 1</p>
<ul>
<li>to hard metal pipework, not soft or flexible pipe</li>
<li>before any branch pipework</li>
<li>after any insulating sections.</li>
</ul>
<p>The connection point is required to be accessible for future inspection and testing.</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251222-63e5168d.jpeg" alt="img-553.jpeg">
▲ Figure 4.244 Bonding to gas supply</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="choice-of-bonding-clamps">Choice of bonding clamps<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#choice-of-bonding-clamps" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Bonding clamps must:</p>
<ul>
<li>meet the requirements of BS 951:2009</li>
<li>be suitable for the environment in which they are to be installed</li>
<li>be labelled in accordance with Regulation 514.13.1 and Appendix 11 of BS 7671.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="health-and-safety">HEALTH AND SAFETY<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#health-and-safety" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Always make sure all connections are electrically and mechanically sound. Bad joints are dangerous.</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251222-9879a6ab.jpeg" alt="img-554.jpeg">
▲ Figure 4.245 Colour-coded BS 951 bonding clamps</p>
<p>BS 951 clamps are designed only to fit circular pipes or rods. They are not designed to fit objects of irregular shape, to be attached to steel wire armoured cable or lead-sheathed cable. They are available in different lengths and different materials to suit different pipe sizes and different installation environments.</p>
<p>BS 951 clamps are designed for connection of bonding conductors of between <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>2.5</mn><mtext> </mtext><msup><mtext>mm</mtext><mn>2</mn></msup></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">2.5 \, \text{mm}^2</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8141em;"></span><span class="mord">2.5</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.1667em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord text"><span class="mord">mm</span></span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.8141em;"><span style="top: -3.063em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight">2</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span> and <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>70</mn><mtext> </mtext><msup><mtext>mm</mtext><mn>2</mn></msup></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">70 \, \text{mm}^2</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8141em;"></span><span class="mord">70</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.1667em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord text"><span class="mord">mm</span></span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.8141em;"><span style="top: -3.063em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight">2</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span>. They also come in three standard band lengths, to suit pipes with diameters of:</p>
<ul>
<li>12–32 mm</li>
<li>32–50 mm</li>
<li>50–75 mm.</li>
</ul>
<p>BS 951 clamps are available to suit different environments and manufacturers have adopted a three-colour coding system to make selection easier:</p>
<ul>
<li>red for dry, non-corrosive atmospheres</li>
<li>blue for corrosive or humid conditions</li>
<li>green for corrosive or humid conditions, and for larger sizes of conductor.</li>
</ul>
<p>Chapter 4 Electrical installation</p>
<p>Some extraneous parts, such as steelwork, are of an irregular shape but still require bonding. Various clamps are available from suppliers and these must be:</p>
<ul>
<li>electrically durable</li>
<li>of adequate mechanical strength</li>
<li>suitable for the environment where they are to be installed</li>
<li>labelled in accordance with Regulation 514.13.1 and Appendix 11 of BS 7671.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="labels-for-bonding-clamps">Labels for bonding clamps<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#labels-for-bonding-clamps" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>BS 7671 requires that the point of connection of every bonding conductor to an extraneous conductive part has a permanent and durable label fixed in a visible position stating ‘safety electrical connection – do not remove’ (Figure 4.246).</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="installation-of-bonding-clamps">Installation of bonding clamps<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#installation-of-bonding-clamps" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The photograph in Figure 4.247 shows a bonding clamp as it appears when it first arrives. Note that the label is fitted this way for packaging; the slots in the label are only there for this purpose.</p>
<p>The six parts of the bonding clamp are:</p>
<ol>
<li>strap</li>
<li>label</li>
<li>bonding clamp body</li>
<li>cable termination point and screw</li>
<li>locking nut</li>
<li>tightening screw.</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="step-by-step-instructions-for-fitting-a-bs-951-clamp">Step-by-step instructions for fitting a BS 951 clamp<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#step-by-step-instructions-for-fitting-a-bs-951-clamp" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="6a1b1131">Step 1 – Preparing the bonding clamp for installation<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#6a1b1131" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<ul>
<li>Remove the label from the strap.</li>
<li>Remove the tightening screw and locking nut from the body of the clamp.</li>
<li>Pass the tightening screw through the hole in the label and fit the locking nut.</li>
<li>Refit the assembly to the clamp body, but leave the screw so that it is not protruding into the slot of the body.</li>
<li>The clamp is now ready for installation.</li>
</ul>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251222-fef4937f.jpeg" alt="img-555.jpeg">
<img src="assets/images/image-20251222-5d9bc1de.jpeg" alt="img-556.jpeg">
Figure 4.246 BS 7671 permanent label</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251222-92200297.jpeg" alt="img-557.jpeg">
Figure 4.247 A bonding clamp as supplied</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251222-83e28be4.jpeg" alt="img-558.jpeg">
Figure 4.248 Preparing the bonding clamp for installation</p>
<p>The City &amp; Guilds Textbook: Electrical Installations Book 1</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="industry-tip">INDUSTRY TIP<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#industry-tip" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Even if the pipe looks clean there may be an oxide on the surface. Make sure you clean the pipe before fixing the clamp to it.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="521f1a51">Step 2 – Preparing the pipe for installation of the bonding clamp<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#521f1a51" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>It is vitally important that the connection between the bonding clamp and the pipework is electrically sound. Tarnished pipework can be cleaned using wire wool; paint must be removed from painted pipework and the metal should be cleaned with wire wool.</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251222-1f31d1f3.jpeg" alt="img-559.jpeg">
▲ Figure 4.249</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="be340dc8">Step 3 – Installation of bonding clamp to pipe<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#be340dc8" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Place the body of the clamp against the cleaned section of pipework.</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251222-74696be7.jpeg" alt="img-560.jpeg">
▲ Figure 4.250</p>
<p>Pass the strap around the pipe and through the slot in the body of the bonding clamp.</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251222-3f486a46.jpeg" alt="img-561.jpeg">
▲ Figure 4.251</p>
<p>Pull the strap tight with one hand and, with the other hand, tighten the screw with a screwdriver.</p>
<p>Make sure that the locking nut is far enough up the tightening screw to prevent it locking against the body of the clamp.</p>
<p>The bonding clamp should now be tight against the pipe.</p>
<p>Chapter 4 Electrical installation</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251222-b1101d2e.jpeg" alt="img-562.jpeg">
Figure 4.252</p>
<p>The locking nut is now tightened against the body of the clamp.</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251222-c512bb46.jpeg" alt="img-563.jpeg">
Figure 4.253</p>
<p>The bonding clamp is now installed ready for connection of the protective bonding.</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251222-9e153216.jpeg" alt="img-564.jpeg">
Figure 4.254</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="termination-of-bonding-conductors">Termination of bonding conductors<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#termination-of-bonding-conductors" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Regulation 526.1 of BS 7671 requires that all electrical connections are:</p>
<ul>
<li>electrically durable</li>
<li>of adequate mechanical strength.</li>
</ul>
<p>The City &amp; Guilds Textbook: Electrical Installations Book 1</p>
<p>The ideal method of terminating the bonding conductor is by means of a cable lug of the correct size for the cable.</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251222-3ea5e90e.jpeg" alt="img-565.jpeg"></p>
<p>▲ Figure 4.255 Cable to be terminated and correct size lug</p>
<p>Strip enough insulation from the cable so that the copper conductor meets the end of the cable lug, while the sheath of the cable fits tight to the base of the lug.</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251222-bf5015d2.jpeg" alt="img-566.jpeg"></p>
<p>▲ Figure 4.256 Fitting the lug to the cable</p>
<p>The cable lug is then crimped to the cable using a proprietary cable crimper that suits the size of the lug.</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251222-6c548330.jpeg" alt="img-567.jpeg"></p>
<p>▲ Figure 4.257 Crimped lug</p>
<p>372</p>
<p>Chapter 4 Electrical installation</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="connection-of-bonding-conductor-to-bonding-clamp">Connection of bonding conductor to bonding clamp<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#connection-of-bonding-conductor-to-bonding-clamp" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Remove the cable termination screw.</p>
<p>Align the cable lug hole and reinsert the cable termination screw. Tighten with a screwdriver.</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251222-deffbc94.jpeg" alt="img-568.jpeg">
Figure 4.258 Connecting the bonding conductor to the bonding clamp</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251222-dcb01994.jpeg" alt="img-569.jpeg">
Figure 4.259 The finished connection</p>
<p>Some of the larger bonding clamps are designed so that the cable can be terminated without the use of a cable lug. In this case, the cable is stripped back far enough to allow good metal-to-metal contact; the stripped end is inserted between the two connection screws and the screws are tightened equally to give a sound electrical connection.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="industry-tip">INDUSTRY TIP<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#industry-tip" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Be careful not to over-tighten the screws and strip the thread. This can be very time wasting as you remove the damaged clamp and search for a new one.</p>
<p>The City &amp; Guilds Textbook: Electrical Installations Book 1</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251222-ab8e863a.jpeg" alt="img-570.jpeg">
▲ Figure 4.260 Bonding clamp for use without cable lug</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="industry-tip">INDUSTRY TIP<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#industry-tip" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>There is a risk that if another trade removes a bonding conductor they may not bother to replace it. By using an unjointed bonding conductor for two services at least the end service is still bonded.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="termination-of-more-than-one-cable-to-a-bonding-clamp">Termination of more than one cable to a bonding clamp<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#termination-of-more-than-one-cable-to-a-bonding-clamp" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Where two services are in close proximity to one another, it is acceptable to run one bonding cable to serve both services. If the bonding cable loops from one bonding clamp to another, the bonding conductor should be unbroken.</p>
<p>As shown in the photograph below, strip off enough insulation from the bonding cable to enable the cable to make metal-to-metal contact with the bonding clamp. A stripping knife would be the ideal tool to accomplish this task.</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251222-7f398ecd.jpeg" alt="img-571.jpeg">
▲ Figure 4.261 Preparing cable to loop from one bonding clamp to another</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251222-b933fbcf.jpeg" alt="img-572.jpeg">
▲ Figure 4.262 Parting the strands of the cable so that the connection screw of the bonding clamp can be fitted</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251222-303a3c06.jpeg" alt="img-573.jpeg">
▲ Figure 4.263 Passing the screw through the hole created</p>
<p>Chapter 4 Electrical installation</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251222-0574ae2e.jpeg" alt="img-574.jpeg">
Figure 4.264 Use a suitably sized screwdriver for tightening the connection screw for the finished connection</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="testing-of-bonding-conductors">Testing of bonding conductors<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#testing-of-bonding-conductors" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Later in this chapter we look at how to carry out several tests that have to be performed on electrical installation work (starting on page 388). One of the tests is called 'Continuity of protective conductors'. BS 7671 identifies that both main and supplementary bonding conductors are included in this test.</p>
<p>There are two methods of continuity testing; for protective conductors such as bonding conductors, method 2 is preferred. The test method is covered on page 392. Here we will consider how to prepare the bonding prior to testing.</p>
<p>The purpose of the test is to ensure that the clamp and cable are securely and effectively connected to the extraneous conductive part.</p>
<p>Before the continuity test can be performed, the bonding conductor must be disconnected from the MET or, in the case of supplementary bonding, disconnected from the relevant circuit protective conductor (cpc). With one end of the bonding disconnected, clean a part of the extraneous conductive part close to the clamp. (If the extraneous conductive part has been painted then the paint must be removed from a small part to expose the metal.) Place a test probe in direct contact with the clean metal.</p>
<p>Now continue with the test method 2, using the long 'wander lead' (see page 392).</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="4-inspection-and-testing">4 INSPECTION AND TESTING<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#4-inspection-and-testing" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>It is a fundamental requirement of BS 7671 The IET Wiring Regulations that 'during erection and on completion of an installation or an addition or alteration to an installation and before it is put into service, appropriate inspection and testing shall be carried out...'</p>
<p>Regulation 134.2.1 and Part 6 of BS 7671 gives the requirements for inspection and testing.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="industry-tip">INDUSTRY TIP<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#industry-tip" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Remember an extraneous conductive part is defined in BS 7671 as a conductive part liable to introduce a potential, generally Earth potential, and not forming part of the electrical installation.</p>
<p>The City &amp; Guilds Textbook: Electrical Installations Book 1</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="why-carry-out-inspection-and-testing">Why carry out inspection and testing?<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#why-carry-out-inspection-and-testing" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>The reason for carrying out initial verification is to ensure that the installation is safe to be put into service and that it meets the requirements of BS 7671.</p>
<p>The fundamental principles that must be followed when completing an electrical installation are that:</p>
<ul>
<li>good workmanship is employed</li>
<li>proper materials are used</li>
<li>equipment is installed in accordance with manufacturer's instructions.</li>
</ul>
<p>It is these principles that are being checked when carrying out an initial verification.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="installation-of-electrical-equipment">Installation of electrical equipment<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#installation-of-electrical-equipment" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="compliance-with-standards">Compliance with standards<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#compliance-with-standards" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>BS 7671 requires that any installed equipment complies with relevant British or equivalent standards. Other standard numbers that you may see on equipment are those relating to European Norms (EN) or to the standards of the International Electrotechnical Commission (IEC). The same numbers are often used for equivalent standards, in combination with different prefixes. For example, the switch disconnector in a consumer unit may be marked as:</p>
<ul>
<li>IEC 947-3</li>
<li>EN 60947-3</li>
<li>BS EN 60947-3.</li>
</ul>
<p>All three of these standards meet the requirements; in fact they are the same standard adopted in different parts of the world.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="damage-to-equipment">Damage to equipment<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#damage-to-equipment" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>There should no damage to installed electrical equipment. Damage could result in the exposure of live parts and a consequent risk of shock.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="equipment-suitable-for-its-environment">Equipment suitable for its environment<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#equipment-suitable-for-its-environment" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Wherever a piece of electrical equipment is installed, it must be suitable for that environment. The specification for installed equipment is drawn up by the designer. When inspecting equipment for an initial verification, you are checking that the installed equipment conforms to the designer's instructions.</p>
<p>The designer will have taken into account:</p>
<ul>
<li>the environment where the equipment is to be installed</li>
<li>the construction and materials of the building</li>
<li>the intended use of the building</li>
<li>who will use the building.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="equipment-correctly-installed">Equipment correctly installed<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#equipment-correctly-installed" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>There are two aspects to consider when installing electrical equipment. Equipment should be installed:</p>
<ul>
<li>in accordance with the manufacturer's instructions</li>
<li>in compliance with BS 7671.</li>
</ul>
<p>Chapter 4 Electrical installation</p>
<p>Where there is a conflict between the manufacturer's instructions and BS 7671, the manufacturer should be consulted and will have final say. The reason for this is that the manufacturer will have designed their equipment to meet the requirements of all the applicable standards.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="remember-the-safe-isolation-procedure">Remember the safe isolation procedure<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#remember-the-safe-isolation-procedure" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Before any inspection and testing is carried out, the full isolation procedure should be carried out to ensure the installation is safe to be worked on, including inspection.</p>
<p>Figure 4.265 provides a reminder of the procedure.
<img src="assets/images/image-20251222-7fb3fa8f.jpeg" alt="img-575.jpeg">
Figure 4.265 Isolation procedure</p>
<p>The City &amp; Guilds Textbook: Electrical Installations Book 1</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="the-schedule-of-inspections-on-an-electrical-installation-certificate">The Schedule of Inspections on an Electrical Installation certificate<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#the-schedule-of-inspections-on-an-electrical-installation-certificate" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>When completing a schedule of inspection printed on an Electrical Installation Certificate, boxes must be marked with either a tick for compliance, or as not applicable (n/a). No box should be marked as unsatisfactory and anything found as unsatisfactory should be corrected before any certification is issued.</p>
<p>The table below gives examples of what should be inspected within each of the 14 groups indicated on the schedule on the Electrical Installation Certificate.</p>
<table><thead><tr><th>Item No</th><th>Description</th><th>Guidance (any numbers shown indicate regulation numbers or sections from BS 7671)</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>1.0</td><td>Condition of intake equipment</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>1.1</td><td>Consumer's isolator (where present)</td><td>These items should be checked for their levels of basic protection against electric shock and how well they are fixed securely. That they are located for easy access for maintenance or proximity to other services such as gas. Inspectors should also look for signs of damage, tampering and that all tails remain insulated to all terminations.</td></tr><tr><td>1.2</td><td>Consumer's meter tails</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>2.0</td><td>Parallel or switched alternative sources of supply</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>2.1</td><td>Adequate arrangements where a generating set operates as a switched alternative to the public supply</td><td>If the installation has a backup (standby) generator, is there a correctly fitted changeover switch in place which ensures that the generator, when on, doesn't power up the supply system? In addition, does the generator system have its own independent earthing system (551.6)?</td></tr><tr><td>2.2</td><td>Dedicated earthing arrangement independent of the public supply</td><td>If the installation is supplied with a form of generator which works with the supply, is there adequate means of ensuring the supply system is not energised if the supply system fails? A common example is where an installation has a photovoltaic (PV) system feeding the installation as well as the supply. In this case, the inverter for the PV will shut down if it detects a supply failure (551.7).</td></tr><tr><td>2.3</td><td>Presence of adequate arrangements where generator is to operate in parallel with the public supply system</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>2.4</td><td>Correct connection of generator in parallel</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>2.5</td><td>Compatibility of characteristics of means of generation</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>2.6</td><td>Means to provide automatic disconnection of generator in the event of loss of public supply system or voltage or frequency deviation beyond declared values</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>2.7</td><td>Means to prevent connection of generator in the event of loss of public supply system or voltage or frequency deviation beyond declared values</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>3.0</td><td>Protective measure: automatic disconnection of supply</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>3.1</td><td>Distributor's earthing arrangement</td><td>The main earthing terminal (MET) is correctly connected to the means of earthing depending on the supply earthing arrangement. For example, for a TN-C-S, the earthing conductor is suitably connected to the supply PEN conductor.</td></tr><tr><td>3.2</td><td>Installation of earth electrode (where applicable)</td><td>The MET is suitably connected to a correctly selected and erected earth electrode in the case of a TT earthing arrangement.</td></tr><tr><td>3.3</td><td>Earthing conductor and connections including accessibility</td><td>Suitably sized to be buried (TT as Table 54.1) or sized for current capacity (TN Table 54.7). Continuous (if not visible throughout its length it may require testing to confirm this). Connections tight, suitably supported.</td></tr></tbody></table>

<table><thead><tr><th>3.4</th><th>Main protective bonding conductors and connections including accessibility</th><th>All extraneous parts connected by main protective bonding (MPB) to the main earthing terminal (MET) as (411.3.1.2). Sized correctly (544.1 or Table 54.8), continuous (if not visible throughout its length it may require testing to confirm this). Connected at a suitable point at extraneous parts (within 600mm of entry or on consumers' side of any valve, stop or meter and before any tee joints). Connections secure and the correct type of clamp used for the external influences (this may be identified by clamp colour coding).</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>3.5</td><td>Provision of safety electrical earthing/bonding labels at all appropriate locations</td><td>Suitable labelling ‘safety electrical connection; do not remove’ at any earth/bonding connection separate from any switchgear (514.13).</td></tr><tr><td>3.6</td><td>RCDs provided for fault protection</td><td>Where an RCD is relied upon as fault protection (disconnection times are not met by a protective device as Z_{s} values are too high) the RCD is selected in accordance with Table 514.4.9 and 41.5. If RCDs are not relied on for fault protection and are provided for additional protection only, this would be marked as n/a.</td></tr><tr><td>3.7</td><td>Provisions where automatic disconnection is not feasible</td><td>In situations where disconnection times cannot be met – perhaps due to high earth fault loop impedance – and the use of an RCD is not feasible as the continuity of service is important, local supplementary equipotential bonding may be provided in the location where a risk of touch voltages may exist. So, in the event of a fault of longer duration, the risk of shock is reduced by maintaining equal potential between extraneous parts local to the circuit equipment having higher disconnection times.</td></tr><tr><td>3.8</td><td>FELV – requirements satisfied</td><td>Any circuit where the voltage has been reduced to values &lt;50V AC for functional reasons, and the requirements of SELV and PELV have not been met, the general requirements for ADS must apply.</td></tr><tr><td>3.9</td><td>RLV – requirements satisfied</td><td>Any circuit supplying equipment at 110V AC must meet the requirements of Section 418 of BS 7671, including the values of earth fault loop impedance as Table 41.8.</td></tr><tr><td>4.0</td><td>Basic protection</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>4.1</td><td>Presence and adequacy of measures to provide basic protection within the installation</td><td></td></tr><tr><td></td><td>Insulation of live parts</td><td>All conductors should be insulated with material suitable for the intended voltage. The insulation must cover conductors right up to the terminal or connection, with no bare conductor showing (416.1).</td></tr><tr><td>4.2</td><td>Barriers and enclosures</td><td>All barriers and enclosures provide adequate protection stopping contact with live parts. This would include checking the correct level of IP protection, such as IP2X or IPXXB applied to all surfaces with exception of any accessible top surface, which must be IP4X or IPXXD. Live parts must only be accessible by the use of a tool or key. There are some exceptions, such as a ceiling rose, but these items must be located in a generally inaccessible location, such as a ceiling where a person requires steps to gain access (416.2).</td></tr><tr><td>4.3</td><td>Obstacles</td><td>These two methods of protecting persons from contact with parts intended to be live are only permitted where they are under effective supervision by skilled persons. Examples of an obstacle include safety railings, or fencing which can be removed without the use of a tool or key stopping accidental contact with live parts (417).</td></tr><tr><td>4.4</td><td>Placing out of reach</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>5.0</td><td>Protective measures other than ADS</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>5.1</td><td>SELV</td><td>Separated extra-low voltage circuits must be supplied by a suitable device, typically a transformer, which provides suitable separation. In addition, any metallic parts of a SELV system must be separated from earth. An inspection of the transformer type, and that cables are segregated from each other would be required (414).</td></tr></tbody></table>

<table><thead><tr><th>5.2</th><th>PELV</th><th>Protective extra-low voltage circuits are similar to SELV, but in PELV systems, there may not be the separation from earth (414).</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>5.3</td><td>Double insulation, i.e. Class II or equivalent equipment and associated circuits</td><td>Rarely used in most installation, Class II protection ensures the risk of parts becoming live is minimised by having basic insulation and further levels of insulation or reinforced insulation. This box is ticked to confirm the rating is correct.</td></tr><tr><td>6.2</td><td>Supplementary bonding</td><td>To confirm, where required, that supplementary bonding has been provided. The particular requirements of Section 729 may also need to be met. In dwellings, particular sections of the Building Regulations may also apply.</td></tr><tr><td>7.2</td><td>Security of fixing</td><td>These are all checks to ensure the distribution equipment has not been damaged during erection and that all suitable fire seals (where needed) have been applied.</td></tr><tr><td>7.3</td><td>Insulation of live parts not damaged during erection</td><td>The housing must provide basic protection (see Box 4.2) and must provide suitable fire ratings for the intended location (421.1). <table><thead><tr><th>8.14</th><th>Presence, adequacy and correct termination of protective conductors</th><th>This is to verify that all protective conductors, other than those verified in 3.1, are selected (Chapter 54) and correctly terminated to all equipment as required by 411.3.1.1.</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>8.15</td><td>Coordination between conductors and overload protective devices</td><td>The inspector must be satisfied that all conductors are suitably sized for the intended load and voltage drop constraints. This item links to item 8.10 of this document.</td></tr><tr><td>8.16</td><td>Wiring systems and cable installation methods/practices with regard to the type and nature of installation and external influences</td><td>Are cables installed using suitable containment or management systems or, where applicable, clipped direct? The method used must be compatible for the external influences present and the type of cable used (Chapter 52).</td></tr><tr><td>8.17</td><td>Cables concealed under floors, above ceilings, in walls/partitions, adequately protected against damage</td><td>If cables are not in the zones of protection as detailed in 522.6.202, they must be protected by an earthed metallic covering. Also, where cables are concealed in a wall and are not provided with additional protection by an RCD as below (8.18 items iii and iv), they must comply with this section. Cables in floors or above ceilings must comply with 522.6.201.</td></tr><tr><td>8.18</td><td>Provision of additional protection by RCDs having a residual operating current not exceeding 30 mA for:</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>8.19</td><td>i All socket outlets of rating 32 A or less, unless an exception is permitted</td><td>All socket outlets rated up to 32 A must have additional protection by RCDs or the designer has carried out a suitable risk assessment. The risk assessment should verify that the organisation using the socket outlets has adequately trained staff, equipment registers and carries out regular checks and tests on equipment used on the socket outlets and that the equipment is suitable for its environment and use (411.3.3 and Appendix 2).</td></tr><tr><td></td><td>ii Supplies for mobile equipment not exceeding 32 A rating for use outdoors</td><td>RCDs in accordance with 415.1 must be provided for all mobile equipment used outdoors not exceeding 32 A (411.3.3).</td></tr><tr><td></td><td>iii Cables concealed in walls at a depth of less than 50 mm</td><td>Cables concealed in a wall and within the zones of protection given in 522.6.202 must have RCD protection in accordance with 415.1 or have further impact protection as 522.6.204.</td></tr><tr><td></td><td>iv Cables concealed in walls/partitions having metal parts regardless of depth</td><td>Cables in partitions having metal parts other than screws, nails or similar, must have RCD protection in accordance with 415.1 or comply with 522.6.204 as stated in 522.6.203.</td></tr><tr><td></td><td>v Final circuits supplying luminaires within domestic premises</td><td>In dwellings, all circuits that supply a luminaire of any type must have additional protection by a 30 mA RCD.</td></tr><tr><td>8.20</td><td>Segregation/separation of Band I and Band II circuits</td><td>The inspector must be satisfied that any electrical circuits operating at ELV are adequately segregated from low voltage circuits unless the ELV circuits are insulated to the low voltage standards. For example, a door bell circuit using bell wire must be segregated from lighting circuits. In addition, all electrical equipment, cables, etc., must be suitably distanced from any services that may affect the installation. For example, hot water pipes near cables. If spacing is unavoidable, the electrical parts must be suited for the effect of the services. See section 528.</td></tr><tr><td>8.21</td><td>Cables segregated/separated from non-electrical services</td><td>Cables are adequately spaced or protected from the effects of other services, such as damage that could occur from heating pipes (Section 528).</td></tr></tbody></table>

<table><thead><tr><th>8.22</th><th>Termination of cables at enclosures</th><th></th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>8.22</td><td>i Connection under no undue strain</td><td>The correct type of connection has been used and the connection is not under strain due to the conductor not being properly supported (522.8.5).</td></tr><tr><td></td><td>ii No basic insulation visible outside enclosure</td><td>Sheathed cables must have the sheathing present up to the enclosure with no core insulation showing outside of that enclosure (526.8).</td></tr><tr><td></td><td>iii Connection of live conductors adequately enclosed</td><td>That the enclosure used to house the connection is of the correct type and provides sufficient protection (526.5).</td></tr><tr><td></td><td>iv Adequately connected at point of entry to enclosure by glands, bushes, etc.</td><td>Ensuring the cable is securely held as it enters the enclosure (where needed) and that the cable is not placed under any strain as a result of the cable being secure (or not) (522.8.5).</td></tr><tr><td>8.23</td><td>Suitability of circuit accessories for external influences</td><td>The inspector must be satisfied that all electrical equipment is suitably selected and erected for all external influences it may be subjected to. If it cannot be supervised, then the switch must be capable of being secured in the off position (464, 537.3).</td><td></td></tr></tbody></table>

This stops the equipment from suddenly re-starting should a power loss occur, followed by sudden restoration of the power (445).</td></tr><tr><td>10.7</td><td>Provision of overload protection, where specified</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>10.8</td><td>Provision of overload and/or undervoltage protection e.g., for rotating machines, if required</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>10.9</td><td>Correct selection and installation of luminaires fitted</td><td>All luminaires within the installation have been correctly selected and erected to be suitable for their location, use and connection method to the final circuit (559.3).</td></tr><tr><td>10.10</td><td>Installed to minimise the build-up of heat and restrict the spread of fire</td><td>Equipment must be suitable for the material it is mounted on and suitable when a risk of fire exists due to the stored or processed material as Chapter 42. <div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="example-check-lists">Example check lists<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#example-check-lists" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Here are some practical examples of the type of checks that would be carried out for different scenarios.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="checks-to-make-at-a-distribution-board">Checks to make at a distribution board<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#checks-to-make-at-a-distribution-board" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Check that:</p>
<ul>
<li>the distribution board is correctly mounted – fitted in accordance with manufacturer’s instructions, is firmly fixed to the wall and with the correct fixings</li>
<li>all terminations are tight. Manufacturer’s information will specify the correct tightness of connections at all terminals within the distribution board. Torque screwdrivers are available for just this task. The correct settings are available from the manufacturer’s literature. Using a torque screwdriver ensures that connections are not over-tightened or too loose. Either situation could lead to problems</li>
<li>all circuit breakers and switches are correctly installed</li>
<li>cable sizes are as intended in the designer’s specification</li>
<li>the neutral and cpc conductors are connected in the same order as the line conductors or where this is not possible the conductors are labelled</li>
<li>conductors are correctly identified: cpc are green/yellow, neutrals are blue, and so on</li>
<li>conductors are correctly terminated so that the terminal screws make correct contact with the conductor cores, but not too much insulation is stripped off, exposing live conductors</li>
<li>the protective device provides overload protection to the circuit conductors – for a cable rated at 17 A the appropriate circuit breaker would be 16 A</li>
<li>the correct type of protective device, B,C or D, is fitted</li>
<li>where RCDs are installed for additional protection, these do not have an <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msub><mi>I</mi><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">Δ</mi><mi>n</mi></mrow></msub></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">I_{\Delta n}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8333em; vertical-align: -0.15em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.07847em;">I</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.3283em;"><span style="top: -2.55em; margin-left: -0.0785em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">Δ</span><span class="mord mathnormal mtight">n</span></span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.15em;"><span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span> rating of more than 30 mA</li>
<li>the incoming supply conductors are connected to the correct terminals of the main switch</li>
<li>internal barriers are in place</li>
<li>the top surface of the distribution board meets the requirements of IP4X or IPXXD (the requirement of IP4X is that a 1 mm diameter wire shall not enter)</li>
<li>the front, bottom and sides of the distribution board meet the requirements of IP2X or IPXXB (the requirement of IP2X is that a 12.5 mm diameter object shall not enter, or that a finger shall not be able to enter and touch live parts, so this requirement would extend to the correct fitting of blanks where circuit breaker ways are not used)</li>
<li>the circuit charts, where installed, are installed according to, and containing, all of the information required by Regulation 514.9.1 of BS 7671</li>
<li>these circuit charts are correct</li>
</ul>
<p>Chapter 4 Electrical installation</p>
<ul>
<li>all necessary labels are installed, including:</li>
<li>periodic inspection and testing notice</li>
<li>RCD test notice</li>
<li>non-standard colours notice, in the case of an addition to an installation.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="checks-to-make-on-containment-systems">Checks to make on containment systems<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#checks-to-make-on-containment-systems" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Before cables are installed, check that:</p>
<ul>
<li>the containment system is suitable for the environment</li>
<li>the containment system is complete</li>
<li>the containment system is installed with enough saddles or fixings to support it</li>
<li>all joints and accessories are tight</li>
<li>there are sufficient draw-in or access points if required</li>
<li>there are no rough edges that may damage the sheathing or insulation of cables</li>
<li>in the case of metallic containment, it is correctly earthed, that the earthing is continuous and that any continuity links required are fitted</li>
<li>that bends in containment are not so tight as to affect the minimum bending radius of cables.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="checks-to-make-on-circuit-conductors">Checks to make on circuit conductors<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#checks-to-make-on-circuit-conductors" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Check that circuit conductors:</p>
<ul>
<li>are correctly sized for current capacity and voltage drop</li>
<li>are supported throughout their length to avoid strain on cables and terminations</li>
<li>are suitable for the environment</li>
<li>are not damaged</li>
<li>are correctly identified (brown for line, etc.)</li>
<li>are correctly terminated</li>
<li>without an outer sheath (apart from bonding conductors) are enclosed within a containment system.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="checks-to-make-on-a-protective-bonding-conductor-connected-to-a-service-pipe">Checks to make on a protective bonding conductor connected to a service pipe<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#checks-to-make-on-a-protective-bonding-conductor-connected-to-a-service-pipe" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Check that the conductor is:</p>
<ul>
<li>the correct size</li>
<li>coloured yellow and green</li>
<li>correctly supported</li>
<li>connected to the MET</li>
<li>connected to a correctly installed BS 951 bonding clamp</li>
<li>correctly terminated and that connections are tight.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="testing">Testing<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#testing" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Testing follows inspection and involves documenting test values for each circuit, which are recorded on a Schedule of Test Results. Many abbreviations are used on test record sheets and below is a guide to some of those abbreviations.</p>
<ul>
<li>cpc circuit protective conductor</li>
<li>csa cross-sectional area</li>
</ul>
<p>387</p>
<p>The City &amp; Guilds Textbook: Electrical Installations Book 1</p>
<p>DNO distribution network operator
MET main earthing terminal
<span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msub><mi>R</mi><mn>1</mn></msub></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">R_{1}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8333em; vertical-align: -0.15em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.00773em;">R</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.3011em;"><span style="top: -2.55em; margin-left: -0.0077em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">1</span></span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.15em;"><span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span> resistance of the line conductor in a final circuit
