<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="policy-documents">Policy documents<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#policy-documents" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Organisations, such as electrical contracting companies, will hold a range of policy documents setting out procedures that they and employees must follow. These could range from health and safety policies to quality control or employees' rights and disciplinary procedures.</p>
<p>The purpose of a policy is to provide a framework that can be followed so people working for the organisation can get on with the work they need to without having to constantly check or discuss the best way forward. Policies are written to ensure the organisation:</p>
<ul>
<li>meets legal requirements</li>
<li>meets regulatory requirements</li>
<li>improves quality</li>
<li>promotes best practice.</li>
</ul>
<p>In some situations, new employees are issued with company policies and have to sign them as a way of agreeing to work to those policies. If an organisation changes their policy, the employee is trained on those new policies and once again, signs them to agree to follow them.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="information-given-to-customers">Information given to customers<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#information-given-to-customers" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>There is a range of information the client receives before, during and at the handover stage of a contract. Knowing the difference is essential in order to meet legal requirements as well as maintaining good relationships.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="quotations">Quotations<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#quotations" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Quotations are generally offers to provide goods and/or services for specific amounts of money. They may have general terms and conditions attached, which are normally printed on the reverse of a quotation. Typical terms and conditions are that the quotation is only valid for 30 days and that the title (ownership) of any fitted goods does not pass to the recipient until full payment has been made.</p>
<p>A quotation may also include specific terms, which define the detail of what has been quoted for and on what basis. An example would be to rewire a specific property as indicated on a specific drawing for a specific sum of money excluding VAT and that the property will be vacant with all fixings and furniture removed by the owner prior to work commencing.</p>
<p>If all the terms and conditions are met and the requirements do not change from those specified in the drawing, the quoted price will stand regardless of how long the contractor takes to carry out the work or how profitable the work is. If there is a change in the terms and conditions, the price should be adjusted and agreed accordingly.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="estimates">Estimates<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#estimates" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Estimates are generally provided when the job is not properly measurable due to time or physical restrictions and therefore a quotation cannot be given. The</p>
<p>Chapter 5 Communicating with others</p>
<p>work is undertaken but may involve unforeseen difficulties that impact on the materials needed, time taken and costs incurred. The final invoice may therefore be different from the initial estimate. However, it is usual to give an explanation for why the price has changed.</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251222-1d4bdc07.jpeg" alt="img-611.jpeg">
Figure 5.13 Invoices</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="budget-estimates">Budget estimates<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#budget-estimates" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>These are estimates that a client may request in order to plan a project or the viability of a project before any formal requests for quotations are made. It enables a client to either set aside a budget for work or decide if the work is necessary based on an estimated cost.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="invoices-applications-for-payment-and-statements">Invoices, applications for payment and statements<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#invoices-applications-for-payment-and-statements" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Invoices are formal requests for payment from one party to another. An invoice will normally contain the name and address of the customer, the trading name and office address of the contractor and any customer order or reference numbers. The registered office address and VAT registration number are given for limited companies. The invoice will also describe the works and give a breakdown of any non-fixed fee items.</p>
<p>Business invoices usually request payment within 30 days. In order to avoid delays in payment, it is important to ensure that the invoice is correctly detailed. Any areas of additional works should already have been agreed and be clearly identified on the invoice.</p>
<p>The contractor raising an invoice owes any tax or VAT to the Government from the date of the invoice regardless of the date of payment. In order to avoid paying out tax and VAT long before payment, especially where payment terms are 60 or 90 days, the contractor can make an application for payment. This is identical to an invoice, giving the expected tax and VAT payment date but not the VAT number. The client sends the application for payment through the payment</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="activity">ACTIVITY<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#activity" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>What is the key difference between an estimate and a quotation?</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="activity">ACTIVITY<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#activity" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Research the internet to see a range of quotations, estimates and invoices. Using the selection, design your own.</p>
<p>The City &amp; Guilds Textbook: Electrical Installations Book 1</p>
<p>processing system and then requires a tax invoice to be provided before or on the date of payment.</p>
<p>A <em>statement</em> is a notification of outstanding invoices or transactions. Where a contractor and client have a long-standing relationship, it is possible for several invoices to be outstanding over a payment period. A statement is therefore issued to act as a reminder and reduce the possibility of confusion about what has and has not been paid. Alternatively, where there is a credit account arrangement, the contractor will build up a number of transactions before issuing an invoice for payment. During the billing period, the unpaid transactions can be itemised on a statement.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="statutory-cancellation-rights">Statutory cancellation rights<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#statutory-cancellation-rights" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Cancellation rights give the consumer the rights, within a specified period of time, to cancel a contract without liability or having to take legal action and to get back any money paid. In the UK, the Cancellation of Contracts made in a Consumer’s Home or Place of Work etc. Regulations 2008 detail what is and is not excepted. As a general guide, the following are typical areas where statutory cancellation rights exist:</p>
<ul>
<li>where the consumer cannot examine the purchase before they buy (i.e. distance selling by mail order, phone or internet)</li>
<li>where the trader can unduly pressurise customers to buy</li>
<li>where the consumer has little opportunity to compare different traders or read the ‘small print’.</li>
</ul>
<p>The Citizens Advice Bureau provides advice and up-to-date publications on consumers’ cancellation rights, the different cancellation periods for different sectors and how cancellation must be communicated.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="handover-information">Handover information<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#handover-information" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Handover information needs to be delivered in order to achieve <em>practical completion</em>. As buildings have become more sophisticated, operation and maintenance documentation, for example, has become even more important. Handover information should include:</p>
<ul>
<li>a design philosophy and statement to say how the building has been designed and how it is to be operated, often now part of the building logbook</li>
<li>Building Regulations tests and approvals, including the sign-off documents from the Building Control officer or approved inspector</li>
<li>building leakage test certificates from construction</li>
<li>the energy performance certification and registration information</li>
<li>electrical test information</li>
<li>lighting compliance certification (e.g. compliance with CIBSE Lighting Guide LG7)</li>
<li>emergency lighting test certification</li>
<li>fire alarm certification</li>
<li>emergency voice communication (EVC) or disabled refuge system certificate</li>
<li>construction plans at a scale of 1:50 or 1:100 as appropriate</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="key-terms">KEY TERMS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#key-terms" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p><em>Practical completion</em>: the point at which a construction project is virtually finished, when the last percentage of monies are paid by the client, the responsibility for insuring the construction transfers to the client and the architect or contract administrator signs the certificate of practical completion. At this point there will still be a few minor snags to sort out (e.g. scratches in paintwork) or insignificant items to be completed.</p>
<p><em>CIBSE</em>: the Chartered Institute of Building Services Engineers.</p>
<p>Chapter 5 Communicating with others</p>
<ul>
<li>building envelope (fabric of the building) details</li>
<li>structural plans with floor loadings, any specialist support information for plant, etc.</li>
<li>mechanical and electrical equipment layouts at a scale of 1:50 or 1:100 as appropriate</li>
<li>plant and specialist area layouts at a scale of 1:50, or even 1:20, depending on complexity of the systems</li>
<li>additional information relating to the cleaning, maintenance and deconstruction of any of the systems or components and any disposal requirements at the time of writing the handover information.</li>
</ul>
<p>It is most important that the documents are up to date and specific and relevant to the building or project being handed over.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="company-working-policies-and-procedures">Company working policies and procedures<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#company-working-policies-and-procedures" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Companies set out working policies and procedures so that all workers can expect to be treated fairly and with respect, know how they can put right a problem should one arise and understand what measures or sanctions will be imposed should a breach of policies and procedures occur.</p>
<p>Working policies and procedures set out a company's expectations on matters such as:</p>
<ul>
<li>behaviour – language and attitude should promote safety and client relationships, for example</li>
<li>timekeeping – poor timekeeping by one person can affect many members of staff and ultimately affect costs and completion targets</li>
<li>dress code – should promote a professional image.</li>
</ul>
<p>These working policies become part of the terms and conditions of employment. They are often provided in a staff handbook, although such a handbook is not required by law. An employee accepts the terms and conditions of employment when they sign a contract of employment or attend work without challenging any of the terms of the contract.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="contract-of-employment">Contract of employment<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#contract-of-employment" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>A contract of employment is a legally binding agreement between employer and employee. It can be a verbal or written contract, including various terms and conditions. Any changes to the terms of employment will probably not be notified in a new contract of employment, but in the staff handbook, in a letter or on the company notice board.</p>
<p>If the contract is verbal, the employer must give a statement of the main terms and conditions within two months of the start of employment, under the provisions of the Employment Rights Act 1996.</p>
<p>The statement would include:</p>
<ul>
<li>holidays entitlements</li>
<li>scale of pay</li>
</ul>
<p>429</p>
<p>The City &amp; Guilds Textbook: Electrical Installations Book 1</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251222-b7a9ae8d.jpeg" alt="img-612.jpeg">
Figure 5.14 Signing a contract</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="key-term">KEY TERM<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#key-term" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Limit of authority: many decisions and actions need to be made on a daily basis, but they must be made by the right person. Dangerous or costly situations could arise if somebody made a key decision without the right knowledge or experience to take that decision. If somebody does this, they are exceeding their limit of authority.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="industry-tip">INDUSTRY TIP<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#industry-tip" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>More information relating to young workers can be found on the HSE website.</p>
<ul>
<li>basic working hours</li>
<li>pensions and pension schemes</li>
<li>notice of rights.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="health-and-safety-policy">Health and safety policy<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#health-and-safety-policy" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>All companies with five or more employees are required by law to set out their health and safety policy in writing. Related issues detailed in this policy, or separately, include:</p>
<ul>
<li>bribery</li>
<li>bullying and harassment</li>
<li>disciplinary and grievance procedures</li>
<li>equality and diversity</li>
<li>maternity, paternity and adoption</li>
<li>pay</li>
<li>redundancy.</li>
</ul>
<p>It is a legal requirement for employers to set out disciplinary rules and grievance procedures in writing and make sure that every employee knows about them and the available courses of action if they are unhappy with a disciplinary decision. Although related, the bullying and harassment policy is often a separate document because of the many issues and sensitivities that have to be considered.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="limits-to-personnel-responsibility">Limits to personnel responsibility<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#limits-to-personnel-responsibility" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Within company policy there is likely to be a statement of the limit of authority for different individuals and groups within the organisation. Limits of authority will vary depending on the responsibility and experience of the employee and the duties expected of them by the company.</p>
<p>Ultimately the employer is responsible for the acts or omissions of their employees, including any financial or legal repercussions. On a project, the employer has a duty to ensure that all personnel are competent and capable of completing the tasks they are required to carry out in their role. As a result, it is in the employer's interests to set limits of authority appropriately.</p>
<p>Apprentices or those undertaking work experience, under the age of 18, are classed as 'young workers' who will not be permitted to make decisions that are beyond their capabilities. Their authority is limited to common sense, basic health and safety matters, and those areas where they have been adequately trained.</p>
<p>A supervisor, with Level 3 qualifications and more training and experience than trainee staff, would have considerably more authority. Supervisors are responsible for ensuring that projects run smoothly, for developing risk assessments and method statements, and for ensuring that agreed assessments and statements are in place and adhered to. Supervisors also have financial responsibilities in ordering materials and requesting labour to respond to work programmes.</p>
<p>Chapter 5 Communicating with others</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="3-communication-methods-in-work-situations">3 COMMUNICATION METHODS IN WORK SITUATIONS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#3-communication-methods-in-work-situations" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Communication in the workplace is essential for the safety and wellbeing of staff and the profitability of a job. Various methods of oral and written communication are used in different circumstances.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="oral-communication">Oral communication<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#oral-communication" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Oral communication (also known as verbal communication) is essentially speech. Oral communication can take many forms on a job or on site, such as a spoken instruction from a colleague, pointing out a potential improvement, or a verbal request on site to stop work on the grounds of health and safety. Oral communication with clients is also crucial make sure the job is carried out as expected. This will involve questions and descriptions. Oral communication may not always be face to face – it could be made via telephone, a site radio, or a public address system (e.g. the client asking for a particular piece of work to be started immediately).</p>
<p>Positive customer relationships must be maintained at all times as these are an essential part of business development and customer retention. Effective communication with customers is a key part of this – the customer should feel confident in your capabilities, that you understand their wishes, and are well-informed about plans and the progress with or any delays to the job.</p>
<p>Oral communication is less formal than written communication. Although oral communication can be legally binding, it is difficult to record and prove, and it can easily become confused and lead to mistakes. Therefore, most important oral communications are followed up in writing, usually referring to the date and time of the original communication.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="activity">ACTIVITY<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#activity" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>While you are at your training centre, imagine you are a client who wants some items of equipment installed at various heights within the building or room you are in. This could be things like socket outlets at 500 mm above the floor, a particular type of light located in a particular location, and so on. Make a list containing around ten items.</p>
<p>Now orally communicate these requirements to a friend or colleague at the centre – but they must not write them down. Several minutes later, ask the friend or colleague to repeat the requirements back to you. How much did they remember?</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="written-communication">Written communication<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#written-communication" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Written communication is any form of non-verbal communication in a written form. Written communication can come in many forms and using many different mediums (channels of communication), including letters, emails and SMS text messages.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="key-terms">KEY TERMS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#key-terms" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p><strong>Profitability</strong>: the degree to which a job produces profit or financial gain.</p>
<p><strong>Oral communication</strong>: expressing ideas through speech – for example, through face-to-face conversations, instructions, questions, and so on.</p>
<p><strong>Customer retention</strong>: methods of keeping customers returning for future business.</p>
<p><strong>Legally binding</strong>: an agreement made to carry out actions that is now required by law.</p>
<p><strong>Written communication</strong>: expressing ideas in written forms.</p>
<p>The City &amp; Guilds Textbook: Electrical Installations Book 1</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="key-terms">KEY TERMS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#key-terms" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>Formal: official, important.</li>
<li>Informal: unofficial, relaxed.</li>
<li>Recipient: a person who receives.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="industry-tip">INDUSTRY TIP<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#industry-tip" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Do be aware that email chains with multiple recipients can quickly become complex: with many replies, this can lead to information overload, crucial information being overlooked by key stakeholders, and can eventually have a detrimental effect on relationships.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="activity">ACTIVITY<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#activity" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Imagine you have been awarded a contract to rewire a house, which will take six days. For three of those days, there will be no power to any of the circuits. Write an email to your tutor or a friend, as if they were the client, detailing the implications of the loss of services and what they need to consider during this time.</p>
<p>Most companies now communicate by email, whether on a formal or informal basis. This is a highly effective method of communicating clear information, with the option of attaching pictures and drawings. Emails are useful to document agreements and plans between multiple recipients – this means lots of the key stakeholders, regardless of where they are in the world, can be simultaneously kept up-to-date with general progress reports or any problems and delays to work. Large attachments, such as plans or images can also be sent.</p>
<p>Letters are considered the most formal method of communication, due to the effort involved in typing, printing and posting them. They are used in the most formal situations, such as offering an appointment, terminating a contract or following up a less formal email.</p>
<p>Written communication is a reflection on your business and once sent, cannot be erased. Time and care should be taken to produce clear, quality and accurate written communication – a badly worded or misleading email or letter can damage years of business building.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="methods-of-communication-for-people-with-different-needs">Methods of communication for people with different needs<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#methods-of-communication-for-people-with-different-needs" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>When choosing the best methods of communication, people's specific needs should be considered carefully, to ensure the work is completed as agreed.</p>
<p>Some clients or businesses you communicate with may not have English as their first language. Friendliness, patience and being receptive to body language are excellent tools for breaking down language barriers. Be considerate and think about how you would feel trying to communicate in a non-English speaking country.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="industry-tip">INDUSTRY TIP<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#industry-tip" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Different dialects or accents can sometimes cause communication difficulties. You can politely request the speaker to repeat what has been said.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="key-fact">KEY FACT<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#key-fact" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>When dealing with a person using English as a second language, it is important to be polite and patient, and to check understanding where necessary. Use of dialect and colloquial terminology – like very informal, regional, or slang terms – should be avoided.</p>
<p>Communicating orally with most people with physical disabilities should be no different to communicating with non-disabled people. Special provision might need to be made for those with a visual impairment, such as communicating verbally, rather than via email. Written communication may be more appropriate for those with a hearing impairment, or using face-to-face communication methods to ensure the speaker's lips are clearly visible for lip readers to follow. The key is to be aware and make adjustments without fuss.</p>
<p>Chapter 5 Communicating with others</p>
<p>When communicating with those with learning difficulties, it is important to remember that everyone has different communication needs, and language must be kept at a level that will be understood by the individual. If there is any doubt, it might be useful to communicate in conjunction with or through a relative or advocate, who can give feedback on whether the communication was appropriate.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="actions-to-take-to-deal-with-conflicts">Actions to take to deal with conflicts<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#actions-to-take-to-deal-with-conflicts" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Conflicts between clients and site operatives should be rare if clear communication is maintained. However, if problems occur and communication breaks down, the company needs to ensure that the client is not offended and everything is done to resolve the situation.</p>
<p>It is important that the correct person, such as the site supervisor or manager, deals with a client who is angry with the organisation or company rather than the operative personally. In employment law, this could be deemed as harassment due to the client's unreasonable response to a breakdown in communication from the company.</p>
<p>Where a dispute is clearly between individuals, each party must be heard in order to find common ground or grounds for reparation (ways to repair the situation). The dispute could be something simple such as the result of poor communication or misunderstanding of something said.</p>
<p>Where the dispute cannot be resolved, it may be necessary to remove the operative from the project and away from any further conflict, without blame (assuming no blame exists). In these situations, it is important to confirm politely to the client that the operative has been moved with no blame attached, in order for both parties to move on.</p>
<p>Where conflict exists between co-workers, there is usually a defined route to follow within the company's disciplinary and grievance policy. This normally involves an opportunity to resolve matters informally, where the two parties air their views and problems, and hopefully reach a resolution. Where this is unsuccessful, the company must get involved formally. It needs to avoid the accusation of constructive dismissal (when an employee resigns as a result of the employer making things difficult for the employee) if one of the parties resigns (quits) because of the dispute.</p>
<p>The company will try to resolve the issue. However, it might be appropriate to put both parties on a first-stage warning to stop the activity that is causing the problem. Disciplinary action will need to be taken if offensive behaviour continues, in line with the bullying and harassment policy.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="activity">ACTIVITY<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#activity" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Try this activity with a small group. One of the group accuses the other of stealing a personal tool but the person being accused believes the owner has simply lost that tool.</p>
<p>Consider the best forms of communication to resolve this conflict and consider the best approach by others so the conflict doesn't get worse. Discuss this as a group.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="industry-tip">INDUSTRY TIP<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#industry-tip" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>For more information on methods of communication with persons with learning difficulties, visit MENCAP's website.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="activity">ACTIVITY<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#activity" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Write a list of equipment or a set of instructions on a sheet of paper – something that contains several points or items. Pass on the information to each person in turn but using a range of different communication methods such as text, email, oral, handwritten, and so on.</p>
<p>Once everyone has passed on the information, compare the end product with the original. Is it the same?</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="industry-tip">INDUSTRY TIP<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#industry-tip" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>If you are unfortunate and encounter a dissatisfied and angry client, remember, they are probably angry with the company and you should try not to take it personally. Look for ways you and your company can improve processes and systems, to avoid similar situations in the future.</p>
<p>The City &amp; Guilds Textbook: Electrical Installations Book 1</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="health-and-safety">HEALTH AND SAFETY<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#health-and-safety" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Communication can also take the form of noises or alerts, such as sounding the horn on a forklift truck to warn people it is coming. Lack of such communication can risk the health and safety of those on site.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="activity">ACTIVITY<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#activity" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>What types of questions should be asked on a customer satisfaction form used to gauge how an organisation and their employees performed when, for example, they rewired a house?</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="the-effects-of-poor-communication">The effects of poor communication<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#the-effects-of-poor-communication" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Poor communication between operatives is likely to create a difficult working environment and lead to losses in productivity and a low team morale. This also risks stifling staff ideas for improvement in working methods and practices.</p>
<p>Management has a responsibility to communicate certain matters such as safety information. Effective communication is a two-way process – both or all parties need to be clear. Where there is misunderstanding, there is a risk of mistrust and where there is mistrust, there is a risk of conflict. Therefore, poor communication from management can lead to mistrust in the wider team infrastructure, or in the organisation as a whole, impacting on productivity and safety.</p>
<p>Customer relationships are an essential part of business development and customer retention – it is essential to have effective, meaningful communication with customers. Good communication between the company and customer ensures that invoices are paid on time and that both parties are prepared to do business together in future.</p>

<p>Synoptic assessment</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="synoptic-assessment">Synoptic assessment<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#synoptic-assessment" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Part of your qualification requires a synoptic assessment, to test your skills as a whole. These assessments are based on a particular electrical installation and an 'assignment brief' that generally outlines the assignment scenario.</p>
<p>The synoptic task is normally broken down into separate parts.</p>
<p>Below is an example of what you can expect to see for a synoptic assignment, along with some tips about completing the non-practical tasks.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="assignment-brief">ASSIGNMENT BRIEF<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#assignment-brief" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>A new art studio is to be built within the grounds of a forty-year-old house, as shown on the next page. The studio is constructed of concrete block work, with a tile hung roof on a wooden truss.</p>
<p>The studio requires an electrical installation which you must plan and install. The installation should follow and adhere to all relevant Health and Safety legislation and procedures.</p>
<p>The studio is to be supplied using a three-core <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>25</mn><msup><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">m</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">m</mi></mrow><mn>2</mn></msup></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">25\mathrm{mm}^2</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8141em;"></span><span class="mord">25</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">mm</span></span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.8141em;"><span style="top: -3.063em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight">2</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span> thermoplastic SWA cable from the existing 230V single-phase installation, utilising a spare way in the distribution board, located in the garage attached to the house. The distribution circuit will be supplied by a 40A Type B 30mA RCBO. The SWA cable is to be installed in a pre-excavated trench as shown on the drawing.</p>
<p>Wiring systems within the new studio are as follows:</p>
<ul>
<li>dado trunking to be installed at <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>900</mn><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">m</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">m</mi></mrow></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">900\mathrm{mm}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6444em;"></span><span class="mord">900</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">mm</span></span></span></span></span></span> above finished floor level around the perimeter of the studio</li>
<li>conduit to be installed to supply <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>3</mn><mo>×</mo><mn>1200</mn><mo>×</mo><mn>600</mn><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">m</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">m</mi></mrow></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">3 \times 1200 \times 600\mathrm{mm}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.7278em; vertical-align: -0.0833em;"></span><span class="mord">3</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span><span class="mbin">×</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.7278em; vertical-align: -0.0833em;"></span><span class="mord">1200</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span><span class="mbin">×</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6444em;"></span><span class="mord">600</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">mm</span></span></span></span></span></span> luminaires on a suspended ceiling</li>
<li><span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>6</mn><mo>×</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">6 \times</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.7278em; vertical-align: -0.0833em;"></span><span class="mord">6</span><span class="mord">×</span></span></span></span></span> twin socket outlets to be mounted directly on the trunking, as located on the drawing</li>
<li>conduit to be installed to supply multi-gang single pole switch at a height of <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>1200</mn><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">m</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">m</mi></mrow></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">1200\mathrm{mm}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6444em;"></span><span class="mord">1200</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">mm</span></span></span></span></span></span>, as shown on drawing</li>

<li>distribution board located in the studio, to be mounted above the trunking.</li>
</ul>
<p>The equipment used in the studio will include small power appliances such as hand-held heat guns or glue guns. No appliance will operate for long durations or have power consumption greater than <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>1.5</mn><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">k</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">W</mi></mrow></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">1.5\mathrm{kW}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6944em;"></span><span class="mord">1.5</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm" style="margin-right: 0.01389em;">kW</span></span></span></span></span></span>.</p>
<p>The distribution circuit has a calculated voltage drop of 2V.</p>

<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="notes">Notes<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#notes" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ol>

<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="tasks">Tasks<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#tasks" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>

<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="appendix-about-your-qualification">Appendix: About your qualification<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#appendix-about-your-qualification" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="introduction-to-the-electrotechnical-qualifications">INTRODUCTION TO THE ELECTROTECHNICAL QUALIFICATIONS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#introduction-to-the-electrotechnical-qualifications" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>You are completing one of the following qualifications:</p>
<ul>
<li>Level 2 Diploma in Electrical Installation (2365-02)</li>
<li>Level 2 Technical Certificate in Electrical Installation (8202-20)</li>
<li>T Level Technical Qualification in Building Services Engineering for Construction (8710)</li>
<li>Level 3 Electrotechnical Qualification (installation or maintenance) (5357-03).</li>
</ul>
<p>These qualifications aim to equip you with the practical skills and technical knowledge necessary to help you gain employment within the industry, or progress your training within the current apprenticeship route.</p>
<p>Alternatively, you may be trying to progress to the Level 3 Technical Certificate (8202-30) as a means of progressing to further education at Level 4 and above.</p>
<p>Whatever route you wish to take, these qualifications fully integrate with each other, allowing seamless progression.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="how-to-become-an-electrician">HOW TO BECOME AN ELECTRICIAN<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#how-to-become-an-electrician" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>To become a fully recognised electrician, you must complete the following:</p>
<ul>
<li>5357-03 knowledge units</li>
<li>5357-03 on-site performance units</li>
<li>Achievement Measurement Test 2 (AM2S) synoptic end test.</li>
</ul>
<p>In addition, on completion of the above, you may also gain EngTech recognition from the Engineering Council through a fast-track process, as the on-site performance units measure the behaviours the Engineering Council requires for this recognition. That means you can use the EngTech abbreviation after your name, showing professional recognition.</p>
<p>If you are not currently enrolled on the Electrotechnical Qualification (5357-03), do not worry. You can transfer your skills gained through the Diploma or Technical Certificate towards the 5357 knowledge units, meaning you will not need to complete all of the assessments.</p>
<p>The 5393 Domestic Electrician Apprenticeship was introduced in September 2022 as an alternative apprenticeship to the 5357 route, specifically for those who work solely in domestic dwellings. The unit structure is very much the same as 5357.</p>
<p>The easiest way to explain your progression route is to show each qualification side by side (see Figure 6.1).</p>
<hr>
<p><strong>INDUSTRY TIP</strong></p>
<p>For more information on EngTech, visit the IET's website.</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251222-eaeebe83.jpeg" alt="img-617.jpeg">
Figure 6.1 Qualification progression routes</p>
<p>The City &amp; Guilds Textbook: Electrical Installations Book 1</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="why-are-there-different-routes">Why are there different routes?<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#why-are-there-different-routes" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>The route you take into a career as an electrician will depend on a number of factors, such as your age, employment status and where you live within the UK.</p>
<ul>
<li>Learners who are 16–19 and not employed full time within the electrical industry would enrol on 8202-20 or 8710-353.</li>
<li>Adult learners wishing to become electricians would enrol on 2365-02.</li>
<li>Apprentices of any age working within the electrical industry would enrol on 5357-03 to become full electricians, or 5393 to become domestic electricians.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="how-to-achieve-your-qualification">How to achieve your qualification<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#how-to-achieve-your-qualification" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>The requirements for successfully obtaining your qualification depend on which programme you are enrolled on.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="8710-t-levels">8710 T Levels<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#8710-t-levels" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>T Levels are nationally recognised qualifications that are equivalent to 3 A Levels but focus on specific careers in industry. T Levels are two-year full-time courses of study.</p>
<p>As well as classroom- and workshop-based learning, 8710-353 (Electrical Engineering) or 8710-352 (Electrical and Electronic Equipment) provide, within the course, nine weeks of work experience with an employer.</p>
<p>The courses share a core unit that looks at the common elements across building services and this serves as a great insight into other occupational specialisms, including the science behind them. So, as well as learning about the electrical industry, students will also learn much about the other building services such as air-conditioning systems, heating, etc. In addition, the course covers the specific specialism content which is covered in this book.</p>
<p>At the time of writing, it is anticipated that the T Levels will integrate into the 5357 apprenticeship in the same way as 8202 and 2365. Figure 6.1 shows the progression route with T Levels.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="8202-20">8202-20<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#8202-20" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Level 2 is assessed using one on-screen multiple-choice examination and one practical synoptic assignment.</p>
<p>For the synoptic assignment, a typical brief might be to install a cable and wiring system. You will need to draw on skills and understanding developed across the qualification content in order to consider the specific requirements of the particular wiring system and related electrical principles, and carry out the brief. This includes the ability to plan tasks, such as marking out and cutting cables, and apply the appropriate practical and hand skills to carry them out using appropriate tools and equipment.</p>
<p>You will also demonstrate that you are following health and safety regulations at all times by drawing upon your knowledge of legislation and regulations.</p>
<p>Appendix: About your qualification</p>
<p>The exam draws from across the entire content of the qualification, using multiple-choice questions to:</p>
<ul>
<li>confirm breadth of knowledge and understanding</li>
<li>test applied knowledge and understanding – giving the opportunity to demonstrate higher-level integrated understanding through application, analysis and evaluation.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="2365-02-5393-03-and-5357-03">2365-02, 5393-03 and 5357-03<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#2365-02-5393-03-and-5357-03" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The Level 2 2365 and the corresponding units of 5357-03 or 5393-03 are assessed using a range of methods including practical assessments, written examinations and online multiple-choice examinations. Each examination, whether written or multiple choice, has a Test Specification. These show the following information:</p>
<ul>
<li>assessment method e.g. multiple choice or written</li>
<li>examination duration</li>
<li>permitted materials e.g. closed or open book</li>
<li>number of questions</li>
<li>approximate grade boundaries.</li>
</ul>
<p>The grade boundaries may be subject to slight changes to ensure fairness, should any variations in the difficulty of the test be identified.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="the-evolve-platform">The Evolve platform<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#the-evolve-platform" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>

If you do not set preferences, the default will be black text on a white background. You can change your preferences at any point during the examination.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="industry-tip">INDUSTRY TIP<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#industry-tip" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>

These can be found on the qualification pages at <a href="http://www.cityandguilds.com" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">www.cityandguilds.com</a>, by searching the qualification number at the top of the screen.</p>
