<p>Appendix: About your qualification</p>
<p>5 When you are taking the examination, the screen has several features.</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251222-c407ef50.jpeg" alt="img-622.jpeg"></p>
<ul>
<li>Timer – shows the time remaining for the examination.</li>
<li>Progress – gives you an indication of how much of the examination you have completed.</li>
<li>Finish – only click this button when you are sure you have completed the examination.</li>
<li>Question numbers – the numbers at the side show the individual question numbers. These indicate the questions that have been answered and the questions that have not been answered. They also indicate any questions that have been flagged (see below). You can navigate through the questions by clicking on each number or by using the ‘back’ and ‘next’ buttons at the bottom of the screen.</li>
<li>Flag – if there are any questions you had doubts with, click the ‘flag’ button and a flag will appear by the question number. This means you can easily navigate back to that question should you have time.</li>
<li>Preferences – throughout the examination you can change the screen preferences.</li>
<li>Help – this offers help with the features of the system (not with the examination questions, unfortunately!)</li>
<li>Introduction – this takes you back to the welcome screen.</li>
</ul>
<p>445</p>
<p>446</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="glossary">Glossary<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#glossary" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Accident: an unplanned event that results in injury or ill health, damage, or loss of business.</p>
<p>Algebra: the branch of mathematics that uses letters and symbols to represent numbers, to express rules and formulae in general terms.</p>
<p>Analogue: instruments that use magnetism to measure electrical quantities.</p>
<p>Arc: an electrical breakdown of a gas that produces an ongoing plasma discharge, resulting from a current through a normally non-conductive medium such as air.</p>
<p>Asbestos: a rock-like mineral that can be used to strengthen materials or provide good fire resistance.</p>
<p>Atomic theory: the study of atoms and electrons (also referred to as electron theory).</p>
<p>Audit: to conduct a systematic review to make sure standards and management systems are being followed.</p>
<p>Authorising engineer: an engineer, usually chartered, appointed to check the knowledge and experience of those operating or working on specialist systems, to make sure that all the employer's legal duties are met.</p>
<p>Average voltage: the peak value multiplied by 0.637.</p>
<p>Base load: basic amount of electricity.</p>
<p>Battering or slope: the angle of the trench walls of an excavation that prevents the walls collapsing, measured in relation to the horizontal surface.</p>
<p>Bend: a British Standard 90° bend. One double set is equivalent to one bend.</p>
<p>Bill of quantity: a contract document comprising a list of materials required for the works and their estimated quantities.</p>
<p>Bit: the part of the drill that does the cutting.</p>
<p>Business opportunity: the opportunity to make profit from the work or contract.</p>
<p>Cable basket: a lightweight containment system that normally clips together.</p>
<p>Carbon emission: the polluting gas given off from the burning of fossil fuels such as gas, oil or coal.</p>
<p>Carbon footprint: the amount of carbon dioxide emitted from burning fuels during the production and transportation process. This may be offset by the amount of carbon released naturally by decay. For example, biomass fuel is made from plant material that would release carbon dioxide as it rots naturally if left, so burning it efficiently and gaining use from it as a fuel means this fuel has a reduced carbon footprint, and is more carbon efficient.</p>
<p>Chair: the person who controls a meeting, ensures that all the topics that need to be discussed (listed on the agenda) are covered. The chair also acts to resolve disputes.</p>
<p>Chartered engineer: a registered engineer with professional competencies through training and experience.</p>
<p>Chuck: the part of the drill used for holding the drill bit.</p>
<p>CIBSE: the Chartered Institute of Building Services Engineers.</p>
<p>Civil law: law that deals with disputes between individuals and/or organisations, in which liability is decided and compensation is awarded to the victim.</p>
<p>Class II Equipment: equipment having basic insulation and a further reinforced layer of insulation around live parts, meaning the risk of faults is minimal.</p>
<p>Closed circuit: a complete circuit connected to a source of energy. If the circuit contains a switch and the switch is off (open), it becomes an open circuit.</p>
<p>Common denominator: a denominator that can be divided exactly by all of the denominators in the question.</p>
<p>Competent person: recognised term for someone with the necessary skills, knowledge and experience to manage health and safety in the workplace.</p>
<p>CompEx Scheme: the global solution for validating core competency of employees and contract staff of major users in the gas, oil and chemical sectors. This covers both offshore and onshore activities.</p>
<p>Compliance: the act of carrying out a command or requirement.</p>
<p>Composite cables: multi-cored cables, where the cores are surrounded by a sheath providing mechanical protection.</p>
<p>Computer-aided design (CAD) software: specialist software for producing drawings, including a library of symbols and features, such as walls and doors, that can be dragged and dropped into the drawing. In the days before CAD, a draughtsperson would have to painstakingly draw every detail on every drawing by hand.</p>
<p>Conductors: materials that allow the movement of electrons and therefore current.</p>
<p>Consignment: a batch of goods.</p>
<p>Containment system: conduit or trunking providing a level of mechanical protection to cables.</p>
<p>Contamination: the introduction of a substance that should not be there, such as water, oil or dust.</p>
<p>Contract: a written agreement between two or more parties for doing something. A contract between a client</p>
<p>Glossary</p>
<p>and contractor is the agreement to carry out specific work for an agreed price.</p>
<p><strong>Contract administrator (CA)</strong> the person named in the contract with the contractual power to change matters or items of work that will cause a contract variation.</p>
<p><strong>Corrosion</strong> the breaking down or destruction of a material, especially a metal, through chemical reactions.</p>
<p><strong>Criminal law</strong> decides if someone is guilty of a criminal act.</p>
<p><strong>Critical path</strong> the sequence of key events and activities that determines the minimum time needed for a process, such as a construction project.</p>
<p><strong>Cross-talk</strong> a bleeding of signal from one conductor to another, through electromagnetic induction. Twisting pairs of cable reduces this cross-talk.</p>
<p><strong>CRS</strong> this means 'centres', indicating that a given dimension on a drawing is measured between the centres of components.</p>
<p><strong>Datum line</strong> a reference point or line from which multiple measurements are made.</p>
<p><strong>Digital</strong> instruments that use electronic components to measure electricity.</p>
<p><strong>Diversity</strong> allows the designer to use skill and experience to calculate what the full load on an installation may be given that some circuits operate at certain times (e.g. lighting) while others operate for very short times (e.g. hand driers in toilets). The result of applying diversity to the maximum demand is usually used to determine the supply characteristics.</p>
<p><strong>Dry-lined wall</strong> an inner wall that is finished with plasterboard rather than a traditional wet plaster mix.</p>
<p><strong>Duty holder</strong> any person or organisation holding a legal duty, in particular with regard to health and safety regulations (i.e. Health and Safety at Work Act etc. 1974). The person in control of a danger is the duty holder. This person must be competent by formal training and experience and with sufficient knowledge to avoid danger. The level of competence will differ for different items of work.</p>
<p><strong>Earth</strong> Earth with a capital E represents the potential of the ground we stand on.</p>
<p><strong>Efficiency</strong> the amount of useful work done by a machine compared to the energy supplied, expressed as a percentage.</p>
<p><strong>Effluvia</strong> emissions of gas, or odorous fumes given off by decaying waste.</p>
<p><strong>Electricity</strong> the flow of electrons as they move from atom to atom.</p>
<p><strong>Electrolyte</strong> a chemical solution that contains many ions. Examples include salty water and lemon juice. In major battery production, the electrolyte may be an alkaline or acid solution, or a gel.</p>
<p><strong>Electrons</strong> negatively charged parts of an atom, which orbit the nucleus. ('Electron' is the Greek word for amber, which is a material that is easily electrified by static.)</p>
<p><strong>Enabling Act</strong> allows the Secretary of State to make further laws (regulations) without the need to pass another Act of Parliament.</p>
<p><strong>Environment</strong> the land, water and air around us.</p>
<p><strong>Equal potential</strong> when the voltage between any two parts of a system is within safe touch voltage levels, usually 50 V A.C. depending on the location.</p>
<p><strong>Fatality</strong> death.</p>
<p><strong>FELV</strong> functional extra-low voltage circuit (requirements can be found in Section 411.7 of BS 7671).</p>
<p><strong>Fossil fuels</strong> fuels found deep under ground that are mined or drilled for. They take millions of years to form, so once used they cannot be replaced.</p>
<p><strong>Funding body</strong> an organisation that provides money for a particular purpose, such as a construction project.</p>
<p><strong>Granular soils</strong> gravel, sand or silt (coarse-grained soil) with little or no clay content. Although some moist granular soils exhibit apparent cohesion (grains sticking together forming a solid), they have no cohesive strength. Granular soil cannot be moulded when moist and crumbles easily when dry.</p>
<p><strong>Hazard</strong> anything with the potential to cause harm (e.g. chemicals, working at height, a fault on electrical equipment).</p>
<p><strong>Hazardous substance</strong> something that can cause ill health to people.</p>
<p><strong>Hot work</strong> work that involves actual or potential sources of ignition and carried out in an area where there is a risk of fire or explosion (e.g. welding, flame cutting or grinding).</p>
<p><strong>HSS</strong> high-speed steel.</p>
<p><strong>Hypotenuse</strong> the longest side of a right-angled triangle, which is opposite the right angle.</p>
<p><strong>I₂R losses</strong> power losses caused by the current heating the cable and the heat energy being lost.</p>
<p><strong>Incorporated engineer</strong> a specialist (also called an engineering technologist) who implements existing and emerging (new) technology within a particular field of engineering, entitled to use the title IEng (which acts as proof that a particular level of training and experience has been met).</p>
<p><strong>Indices</strong> the plural of index.</p>
<p><strong>Induction</strong> a current in a conductor induces (produces) a magnetic field around it, and a magnetic field induces (produces) a current in a conductor.</p>
<p><strong>Insulators</strong> materials that resist the flow of electrons and therefore current.</p>
<p><strong>IP code</strong> international protection code used to identify accessories and equipment according to their resistance to penetration and water ingress.</p>
<p>447</p>
<p>The City &amp; Guilds Textbook: Electrical Installations Book 1</p>
<p>Isolation disconnecting from and separating all sources of electrical energy.</p>
<p>Joule the unit of measurement for energy, defined as the capacity to do work over a period of time.</p>
<p>Landfill burying waste in large holes in the ground.</p>
<p>Liability a debt or other legal obligation in order to compensate for harm.</p>
<p>Limit of authority if somebody makes a key decision, without the right knowledge or experience to take that decision, they have exceeded their limit of authority. Dangerous or costly situations could result.</p>
<p>Live conductor a conductor intended to be energised in normal service.</p>
<p>Load profiles when and where electricity will be needed.</p>
<p>Manual handling the movement of items by lifting, lowering, carrying, pushing or pulling by human effort alone.</p>
<p>Marking out when measurements are identified on the walls and ceilings to ensure that equipment and accessories are installed in the correct place.</p>
<p>Materials the accessories, components and cables acquired specifically for use during the installation process.</p>
<p>Materials take-off sheet a list of all the materials required for an installation, and their quantities, to enable accurate stock control and costing of materials. Sometimes also referred to as a 'materials list', this can be used to record materials used to date and yet to be used on a job.</p>
<p>Maximum demand the full load current of an installation assuming all circuits are drawing their design current at one time. As most installations do not actually do this, designers apply diversity.</p>
<p>Mean the average of a set of numbers. To calculate the mean, add up all the numbers of the set, then divide by how many numbers there are in the set.</p>
<p>Mechanical advantage a measure of the increase in force gained by using a tool.</p>
<p>Method statements instructions on performing tasks safely in accordance with the risk assessment.</p>
<p>Nanotechnology where a material or substance is created by changing matter at an atomic or molecular level.</p>
<p>National Standard based on International Standards produced by the International Electrotechnical Commission (IEC), member nations create their own versions specific to their needs. Other CENELEC countries use the term 'rules' rather than 'standards' or 'regulations'. For example, the national wiring standard in the Republic of Ireland is the National Rules for Electrical Installations (ET101).</p>
<p>Near miss any incident that could, but does not, result in an accident.</p>
<p>Negligible small or unimportant and therefore not worth considering.</p>
<p>Nosings the front edge of a step. If they are not square, they can lead to people slipping down the step. Many steps are fitted with additional metal strips to avoid the step from wearing.</p>
<p>Nuclear fission creating energy by splitting atoms.</p>
<p>Oscillating moving back and forth in a regular pattern.</p>
<p>Passive infrared (PIR) a sensor that detects movement.</p>
<p>Pattress the recessed container behind an electrical fitting, such as a socket, sometimes referred to as a back box.</p>
<p>Peak to peak the value of voltage or current between the positive peak and negative peak of the waveform.</p>
<p>PELV protective extra-low voltage circuit.</p>
<p>Periodic time the amount of time to complete one full cycle.</p>
<p>Permit-to-work (PTW) a written safe system of work produced to support the safe completion of potentially dangerous work and support communications between different persons.</p>
<p>Pi the ratio of a circle's circumference to its diameter. It is a constant value used to determine the properties of a circle.</p>
<p>Plant tools and machinery.</p>
<p>Pollution contamination of the natural environment causing change to that environment.</p>
<p>Power tool any tool that uses electrical energy, from batteries or from a mains supply, in order to work.</p>
<p>Practical completion the point at which a construction project is virtually finished, when the last percentage of monies are paid by the client, the responsibility for insuring the construction transfers to the client and the architect or contract administrator signs the certificate of practical completion.</p>
<p>Protection methods methods given in BS 7671 for protection against faults.</p>
<p>Pythagoras' Theorem for a right-angled triangle with sides of lengths <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>a</mi><mo separator="true">,</mo><mi>b</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">a, b</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8889em; <p>Quantify estimate guideline costs.</p>
<p>Reciprocal the reciprocal of any number is that number divided into 1, so the reciprocal of 10 is 1 divided by 10, which equals 0.1.</p>
<p>Recycling reusing an object or material.</p>
<p>Repose the angle to the horizontal at which the material in the cut face of an excavation is stable and does not fall away. Different materials have different angles of repose – for example, <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msup><mn>90</mn><mo lspace="0em" rspace="0em">∘</mo></msup></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">90^{\circ}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6741em;"></span><span class="mord">9</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord">0</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.6741em;"><span style="top: -3.063em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">∘</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span> for solid rock and <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msup><mn>30</mn><mo lspace="0em" rspace="0em">∘</mo></msup></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">30^{\circ}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6741em;"></span><span class="mord">3</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord">0</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.6741em;"><span style="top: -3.063em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">∘</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span> for sand.</p>
<p>Glossary</p>
<p>Risk the chance (large or small) of harm actually being done when things go wrong (e.g. risk of electric shock from faulty equipment).</p>
<p>RMS the root mean square value (the square root of the mean of the squares of the value) – the value we specify as the nominal voltage. In the UK, the supply voltage is 230 V A.C., which actually peaks at 325 V.</p>
<p>Safety culture the product of individual and group values, attitudes, perceptions, competencies, and patterns of behaviour that determine the commitment to, and the style and proficiency of, an organisation's health and safety management.</p>
<p>Secure safe.</p>
<p>Selectivity arrangement of protective devices that ensures the device on the supply side of the fault operates before any other device.</p>
<p>SELV separated extra-low voltage circuit.</p>
<p>SI units the units of measurement adopted for international use by the Système International d'Unités.</p>
<p>Solder creep sometimes called 'cold flow', 'solder creep' can occur when the termination is under constant mechanical stress and the solder can literally move or 'creep'. Incidence of creep increases with temperature.</p>
<p>Space factors the amount of cable contained – so a 45% space factor means 45% cable, 55% air.</p>
<p>Standard gravity the average gravity on Earth (the actual value can alter depending on where you are).</p>
<p>Statute a major written law passed by Parliament as an Act of Parliament.</p>
<p>Step-down transformer a transformer that has a proportionally higher number of turns on the primary than on the secondary coil.</p>
<p>Step-up transformer a transformer that has a proportionally higher number of turns on the secondary (output stage) than on the primary coil (input stage).</p>
<p>Substructure the type of foundations and support systems for the building, such as steel frames or pillars.</p>
<p>Supply with demand producing (supply) electricity at the rate at which it is being used (demand).</p>
<p>Swarf chips and curly turnings of excess metal and wood produced when drilling.</p>
<p>Switching cutting off the supply of electricity, stopping equipment functioning.</p>
<p>Tender an offer to carry out work, supply goods or buy land, shares or any form of asset for a fixed price, usually in competition with others.</p>
<p>Tender package contains all the information a contractor needs to form a tender. A tender is a formal offer to carry out work for a cost. The client will send tender packages to many contractors and award the contract to the contractor who provides the best tender. The choice is not always based on price – it could be based on service provision or promised completion dates.</p>
<p>Thermal cycling heating and cooling of metal that causes expansion and contraction and, eventually, the loosening of terminals. It is greatest when cables are run at or near their maximum operating temperature. The effects can be reduced by ensuring that terminations and connections are kept tight.</p>
<p>Toolbox talk a method of communicating safety issues (as a supplement to an induction) or of giving continuous training on particular techniques or methods.</p>
<p>Toxic poisonous.</p>
<p>Transformer an item of electrical equipment that is generally used to change the voltage and current from one value to another. When a step-up transformer is used, the output voltage is higher than the input voltage, but the current decreases.</p>
<p>Transposition rearranging a formula to make the unknown you need to find the subject of the formula.</p>
<p>Trigonometry the mathematical study of the relationship between the lengths and angles of triangles.</p>
<p>Variation orders (VOs) official documents that are issued if any part of the work changes from the original contract or agreement. If, for example, it's agreed that some extra lights are needed during the project, a VO would be issued as proof that those additions can be claimed for over and above the initial price given.</p>
<p>Warranty a written promise to repair or replace any defects within a stated period of time. This could be one year after the completion of the contract. Sometimes, longer warranty periods are agreed.</p>
<p>Waste something that has no further use to the person disposing of it.</p>
<p>WEEE waste electrical and electronic equipment regulations</p>
<p>Wholesome term used in law to indicate water that is suitable for drinking.</p>
<p>Work package a 'collection' of work associated with one product on a project e.g. all processes associated with the design, manufacture and installation of the windows or of the sprinkler installation.</p>
<p>Young people people under the age of 18.</p>
<p>449</p>

<p>Common acronyms</p>

<p><span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>ν</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\nu</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.4306em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.06366em;">ν</span></span></span></span></span>  velocity (measured in metres per second, m/s)</p>

<p>Answers</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="chapter-1">CHAPTER 1<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#chapter-1" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>1 C The Health and Safety at Work etc. Act (HSWA) is an Enabling Act passed through Parliament.
2 B The Waste Electrical Electronic Equipment Regulations (WEEE) sets requirements for the control of waste electrical products.
3 D Employers must provide suitable personal protective equipment (PPE) for all employees.
4 B Accident books must be kept for a period of 3 years after the last entry date made in them.
5 C RAMS stands for Risk Assessments and Method Statements which are carried out for all tasks on site.
6 A PPE is considered the last resort when considering risk reduction methods. All other forms of removing or reducing the risk must be considered first.
7 B The Control of Substances Hazardous to Health (COSHH) is intended to control substances such as adhesives, to minimise the risk to health.
8 A The three key parts of the fire triangle are sources of ignition, sources of fuel, and sources of oxygen.
9 B Site transformers are used to transform the voltage to 110 V AC for the supply to power tools on a site.
10 D To prove that a circuit has been isolated correctly, the presence of voltage is checked on the load side of the circuit protective device to ensure the circuit is 'dead', i.e. no voltage present.
11 The person in control of the danger is the duty holder. This person must be competent by formal training and experience and with sufficient knowledge to avoid danger. The level of competence will differ for different items of work. In this example, this would normally be the supervising electrician.
12 Any three examples which may include: COPA, EPA, EA, HWR, PPCA, WEEE
13 1 identify the hazards, 2 decide who may be harmed and how, 3 evaluate the risks and decide on precautions, 4 record the findings and implement them, 5 review the assessment and update if necessary.</p>
<p>14 1 Elimination, 2 Reduction, 3 Enclosure, 4 Remove persons, 5 Reduce contact
15 Supply leads should be manufactured to relevant standards (BS or BS EN).
They should be suitable for the environment.
They should be free from cuts or fraying.
There should be no visible exposed conductor insulation (damaged sheath) or exposed live conductors.
There should be no signs of damage to the cord grip.
There should be no joints evident.
16 A HSR25 is the HSE guidance document to the Electricity at Work Regulations and how to comply with it.
17 B The Management of Health and Safety at Work Regulations 1999 is specific in that it requires risk assessments to be undertaken for tasks and arrangements made to implement necessary measures, appoint competent people and give appropriate information and training.
18 B Paint is classed as a hazardous waste substance under the Hazardous Waste Regulations 2005.
19 C This symbol means that the equipment relies on Class II protection to minimise electric shock.
20 C With the correct 1:4 ratio maintained, the angle formed will be 75°.
21 A Fires involving burning gases must be extinguished by a CO₂ extinguisher.
22 C Exit signs are advisory signs which are white symbols on a green background.
23 C MEWP stands for mobile elevating work platforms.
24 Protection against electric shock for Class III equipment is reliant on the voltage of the equipment being below 25 V AC or 120 V DC. Supplies may be by using a battery or by using a separated source (SELV) such as a transformer.
25 Isolation can be maintained by using a multi-locking device so each operative can use their own padlock.
26 At the installations main, switch on the load side. Test L-N, L-E, and N-E to ensure there is no voltage</p>
<p>Answers</p>
<p>present. Then test the AVI for function on a known supply or proving unit.</p>
<p>27 The first safety consideration is to ensure that the person is still not connected to or touching a live part. If that person is touched by another person, the second person could also receive an electric shock. It is important that the person is removed from electrical parts by using an insulated item or by isolating the supply.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="chapter-2">CHAPTER 2<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#chapter-2" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>1 C 2.3 × 10⁻³ (milli) would be the same as moving the decimal point three times to the left.
2 A In order to determine the sine of an angle, the opposite side is divided by the hypotenuse. Remember SOH CAH TOA.
3 B The unit of measurement for charge is the coulomb (C).
4 C As gravity, g, is 9.81 m/s², and force is determined by F = m × g, so F = 9.81 × 10 = 98.1 N.
5 D A copper atom has 29 electrons. Remember, different elements have a different number of electrons.
6 D If the resistors are in series, the total resistance is 36 Ω so, applying Ohm's law I = V/R then 200/36 = 5.56 (to 2 d.p.)
7 D When two conductors are placed together carrying equal current but in opposite directions, the equal magnetic fields rotate in opposite directions and cancel each other out leaving no magnetic field.
8 A If a wire is wound around a core creating a electromagnet and the fingers of the right hand follow the direction of current flow, the thumb will point to the magnet's north pole.
9 C Transformer cores are made from thin metal sheets known as laminates which reduce eddy current flow.
10 D A diode will only allow current to flow in one direction.
11 As</p>

<p>The City &amp; Guilds Textbook: Electrical Installations Book 1</p>
<p>17 D The volume is the area × height so: 36 × 3 = 108 m³
18 B To accurately read the load resistance, the meter is connected in parallel to the load only to remove the resistance of any supply conductors.
19 B A wheelbarrow is a Class II lever, as the fulcrum (wheel) is on the end of the bucket holding the load and the handles are where effort is applied.
20 C I = Q/t so 12/3 = 4 A
21 D If the length is halved, the insulation resistance will double as the conductors are in parallel.
22 D Where current is passed between two metals in a salty solution, the process is called electrolysis.
23 D The grip rule is used to determine the direction of the north pole by using the right hand; the thumb points north when the fingers follow the direction of current flow.
24 When the current flow is in the same direction, the magnetic fields around the conductors rotate in the same direction, so rather than cancelling out, they intensify in strength.
25 As: F = BLI
Then: I = F/BL so 5/3 × 0.5 = 3.34 A
26 Firmware is the software which is permanently installed in the equipment and is designed to operate the equipment.
27 WLAN stands for Wireless Local Area Network and is the WIFI network for a particular house or building.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="chapter-3">CHAPTER 3<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#chapter-3" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>1 D The IET On-Site Guide is non-statutory and provides technical detail on how to carry out inspection and testing.
2 C A circuit diagram shows detailed connections between components.
3 B The actual scale is 1:50, so if 1 mm = 50 mm then 200 mm (20 cm) is 50 times bigger so 200 × 50 = 10 000 mm or 10 m.
4 D 400 000 V or 400 kV is a transmission voltage. A and B are distribution voltages, and C is the voltage at which electricity is generated.</p>
<p>5 C Solar is a renewable energy source utilising the Sun's energy. The others listed are fossil fuels, producing CO₂ when used.
6 D Extraneous parts are parts that do not form part of the electrical installation but may provide a path to earth.
7 A In any TN system, a circuit supplying socket-outlets less than 63 A, or fixed equipment less than 32 A, must disconnect within 0.4 seconds.
8 A Where additional protection is required, the maximum rating for an RCD is 30 mA.
9 D The total earth fault loop impedance uses the symbol Zₑ.
10 C The main switch for an installation is the means used to isolate the entire installation by an electrician, as it controls the whole installation and can be secured in the off position.
11 The wording on the label must read 'Safety Electrical Connection. Do Not Remove.'</p>

<p>16 C The guide is restricted to installations having a supply rating of 100 A or less, so the maximum is 100 A.

<p>Answers</p>
<p>19 C Section 5 and specifically 5.1 deals with the requirements for isolation. To isolate an installation, the device must be located at the origin of the installation and that section states that this device must interrupt all live conductors for a TT arrangement.</p>
<p>20 C Using Table 7.1(i) and cross referencing a 32 A circuit protected by a 30 mA RCBO and wired in 4/1.5 mm² conductors, the maximum length (regardless of Ze) is 43 m.</p>
<p>21 D Section 7.3 of the OSG details installation conditions and Figure 7.3.1 shows the distances of notches and holes. The minimum distance from the end of the joist to drill a hole is 0.25 × 5 m which is equal to 1.25 m.</p>
<p>22 B Section 8 and in particular Table 8.1 gives criteria for locations containing a bath or shower and socket outlets must be outside the zones with a dimension of 2.5 m (this was 3 m up until 2022 and changed to 2.5 in amendment 2 of BS 7671: 2018 (2022)).</p>
<p>23 A Using Table I1 in Appendix I, the value can be calculated using the value of 10.49 mΩ/m from the table.</p>
<div class="math math-display"><span class="katex-display"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" display="block"><semantics><mrow><mfrac><mrow><mn>10.49</mn><mo>×</mo><mn>24</mn></mrow><mn>1000</mn></mfrac><mo>=</mo><mn>0.25</mn><mtext>&nbsp;</mtext><mi mathvariant="normal">Ω</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\frac{10.49 \times 24}{1000} = 0.25\ \Omega</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 2.0074em; vertical-align: -0.686em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mopen nulldelimiter"></span><span class="mfrac"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 1.3214em;"><span style="top: -2.314em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 3em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord">1000</span></span></span><span style="top: -3.23em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 3em;"></span><span class="frac-line" style="border-bottom-width: 0.04em;"></span></span><span style="top: -3.677em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 3em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord">10.49</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span><span class="mbin">×</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span><span class="mord">24</span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.686em;"><span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mclose nulldelimiter"></span></span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span><span class="mrel">=</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6833em;"></span><span class="mord">0.25</span><span class="mspace">&nbsp;</span><span class="mord">Ω</span></span></span></span></span></div>
<p>As the table is based at 20°C, no factors are required.</p>
<p>24 Using Table E3, first calculate the overall cable factors. So:</p>
<p>1.5 mm² conductors = 22 × 3 = 66
2.5 mm² conductors = 30 × 4 = 120
6.0 mm² conductors = 58 × 2 = 116</p>
<p>Total factor = 66 + 120 + 116 = 302</p>
<p>So, using Table E4 and cross referencing 5 m with the one bend section, the diameter that has a factor greater than 302 is a 25 mm conduit having a factor of 442.</p>
<p>25 Using Appendix F and in particular Table F5, the value of millivolts per ampere per metre (mV/A/m) for a 4.0 mm² circuit is 11, so as:</p>

<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="chapter-4">CHAPTER 4<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#chapter-4" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>1 B 20 mm is a standard conduit size.
2 D A reamer is used to remove any rough edges from the inside of a conduit.
3 A A bending spring is inserted into a PVC conduit when forming any bends to ensure the conduit keeps shape.
4 B An internal bend is used to ensure the lid is on the underside of the ceiling.
5 D Red indicates that the clamp is suitable for these areas.
6 A A crimp requires a compression tool to secure the crimp to the cable conductor.
7 C The shroud must be fitted first otherwise it will not fit over the gland.
8 D A hacksaw is used to score the armouring of an SWA cable.
9 B A low-resistance ohmmeter is used to check the polarity of the cores.
10 A Insulation resistance testers use a high voltage to ensure that there are no insulation faults leading to short circuits.
11 A crampet is used to fix conduit to wood or into concrete and usually used to secure conduit which will be in concrete such as floor screeds.</p>
<p>A spacer bar saddle is used in most common situations where the wall is even and dry.</p>
<p>A distance saddle is used where a wall is not even or is damp.</p>
<p>The City &amp; Guilds Textbook: Electrical Installations Book 1</p>

<p>15 Step 2 L-N: <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mfrac><mrow><mn>0.8</mn><mo>+</mo><mn>0.8</mn></mrow><mn>4</mn></mfrac><mo>=</mo><mn>0.4</mn><mi mathvariant="normal">Ω</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\frac{0.8 + 0.8}{4} = 0.4\Omega</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1.1901em; vertical-align: -0.345em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mopen nulldelimiter"></span><span class="mfrac"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.8451em;"><span style="top: -2.655em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 3em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">4</span></span></span></span><span style="top: -3.23em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 3em;"></span><span class="frac-line" style="border-bottom-width: 0.04em;"></span></span><span style="top: -3.394em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 3em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">0.8</span><span class="mbin mtight">+</span><span class="mord mtight">0.8</span></span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.345em;"><span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mclose nulldelimiter"></span></span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span><span class="mrel">=</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6833em;"></span><span class="mord">0.4Ω</span></span></span></span></span></p>
<div class="math math-display"><span class="katex-display"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" display="block"><semantics><mrow><mtext>Step&nbsp;3&nbsp;L-E:&nbsp;</mtext><mfrac><mrow><mn>0.8</mn><mo>+</mo><mn>1.34</mn></mrow><mn>4</mn></mfrac><mo>=</mo><mn>0.54</mn><mi mathvariant="normal">Ω</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\text{Step 3 L-E: } \frac{0.8 + 1.34}{4} = 0.54\Omega</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 2.0074em; vertical-align: -0.686em;"></span><span class="mord text"><span class="mord">Step&nbsp;3&nbsp;L-E:&nbsp;</span></span><span class="mord"><span class="mopen nulldelimiter"></span><span class="mfrac"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 1.3214em;"><span style="top: -2.314em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 3em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord">4</span></span></span><span style="top: -3.23em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 3em;"></span><span class="frac-line" style="border-bottom-width: 0.04em;"></span></span><span style="top: -3.677em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 3em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord">0.8</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span><span class="mbin">+</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span><span class="mord">1.34</span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.686em;"><span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mclose nulldelimiter"></span></span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span><span class="mrel">=</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6833em;"></span><span class="mord">0.54Ω</span></span></span></span></span></div>
<p>16 B The tool used to score the sheath in order to strip it perfectly square is a ringing tool.</p>
<p>17 B The brad-point drill bit is used for drilling through wood.</p>
<p>18 C The ladder must extend above the platform by 1 m minimum in order to provide a hand hold.</p>
<p>19 C Circle is a standard switch symbol and the two lines on the stalk denote double pole.</p>
<p>20 D Because the tee box has the upper spouts in line with the edge of the box, it is a tangent-tee box.</p>
<p>21 C There are three bends needed for a bubble set. A set has two and a saddle set has four. One bend is a bend!</p>
<p>22 A A spring used for bending PVC conduit is essential to stop the conduit from collapsing.</p>
<p>23 Answers may include the following:</p>
<ul>
<li>external influences such as wet, heat, etc.</li>
<li>aesthetics (what it looks like)</li>
<li>capacities such as weight or number of cables to support, including size.</li>
</ul>
<p>24 Answers should relate to the following: The motor will vibrate when operating, so the method of connection must be flexible to allow for this movement. Good examples include flexible conduits or SY flexes as they still provide good mechanical protection.</p>
<p>25 The first number in an IP code relates to the protection against the ingress of dust or bodies, and 3 denotes that a tool <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>2.5</mn><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">m</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">m</mi></mrow></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">2.5\mathrm{mm}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6444em;"></span><span class="mord">2.5</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">mm</span></span></span></span></span></span> in diameter shall not penetrate the enclosure.</p>
<p>The second number relates to the protection from water and moisture, and X denotes not applicable.</p>
<p>26 The banjo is a brass fitting that has two holes, one for the gland and the other for a small bolt. It is used to ensure the armouring, via the gland, has a reliable connection to the enclosure (if metal) and any protective conductor connected via the nut and bolt.</p>
<p>27 Answers must include:</p>
<ul>
<li>to ensure all single pole devices connect to the line conductor</li>
<li>to ensure all ES lamp holders have the centre contact connected to the line conductor</li>
<li>to ensure all accessories are correctly connected.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="chapter-5">CHAPTER 5<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#chapter-5" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>1 C A carpenter/joiner
2 A A sub-contractor is employed by the main contractor.
3 B A structural engineer would design the main building core to ensure it suitable supports the building.
4 C The Data Protection Act places a duty on companies to keep records of customer details safe and secure.
5 B Where the work involved has many unknown factors, an estimate of the costs would be given. As an example, if the work was in an occupied office, hold ups may exist where drilling etc. has to be done at times where disruption is minimised. This could end up taking much more time than anticipated.
6 C Certification would be handed to a client during the handover process.
7 D The required basic working hours must be included on a contract of employment.
8 B Verbal communication is only effective if both parties are speaking and listening alternately.
9 A Constructive dismissal.
10 A When communicating orally, body language and/or responses give a good indication that instructions are understood.</p>
<p>Answers</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="how-to-approach-the-synoptic-assessment">HOW TO APPROACH THE SYNOPTIC ASSESSMENT<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#how-to-approach-the-synoptic-assessment" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Make sure you study the drawings and brief carefully and take in all information. Anything not mentioned may be assumed. It is always a good idea to list these assumptions as you go.</p>
<p>Use the scales on the drawings to measure the quantity of materials, and to get an idea of how long the circuits will be. Circuit lengths may dictate how many circuits there are in the installation.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="task-1a-produce-and-complete-a-circuit-schedule-and-divide-the-installation-into-circuits-giving-reasons-for-your-decisions">Task 1a: Produce and complete a circuit schedule and divide the installation into circuits, giving reasons for your decisions<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#task-1a-produce-and-complete-a-circuit-schedule-and-divide-the-installation-into-circuits-giving-reasons-for-your-decisions" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>There is no single correct way to divide this installation into circuits. Assumptions need to be made on the loading but, as mentioned in the brief, this will be low.</p>
<p>Whatever approach is taken, justify the reasons why you have taken that approach. For example, a four-way distribution board could be used to accommodate:</p>
<ul>
<li>× 2 16A radial circuits for the socket outlets</li>
<li>× 1 6A lighting circuit for all indoor and outdoor lighting</li>
<li>× 1 spare way.</li>
</ul>
<p>The reasoning for dividing the socket outlets into two circuits is to allow for one to remain working should the other fail. This also splits loading and allows for smaller csa cables.</p>
<p>Other options will also work, such as using one ring-final or one radial circuit with a higher rating.</p>
<p>Use Table 7.1 in the IET On-Site Guide to check maximum circuit lengths and use this data as part of your justification. From this, select suitable conductor sizes.</p>
<p>Consider what devices are needed for circuit protection in the studio and again, justify your choice. Consider if RCD protection is needed when the distribution circuit already has RCD protection. Think about the type of circuit breaker which is needed, such as Type B or C, and again, write down reasons why you have chosen the specific type.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="task-1b-produce-a-plant-and-materials-list-justifying-the-choices-and-decisions-made">Task 1b: Produce a plant and materials list, justifying the choices and decisions made<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#task-1b-produce-a-plant-and-materials-list-justifying-the-choices-and-decisions-made" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>For this part of the task, it is important to make good use of technical terms for items so you can demonstrate recall and understanding. As a tip, use the key on the drawing for information.</p>
<p>459</p>
<p>The City &amp; Guilds Textbook: Electrical Installations Book 1</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="key-term">KEY TERM<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#key-term" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Two-gang socket outlet: most people will call it a twin or double socket but the correct term is two-gang.</p>
<p>What type are the socket outlets, twin or two-gang? What finish are they? What are they mounted on and therefore what accessories are needed for them to fix into the trunking?</p>
<p>Use the scales to estimate the lengths of trunking, conduit, cable, etc., needed. While you need to be as detailed as possible with your list, small sundries such as screws and small fixings do not need to be listed.</p>
<p>As well as materials, the task asks for plant needed, and this could include drills for drilling fixings and holes in the building to pass wiring through and other cutting equipment.</p>
<p>Make sure you make justifications for equipment and plant. Not everything needs justifying as some things are given, such as the luminaires. However, consider other items such as cable csa; this can be justified by referencing Table 7.1 of the IET OSG.</p>
<p>Consider what type of distribution board you will choose. Will it be metal or insulated plastic? As it is not located in a dwelling, it does not need to be metal, but metal does offer better fire protection.</p>
<p>As well as conduit and trunking lengths, consider what further accessories are needed, for example, conduit draw-in boxes such as tee boxes, terminal boxes, as well as saddles. Are trunking bends internal, external, flat, etc.?</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="task-1c-produce-a-method-statement-for-the-safe-isolation-procedure">Task 1c: Produce a method statement for the safe isolation procedure<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#task-1c-produce-a-method-statement-for-the-safe-isolation-procedure" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>This task requires you to provide a step-by-step method of how the safe isolation procedure would be applied for this installation.</p>
<p>As the installation is single-phase, the three-step test approach is necessary, rather than the three-phase ten-point test.</p>
<p>Think about the task in stages such as preparation, proving suitability of equipment, undertaking the isolation and ensuring security of isolation. Once broken into stages, think carefully about what needs to be done, in what order, for each.</p>
<p>For example, the preparation stage might involve, among other things:</p>
<ul>
<li>identifying the correct device for isolation</li>
<li>seeking permission from the client to turn off the power</li>
<li>ensuring all equipment and devices are compatible, such as lock off kits</li>
<li>considering the implications of isolation, such as loss of power to other services or systems.</li>
</ul>
<p>Once you have planned all the steps for all the stages and have checked that the order is logical, you can finish the method statement. This may be handwritten or typed.</p>

<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="peter-tanner">Peter Tanner<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#peter-tanner" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Equip yourself with the tools for success in Electrical Installations with this comprehensive and updated edition of the bestselling textbook, published in association with City &amp; Guilds and IET.</p>
<ul>
<li>Study with confidence using the most up-to-date information available for the new industry standards, including the 2022 amendments to BS7671: 2018, The IET Wiring Regulations 18th Edition.</li>
<li>Enhance your understanding of concepts in electrical installation with hundreds of clear and accurate technical drawings and step-by-step photo sequences.</li>
<li>Get ready for the workplace with industry tips.</li>
<li>Prepare for your trade tests or end-of-year exams with end-of-chapter practice questions and end-of-book synoptic assignments.</li>
<li>Engage with author Peter Tanner’s accessible text, drawing on his extensive industry experience.</li>
<li>Target your learning with detailed qualification mapping grids for the latest City &amp; Guilds Level 2 qualifications – including the 2365, 8202, 5357 and 5393 specifications, as well as the 352 and 353 T Level occupational specialisms.</li>
</ul>
